div.p: THE OBMVTESCE OF F. T. TO THE EPPHATA OF D. COLLINS.

OR The Reply of F. T. to D. Collins his defence of my Lord of VVinchesters Answere to Cardinall Bellarmines Apology. In which Reply M. Collins is conuinced of most manifest frauds, falsityes, fooleryes, & lyes.
WRITTEN By Thomas Fitzherbert Priest of the Society of Iesus, in defence of his Adioynder impugned by M. Collins: wherein the Authors name was cyphred with the two letters F. T.
div.q: Hold thy peace, and goe out of the man.

q.hi: Sic est voluntas Dei, vt bene facientes, obmutescere faciatis imprudentium hominum ignorantiam.

div.q: So is the will of God, that doing well, you may make the ignorance of vnwise men be dumbe.
div.p: Permissu Superiorum, M.DC.XXI.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRABLE AND RENOVVNED VNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE, Thomas Fitzherbert Priest of the Society of IESVS, wisheth all Health, Honor, and true Felicity.
div.p:
IT may perhaps seeme strāg vnto you (dearly beloued, & my much respected Countreymen) that I (being a meer stranger to you all, and very different from you, both
in state of life, and Religion) doe presume to dedicate vnto you this my Reply, written in Answere of one, who, as I vnderstand, is a man of quality amongst you, and a principall member of your Vniuersity, and therefore by all likelyhood very much respected, honoured, and beloued of many of you, though perhaps not of all. But the truth is, that if I sought protection (as most doe who dedicate bookes, or remuneration, as those that write for hyre or gaine) I would follow the example of my Antagonist, who hath made choice of no meaner a Patron then of his Maiesty himselfe, from whome he may assuredly expect both Princely protection, and a Royall Reward; but seeing that my end, and desire heerin is no other, then the defence of the truth, & of my self; and that the confidence I haue in the iustice of my cause is such, that I feare no Iudge but Ignorance; I haue presumed so much of your fauour, as to remit it to your censures, not doubting,
but that you being men of iudg
• ent, bred vp in Schooles, & Exercise 〈◊〉 all kind of learning, will easily dis
•• rne betwixt sleight and plaine dea
•• g, shew and substance, falshood & •• th, & lay the fault where you find 〈◊〉 to which end I require no other fa
• our of you for my part, then your pa
•• ence to read this Reply, & to suspend • our sentence, vntill you haue seen the • hole, notwithstanding any preiudi
•• te opiniō which you may haue alrea
• y conceaued by reading my Aduersa
•• es worke, not hauing seene myne • hich he impugneth, neither hauing • ad other notice of it, as I thinke, then •• ch as he hath thought good to giue • ou; which how fraudulent it hath byn 〈◊〉 many respects will euidently appear • nto you by the ensuing Treatise.

And now for as much as I thinke 〈◊〉 necessary for your better informatiō •• uching the whole Controuersy, to • duertise you of certaine things, belon
• ng thereto, and first of the ground,
and occasion thereof, you shall vnderstand, that Fa. Robert Persons of goo • memory, hauing begun, and almos • ended a worke of his entitled, A discussion of M. Doctor Barlowes answere &c.
〈◊〉 pleased Almighty God to call him out of this life, in which respect I vndertooke to finish the same (being requested so to do by himself in his last sicknes) and therefore beginning where he left, and enlarging my selfe so far (vpon iust occasions offered) that my Answer grew to a iust volum, I thoght good to print it by it selfe, and to entitle it. A supplement to Father Robert Persons his Discussion &c. And when th •• same was almost finished, and the beginning already sent to the print, it was my chance to haue a sight of my Lord of VVinchesters answere to Cardinall Bellarmines Apology; and to find therein that the subiect thereof was the same in effect, which I had treated with M. Barlow, and that by the occasion thereof, diuers places, authorityes, and
arguments which were obiected, as wel 〈◊〉 me in my Supplement, as by the • ardinal in his Apology, were preten
• ed to be āswered by my Lord of VVin
•• ester in his sayd worke; whereupon I •• solued to examine and confute my • ords answers to those places, autho
•• tyes, and arguments, to preuent the •• uills of my aduersary M. Barlow,
• ho otherwise might perhaps in his • eply (if he were disposed to make a
• y) blame me for not taking notice • herof, and either turne me ouer to his • ordship for satisfactiō touching those • oints, or els make vse of the same an
• wers himselfe. And considering af
• erwards that my sayd Confutation of • y Lords Answers grew to a greater • olume then at the first I determined, 〈◊〉 thought good to cause it to be printed • lso a part, and gaue it the title of An Adioynder to the Supplement of Fa. Ro
• ert Persons his Discussion &c.

When my Supplement, and Ad
• oynder were diuuldged in England, I
expected what would be answered t • either of them, eyther by M. Barlow, o • by my Lord of Winchester or by any other for them: but within a while I vnderstood of M. Barlowes decease, an • neuer heard more of him, or of any mā that had vndertaken to answere for him. And some fiue or six yeares after (when I imagined by my Lord of VVinchesters long silence that my Adioynder had beene forgotten) I heard that one of your Vniuersity had answered it for his Lordship, and there passed many moneths before I could get a sight of it, or vnderstand so much as the name & quality of the Author. When I saw it, and found the title to be, Epphata t •
F. T. I do assure you I wondred not a litle, what had moued him so to entitle it, as whether it was only a bare allusion to the sound of the two letters F. T. (which me thought was to light a motiue for so graue a man, and serious 〈◊〉 a matter) or that he imagined me to be become so dumbe, and deafe, that I
should needs to be coniured with that • ord of our Sauiour to make •• e heare •• m, and answere him; wherin neuer
• elesse I must needes confesse he had • ore reason, then he was aware of; for •• ch was at that tyme the infirmity of • y body growne by frequent diseases, •• cident to my declyned age, & weake • onstitution, that I was resolued to be •• ent from thenceforth, howsoeuer I •• ould be prouoked, and to desist from •• ch laborious exercises, and studyes, •• s required more health, and strength, •• en my yeares, and weaknes could af
•• rd: yet when I had perused some • ood part of his worke, and noted as • el his manner of writing, as the sub
• ance of his discourse, & that he pre
• ended so to confute my Adioynder, 〈◊〉 not only to answere euery chapter, • ut also euery Paragraffe, & as he saith 〈◊〉 his preface to the Reader, to leaue no •• rt of the whole vnexamined, and yet • euerthelesse that he neuer set downe •• y wordes fully, but either his false
construction of them in a different letter (as if it were my text) or so lamely that the substance, pith, & force therof neuer appeared (whereby he both sayd himselfe, and made me say wha • he list, without any feare of controule) besides that I discouered in him by the way so many egregious fraudes, and falsityes in the abuse of the ancient Fathers, Historiographers, and other authors, so cunningly couched, and coloured many times, that it was not easy to be perceaued; & all this so būbaste • with the vaine ostentation of Greeke pedanticall phrases, thrasonicall brags & triumphāt exaggerations, that to a •• vnwary Reader (yea almost to any tha • hath not seen my Adioynder) he migh • seeme to trample me vnder his feet, & to haue got a notable victory. Hauing I say, noted all this, and being iustly moued thereby to indignation (in respect of the iniury offered as well to ou • Catholike cause, as to my selfe) I resolued presently to giue way to his Eppha ••
t • , that it might worke in me the effect • hich he seemed to desire, that is to say 〈◊〉 breake my determined silence; and • et so, that I might hope withall to • op his mouth, not by a formall con
•• tation of his whole worke (which I • old both for a needles, and for a lost • bour) but by some briefe, & yet clear • iscouery of his fraudulent dealing, 〈◊〉 such sort that it should euidentiy ap
• eare to any indifferent Reader, that he • eserueth no other answere, then such • s might display him to the world for a • otorious falsificatour, and coosener, • n the highest degree.

This then being my intention, I • aue laboured to performe it in this •• y Reply, with such pregnant proofs, • nd manifest examples of his forgery, • nd falsity, that they can admit no co
•• ur, nor shadow of excuse. And the
• efore as he thought good to imitate • ur Sauiour in the vse of Epphata, to • ake me heare, and speake when I • eant to be silent; so I haue thought
it not amisse to seeke to stop his mout • with Obmutesce, in imitation also of our Sauiour, who did therewith put to silence a iangling, and ta • ling Diuell saying, Obmutesce, & exi de homine. Marc. 1. For albeit I presume not to do a miracle, as our Sauiour did, yet I may well hope that my Obmutesce, seconded with verity and truth, shall haue a • much force to put him to silence, a • his Epphata grounded vpon falsehoo • & fraud, hath had to make me speake and thereupon I haue made my title as you see to be, The obmutesce of F. T▪ to the Epphata of D. Collins: but how wisely, or folishly, I haue done therein, I am content to leaue it to you • censure: only I will say this for my further excuse, that if my Aduersary ha • reason for his Epphata, I think I had no lesse for my Obmutesce, if he had none but plaid the foole in his, I haue followed neuerthelesse the counsayle of th • Wise man, in answering a foole acco •
ding to his folishnes, Prou. 26. Thu •
much concerning my Title.

Now then you shall further vn
•• rstand, that albeyt my first, and •• incipall intention was (as I haue •• d) only to discouer certayn notable •• audes and falsityes of his in a little •• mphlet of a few leaues (to shew the
•• by that he is not worth the answe
•• ng) yet considering afterwards that •• me perhaps might think that he had 〈◊〉 other thinges said somewhat to the • urpose, and that therefore I durst not •• ckle with him hand to hand in a sin
• e combate; I thought good to exami
• e some part of his worke in order as it •• eth, for some one poynt or question 〈◊〉 controuersy; and so I haue followed • s footesteps for more thē fifty pages, •• swering many obiections, and argu
• ents which he vrgeth mightely out 〈◊〉 S. Augustine concerning the suprea
• e authority of the Sea Apostolique. • nd this I haue done in six Chapters • e more amply, because it seemeth by 〈◊〉 ostentation, and triumph, that he
hath pleased himselfe therein exceedingly, though you shall see, that h • hath notably bewrayed, not only hi • own ignorance and folly, but also hi • bad conscience, and little honesty whereby you may also conceaue ho • easy it would be for me to answer hi • particulerly to euery thing, to hi • shame, if I had leasure, and would loo • so much tyme to do it.

And yet for your further satisfaction, and his greater confusion I hau • added six other chapters, touching th • Inuocation of Saynts, and the Veneration of theyr holy Reliques, with intention neuertheles, for breuityes sake not to deale therein with his impert •
nent fooleryes (which are inumerable but to discouer only such of his euidē • and inexcusable fraudes, as should o •
curre in debating with him some pa •• of the said question concerning pray •• to Saints. And those I haue thoug • good to represent vnto you for exāp •• sake only, that you may thereby ta ••
a skantling of the rest of his worke
• r, to vndertake to lay open all his • udes, and coosenages that may be • erued in his whole Treatise, were lesse then to vndergo the labour of
• rcules, to purge the filthy stable of
• geas, as you will perceaue by the • ltitude, & enormity of those which • aue discouered in this Reply, and in him so thick heaped one vpon other, that you will easely iudge whole worke to be compaginate of thing els but fraudes; amongst the • ich also, none is more ordinary, or •• arkeable then his wilfull corrup
• n of the ancient Fathers, of whom •• y few, or none haue escaped his • gers (as I may say) Scot-free; in so •• ch that within the compasse of two • ues of his, I haue noted his notable • se of no lesse then ten holy Fathers, • d ancient Authours, to wit, S. Am
•• se, S. Augustine, S. Hierome, S. Chry
•• ome, S. Gregory the great, S. Gregory Towres, Optatus, Theodoret, Sozomen,
and Victor Vticensis, as you may see my eleauenth Chapter: wherto if 〈◊〉 add his fraudulent handling of my t •• in the dissimulation, lame allegatio • and peruerse construction of it, 〈◊〉 changing the state of the question, 〈◊〉 contradictions, his manifest lyes, 〈◊〉 foule ouersights, his vayn Argume •• more forcible many tymes agai • himselfe, then against his aduersar • & lastly his other impertinencyes, a •• fooleryes, it wilbe hard to determy • whether is greater, his fraud, or 〈◊〉 folly; albeyt the latter is so notorio • thoughout all his work, that I can n • but wonder, how he got so much rep •
tation among you, as to be doctoure yea and to be approued for a publiq • Reader, & Writer; or that my Lord Winchester, would eyther admit h •• for his champion, or could hould hi • selfe to be sufficiently defended by hi • in this work of his, which I make 〈◊〉 doubt but his Lordship saw before was published, and therefore could 〈◊〉
b • t note therein how miserably he •• eadeth for him, how often he becom
• eth non-suite, and abandoneth him •• ite; and that his fraudes and cogge
• es would be most manifest to any •• at should but confront his Answere •• th my Adioynder, whereof I am for
•• d to lay down whole pages, and lea
•• s in euery chapter to shew his perfi
• ous treachery aswell in corrupting •• y text many tymes, as in peruerting •• e sense of it, which (as I haue said) very ordinary in him; in so much •• at I may well say of him as Tertullian
•• th of all Heretikes in generall, tou
•• ing theyr handling of holy scripture;
• ntum veritati obstr • pit adulter sensus, • antum corruptor stilus lib. de praescript.
〈◊〉 . 17 Besides that, my Lord might •• y well see, that whereas his Lord
•• s reputation is deepely wounded ••• h the imputation of many foule fal
• es, and fraudes, wherewith I char
•• his Lordship, this his aduocate hath 〈◊〉 discharged him of any one, but
only of a falsification of a place of Ambrose which I obiected to his Lo ••
ship (because I found not some word of the text in two or three seuerall i •
pressions, which I had seene, and e •
amined) of which imputation I no • acknowledge his Lordship to be ful • cleared by certayne printes produce • by M. Collins, which haue the text • my Lord alleadgeth it; albeyt neith •• my Lord nor he hath gayned any thin • thereby for theyr cause, as I haue sh •
wed euidently in my sixt chapter. An • truly this is the only seruice that M. Collins hath done his Lordship in a • his prolixe, and tedious Treatise.

Therefore seeing it hath not ple •
sed my Lord to pay his own debt himself, but to put me of to M. Collins, wh • hath tendred me payment in suc • false money, that I haue no reason 〈◊〉 accept it; his Lordship cannot blam • me if I do not giue him a quitance, bu • hould them both for my debters, vnti • the one of them do make me bette •
payment, or proue at least the money 〈◊〉 be good, which I haue here reiected false, and counterfaite. For if my • ord, M. Collins, or any other can so 〈◊〉 , I will acknowledge my self to be •• tisfyed for the whole. And of this I • ill desyre no other iudges but your •• ues. Only I will beseech you, that M Doctor Collins do resolue to iusti
•• his counterfait co • ne, you will do • e the fauour, or rather the right, to • ake tryal of the truth by the touch
• one; I meane by cōparing his answer • ith the text of my Adioynder, and • f this my reply, and not otherwayes • o beleeue him: for if in so doing you • nd, that I haue done him wrong in •• fusing his payment, truly I will not • nly accept it for good, and lawfull, • ut also acknowledge my errour, and •• ke both him, and my Lord pardon. • he like also I request of you (not a matter that any way toucheth my •• rticuler, but that concerneth your •• lues, and the honour of your Vniuersity)
to wit, that when you heare him at any tyme labour to confute, or to traduce Catholicke writters, ex cathedra, I meane in his publicke lectures or sermons, you will examine his allegations, & assertions by the Authours thēselues, seeing that he maketh no cōscience, nor scruple to belye, corrupt, and peruert all kind of Authours ancient, and moderne (and especially Cardinall Bellarmine, and the Iesuites) as you shall euidently see in this my reply by many examples; which if you doe well consider, you will no doubt think that to be true in him, which S. Austin sayd of the Pelagians of his tyme, viz. frontem illorum non esse frontem, that his forehead is no forehead, seeing he is not ashamed of such enormious, and prodigious impostures, as you shall find to abound in him euery where.

This being so, I leaue it to your prudent consideration, what a desperate cause my Lord of VVinchester, & M. Collins do mayntayne, seeing they
are forced to defend it with so much • alsehood, as I haue discouered first in my Lord, & now in M. Collins, who hauing vndertaken the defence of his Lordship & finding him, as I may say, ouer the shoes in fraudes, and falsityes, • ad no other way to deliuer him, then • o run himself ouer the eares to fetch him out, that is to say, to become gna
• iter impudens; and no meruayle, seeing • hat a lye can neuer be defended with • ruth, nor one errour without many, • nd euer the longer the worse. And • herefore I make account, that if M. Collins do attempt to iustify his former • raudes, he must perforce passe the • ounds of all modesty, conscience, & • hame, and shew himselfe to be the im
• udentest fellow, that euer liued, al
• eit I verily think, that when you shal • aue seene how farre he hath exceeded • herein already, you will be of opinion • hat he cannot go one step further.

But if you thinke that in all this, 〈◊〉 do but exagerat some smal ouersights
of his out of passion, I beseech you to suspend your iudgment vntil you com • to the sixt, and seauenth chapter, where I do purposely vndertake the discouery of his fraudes, and from thenceforth note well what you find, & then iudg of him and me, as you shall see cause. And this shall suffice for the present; for in the Conclusion of the whole, I meane to say somwhat more vnto you concerning him, as also vnto the Reader in my Preface, wherein you may see (if it please you) my Answere to certaine calumnious cauils, and obiections of his cōcerning my self, wherof I will remit the iudgement to any indifferent Reader; not doubting but to discouer therein no lesse fraud then in the rest, with such grosse ignorance and exorbitant malice on his part, that my
•• mutesce shall haue the desired effect, and stop his mouth, in such sort, that I may truly say with the Psalmist, Obstructum est os loquentis iniqua. Psal. 62.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER. Wherein certaine malicious cauills, & opprobrious reproaches obiected aagainst the Author by M. Collins in his Preface, are fully answered; and his notable fraud, folly, and grosse ignorance, euen in Grammer is discouered.
div.p:
FORASMVCH as I haue already declared in my Epistle Dedicatory, the groundes and causes of this Controuersy betwixt M. Collins & me, and his fraudulent manner in answering my Adioynder, togeather with my whole drift, and scope
in the ensuing reply, I will now gentle Readers) endeauour to giue you satisfaction in this Preface concerning some ignominious aspersions, which he laboureth in his Preface to c • st vpon my reputation, wherby I hope to make it appeare vnto you, that Verba oris eius iniquitas & dolus. Psal. 35. The words of his mouth, are nothing els but iniquity and deceit: and that therefore, Conuer • etur dolor eius in caput eius, & in verticem ipsius iniquitas eius descendet. Psal. 7. His sorrow shalbe turned vpon his head, and his iniquity shall descend vpon his owne crowne. Neuerthelesse my meaning is not to trouble you, or my selfe with the answer of many trifling obiectiōs, maleuolous cauils or s • urrilous scoffs which occur euery where in him in such abound • nce, that if I should but take knowledge of them this Preface would grow to a volume) but my intention is to say somewhat briefl • to those points only, which may seeme most to import, and being most vrged & ampl • fied by him, may perhap • bre • d some scruple, or doubt in the Reader.

1. Therefore wheras he insinuateth, that he could touch me if he list, with personall vices, I will let it passe as an idle vaunt of an idle brayne, seeing that I fi • d in diuers parts of his worthles worke, that he knoweth not as • et the condition, and quality of my person. For albeit he sayth truly of me, that I am a Iesuite (as I am indeed, I humbly prayse God for it) yet he holdeth me for a lay, and a marryed
Iesuit, shewing his ignorance as well of my present • state (who haue beene vnmaryed, and a Priest these • wenty yeares) as also of the custome of the Catholik • hurch, which doth not admit to Priesthood any that • re marryed, and liue with their wiues: so as I see • ot what he can truly vnderstand of my more priuate • nd secret demeanour, when he so much mistaketh • y publique profession and quality, wherof no man is • gnorant that knoweth me. Therefore for as much • s he promiseth his Reader to giue him a tast of my
• onditions, and spirit, out of myne owne wry
•• ngs, and especially out of my Adioynder, by the • iscouery of foure speciall thinges, which he sayth he • ath obserued therein, (to wit, my vanity, my vi
• ulency, my ignorance, & my circumstance) 〈◊〉 will examine how well he hath performed his pro
• ise; and I doubt not but you will find, that he hath • ot only fayled in all, but also foyled himselfe nota
• ly, discouering in himselfe both great fraud, and • rosse folly.

2. First then for my Vanity, he sayth in the •• urth page of his Preface thus: It is worth the • onsidering how euery where he coupleth • imselfe with the Cardinall, and somety
• es iets before him, sometymes behind • im, like the fantasticke wooer that Ouid
• escribes, & modò praecedit, sequitur modò. • hus sayth M. Collins. And why forsooth? • ary because I say in my Adioynder pag. 68. Places
alleadged by the Cardinall, and my selfe. And againe, pag. 38. The law Inter Clara •
alleadged both by the Cardinall, and me. And againe pag. 356. Twelue Fathers alleadged by the Cardinall and me, and the like in diuers other places: but most ridiculous sayth M. Collins, where I go before the Cardinall, 〈◊〉 when I say: Obiected as wel by me, as by the Cardinall. And againe in another place, The Bishops answere to S. Cyprian, makes as much against me, as against the Cardinall. All which M. Collins taketh to be feathers of my frantique ambition, scattered euery where throughout my worke. VVherto he also addeth the frequent mention, which I make of my Supplement, because I say many tymes, As I haue noted, & shewed in my Supplement: A quality, sayth M. Collins, somewhat vnusuall amongst Writers that are not starcke madd, to beate vpon their owne, especially so often. So he, with a great deale of other idle stuffe, and bitter taunts touching both these points, which I omit as well for breuityes sake, as because his booke, I am sure, is so common amongst you, that I need not to be ouer tedious in laying downe his text.

3. Now then heere you see, what he sayth of my Vanity, and how well he proueth his imputation thereof; wherein he beginneth to play his prize,
that is to say, to practise that kind of fraud, which he continueth for the most part throughout his whole worke, I meane his dissimulation of my text, and of • he circumstances of the matter in question betwixt vs, by which meanes he doth charge me with what • he list, without feare to be controuled by any that hath not my Adioynder, to confront with his answere, as you shall now euidently see in this, whereby you may the better iudge of the rest.

4. Therefore to discouer his cozenage in this point, you are to vnderstand the cause, why I do so often speake as well of the Cardinall, and my selfe, as also of my Supplement. This doth appeare sufficiently in the very title of my booke, which is this: An Adioynder to the Supplement of F. Rob. Persons his discussion of M. D. Barlowes answere &c. conteyning a discouery, & confutation of very many foule absurdityes, falsityes, and lyes in M. D. Andrewes his latin booke intituled: Responsio ad Apologiam Cardinalis Bellarmini &c. Thus did the Printer set downe my tytle, and added further that the sayd Adioynder was written by F.T. author of the Supplēent, to iustify certaine places, and authorityes alleadged as wel by him, as by the Cardinall in his Apology, and pretended to be answered by M. Andrews.

5. VVho now is he, that seeth this, and doth
not euidently see withall, what reason I had to make mention of my selfe many tymes togeather with the Cardinall, seeing that the speciall scope of my adioynder was to confute the Answeres of my Lord of Winchester to certain places, first alleadged by the Cardinall, and cyted after by me, in my Supplement, so as my intention was to answere for vs both, for so much as concerneth those authorityes or arguments, which were common to vs both. And this I say was euident inough by the very title of my Adioynder. Besides that, I also declared the same expresly & amply in the very first chapter thereof, wherin I signifyed, that when I had well neer ended my Supplemēt, I chaunced to haue a sight of my Lord of Winchesters answere to Cardinall Bellarmines Apolog • , and found therein that his Lordship pretended now and then to answere some places, authorityes, and arguments which had been obiected by me to M. Barlow in my Supplement, and that therefore fearing, that if I did not confute the sayd answeres of my Lord of Winchester, M. Barlow might either blame me for not taking notice thereof or perhaps make vse thereof himself, I resolued to examine and confute them.

6. As for as much as my meaning was not to answere my Lords whole worke, or any part thereof further then those places, authorityes, or arguments should giue iust occasion; I signifyed diuers tymes, that the place which I handled was cyted, not only by
me, but also by the Cardinall, to the end it might ap
• eare, that I kept my selfe still within my compasse, • nd did not extend further then to those authorityes, • r arguments, which as I haue sayd were common to • s both, or had dependance thereon, and contayned withall some notable fraud, or falsity. This then be
• ng my only drift, and intention in my Adioynder,
• an any man with reason blame me, or ascribe it to
• anity, that I mentioned my selfe now and then • ogeather with the Cardinall, hauing vndertaken to • nswere for vs both.

7. The like I say also for the mention I make • therwhiles of my Supplement, as that hauing • eated therein diuers thinges at large, which occur
• ed afterwards to be touched in my Adioynder, and might haue requyred some large discourse, if I • ad not handled it before) I referred the Reader of • y Adioynder to my Supplement for those • atters already handled therin, to auoyd the need
•• sse repetition thereof; besides that it appeareth eui
• ently by the Printers Epistle, to the Reader, that my •• tention was to haue had the Supplement, & the
• dioynder bound both in one volume, albeit the • rinter altered my designe because it seemed to him, • at the volume would be ouer great: so as my inten
••• n being considered, it may easily be conceaued how •• perfluous, and ridiculous it would haue beene 〈◊〉 haue repeated in my Adioynder those thinges, • hich I made account might be easily seene in my
Supplement, euen in the same Volume.

8. Now therefore iudge, good Reader, what Vanity it was in me to me make mention of my Supplement, as often as I had iust occasion to remit my Reader thereto for his better satisfaction, concerning those points, which I had already treated more amply therein. And consider I pray you withal both M. Collins his folly, and his fraud: his folly in that he picketh such an impertinēt, & foolish quarrel against me without any ground, or cause giuen o • my part, his fraud in that he abuseth both me, and his Reader, in dissembling all that in my Adioynder which sufficeth to cleare me of the imputation, wherewith he chargeth me. Thus much for the first point.

9. The second is my Virulency, as he calleth it, because I speake sometymes sharply to my Lord of Winchester, retorting vpon him many cōtumelious speaches, which he vsed not only against Catholiques in generall, but also particulerly against Cardinall Bellarmine, calling him lyar, and dotard, and against all Popes (tearming them Antichrists) yea against S. Peter
• imselfe, whome he blasphemously called caput morbidum, and vert • cem ma • è sanum) besides the notorious calumn • es and vntruths which he inuented, and vttered against t • e Iesuit • ; all which I must needes confesse moued me other whyles to some asperity of speach, to make him see how true it is which the Comicall Poet
sayth, Qui dicit quod volt, audiet quod non volt. But whatsoeuer passed in that kind in my Adioynder, I hope his Lorship cannot take any iust offēce at my manner of treating him in this my reply, wherein you shall find, that I beare all due respect to his Lordship otherwise thē I did in my Adioynder, the reason whereof I thinke good to yeild you, because I make no doubt, but that you of your selues, will note the difference, and perhaps desire to know • he cause.

10. The truth is, that when I wrote my Ad
• oynder, I did not know in his Lorship any true title • f Honour, or Dignity, Ecclesiasticall or Temporall, • hich might mooue me to esteeme or respect him o
• herwayes then as a priuate person; for albeit he was • hen called Bishop of Ely, yet I could not (according • o our Catholike doctrine) acknowledge either that • itle, or any Episcopall authority in him, being no o
• her, but a meere lay man, and consequently voyd of • ll Ecclesiasticall function, and dignity, in which res
• ect I gaue him no better title thē of M. Andrews:
• ut seeing he is now aduanced to the state of a priuy • ounsellour to his Maiesty, I do most willingly yeild • im the respect, and honour due to his place and qua
•• ty; and therefore do not only forbeare all vnreue
• ent manner of speach, but also treate him with the • onourable stile of Lordship, as one of the Lords of • as Maiesty most Honourable priuy Counsell. And • hereas I call him also my Lord of Winchester, I
wish it to be vnderstood, that I do not acknowledg hi • therby to be a Bishop (for the reason before declared but that I do it, because I will not deny to any Counsellour of his Maiesty any Honorable stile, or ti •• which is commonly giuen him, so as it may be vnderstood to be abstracted from all spirituall power an • authority, as I conceaue this may be, and therefor • I do so intend it: And this I say, notwithstandin •
M. Masons pretended Register, whereby he laboureth to iustify the consecration of the first pretende • Bishops in Queene Elizabeths tyme; which hat • been so fully answered by our learned countryman M. D. Champney, that there remayneth no furthe • doubt, or scruple concerning that matter.

11. And now to returne to M. Collins,

• roachfull, and reuyling speaches, I little regard thē, • nowing from what spirit they proceed, I meane a •• irit that rather deserueth to be coniured with an • xorcisme (such as our Sauiour vsed to the tatling Diuell, when he sayd, Obmutesce, & exi de ho

13. First, sayth he pag. 40. cap. 2. num. 3. because the Bishop had sayd, legat canone mustum, ne maiora sed aequalia sint priuilegia, &c. He thus: whereas he sayes that the Coūcel of Chalcedon did by that Canō giue to the Bi hop of Constantinople ne maiora sed aequalia priuilegia &c. which though it be the reseruing of the word ne in both places, yet euery meane Latinist easily sees that ne should haue beene turned into non in the later place, if he meane any sense should be in his sentence, as he began it, and therefore I ca • impute it to nothing but to his lacke of skill in the rudiments. Thus sayth M. Collins, wherin I beseech you to note, that he himselfe acknowledgeth that in my allegation of my Lords words, I preserue the word ne, euen as my Lord hath it, thogh he sayth it should haue beene turned into non to make it good Latin is the later place where I repeate it; which obiection of his would haue beene of little force if he had not fraudulently ended his allegation of my text with an &c. insteed of setting downe my translation of my Lords words which immediatly followed. For hauing sayd (as you haue seene heere alleadged by him) That the Councell of Chalcedon did giue to the Bishop of Constantinople, ne maiora sed aequalia
per omnia priuilegia, I translated those la
•• n words thus, not greater but equall priui
•• dges in all thinges, wherby you may euident
•• see, that I tooke ne for non, translating ne ma
•• ra, not grea • er though I was scrupulous to repeat •• y Lords words otherwayes then I found thē in him, • nd therefore I preserued the word ne in both places, • ecause my Lord hath ne & not non; for I know not • ny such r • le of construction, or congruity to be obser
• ed, betwixt Latin, and English, as might bind me 〈◊〉 alter his Latin word, when I meant to giue the •• ue sense of it, as you see I did in translating it, which 〈◊〉 I haue sayd M. Collins dissembled, and con
• ealed, least it might help to discouer the vanity of his • euill; and therefore wheras he sayth, that ne should • aue beene turned into non in the Latin to make •• ue sense in my sentence, I remit it to thy iudgment • ood Reader whether taking the Latin togeat • er • ith my translation (which he concealed) the sense be • ot both true, and cleare in my sentence, and his solly • nd fraud notorious in this his first instance; so as • ow I may passe to the second, which you shall see to • e more friuolous, and foolish then the former.

14. He alleadgeth the words of my Adioyn
• er out of my second Cha • ter nu. 6. pag. 42. where 〈◊〉 say thus: It is sayd expresly of the Church • f Constantinople that it should be magnifyed & extolled as old Rome was, secundam post • llam existentem. Thus sayd I, which he layeth
downe, and then proceedeeh in these wordes: This is the letter I graunt, in the Councel of Chalcedon, but almost killing Priscian, as he sets it downe, for secunda post illam existens, the Church of Constantinople (to which that refers) being Ecclesia, and not Ecclesiam, in his period, & so to be translated if it were to be put in Latin. So he. Graunting as you see, that I lay downe truly the Latin words (to wit secundā post illam existentem) as they are in the Councell of Chalcedon, albeit being referred to the English which goeth before, they do not, as he supposeth, make good construction with it, and so do almost kill P •• scian. But this is much like vnto the former, for wheras I had a little before alleadged the whole Canon of the Councell in English & concluded the same with those wordes in Latin (which were the very words of the Councell, and most to be noted for the matter then in controuersy) I had occasion a little after to vrge the same words, and repeated them againe in such sort, as M. Collins hath noted, translating them immediatly thus, being the second after her, which translation being also concealed by M. Collins, as the former was, agreeth both with the Latin, which I alleadged, and with the English which went before, and made the sense perfect; so as all the incongruity which M. Collins doth imagine in my wordes, is betwixt the Latin and the English; and therefore to make good this his conceit of
errour and ignorance in me, he must frame some new Grammer with rules, and precepts ordayning a new •• nd of cōstruction (neuer yet heard of) to be obser
•• d betwixt two diuers languages, whereof indeed I • cknowledge my selfe to be ignorant.

15. But what will you say, if he himselfe do • ustify me in this, and eyther defend me against him • elfe, or els condemne himselfe of ignorance aswell • s me? will you not take him for a very wise, and • onsider at doctor? In the 4. chapter of my Adionder, 〈◊〉 alleadged a place of Optatus, beginning thus; Legimus principem nostrum &c. we read • hat Peter our Prynce receaued the whol
• ome keys against the gates of hell &c. And M. Collins comming to answer this place in his 4.
• hapter. nu. 27. saith thus. Yet in the same booke Optatus calles Siricius in playne tearmes not princeps noster, but socius noster, our fryend, • nd fellow. Thus sayth M. Collins, and now I may say to him, as you heard him say to me a little • efore, (mutatis mutandis) this is the let
• er I grant in Optatus, but almost killing Priscian, as he sets it downe; for as M. Collins exacteth of me a Grāmaticall constructiō betwixt the latyn and the English in t • e former sentence, so may I also, eodem iure, exact the same of him here betwixt the verbe call, and the nownes princeps, and socius, which should therefore be • n the accusatiue case; but if he say, that princeps,
and socius, in him, must be the nominatiue case 〈◊〉 agree with Siricius (because he saith, that 〈◊〉 calls Siricius not princeps, but socius noster &c.) I say that Siricius being a proper name, i • English aswell as latyn, and therfore may passe s • in all cases, without variation, what English wor • soeuer doth gouerne it: but Princeps, and socius, being pure latin wordes must according to M. Collins his new grammar haue a latyn construction, & therefore being gouerned by the verbe call, they must be in the accusatiue case. And if he wil haue Siricius in that sentence to be a pure latyn word, and not english, then he should haue said by his own rule, that Optatus called Siricium, and not Syricius, so as let Syricius be what language he will (I meane English or latin) he should haue sayd of him, that Optatus called him, not principem nostrum, but socium nostrum. Doe you see now how the poore man is ouer taken here? for eyther he must cleare me of the ignorance, which he imputeth to me, or els he must condemne himself as much as me, in so much that the wordes of the Apostle, Rom. 2. may be iustly applyed vnto him, in quo iudicas alterum, te ipsum condemnas; eadē enim agis quae iudicas. Thou cōdemnest thy self in that wherein thou iudgest another, for thou doest the same thinges which thou iudgest; thus much for the second poynt.

16. Thirdly he obiecteth my translation of these
words of S. Aug. pag. 149. componit salutem mem • rorum in capite, which I englished thus; he compounded the health of the members in the head, and in this translation, he taketh exception to the word compounded, because compounding of health, saith he, is a phrase scarse fit to be vsed by Apothecaryes, or theyr boyes, much lesse by Phisitians, but least of all by him that would seeme to know the latyn, and to english S. Augustin. So he. VVhereto I answere, that whereas he vndertooke to shew my ignorance in the latyn tongue, the fault which he findeth here is only in my English, so as the question is, whether to compound health, be a good english phrase? the truth is, that I vsed the word compound, because it is a true english word (though deriued of the latin) and doth signify the same that compono doth in latyn; and forasmuch as the very latyn phrase of componere salutem, is somewhat strange, and that there did not occurre vnto me any other proper english word to explicate the same, I thought it better to translate it so, according to the very letter (which I alwayes do as neere as I can) then to vse circumlocutions, and multiplicity of wordes, when it may be auoided; and truly it were no great maruell, nor would giue (as I hope) any great scandall to my reader, if hauing been out of my country aboue 40. yeares, I should eyther want now and then a proper english word, or
erre in some English phrase, considering the grea • mutation, and change of the English tongue synce I came thence, which in deed I haue noted to be such in those few English bookes which I haue seen, that I do not sometymes well vnderstand them; and none that I haue read do seeme to me so extrauagant for strange, and new fangled wordes and phrases as M. Col • ins; as for example, when he sayth heer a little after, that the translatours Latin is not afrayd of a
• ar nycer teste; also pag. 260. thats the blindation. Likewise pag. 307, reliquations, pag. 365. circumgestation, pag. 395. inerrablenes, pag. 273. to • renlace, pag. 156. Cicero Rhetoricates of Pompey, pag. 266. hypercriticall: and in his epistle to his Maiesty, intimity, and personating another, in the abstracts of his second part num. 4. mistakes of memory not sonticall. And finally to omit many other, whereas I do once in my Adioynder vse the word cult pag. 388. (saying that Vigilantius tooke adoration for a diuine cult, and worship) he sayth pag. 371. that I am so cult, and so quilted in my tearmes &c. where you see, that cult, as I vse it, is so fully explicated, with the word worship and the circumstances, that no man can doubt of the sense therof; wheras his cult, and his quilted are so obscure, that for my part, I know not what he meaneth thereby: and sure I am, that the other wordes also aboue mentioned, would not haue passed for
good English in my tyme, howsoeuer they do now, • hich I leaue, good Reader, to thy iudgment. And • is shall suffice for his third instance.

17. His fourth is, that I haue marred my •• rd of Winchesters latin with my addle cor
• uptions, because I alleadged my Lords wordes:
• oncludit testes suos Augustino, with the addition of cum, which my Lord hath not; & againe • hat I alleadge scrutabitur Hierusalem cum • ucernis. Sophon. 1. for in lucernis, either adding to the scripture, sayth he, or correcting • he ould translators latin, or both, wherof he counteth the one impious, and the other ridiculous; of all which he hath no other ground, but his owne malice. For although I alleadged my Lords words, and the text of Scripture, so as he sayth, because I trusted to my memory, yet it is euident, that there is no corruption, nor any kind of fraud therein, nor change of the sense, or meaning, seeing that in any allegation of my Lords wordes, cum is but onely superfluous, and altereth nothing of the sense; neither doth it marre my Lords latin in such sort, as to make it either false, or barbarous; for albeit I graunt, that it may well be sayd, as my Lord hath it, concludit testes suos Augustino, yet cum Augustino, is much more common, and no way to be reprehended: and whereas I haue cum lucernis, in the other text, for in lucernis, it is euident, that I keep the 〈◊〉 sense, as it may appeare by the Greeke text of the
Septuaginta, which hath 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , cum lucerna. Therefore this would not haue seemed to M. Collins any great matter, if he were not toot • malicious, or were but halfe as sauourable to me, as he would • eeme to be to S. Augustine, whome be excuseth in like case, pag. 133. for altering certaine words of S. Cyprian, saying: That though he altered the wordes (as is soone done (sayth he) in allegations of memory) yet he keep • the sense: so as to alter wordes in allegations of memory when the sense is kept entyre seemed to him no greater matter in S. Augustine, though he houldeth the like in me, to be a heynous crime, no lesse then
• mpious, and a notable argument of my ignoran • e: but how much he abuseth S. Augustine with what needles excuse of him, you shall see in my fifth Ch • pter nu. 11 12.13. & 14. where I haue occasion to speake of that point.

18. But what need I alleadge his fauorable excuse of S. Augustine in this, when he is fayne to make a serious Apology for my Lord of Winchester in like manner, saying thus. pag. 266. num. 17. The most reuerend Bishop neuer sayd of himselfe that he could not slip in matter of memory. Si sciens fallo, is his imprecation. So Hieremy for Zachary Matth. 27.9. so diuers like. For what should I say of the Fathers quoting Scripture, as they often do, rather as it was in their memoryes, thē
as we read it in the text? And yet no ho
• est learned man, but would hould such • apes for very veniall I imagine. So he, • ith more to the same purpose concerning the forsayd • istake of S. Augustine, and Ciceros short me
• ory touching quotations. But that which I wish to • e specially noted heere, that he condemneth himselfe 〈◊〉 be no honest learned man, seeing he doth not • ould a scape of memory in me to be very veniall
• or as he tearmeth it more finely in his table not • onticall) but vrgeth it potently for impiety, and a • idiculous absurdity. And yet truly he had as much • eed as any other, for ought I see, to plead for pardon • n this behalfe, for a notable mistake, and scape of his • wne memory in the very same page of his Preface within 8 or 9. lynes after this, which he layeth to my • harge, as it shall appeare now presently in this next • nstance.

19. Thus then he proceedeth: Repraesenta
• e Theodosium in liberis, is to giue the children grace to be like their Father, but re
• raesentare defunctum, is to supply the losse of the dead, by yealding another in his roome, which S. Augustine wishes may be of the posterity. So he. VVherein first I wish • o be noted, that I do alleadge this place in my Adioynder out of S. Ambrose his funerall oratiō made at the exequyes of Theodosius the Empe
• our, which you see M. Collins attributeth to S.
Augustine. Now then is this sonticall, or no • sonticall? veniall, or mortall? if it be veniall
〈◊〉 him, why is the like mortall in me? if sontical •
in me, why not sonticall in him? so as you s •• his memory is no better then other mens. Secondly t • answer also to his obiection in this instance, th • wordes of S. Ambrose, which I alleadged are these Tu so • us Domine inuocandus es, tu rogandus, vt eum in filijs repraesentes, which I translated thus: Thou O Lord alone art to be inuocated, thou to be prayed, that thou mayst represent him in his children; and afterward in the number following, viz 33. (which M. Collins quoteth) I do explicate the same, saying that S. Ambrose in those wordes, speaketh of prayer to a particuler purpose, to wit, to obtayn grace of God for the Emperours children, to make them like their father. And how doth M. Collins confute this? Marry forsooth • he saith, that repraesentare defunctum, is to supply the losse of the dead Theodosius, by yealding another in his roome. B •• will you see his egregious foolery? for what reason or need had S. Ambrose to pray, that the children of Theodosius might succeed him, and be in his roome, when his two sonnes Arcadius, and Honorius, were already in possession of the Empyre, not only then when S. Ambrose made that oration, but also before Theodosius dyed; for Arcadius
had reigned togeather with him ten yeares, and Honorius two yeares; who also (I meane Honorius) was present at this funerall oration (as it appeareth therin,) Arcadius being gone, presen
• ly vpon his fathers death, into the east partes, which were assigned, and allotted to him for his gouerment; • ow then is it likely that S. Ambrose would pray • o God for that which was already performed long • efore, and then in vre? I meane that his roome might be supplyed by some of his posterity? what the •
• ould he meane by praying God to represent Theo
• osius in his children, but only to make then like • im in wisdome, and valour, for so indeed the losse • f him would be as fully supplyed by theyr vertue, as • is roome was already possessed by theyr personall suc
• ession. And yet forsooth M. Collius concludeth a
• ainst me thus: Does not this, saith he, also • rgue him a solid Latinist? But I may say of • im with more reason, Doth not this argue him a • olemne foole?

20. But what will you say if his next instance • e as wise as this? Marke well what he sayth, & he will tell you so himsel • e. Semblable, saith he, is • hat cap. 1. nu. 11. where thus be construes the Bishops words, Clariùs id loquuntur Ambrosius, & Augustinus, quàm vt obstrepere possint nouitij nostri: they speak it lowder or clearer, then that our nouices can con
• radict it, whereas it should be, then that our
nouices can drown it, for a man may contr •
dict that which is neuer so clearely spoken; drown 〈◊〉 or suppresse it he cannot, but because he knew not 〈◊〉 other sense of the word obstrepo (as in Tully p ••
Marc • llo, obstrepi videntur milirū clam •
re & tubarum sono) therefore he commits th ••
soloecisme in translating. Thus sayth this accur •• Grammaticall, and hipercriticall Doctour, w •• you see telleth you, that this is semblable to the former: & truly you may wel belieue him; for he playet • the foole no lesse in this thē he did in the other. He telleth you of a great soloecisme, which he sayth 〈◊〉 haue committed in translating obstrepere, to contradict; because I knew not of another sense it hat • in Tully p • o Marcello, where it signifyeth to drowne, as a greater sound drowneth a lesse; an • to make this deuise of his the more probable, he vset • a pretty sleight to corrupt the text of my translation; for whereas I translate my Lords wordes thus: Ambrose, and Augustine do speake (or affirme) it more plainely then that ou • Nouices can contradict it. He hath it in a different letter (a laying downe my wordes) that they speake it lowder or clearer thē that our Nouices ca • contradict it; Changing the word plainly into lowder & clearer, to draw the matter to a soun • that his inuention of drowning it, may seeme to hau • the more ground in the sentence now in question; b •• to decyde this Grammaticall Controuersy I remit 〈◊〉
• o all Dictionaryes, and to the vse of that word in • ll Authours; for although it doth most properly sig
• ify to make a kind of noyse or rustling; yet it inclu
• eth an opposition, or contradiction, as when a noyse 〈◊〉 made to hinder, interrupt, or contradict some bo
• y.

21. Therfore Calepine doth explicate it in his manner, contra aliquem strepitum facio, • bloquor, contradico. The like we read also in Thesauro Linguae latinae. Also Nizolius,
• ho professeth to giue the sense of Ciceronian words, • nd to shew how Cicero vseth them, giueth no o
• her Sinonymum of obstrepo, but obloquor,
• hich is to speake against, or contradict; & to these 〈◊〉 may add our English Dictionaryes, wherof I haue • wo heere; the one set forth in Oxford by Ryder,
• nd the other in Cambridge by Thomas Thomasius (for I haue not Cooper) but these being la
• er then he, doe by all likelyhood, either agree with • im, or correct him, if he haue erred) and these two • re very consorme to the latin Dictionaryes before al
• eadged. Ryder hath for obstiepo, to make a • oyse, or otherwise to stir against, to trou
• le, interrupt, or be against. And Thomas Thomasius, hath also the very same: so as all these • o iustify my transl • tion of obstrepere, to contra
• ict. And as for the reasons which M. Collins
• ringeth to the contrary, they are indeed worthy of • is profound wit, and skill in Grammer. The first is,
That a man may contradict that which i • neuer so clearely spoken; drown it, or suppresse it he cannot. So he. But by his leaue when any thing is so cleare, that it cannot be impugned, or gainesayd with any shew of reason, it ma • well be sayd, and is sayd commonly, that it cannot b • contradicted, supposing that it cannot be done with reason. For as the Lawyers say, hoc possumus, quod iure possumus, we may do that, which w • may do by right, and reason.

22. Moreouer wheras he confirmeth his idle conceit with an example out of Tully pro Marcello (wherin obstrepi militum clamore, doth signify, as he sayth, to be drowned) he sheweth himselfe to be a silly Grammarian; for put the case, that it should signify so there, will be therfore restrayne it alwayes to that sense: and by that example, reduce all the seuerall significations of obstrepere, to drowning, as if it did or could signify nothing els? Then le • him tell me, whether it shall signify to drowne also in Cicero, when he sayth in his Epistle to Metellus vt tibi literis ostrepere non auderem, which Thomas Thomasius expoundeth to trouble with letters; but according to M. Collins, Cicero durst not drowne Metellus with his Letters. Also in his third booke de Oratore, speaking of some Oratours that were so obscure by the multitude, & confusion of strange wordes, that they hindred and confounded themselues, he sayth, ipsi sibi quodāmodo
obstrepere videntur. Shall we then say that • hose Oratours did drowne themselues? Yea, but • hat will you say, if obstrepi clamore militum
• e expounded by an approued Author, to be cryed out • gainst which is in effect to be contradicted? VVill • ot that, trow you, suffice to make good my translati
• n? So doth
• homas Thomasius expound it in his Dictionary, printed the fourth tyme in Cambridge, and therefore belike approued by the whole Vniuersity; & if I should graunt him, that ostrepe
• e in my Lords sentēce may be translated to drown,
• hat should he gayne thereby? Is it not cleare, that the same also must needs include a gaine saying, or a contradiction, as to say, that S. Ambrose, or S. Augustine do speake it lowder then any contradiction shalbe able to drown it? Or that it cannot be drowned by any contradiction? Or by any man that shall contradict, or impugne it? But now take away his forgery of the word lowder, which he hath foisted into my translation, insteed of more plainly, there is no appearance in the world why obstrepere should signify there to drown. And how ridiculous is he to translate clariùs, lowder? For who would say of those Fathers, that they speake or say any thing lowder, when the same may be more properly expressed after the ordinary manner, by more clearely, more plainly, or more manifestly, as the word clariùs doth indeed import? So as his folly is no lesse manifest in this then his fraud. Finally if we
consider aswell the nature of the word obstrepere, as also my Lords scope, and drift in that sentence, it will • e euident, that it is so farre from signifying to drowne by any lowd kind of contradiction, that it rather signifyeth the quite contrary, to wit, to contradict by way of muttering, as to say, in effect thus: Those fathers do speake or affirme it so manifestly, that none can so much as whisper, mutter, or open his mouth against it; for no doubt my Lordes meaning was that the matter was so cleare, and manifest in S. Ambrose, and S. Augustine, that it could not admit the least contradiction in the world: and to this purpose it is to be noted, that he who added the English to the other languages in Calepine, did very well expresse the nature of the word obstrepere, expounding it in English to hisse, or mutter against, which is farre from crying out so lowd, as to drowne any thing by force of voyce. Thus much to his sixt instance, wherby you see how good a Grammarian he is.

23. His seauenth and last, is sutable to the former for fraud, foolery, and ignorance. But to the end you may the better vnderstand the whole matter, I must first acquainte you with the occasion thereof which was this. Cardinall Bellarmine for the proofe of S. Peters supremacy ouer the Apostles, and the whole Church, alleadged a place of S. Augustine out of his sermons de tempore, serm. 124. in these wordes: Totius corporis morbum in ipso
capite curat Ecclesiae &c. He (to wit, Christ) cureth the disease of the whole body in the very head of the Church, and cō
• oundeth the health of all the members, in • pso vertice, that is to say, in the very crowne, or top of the head. Thus sayth S. Augustine,
• lleadged by the Cardinall. To this my Lord of Winchester answered two wayes; the one reiecting • he sermon whence the place was taken, as not S. S. Augustins, because, sayth he there were no • ermons de tempore in S. Augustines tyme, whereof I proued the contrary at large in my Adioynder cap. 4. num. 21. 22. & 23. His other answere was, that the Cardinall had produced that testimony of S. Augustine very vnluckily, because it giueth vs notice, sayth he, of no other head but of a sickly head, nor of any other crowne of a head, but of a crazed, or crakt crowne. Thus sayd my Lord of S. Peter, & then addeth further thus: Praesertim cùm eumdem morbum in capite vestro notarint diu iam medicorum filij, etsi omnes non ego, id est, plus ego quàm omnes, that is to say, especially seeing that the Phisitians children haue now a long tyme noted the same disease in your head, althogh all not I that is to say, I more then all. Thus sayd my Lord, which seemed to me very mysticall, and so like a riddle, that I was fayne to ghesse at his meaning, and to make diuers constructions of it, touching aswell the Phisitians,
as their children, and specially concerning the wordes etsi omnes non ego, id est, plus ego quàm omnes, of which I sayd thus in my Adioynder pag. 153. num. 33.

p.q:
But although we may ghesse, who were the Physitians, and their children, yet it will not be so easy to coniecture what he meaneth by etsi omnes non ego, id est, plus ego quàm omnes, although all not I, that is to say, I more then all for truly I haue shewed it to diuers, and haue not found two that agree in the interpretation of it; but the most probable seemeth to be the one of two; one is, that he alludeth to the wordes of S. Peter, when he sayd, etsi omnes scandalizati fuerint, sed non ego, althogh all shalbe scandalized, yet not I, who neuertheles was scandalized more then they all, because he alone denyed his Maister; which sense hath great difficulty, because it neither hath connexion with that which goeth immediatly before, nor is truely applyable to the Pope (of whome M. Andrewes seemeth there to treate) but is only contumelions to S. Peter (being a taunting kind of exprobation of his fall) and therefore me thinkes M. Andrewes should not admit it to be his meaning, as sauouring to much of impiety. The other sense is, that it should be referred to M. Andrewes himselfe, and that there is some little fault in the print, I meane in the points, though not in the words, which therefore should be pointed thus, etsi omnes, non ego? And if all, not I? that is to say,
of all haue noted this disease in your head, why should not I note it? Giuing to vnderstand, that he will not yeald to any of his brethren for zeale, and skill in noting the faults of Popes, but rather plus ego quàm omnes, that is to say, therein will I go beyond them all; which sense hath at least some good coherence with the precedent clause, and well befitteth, M. Andrewes his zeale to the Ghospell, and hatred to the Pope, and so may passe for his meaning.

div.p:
25. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder, making two expositions of my Lords words: the former, as you may well perceaue, more serious then the later: neuertheles M. Collins maketh no mention of the former, but taketh hould of the later, because I deuided etsi, into et and si, and make an interrogatiue at ego? VVhereupon he sayth thus: These are the fopperyes of this great gul, & you see how profound an vnderstander of the Latin he is, that he is fayn to point the Bishops wordes a new, with his senseles interrogatiues, before he can construe them or miscōster them rather, as likewise to deuide them, and clip them by turning etsi into et, and si, but lastly to deuise a difference betweene, medici and medicorum filij, a most palpable demonstration of his vnmatchable dunsery, & like the boy in the Grammer schoole, that construed pullus equinus, a horse chicken. Thus raueth M. Collins, carping at this
my construction, which any man may see I made Ironicè, and by the way of iest, to play a little vpon my Lords obscure manner of writing, wherein nothing was so cleare as his blasphemy against S. Peter, which indeed moued me to treate his Lordship with lesse respect then otherwayes I would haue don, though at that tyme I esteemed him for no better thē D. Andrewes. But M. Collins (to the end he might the better charge me not only with ignorance in vnderstanding the Latin, but also with falsity in changing the points, and in clipping, and deuiding the wordes) wholy dissembleth aswell my whole text, as my other more serious interpretation, wherof he maketh no mention at all, but layeth load vpon this, as if I had giuen it alone, and in good earnest: which putteth me in mind of what he sayd of me in his third Chapter pag. 146. because I reproued my Lord of Winchester for saying that Card. Bellarmin did imitate or follow Iouinian, which M. Collins sayth, my Lord sayd in iest, and therefore he calleth me a Rustique, and an arrant Clowne, not discerning, sayth he, what is iest, and what is earnest. But if that be a true property of an arrant Clowne, then truly M. Collins may passe properly for one, and a kindly one, who will needes take such an euident iest (as that of myne was) for earnest and deny that of my Lordes to be earnest, which no man that reades it can take for a iest, but for a meer • aunder, as may be seene in my Adioynder cap.
3. num. 22. 28. & sequent.

26. Moreouer I cannot but wonder why he • counteth it an vnmatchable Dunsery in me, to make a difference betwixt medici, and medicorum filij (because I did descant a little vpon it, examining who might be the Fathers, & who the sonns) for I cannot conceaue, that either there can be a son without a Father, or an identity betwixt any Father & his sonne except in the Blessed Trinity, wherin neuerthelesse there is a reall, and true distinction of persons, and much more in all creatures; and therfore except he can tell me of some mens sonnes (be they Phisitians or others) that are all one with their Fathers, he may go for an vnmatchable dunse himselfe, to hould it for an vnmatchable dunsery in me to make a difference betwixt medici, and medicorum filij, shewing himselfe to be as wise, as the Grammar schoole-boy, of whome he speaketh; for as the foolish boy tooke a horse colt for a horse chickē, so this silly Doctor taketh a horse and a colt for all one, and therefore if the boy had beene demaunded, what is pullus asininu • , he might haue sayd very truly, that i • signifyeth M. D. Collins.

27. But to proceed to the conclusion of this point, be censureth the relation which I make of plus ego quàm omnes, to S. Peter, as a token of my bad latin, because I do thereby vnderstand that S. Peter was more scandalized then all the rest of the Apostles, and consequently, that I would say in Latin,
plus scandalizatus, which cannot passe for currant (sayth he) by the touch-stone of the more accurate Grammarians, who happily would no more say, plus scandalizatus, for more scandalized, thē plus illiteratus, for more vnlearned. So he; not wholy condemning me (as it seemeth) of false latin, but of barbarisme at least: neuertheles he might haue considered, if it had pleased him, that I did not vse that phrase as my owne, but ascribed it only to my Lord; and for as much as his Lordship was so mysticall, and obscure in that sentence, that he was scant intelligible, I had no reason t • thinke that he did speake so accurately then, as at other tymes, but that it might suffice, if it were true latin though perhaps none of the best. But will M. Collins maintayne it, out of his great skill in Grāmer, that plus scandalizatus may not passe for currant amongst the accurate Grammarians? By whome trow you, will he be content that the matter betryed? By Poets? By Oratours? Or by both? For my part I am cōtent to remit it to either of both. For who knoweth not that plus is vsed aswell by Oratours as by Poets for magis, & ioyned with verbs and participles both actiue, and passiue? Nullum adolescentem plus amo, sayth Plautus. Mer. Diligo illum plus in dies, sayth Cicero ad Atticum lib. 6. Calesces plus satis, sayth Terence. And that it is vsed with verbes passiue, it is cleare in Cicero ad Atticum, who sayth, caue
putes plus me quemquam o • uciari.

28. Now then I would gladly know of the
• curate grāmarian M. Collins what difference • he findeth for the construction, or propriety, yea or elegancy of the phrase betwixt plus cruciari, and plus scādalizari: & if we may say plus cruciari, and plus scandalizari, why not plus cruciatus, and plus scandalizarus. And therefore Plautus in True. made no doubt to say, plus intromissus, for magis intromissus. D. Non ego saith he, nunc intro ad vos, mittor? A. qui dum? quam miles magis D. quia enim plus dedi. A. plus enim es intromissus cùm dabas. So he. And I doubt not but that both Cicero, and Plautus, were as accurate Grammarians as M. Collins, and that they had the touchstone as well as he. This then being so, I hope I may also goe for a Grammarian, notwithstanding these exceptions which M. Collins hath taken against my skill in grammar, whereby also it may appeare, what a good grammarian, and latinist he • s, who can so litle iudge of latyn as heer you haue seene. And to the end that the same may be yet more euident, I will acquaynt you with some of his translations, whereof I haue not had occasion to speake in my reply. I omit as a trifle (thought I am sure he would not let it escape in me, without an ample, & a seuere censure) that he translateth sedula for dutifull. pag. 111. in Pope Leo's epistle to the
Emperour Martian in these words, Et precor, & sedula suggestione vos obsecro. I pray, and beseech you (sayth he) dutifully, aduising or informing, and this he translateth in this manner, to proue that Pope Leo did make suite to the Emperour with acknowledgment of duty; but because he translated it truly before, saying, sedula suggestione, by diligent suggestion, I will not insist vpon it, but will let you see how wel he vnderstandeth a place of S. Augustine de ciuitate dei. lib. 10. cap. 1. S. Augustins wordes are these. Quia latinè loquendi consuetudine non solùm imperitorum, verum etiam doctissimorum, & cognationibus humanis, at{que} affinitatibus, & quibuscun{que} necessitudinibus dicitur exhibēda religio, non eo vocabulo vitatur ambiguum, cùm de cultu Deitatis vertitur quaestio. &c. For asmuch as by the custome of speaking latyn, not only of the ignoranct but also of the best learned, religion is to be exhibited both to humane kindreds, and affinityes, and also to all kynd of alliance, and association (by friendship, or otherwayes) the ambiguity is not auoyded by that word when question is made of the worship of the Deity &c. Thus sayth S. Augustine, giuing to vnderstand that the latin word Religio is equiuocall, and ambiguous, signifying not only the worship of God, but also the obseruance, or reuerent respect due to all kind of kindreds, and alliances, and to
proue this, he alleadgeth the common vse, and custome 〈◊〉 speach aswell of the ignorant, and vnlearned, as 〈◊〉 the best learned, who vse the word in both senses: so 〈◊〉 it is to be obserued heere that S. Augustine
•• eaketh of the custome of the learned, and vnlear
• ed.

29. But how doth M. Collins vnderstand 〈◊〉 ? Forsooth the ioyneth the wordes imperitorum
• nd doctissimorum (not to consuetudine, as S. Augustine doth, but) to affinitatibus, and
• ecessitudinibus, and saith thus pag. 369. lin.
• 2. Exhibemus religionem (sayth S. Augu
• tine) quibuscum{que}, necessitudinibus, not • nly doctissimorum, but also imperitorū. To • ll these we performe a reuerence of religion. So he; as if S. Augustine had said, or meant, that a kind of religious respect is to be had • o the kindred, and alliances aswell of the vnlearned, as of the learned, which no grammar boy that could but construe latyn, would haue so much mistaken, as • e hath done. Besides that it is to be noted, that be • hangeth the order of S. Augustine his wordes to make good his errour; for whereas S. Augustine saith non solùm imperitorum, sed etiā doctissimorum, he hath it, non solùm doctissimorum, sed etiam imperitorum; wherein • his difference is to be obserued, that S. Augustine
• peaking of custome or manner of speach, had reason • o make more account of the custome of the best learned,
then of the ignorant; and therefore to pro •• that the word Religion is ambiguous, he said that not only the ignorant, but also the best learned vsed i • ābiguously; But as M. Collins hath placed the wor ••
S. Augustine should seem to make the emphasis vpon the ignorant, as to say, that the word Religion was vsed ambiguously by the custome not only of the best learned, but also of the ignorant, as if the vse of word • s receaued more authority from the custome of the ignorant then of the best learned, so as by this transposition of the words, M. Collins hath m •• e S. Augustine speake absurdly. Agayn if we take the wordes impe • itorum, and doctissimorum as they lye in S. Augustine, and apply them to
• ffi • itatibus as M. Collyns doth, no lesse absurdity will follow; for so S. Austine shall seeme to haue conceaued that his reader might doubt whether the affinity of the best learned were to be respected, aswell as the affinity of the ignorant, and that therefore to res lue that doubt S. Augustine said that a reuerend respect was to be had to the affinity not only of the ignorant, but also of the best learned; which would haue been a very idle speach, and most vnworthy of S. Augustine; for no man that reuerenceth affinity in the ignorant, would doubt whether it were to be respected also in the most learned; so as the very absurdity in the sense might haue moued M. Collins to suspect his construction of the wordes, if he had not been as witles in vnderstanding S. Augustines
meaning, as ignorant in construing his • atyn.

30. The like ignorance, but with more fraud, • e sheweth in correcting a translation of myne in his 〈◊〉 . chapter. nu. 33. The place which I translated was of S. Augustine in his Booke de cura pro mortuis cap. 4. (concerning the good which the dead may receaue by the care of their friends to bury their bodyes neer to the monuments of Saints) which I layd downe in my Adioynder pag. 301. in these wordes. Sed cùm talia viuorum solatia requiruntur &c. but when such comforts of the liuing are sought, whereby they may shew theyr pyous mynd or affection towardes theyr friendes, I do not see what help the dead may receiue therby, but only this, that whiles the liuing do remember where the bodyes of theyr frynds are layd, eisdem illis tamquam patronis susceptos apud Dominum adiuuandos commendent, they may recommend them to the same (Saynts) as to their patrons, who haue receaued them into theyr protection, to be helped with God, which truly they might doe, although they could not bury them in such places.

31. Thus farre I translated, and cited S. Augustines words: which M. Collins censureth thus. pag. 283. By the way, saith he,
you construe apud dominum adiuuandos co •
mendent, they may commend them to b • holpen with almighty God, as if, apud dominum depended of adiuuandos, and not o •
commendent; with such pretty bosles of exquisit learning it your worke embellishe • that write against bishops. So he, shewing therein his own grosse ignorance, and notorious wa •• of wit, which will be most euident, if we consider the latyn words layd down by me in my translation, w • ereof he doth fraudulently dissemble some part. The words are these: E • sdem illis aquam patronis susceptos apud dominum adiuuandos commendent; in which words I desyre to be noted, eisdem illis, as being in true grāmaticall construction the datiue case, and necessarily to be gouerned by commendent; so as the sense must needs be, that they may recommend them to the same saynts, as to theyr Patrons &c. which being so, I would gladly know of this accurate Grammarian M. Collins, how apud dominum can depend on cōmendent, to make good sense and construction? will he say, that commendent shall gouern both apud dominum, and eisdem sanctis how then shall we construe it? must we say, that they may commend them to God to the same saynts? or to the same Saynts to God? then what construction or sense is there in the sentence? but perhaps he will say, that it must be
construed, that they may commend them to • he same Saints with God; if he say so, then
• pud Dominū doth depend rather vpon eisdem • anctis, then vpon commendent, or rather it • ependeth vpon some wordes to be vnderstood, as
• ui sunt, or the like, As to say, that they may • ommend them to the same Saints, qui sunt • pud Dominum, which are with God: whereby it • ppeareth that apud Dominum, can no way de
• end vpon commendent, as M. Collins would • aue it to do; whereas making it to depend on aduuandos, and that eisdem Sanctis be gouerned • y commendent, the sense is cleare, and the con
• truction very good; for so it will be (as I translated it • efore) that they may commend them to the • ame Saints, as to their patrons, into whose protection they were receaued; adiuuandos a
• ud Dominum, to be helped with God. Can a
• y thing be more cleare then this? And yet you see • he silly fellow triūpheth, as if he had vtterly confoū
• ed me with this instance; and therfore as he sayth of • e, that with such bosses of exquisite learning my wo • k is embellished that write against Bishops, so I may say more truly of him • hat with such botches of gross ignorāce his worke it patched that writes against Iesu
• ts. And yet forsooth this is the man who as M. Io
• eph Hall his fellow Doctour affirmeth (Mulus • ulum) is one of the prime ornaments of
Cambridge, whose learning, sayth he, wit, indgement, eloquence the world knoweth, whose workes doe prayse him inough in the gate, from whose learned hand there neuer fell any thing without applause: an • finally he appealeth to al the Tribunals of learning, whether all Doway haue yeilded ought comparable to this mans pen; but how little honour, or rather how great iniury he doth to the Vniuersity of Cambridge, in making such a • ignorant fellow the prime Ornament therof, I lea •• it to the iudgement of the discreet Reader.

32 VVell then, you haue now seene how wel he hath proued his imputation of my ignorance, 〈◊〉 rather how ignorant & childish he hath shewed himselfe euen in the latin tongue, albeit there is nothing more frequent in him, then to call in question my latinity as if he were Lord of the Latin language, and th • t I could haue no greater part therof then it should please him to affoard me: when neuerthelesse I may boldly say, that although I do not take vpon me more skill in the latin then ordinary, yet I could both speak and write true Latin before he was borne, and do n •• yet need, as I hope, to begge, or borrow any of him, for ought I see either heere or in his latin booke written against Father Eudaemon Ioannes, which i • nothing el, but a very rapsody, as I may say, of oul • rusty, and barbarous words, and vncouth phrases, whereby his stile is so obscure, and harsh that no man
can read it with patience, much lesse with pleasure, and delight: in so much that it may iustly be sayd of him, at S. Hierome sayd of Iouinian the here
• ike, Non est contentus nostro, id est huma
• o, more loqui: altiùs quidam aggreditur, parturiunt montes, nascelur ridiculus mus, quod ipse non sani esse hominis, non sa
• ius iuret Orestes. Thus much concerning his third obiection.

33. There resteth now the fourth, and last of his obiections, to wit my circūstance (as he termeth it) which if he did not himselfe explicate, it would I thinke pose the Reader to ghesse what he meant by it. Thus then he sayth: Come we now to the fourth, which is his tediousnes, and his talketiuenes, in very truth insupportable, I meane his lazy, heauy, and dull repetitions of the selfe same thing often. So • e. And what repetitions thinke you are these, which are so odious, and insup • ortable? Marry forsooth, they are the recapitulatiōs of my Lord of Winchesters errours, ouersights, falsityes, and absurdityes, which I do sometymes vpon occasion repeate, remitting the Reader to the places where I had before treated thereof: & the like I do with M. Collins in this my Reply, which as it seemeth will displease him highly, and put him into a pelting chafe, for he doth no more loue to heare of his faults, then the dogge to see the whip, or the scolding queane the cucking-stole, or the Thiefe
the gallowes, but he must haue patience; for I must by his leaue, be so bould, as to put the Reader in mynd of them now and then, to the end he may remember them the better, and know M. Collins for a most fraudulent, and cogging companion. And this I hope may suffice for answere to his foure obiections against my selfe.

34. Heere then, thou hast seene, good Reader, that the calumnious cauills of my Aduersary (which haue obliged me to the iust defence of my self) haue already drawne me almost beyond the bounds of a Preface; and if I should proceed to discouer the rest of his impertinent fooleryes, this would become a treatise, rather then a Preface; and therfore I will now draw to an end, and will only say somewhat briefly to a friuolous imputation of corrupting the Fathers, wherewith he chargeth me, giuing two examples thereof: the one concerning a place of S. Augustin, which I haue answered fully in the second Chapter of my Reply, num. 37. (& therfore I omit to speak of it heere) the other is touching a place of S. Cyprian de vnitate Ecclesiae, out of whōe I alleaged in my Adioynder pag. 101. these wordes: To shew a vnity, he ordained one chaire: and a litle after, the Primacy is giuen to Peter, that one Church of Christ, and one chaire may be shewed. Now M. Collins sayth of this my allegation thus: In Cyprians wordes there is no mention of chayre, one, or more. The
wordes are only these, vt vnitatem manifesta
• et, vnitatis eiusdem originem ab vno incipientem • ua authoritate disposuit, and yet professing to English them, he couches very handsomly • n the very hart of them, I know not what • bout the appointing of one chayre. Thus • ayth M. Collins, accusing me as you see, to haue • dded those wordes to the text of S. Cyprian, & • et after a few lines, the silly fellow sayth inough to • eare me of this accusation, confessing that I follow
• amelius in his edition of S. Cyprian, according • o a coppy which he found in Cambron, wherof he • aith thus. As for the Cābron coppy, & Pamelius
• he finder, they are to light of credit to out
• ace so many, so ancient, and so vncontro
• able. Shal the Bishop be censured for allea
• ing that which all haue saue one (and yet • o iustly suspected as sauouring of Sixtus Quintus poysoned sallet) & shall not this be • alled forgery, to cleaue to one so abortiue, • nd new fangled, and forsake the rest? So • e. VVherin you see he confesseth that I haue the edi
•• on of Pamelius for me, and that Pamelius fol
• wed a coppy which he found in the Abbey of Cam
• ron; so as if there were no more to be sayd in my •• fence but this, it might suffice to cleare me from • rruption, and forgery, seeing that I follow an editi
• receaued, and publiquely bought and sould throgh
•• t Christendome.

list.item: against the veneration, reseruation, digging vp; & carrying about of holy reliques is throghly examined, and his incredible impudency, fraud, and falseho •• therein discouered by the manifest abuse of S. Ambrose, Sozomen, Theodoret, S. Chrysostome, Optatus, S. Gregory the great, S. Gregory of Towers, Origen, Victor Vticensis, and S. Hierome. pag. 419.

Chap XII. My Lord of Winchester being charged in the Adioynder with inexcusable falsity in the manifest abuse of S. Augustine, is abandoned by his Champion M. Collins; in whom also 3. notable frauds are discouered touching one sentence of the same holy Father; and that he hath shamefully • clyed and Bellarmine.
