Lastly the veneration & • anslation of holy reliques and the custome to carry ••• m in procession is clearly proued out of S. Augu
•• ine. pag. 504.
The Conclusion to the Vniuersity of Cambridge. pag. 539.
An Appendix touching a place of S. Ephraem alleadged by my Lord of Winchester, against prayer to Saints, debated with M. Collins in the 7. • hap. num. 50. & sequent. pag. 545.

div.head: A Declaration of the first poynt to be debated. M. Collins his grosse or rather malicious construction of gerere personam. His notorious want of memory, wit, & conscience. CHAP. I.
div.p:
THE first point that I meane to debate with M. D. Collins shalbe the very first of my Adioynder, concerning the Primacy of S. Peter, which is also the first of the three Controuersies, which he promiseth in the title of his booke to discusse. And I doubt not but to make the Catholik Verity in this point so euident, & by the way to discouer so many absurdities, lies, fraudes, & falsityes of his, that my Obmutesce shal • aue no lesse effect with him, to put him to silēce, thē his Epphata hath had with me, to
make me speake, when I was, and meant t • be, silent. Now then to come to the matte • Whereas my Lord of VVinchester affirmed, that S. Peter had no peculiar increase of authority giuen him by the words of our Sauiour, Pasce oues meas, and for proofe thereof alleadged S. Augustine thus: Cùm Petro dicitur, ad omnes dicitur, pasce oues meas: when it was sayd to Peter, it was sayd to all, feed my sheep; I chardged his Lordship with a lame and fraudulent allegation of S. Augustines text in these words, pag. 4. num 3.

2. To the end thou mayst (good Reader) see & note with what fidelity, & conscience this man alleadgeth the Fathers, I will lay downe the place of S. Augustine more amply then he hath done, wherby thou shalt discouer his notable fraude. S. Augustine in the place alleadged sayth thus: Non enim sine causa inter omnes Apostolos &c. For not without cause doth Peter sustayne the person of the Catholike Church amongst all the Apostles; for to this Church the keyes of the Kingdome of heauen were giuen, when they were giuen to Peter: and when it is sayd to him, dost thou loue me, feede my sheepe, it is sayd to all; and therefore the Catholike Church ought willingly to pardon her children when they are corrected, and strengthened in piety, seeing we see that to S. Peter himselfe bearing the person of the Church, pardon was
graunted, both when he had doubted vpon the •• a, and when he had thrice denyed his Mayster • c. Thus sayth S. Augustine, declaring that
•• sceoues (which our Sauiour sayd to S. Peter) was sayd to all the Church, because S. Peter
〈◊〉 are the person of the Church, which he did • y reason of the supreme authority that he • ad ouer the Church; or els why should • ather he, then others of the Apostles be said • o represent the whole Church, but because • e was head or supreme Gouernour therof? which we may learne euen in Cicero, who • ayth, that, Est proprium munus magistratus &c. It 〈◊〉 the proper office, or duty, of the magistrate to vn
• erstād that be beareth the person of the Citty. So he, • peaking of the chief, or suprem magistrate.

3. Whereby it appeareth, that what
• oeuer is giuen to the King, as King, and • ead of the Commonwealth, the same is gi
• en to the commonwealth whereof he bea
• eth, and representeth the person: and so in • ike manner what was giuen to S. Peter as • ead of the Church, the same was giuen to • he Church which he representeth. For which cause also S. Cyprian sayth, that Ec
• lesia est in Episcopo, the Church is in the Bi
• hop; and the reason is, because the Bi
• hop is head of the Church: & as this is true • n euery particuler Bishop, in respect of the
particuler Church, which he gouerneth; 〈◊〉 also it is most truly verified in the supreme, and vniuersall Pastour, in respect of the whole Church, wherof he his head. Thus farre I, in my Adioynder; whereunto I added three places of S. Augustine to the same purpose, which I will lay down hereafter with M. Collins his answere, when I shall haue first sayd somwhat to his answere to this. Wherin I must desire thee (good Reader) to note two things very remarkable in this very first encounter, that thou mayst the better discouer his impe • tinent, and fraudulent dealing in the rest.

4. First then, thou shalt vnderstand that in answere of this which I haue laid down, and of those three places of S. Augustine, before mētioned he spendeth at least 40. pages, and through his whole discourse doth wilfully, and wittingly peruert the sense of my words. For whereas I alleadge out of S. Augustine, that S. Peter bare the person of the Church, and do expound the same, that he represented the Church, giuing also the reason therof, viz. because he was head, and supreme gouernour of the Church; M. Collins dissembleth wholy what I say about the representation of the Church, and maketh me to vnderstand gerere personam Ecclesiae, to signify
regere Ecclesiam, to gouerne the Church; • heras I make the one to be but a consequēt the other, viz that he representeth the • hurch, because he was head of it. To this • urpose therefore M. Collins sayth, that with • e, to beare the person of the Church, importeth as • uch as to be endewed with suprem authority ouer the • hurch. And againe pag. 4. that I expound the • earing of the persō, by Tullius office, to beno o
• er, thē to be made supreme Magistrate; and after • gayne pag. 7. he sayth thus. I affirme, sayth he,
• at gerere personam, is to resemble the Church, or to and for the Church not to be made chiefe Magistrate 〈◊〉 the Church, as you would face vs. And pag. 16. ha
• ing sayd out of S Augustine, that Petrus infir
• os Ecclesiae significat, he addeth, is this also to be cō
• rued by Tullius office, or gouernement? or doth not
〈◊〉 . Augustine speak yet significantly inough, without • e turne the Iesuites dictionary? And after againe • ag. 17. he sayth that, gerere personam, must be •• nstrued as S. Augustine doth, by figurare, & sig
• ificare, and not by regere, a word not once vsed by S. Augustine in that sense. And lastly to omit di
• erse other places to the same purpose, he • ayth, that I thinke gerebat personam, to be as • uch, as tenebat regimen, pag. 20 num. 17.

5. I haue alleadged all this out of so many different pages of his, that you may see • ow idlely he iangleth all this while, fighting
with his owne shaddow whiles he ••
loweth his owne false sense, and misco •
struction of my wordes, by the which it euident, that I vnderstand gerere personam E •
clesiae, in S. Augustine, no other way then 〈◊〉 represent or signify the Church; albeit I a •• withall the reason thereof; making the one as I haue sayd, a consequent of the other, viz because he was head thereof: and not confounding them as he would make his reade belieue, to frame matter for himselfe to impugne, as you shall further see after a whil • when I shall haue represented vnto you 〈◊〉 ridiculous grammaticall conceyt of his, togeather with his bad memory and wor • lucke about the phrase gerere personam. Thu • then he sayth pag. 5. num. 5.

6. In Tully it is gerere, in Saint Augustine gestare personam Ecclesiae. Is there no difference, thinke you, betweene these two? VVhat, if 〈◊〉 be of things figuratiue, another of things essentiall? 〈◊〉 you blame me as too Criticall for distinguishing b •
tweene gerere, and gestare; gerimus magistr •
tum, gestamus vestem, eyther Scenicam, 〈◊〉
some other, gestamus & personam. I meane 〈◊〉 now personam in S. Augustines sense, least
〈◊〉 Peter be further of his supremacy, then you are 〈◊〉 ware. And though Augustine in some place may s •
gerere personam, euen of Peter in this case, y •
neyther in that place which you now alleadge de ago
• Christiano cap. 30. for one gerebat, you shall • e fiue gestabats in S. Augustine. I belieue ge
• re, portare, sustinere, figurate, all these, • ay remember gerere, though I deny not, yet it • nes so seldom, as I may truly say, I scarce remember.
〈◊〉 farre he.

7. Wherein you may note what a nyce • fference this man hath made heere bet
• eene gerere and gestare, only to shew his skil 〈◊〉 grammer, for I cannot tell to what other •• rpose it may serue: for albeit in alleadging Augustines wordes in that place I haue gerere
•• steed of gestare, yet is it euidēt that the sense all one, & that I take it in no other sense, •• en M. Collins himselfe doth; which is to present, or figure the Church. But in that • hich followeth in him concerning how • ft gestabat, and gerebat may be found in S. • ugustine, thou mayst note (good reader) that is beliefe is no better then his memory, & • oth very bad. For wheras he sayth he belie
• eth, that for one gerebat, we shall haue fiue
•• stabats (of the which neuertheles he allead
• eth but two) I do not belieue, but know, • nd can shew him, at least, six gerebats for • is two gestabats, as, if his memory had been • ught worth, he might haue partly remem
• red in that which he both saw alleadged
by me, and alleadged also afterwards hi • selfe, and partly might haue noted in oth •• places or S. Augustine, if he had read him so ••
ligently as he would seeme to haue done.

8. For first he saw alleadged by 〈◊〉
pag. 5. num. 5. these wordes. Cuius Ecclesiae P •
trus Apostolus propter Apostolatus sui primatum ger •
bat figurata generalitate personam. Which word he also alleadgeth himselfe afterwards pag. 20. num. 17. besides that he produceth another place out of S. Augustine pag. 13. in thes • words: Cuius populi diximus Iudam in figura gess • sse personam, sicut Ecclesiae gessit Apostolus Petru • , where you see gerere personam is twice, which he could not haue forgot, if he had but a • much memory as a goose, seeing he alleadged it himselfe: wherunto I add, that S. A •
gustine in his exposition vpon S. Iohns gospell tract. 118. hauing alleadged these wordes o • our Sauiour, Tibi dabo claues regni caelorum, addeth, Et hoc cum omnibus tanquam personam gere •• ipsius vnitatis accepit; and agayne vpon the 30 psalme concione 2. he sayth. Hoc agit Ecclesiae, c •
ius personā gerebat Petrus, quando ei de caelo submiss •• est discus. Lastly in his treatise de Baptismo co ••• Donatistas lib. 3. c. 18. he faith, that the Apostle •
personam gerebant Ecclesiae, whē Christ sayd vnto them accipite Spiritum Sanctum; and I doub • not but if I would haue taken the paynes 〈◊〉
search for more gerebats, I might haue found • ore, for these occurred to me by chaunce, • arching for somewhat els, and vpon other • ccasions. Therefore I leaue it, good Reader, • o thy consideration, what credit this man • eserues, when he pawneth eyther his beiefe, or his memory, seeing both are so bad • s you see. Wherof I may add yet this fur
• her proofe, that he himselfe pag. 30. calleth
• erere personam, the wonted phrase of S. Augustine,
• aying that in the 20. cap. of that book (viz. de •• gone Christiano) S. Augustine sufficiently shewes what he meanes by his wonted phrase of gerere personam. So as you see how weake not only his beliefe and memory is, but also his wit, seeing he so cōtradicteth himselfe, as to affirme that gerere personam is so seldō in S. Austine, that he scarce remembreth it, & neuerthelesse alleadgeth it himself thrice, & calleth it afterwards his wonted phrase; therfore were it not better for him to be dūbe, thē to talk so idly?

9. But now to proceed with the rest of my text concerning this matter; hauing said in my Adioynder, that S. Augustine affirmed, that S. Peter bare the person of the Church (that is to say represented the same) because he was head of it; I proceeded to the further proofe thereof thus. That this was S. August. meaning it is euident by his own doctrin in
other places, where he sheweth plainly tha • S. Peter bare the figure or persō of the Churc • in respect of his primacy, Cuius Ecclesiae (sayt • he) Petrus Apostolus propter Apostolatus sui prima ••• gerebat figurata generalitate personam &c. Of which Church Peter in respect of the primacy of his Apostleship did beare the person figuring, or representing the generality therof; for if we respect what did belonge properly to himself, he was by nature one man, by grace one Christiā, & by a more aboundant grace Vnus, idemque primus Apostolus; one and he the chiefe Apostle: but it was sayd vnto him Tibi dabo claues &c. I will giue thee the keyes, he signifyed, the vniuersall Church. Thus sayth S. Augustine, teaching euidently that S. Peter bare the person of the Church by reason of the primacy of his Apostleship, that is to say, because he was the chiefe Apostle, which the same holy Father signifieth more plainly in another place, saying: Cuius Ecclesiae ille agnoscitur gessisse personam propter primatum quem in discipulis habuit: of which Church he is acknowledged to haue borne the person, for the primacy which he had amongst the disciples. And to the same purpose he sayth also elsewhere, Petrus à petra cognominatus &c. Peter taking his name from the rocke, was happy bearing the figure of the Church, hauing the principality of the Apostleship. Lo then for what
cause S. Augustine sayth, that when Christ • aue to S. Peter the keyes of heauen, and Pa
•• orall authority to feed his sheepe, he gaue •• e same to all the Church, viz. because S.
• eter hauing the principality or primacy of • he Apostolicall dignity, and being conse
• uently chiefe pastor, & head of the Church, • id beare, & represent the person or figure of • he whole Church. So that you see the place which M. Andrewes bring • th out of S. Augu
• tine agaynst the primacy of S. Peter, maketh • otably for it, if it be considered with the • ircumstances thereof, which he cunningly, • nd craftily concealed.

10. Thus farre the Adioynder, wherein I wish to be noted, first how euident it is that I do by these 3. places of S. Augustine confirme the sense I formerly gaue of gerere personam Ecclesiae, to be no other but to represent, or signify the Church as a figure; and therefore in the introduction to the said places, I say that S. Augustine sheweth plainly in other places that S. Peter bare the person, or figure of the Church. To which purpose I alledge S. Augustines wordes thus. Whereof (that is to say of which Church) S. Peter did beare the person, figuring, or representing the generality therof. And in the 3. place thus: That he did beare the figure of the Church. And
afterwards in the conclusion of the whol • discourse, I expound to beare by represent and person by figure, saying that S. Peter di • beare, and represent the person, or figure o • the whole Church. Now then can any thing be more c •• are, then that I do not take gerere personam Ecclesiae, to signify regere Ecclesiam, to gouerne the Church? What meaneth then this poore man to trouble himself so much as he • oth to find out, and alleadge diuers other places in S Augustine, where he teacheth that S. Peter did signi • y the Church, and beare the figure of the Church as though I denyed it, when I did shew and proue it expresly by S. Augustine? Nay what conscience hath he to charge, me as he doth, with quoting this place, and these wordes of S. Augustine against the light of Conscience?

11. For thus he sayth to me pag. 9. lin 7. But for quoting of places against the light of Consciēce, was ther euer any wretch so taken
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so 〈◊〉 the very manner, as you are in the construction of gerere personam, which S. Augustine expounds by gestare figuram, or portare figuram? You would fayne extend to boundlesse iurisdiction; and if gerere, and gestare were graunted to be all one, is there 〈◊〉 difference betweene figura, and persona, as persona is put for maiestas reip? VVill you put figura in that sense too? So he. As if I did take persona for
the maiesty of the common wealth, and not • r a figure of it, as I do expresly. Who then the wretch that quoteth places, and parti
• lerly this agaynst the light of Conscience? • or he? Neuertheles I would not haue him • inke that when I do expound persona by fi
• ra (as S. Augustine doth) I doe deny, that he • ho doth beare the person, & figure of the • mmon wealth doth also represent the ma
• sty of it; for he that representeth the whose • mmon wealth representeth al that is in it, • r properly belongeth vnto it, be it maiesty, • uthority, iurisdiction, prerogatiues, priui
• dges, or what els soeuer is properly the cō
• on wealthes, the same being al virtually in •• e Gouernour, and deriued from him, to e
• ery member of the common wealth, accor
• ing to their seuerall functions, and offices; • hich shalbe further treated and explicated • ereafter cap. 2. num. 7. & 8. Item. cap 4. num.
〈◊〉
& 10. And in the meane tyme S. Augustine
• oth signify this sufficiently, when he sayth • hat S. Peter bare the person of the Church
•• opter primatum quem in discipulis habuit: in respect 〈◊〉 the primacy which he had amongst the disciples, as • ppeareth in the 3. places alleadged out of • im before, which therfore we will now • onsider how M. Collins answereth.

12. For albeyt I resolued at the first to
answere him as I may say in grosse, that to say, to discouer only some such notab •• frauds, and extrauagant follies, as might s •
ffice to shew how vnworthy he is of a mo •• large, and particuler answere; yet consid •
ring that for the clearing of this controue •
sy, concerning S. Peters primacy, it importe •• very much to take frō our aduersaries the • ordinary euasion to make the Apostles equ •• compartners with S. Peter of the authority 〈◊〉 the keyes, and Commission to feed Christe • sheepe; and seeing that M. Collins in this hi • defense of my Lord of Ely laboureth tooth 〈◊〉 nayle (imploying all that little wit, & poor • talent that he hath) to proue that S. Augusti ••
for this poynt is wholly theirs (to which purpose he is so copious, & prodigall in the allegation of him, that sometymes he cyteth almost whole pags out of him to no purpose insulting agaynst me, and charging me also otherwhiles with the scant, and lame allegation of him) I will therefore take a little payns to trace his footsteps for some pages and to examine all that he bringeth out of S. Augustine (of any moment) in answere of the places alleadged by me, or to fortify my Lord of Elyes doctrine touching this point. And this I will do the rather, because I shall thereby discouer so much trumpery, and
treachery in him, as may suffice, not only to • tify my owne allegations of S. Augustine
〈◊〉 this matter, and to shew how weake, & • y a champion my Lord of Ely hath chosen 〈◊〉 defend his cause; but also to make it eui
• nt to the reader what a world of absurdi
• es, falsities, and follies would be found in • m if I would take the paynes to examine, • d answere euery thinge in particuler, • roughout his idle, and worthlesse worke, • hich is nothing els but a very packe, and • dell of fraud, and folly; as I doubt not • t it shall euidently appeare by that which • lloweth.

div.head: M. Collins his answere to a place of S. Augustine, & his 6. notes vpon the same are examined, and confuted. And by the way his notable folly, fraude, contradictions, and shamefull abuse aswell of S. Augustine & Origen, as of his Aduersary, is discouered. CHAP. II.
div.p:
THE first of the 3. places which he vndertaketh to answer is the secōd in my Adioinder, cited by me out of S. Augustine his Commentary vpon the 108. psalme briefly thus. Cuius Ecclesiae ille agnoscitur gessisse personā &c. Of which Church he (Peter) is acknowl • dged to haue borne the person, for the primacy which he had amongst the disciples. Now M. Collins to g ue me a great blow (as he pretendeth) and t ••••• ore the place vpon me, cyteth it pag. 10. num 7. much more largely thus. Sicut quaedam
dicuntur quae ad Apostolum Petrum propriè pertinere videntur &c. As some things are layd, which may seeme properly to belonge to the Apostle Peter, and yet haue no cleare sense, but whē they are referred to the Church, wherof he is knowne to haue represented the person figuratiuely, for the chiefdome that he had among the disciples (as that is for one; To thee I will giue the keyes of the Kingdome of heauen, and if there be any like:) So Iudas sustaynes after a manner the person of the Iewes, Christes enemyes, who both then hated Christ &c. This farre M. Collins alleadgeth S. Augustine, and then sayth thus. Heere is somewhat that you catch at, but more that wee may retort vpon you; you catch very greedily at propter primatum quem in discipulis habuit, which we neuer doubted, but S. Peter had a place of some priority in the qui • e Apostolike, and it may be, for that our Sauiour the rather chose him to represēt his Church, more zealous then the rest, more auncient then the rest, whether to figure the fayth or the eternity of the Church, thone in this world, thother in the next, and for what endowments els you can deuise: for some no doubt; and if it be secret, is it therefore none? Will you call Christ to account for euery thing, and vnlesse we can answere
for him, will you condemne him? So he; trifling as you see aboue measure.

2. For what answereth he heere to any purpose to the place of S. Augustine, otherwayes then eyther to deny his assertion, or els to doubt of the verity of it; for wheras the Father affirmeth that S. Peter represented the Church propter primatum, for his primacy, or by reason of his primacy; M. Collins graunting that he had some priority in the Apostolike quite, addeth, that it may be for that our Sauiour the rather chose him to represent his Church; so as it may be also he did not; and that S. Augustine was deceiued; and that there might be • ome other causes of it, namely those, which M. Collins hath drawne out of the depth of his profound braine; to wit, because S. Peter
• as more zealous, & more auncient then the rest &c. or for what endowments el • of his the reader can deuise: yea he maketh no doubt but that there was some cause though perhaps it was so secret that we cannot searc • into it, except we call Christ to account, • ea and condemne him for it. And therfore hauing also giuen afterwards another reason, or cause why S. Peter was chosen to represent the Church (to wit to figure vnity) he addeth that perhaps it was the secret of our Sauiours brest; and then concludeth,
and are you so little acquainted with the liberty of Gods actions, or reserue you nothing for our knowledge in the world to come? This to your obiection. So he: wherin you see what small account he maketh of the authority of that famous Doctor, & most learned Father, seing that notwithstāding the reason which he yealdeth, this poore pedantical Doctor holdeth it to be so vncertayne, that it may be doubted whether the true reason therof will euer be knowne in this world; but for as much as he laboureth afterwards to shape vs a better answer by way of certayn remarkable notes which he recommendeth to his reader to be considered, I will take a little paynes to examine them, not doubting but to discouer withall as well his folly, as his fraud, & impudency in alleadging, glossing, & expounding the Fathers.

3. Now then he maketh vpon the aforesayd place six notes, which I will lay downe in his owne words, and answere as briefly as conueniently I may. His first note is this, pag. 12. num. 8. Now marke, sayth he, what we gather out of S. Augustines text. First some things there are seeming to belonge to Peter, which can make no cleare sense, but when they are construed of the Church. This is flat agaynst you, that would haue
Peter such a figure of the Church forsooth as yet to occuppy a certayne place of his own, & what is g • uen to Peter should be giuen to the Church, and what to the Church, the same to Peter. But some thinges sayes S. Augustine, are sayd to Peter, which can haue no pregnant construction, but of the Church. So he. Wherein you see, he mentioneth, and taxeth as an errour, that we would haue Peter so to represent the Church, as to occupy a certayne place of his owne, and that what should be giuen to him, or to the Church, should be giuen aswell to thone, as to thother. This I say he taxeth as an errour, and would perswade his reader that it is confuted by this text of S. Augustin, whom he affirmeth to teach, that some things are sayd to Peter, which haue no pregnant construction, but of the Church: which last wordes, but of the Church, he hath put in a different letter, as S. Augustines, whereas they are but his owne falsification thereof, excluding therby S. Peter, wholy from al participation of the promise of the keyes, which S. Austine neyther sayth, nor meaneth, except we will also haue him to exclude all the Apostles frō receiuing the holy Ghost, and the power to retayne, and remit sinnes.

4. To this purpose it is to be vnderstood
that S. Augustine lib. 3. de baptis. cap. 18. • ayth of all the Apostles, that (when our Sa
• iour sayd vnto them, Accipi • e Spiritum sanc
• um &c. Receiue the holy Ghost, whose sinnes you forgiue they shalbe forgiuen &c.) gerebant personam Ec
• lesiae: They bare the person of the Church. That is • o say, they represented, and figured the Church, and consequently (according to S. Augustines doctrine) receiued the holy Ghost, • nd the power to retayne, and remit sinnes • or the Church. Will now M. Collins say, that they receyued not this power for thēselues, but only for the Church? or that our Sauiours words can haue no pregnant, or cleare construction but of the Church? I thinke he will not be so absurd, & yet if he mayntaine his glosse vpon S. Augustine touching S. Peter he must say so; for S. Augustine sayd of S. Peter,
• hat which you haue heard for no other reason, but because S. Peter bare the person of the Church, and therefore the like is to be sayd of all the Apostles, seeing that they also in receyuing the power to remit sinnes, bare the person of the Church. So as if M. Collins will deny the power of the keyes to S. Peters own person, & allow it only to the Church, because he represented the Church, the same must needes follow concerning the rest of the Apostles for the same reason. Loe then,
how M. Collins bestirreth himselfe, & layeth about him • ike a mad man (light where it will) striking all the Apostles at one blow insteed of S Peter; and no meruaile, seeing you shal see him anone as bold with our Sauiour himsel • e, cap. 3. num. 7. 8. & 9.

5. But now I am sure he will aske me heere, whether all the Apostles did beare the person of the Church propter primatum, for the primacy? And if it were so, where then was S. Peters primacy aboue the rest? To answere to this, he is to vnderstand, that albeit euery one that representeth a Citty, Commonwealth or Kingdome, is not necessarily gouernour thereof (as shalbe declared hereafter more at large cap 3. num 9.) yet the same may be well graunted of the Apostles without any derogation to S. Peters primacy. For there is no doubt, but that they were all of them gouernours of the Church, and consequently did represent it, and therefore receiued the power to remit sins for the Church, yet wit • out preiudice to the primacy of thei • superiour, who did beare the person of the Chur • h in a more eminent manner, as being head not ōly of the rest of the Church, but also of the Apostles themselues; which S. Augustine signifyeth plainly inough, euen in this place now in question, where he
sayth, that S. Peter bare the person of the Church propter primatum quem in discipulis habu
• t; for the primacy which he had amongst the disciples. And in his booke de Baptismo contra Donatistas, lib. 2. cap. 1. he sayth of S. Peter, that in him primatus Apostolorum praeeminet excellenti gratia: The primacy of the • postles is praeeminent with an excellent grace And therefore as they rep • esented the Church for the power, and domination which they had ouer it, so did he represent the same much more eminently for the primacy which he had as well ouer them, as ouer the rest of the Church.

6. But for asmuch as S Augustines meaning in the place now in question betwixt M. Collins and me, may best be vnderstood by the circumstances therof, and especially by the drift, and end which he had therein, it is to be considered that S. Augustine expounding the 108. psalme, which was a prophecy, or prediction of the malice of the Iewes against our Sauiour Christ (& especially of the traitor Iudas) applied it to the wicked generation of the Iewes; I meane that he applied to them, not only that which was euidently spoken of them in that psalme, but also that which was properly, and expresly sayd of Iudas himself, as namely that verse; Fi • nt dies eius pauci, & episcopatum eius accipiet alter: Let his dayes
be but sew & let another take his bishoprike (which words of the psalme are interpreted in the Acts of the Apostles expresly of Iudas) so that S. Austine to shew the probability of this his • x • o •• son confirmed it by the like interpretation made elswhere by himselfe of certayn speach • s addressed to S. Peter, which albeyt they m •• seeme to belonge properly to him (that is to sa • to be so proper to him as not to haue a • y further relation to any other,) yet they cannot haue, sayth S. Aug. their cleare sense, but when they are referred to the Church, whereof he is acknowledged to haue borne the person in a figure, by reason of the primacy which he had amongst the disciples. And this S. Augustine exemplifieth by, Tibi dabo claues regnicalorum. Which words being spoken by our Sauiour to S. Peter himselfe expresly, and directly, it were absurd to thinke that S. Augustine would not haue them to be vnderstood at all of him, but only of the Church, as M. Collins doth interprete him.

7. To this purpose it is to be noted that S. Augustine sayth not, that they can haue no cleare construction, but of the Church, as M. Colli • s falsely affirmeth, but that they haue not a cleare sense but when they are referred to the Church, signifying only thereby that
albeit they were spoken to S. Peter, and meant of him, yet they had a further relation then to him alone, to wit to the Church, of which he represented the person in respect of his primacy; for albeit a thinge be properly spoken of a man, yet it may haue a further relation to some other man, or to something els, without preiudice to the propriety thereof; and to make this cleare in this case, it is to be vnderstood that S. Peter did beare heere two persons, thone true, and proper, which was his owne naturall person, and thother figuratiue, which was the person of the Church (wherof he was head,) & therefore these wordes which were spoken directly to him were spokē with respect to both, to him first, immediatly, and properly, and to thother (to wit to the true Church) secondarily and by way of reference, and relation, because he represented it; which he did two wayes, thone as euery King, or absolute Prince representeth the Kingdome, & commonwealth which he gouerneth, in which respect the authour of the Questions of the n •• , testament in S. Austines workes sayth of S. Peter quaest. 75. Saluator cùm pro se, & Petro dari iubet &c. VVhen our Sauiour commaundeth that the tribute should be payed for himselfe, and for Peter, he seemeth to haue payed for all; for as all the causes of superiority
were in our Sauiour, so after our Sauiour, all are contayned in Peter; for he made him their head, that he might he Pastour of our Lordes flocke. So sayth this auncient authour. And a little after: Christ (sayth he) praying for Peter, prayed for all the Apostles, for the people is eyther corrected or cōmended in the gouernour. So he; giuing the reason why, and how our Sauiour praying, and paying for Peter, prayed and payed for all the Apostles, viz. because Peter being their head, represented them all: and the like is to be sayd of any supreme gouernour, in respect of his subiects, and whole commonwealth during his owne lite, and gouernement.

8. But now S. Peter did represent the Apostles, and the whole Church in another respect, & in a peculiar manner, not cōmon to all heades but to him only, that is the first created & instituted gouernour of some new Kingdom or community, to whom the authority which is giuen him, is giuen (not only to himselfe for his owne tyme, but also) to the whole Kingdome, or community for the tyme to come, yea so long as the said Kingdome shall stand. As for example; If an Emperor should erect some part of his estate into a Kingdome, and create a King therof, it is euident that all the power, and authority which the Emperour giueth to this new,
and first King, is intended, and giuen both to him, and to the Kingdome erected in him, seeing that the sayd power, and authority is to be exercised by him and all his succ • ssors, and other their instruments for the good, and benefit of the sayd Kingdome; & therefore the wordes, writings or ceremonies vsed in the creation of such a King, or directed to his person, to signify the regall power, and authority giuen him, is to be vnderstood properly of him, yet with a relation also to his successors, for all future tymes, and consequently to the whole Kingdome, for the benefit wherof he is created King. And this is the true case now in questiō betwixt M. Collins and me, concerning S. Peter, whome our Sauiour ordayned the first head, or (b •
M. Collins leaue) the first Monarch of his Church, that is to say, of the Ecclesiastica • l Monarchy; in respect whereof S. Augustine sa • th, that some things were spoken by our Sauiour to S. Peter, which haue not their cleare, or full sense, but when they haue a reference, or relation to the Church which he represented, and for the benefit whereof he receiued the power of the keyes, & commission to feed the flocke of Christ; which power, and commission was not giuen him for himselfe alone, but for the sake & benefit
of the whole Church, & therfore it was not to dye, or end with him, but to continue in the layd Church, and to be administred for the good thereof by his successors, vntil the end of the world.

9. But now M. Collins will say perhaps that he hath reiected, and confuted this similitude before pag. 6. nu. 6. The truth is, he hath sayd somwhat of it, but so little to the purpose that he hath thereby rather confirmed, then cō • uted it. He impugneth it with t • o reas • ns; thone because it is preiudiciall to the sta • e of temporall Princes, giuing as much authority to the people, as to the Prince, and therfore he sayth that secret might haue rotted in my brest. And thother, because I am as rude sayth he) with our owne Doctours, as rash with Princes crownes, making generall Councells quarter-Maysters with the Pope: & by this occasion he also glaunceth at the Councells of Basill and Constance, & the opinion of some Catholike Doctours, who hould that a generall Councell is aboue the Pope. But if it please D. Collins to consider the matter a little better, he shall see, that neyther temporall Princes, nor the Popes loose any part of their authority by this similitude; for when I say that what is giuen to the King, as King, is giuen also to the Commonwealth; I doe not
meane by the Commonwealth a body without a head, but the body with the head, that is to say, the commonwealth togeather with the Prince, & subordinate to him, so that the authority, & power which is in the head, is deri • ed from him into the seueral members, and partes of the body, according to their seuerall functions, and mynisteries, whereby the said authority may well be said to be the common wealths, because it is giuen to the Prince (as I haue signified before) for the benefit of the Common wealth, and to be exercised therin, yet still depēding of the Prince, and flowing into the Commonwealth from him; what then doth the temporall, or spirituall Prince loose by this? doth this make the people eyther quarter-maister with the King, or the Councell with the Pope? seeing that it doth not follow of my similitude, that eyther the Councell hath any authority ouer the Pope, or the Parlamēt ouer the King, but both of them may, and do (for ought I say to the contrary) remayne alwayes subiect to their head, in such sort, that they cannot make so much as a decree without his consent, as we see by experience in our Parlaments; and the like is also to be sayd of generall Councells. And this being so, you may se how idly he tatleth of the Councells of
Constance, and Basill, and the doctrine of some Catholikes, which teach that the Councell is aboue the Pope, and therfore I let it passe as nothing to the purpose, and drawing vs to another question needles to be treated in this place.

10. Now then to returne to S. Augustines wordes vpon the 108. Psalme: whereas M. Collins maketh him teach, as you haue heard, that the wordes, Tibi dabo claues, spoken to S. Peter, were not to be construed of him, but of the Church, the same may be easily confuted, euen by the comparison it selfe, which S. Augustine maketh there betwixt thinges spoken of Iudas, and other speaches directed to Peter, saying that not those thinges only, which are sayd in the 108. psalme cleerly inough of the wicked Iewes, • re to be vnderstood of them: Verumetiam illa (sayth he) quae proprie de ipso Iuda dicuntur expressiùs: VVhich are properly and more ex • resly sayd of Iudas himselfe. And to cōfirme this, he compareth the same with, Tib • dabo claues, spoken to S. Peter. And therfore S. Augustine his intention being to shew by that exāple that these things which were spoken properly of Iudas might be conueniently vnderstood of all the wicked Iewes, the substance, and force of this comparison must needes consist in this, that as certayne
thinges spoken to S. Peter, to wit, Tibi • bo claues, and, pasce oues meas, and, Tu es Petrus • c. were meant, and are to be vnderstood • roperly & expresly of S. Peters owne person yet with relation to the Church, which he • epresented): So also those thinges, which • n the 108. psalme are sayd properly, and ex
• resly of Iudas, may haue relation to the wic
• ed Iewes, whose person he bare in some • ort, to wit, as their Captayne, or head in res
• ect of his exorbitant malignity, and im
• iety. So as to make S. Augustine his compa
• ison, and argument good, these thinges which were spoken to S. Peter, and withall were referred to the Church, must needes be • s properly, and truly vnderstood of S. Peter himselfe, as these other spoken of Iudas, were • o be vnderstood properly, and truly of him, • hough withall they were to be referred to • he wicked Iewes; for otherwise the cōparison & argument grounded therupon should fayle euen in that, wherin the greatest force of it should consist, which were absurd, and most vnworthy of the most excellent iudgement, and learning of that most worthy, iudicious, and learned Father.

11. Thou seest then (good reader) how absurdly M. Collins seeketh to draw out of this place of S. Augustine his owne idle fiction, viz.
that these wordes of our Sauiour to S. Peter Tibi dabo claues, and the like, can haue no pregnant construction but of the Church; wheras S. Augustine teacheth the flat contrary by this example and comparison. And M: Collins to deceaue the vnwary reader setteth downe part of his false glosse in a different letter, as if it were S. Augustines owne wordes, & text. Thus much to his first note.

12. The second is this pag. 12. Secondly, sayth he, amidst those somethings (which are spoken of S. Peter) is Tibi dabo claues; S. Aug. vseth this very example, which you would fayne haue to be ingrossed by Peter; as if the keyes had been personally deliuered to him, and in his owne right, which S. Augustine denyes. So M. Collins: wherin are two manifest vntruthes (not to call them lewd lyes, to auoyd wordes of reproach:) one is, that we would haue the power of the keyes ingrossed b • S. Peter, and deliuered vnto him, not only personally, but also in his owne right, whereof you haue seene the contrary in all my former discourse concerning this matter, wherby it is cleare that we teach, that albeit the power of the keyes, and the Commission to feed Christ his sheep, were giuen t • S. Peter p • rsonally (that is to say, to his owne person to be vsed by him) yet not to be
ingrossed by him, or so deliuered vnto him in his owne right, as to exclude others, but to be exercised by him, and his successors, and others subordinate to them, for the behoofe, and benefit of the church; and therfore giuen both to him, and to the church in his person. This then being our doctrine the reader may cōsider how false it is, which M. Collins affirmeth heere of vs, viz. that we would haue all the power of the keyes ingrossed by S. Peter, as if the church had no part therin, nor right therto. The second vntruth in his second note is, that S. Augustine denyes that the keyes were personally deliuered to S. Peter; wheras S. Augustine teacheth euen in this place, that Tibi dabo claues was spoken properly to S. Peter himselfe, though with relation to the Church, as I haue shewed in the last paragraph.

13. In his third note he sayth thus: Thirddly, Siqua alia, if there be any more, there may be more, then as Pasce oues meas, no doubt this must be one, by his owne exposition before de Agone Christiano. cap. 30. So he, Giuing to vnderstand that aswel pasce oues meas, as tibi dabo claues, can haue no pregn • nt construction of S Peters person but of the church only; and this he groundeth also vpon S. Augustine his doctrine in the same place; but how falsey, you haue
seene euidently already in Tibi dabo claues, and therfore may easily discouer the like falsity, and his vanity, and folly with all, in this his other instāce of pasce oues meas, which we graunt indeed to haue the like construction to Tibi dabo claues; that is to say, that it was spoken personally to S. Peter and in his person to the whole church which he represented propter primatum, by reason of his primacy; which is S. Augustine his expresse doctrine, as you haue seene; so as M. Collins his third note is as fond, & fraudulent as the 2. precedent, being al three groūded vpon the false foundation of his owne friuolous glosse.

14. His fourth note vpon S. Augustines words is, that Peter bare indeed, sayth he, personam Ecclesiae; but in figura, which you pared of; not by power of his place, or authority permanent; but culd out before the rest by our Lord for that end to signify vnity. So he. wherin you see he taxeth me by the way, for paring out these words, in figura, when I alleadged some part of this place of S. Augustine which I omit to answere now, meaning to say somewhat therto anone in the end of this chap. num. 37. & for the present do request thee, good reader, to note, how this his note cōtradicteth S. August. or rather maketh S. Augustine contradict himself in this very place now in questiō, wherin
S. Augustine sayth expressly that Peter bare the person of the church in a figure, propter primatum quem in discipulis habuit, for the primacy winch he had amongst the disciples: wh • ras M. Collins by this glosse maketh him say, or meane at least, that S. Peter di • beare indeed the person of the church in figure, but not by the power of his place, and if this be true, how did he beare the person of the church propter primatum? for what place had he more then the rest of the Apostles, but his primacy? if then he bare the person of the church for his primacy (as S. Augustine express • y affirmeth) how then is M. Collins his glosse true, that he did not beare it for his place, or (as he sayth more obsurely) by the power of his place? Was his place of primacy vo • d of power? yea sayth M. Collins, he had a priority, a superiority, or a primacy of place, order, and excellency, but not of power, authority, and gouerment.

15. But this is most absurd, seeing that it is clere, that he had his primacy in respect of the keyes, and commission to feed Christs flocke giuen him for the Church, and to the church in him, as S. Augustine teacheth; or (as Tertullian sayth in Scorpiaco) to him and to the church by him; Memento (sayth he) claues caeli hic Dominū Petro, & per cum Ecclesiae reliquisse.
Remember that our Lord left the keyes of heauen heer to Peter, & by him to the church. To which purpose Optatus also sayth lib. 7 cont. Donat. that Peter, solus accepit claues caeteris communicandas: receiued alone the keyes to be communicated to the rest of the apostles, wherby Optatus giueth to vnderstand that Peter being Apostolorum caput, the head of the Apostles (as he calleth him expressly lib. 2.) was to communicate to them the power of the keyes, which he had receiued alone, yet not for himselfe alone, but for himselfe, and them; and therfore not as a proxy (as M. Collins absurdly affirmeth pag. 81. in answere to this place of Optatus) but a •
caput, a head, from whence the power is to be deriued, and communicated to the body, and to the seuerall partes therof. If therfore ther be any authority in the whole church by reason of the keyes, and commission giuen to Peter, the same must needes be principally in him, to whome they were giuen as Primate, or head for himself, & by him to the church.

16. In which respect S. Augustine sayth also, in his treatise of Baptisme against the Donatistes lib. 3. cap. 17 (which M. Collins himselfe alleadgeth pag. 4. num. 10.) that God gaue potestatem Petro in typo vnitatis, power vnto Peter in the type, or figure of vnity; that the same
which he loosed in earth, should be loosed 〈◊〉 heauen. And againe in his tract. 123. in E
• n. Ioan. speaking of the pastorall comission • uen to S. Peter all pastors, by the words
• sces oues meas, he expoūdeth pascere by docere, • regere, to teach, & gouern; saying, Quibus oues ipsas • scendas, hoc est, docendas, regendas{que} committit. • o which (Pastors) he committed the sheep to be fed, • at is to say, to be taught and gouerned. Thus sayth 〈◊〉
Augustin, teaching euidently that our Saui
• ur giuing S. Peter comission to feede his • eep, gaue him authority and power to • ouerne; wherupon it followeth that the • lace of Peters primacy, or the primacy of • is place cannot be separated from his po
• er, and authority giuen him altogeather • y the keyes, & commission of Pastour. For • lbeit all the Apostles, & the whole church • eceiued the same power, and comission in • im, and by him, yet in respect of his primacy the same must needes be principally, • nd eminently in him; which S. Leo teacheth • xpressly, yealding also the reason thereof, • aying serm 3. in assump. suae ad Pontif. that God would haue the mystery of the charge (of preaching vniuersally) so to belong to the office of all the Apostles, that he placed it principally in Peter, the cheefe of them to • hend that he might dilate, or spread abroad
his giftes, as into all the body, ad ipso quasi quodam • api • e, from him as from a certaine head. Thus sa • th S. Leo, of whole worthines, & great authority in Gods church, I shal haue occasiō 〈◊〉 say somwhat herafter cap 6. nū 38.

17. Fu • thermore M. Collins sayth in his 4. note that S. Peter was cul • out by our Lord before the r • st, to represent hi • church, to sig • i • y vnity, which as you haue heard, he affirmeth also in diuers other places, grounding himsel • vpon S. Austine & therupon denyeth that S. Peter bare the figure of the church, by the power of his place, or authority permanent, which is as much in effect, as to deny that he represented the church propter primatum, for his primacy; which n • uerthelesse you see is S. Augustine his expresse doctrine, and vtterly ouerthroweth M. Collins his glosse. Besides that, what a simple, and absurd manner of arguing is this, to deny, or impugne one truth by another, as thogh two truths, or al truthes could not stand togeather, or that diuers cōsideratiōs, causes or motiues might not concurre to produce one effect? What Catholike denieth, or doubteth, that for the loue of vnity, and the necessity therof in the church, our Sauiour did chuse one head of the Apostles, and of the whole church (and consequently to beare the person, and figure
of the church) not onely to shew the vnity therof, but also to cause, and to conserue vnity therin; as I haue proued in my Adioynder out of S. Cyprian, & S. Hierome. How absurdly then doth M. Collins argue thus in effect? Our Sauiour chose S. Peter to be the chiefe Apostle (or to haue the primacy of the Apostles) to signify vnity, ergo for nothing els, but to stand for a bare Cyphar, or figure, and not to haue any power, or commaund for the gouerment of the Church?

18. But how doth this follow? Nay how euident is the contrary? to wit, that our Sauiour had so great respect, and loue to vnity, that for the conseruation therof in the church it seemed to his diuine wisedom most necessary to giue to one (viz. to S. Peter and his successors) most ample power, and authority to command, ordayne, & punish, without the which neither schisms, nor heresyes can either be preuented, or remedied, nor consequently vnity conserued; and this I say, is so euident, that my L. of VVinchester denyeth not Apol. cap. 8. pag. 219. (in answer to the place of S. Hierome aboue mentioned) that one (to wit S. Peter) was chosen head amongst the Apostles to auoyd schisme; yea and graunteth that he had so much power giuē him, as might suffice for tend, for the
which h •
〈◊〉 ord •• ed; whereupon ••
duced •• ny Adi • r cap. 3. num.
〈◊〉 b • a necessary conseq •••• , all that power, & authority, which we acknowledge to be in S. Peter, and his successours. Thus then you see that the reason of vnity, with the which M. Collins impugneth S. Peters primacy doth nothing preiudice it, but rather notably confirme it. Thus much to his fourth note.

19. In his fifth he sayth thus. Primatus, sayth he, was not the Primacy of Magistracy, euen that declares that he sayes the keyes were promised to him propter primatum. So that first the primacy, and then the keyes, and his primacy amongst the Apostles was a motiue cause to promise him the keyes in the name of the Church, whereas els Primatus, & the keyes had gone togeather, and as soone Primatus, so soone the keyes; but now they are promised him for some speciallty in him, not for office then, as you would haue it. Thus far M. Collins, who hauing granted, as you haue heard before some kind of primacy in S. Peter, seeketh to exclude him heere from all primacy of gouernement, or magistracy (as he tearmeth it) and to that end he supposeth one thing, & affirmeth another, neither of them euer meant by S. Augustine. He supposeth that S. Peter had his primacy before he represented the Church, & affirmeth that the keyes were promised him
propter Primatum, whereupon he argueth as you haue heard. But his supposition is flat against S. Augustines meaning in this place, who sayth, that gessit personam Ecclesiae propter Primatum: He bare the person of the Church for his Primacy (or in respect, or by reason of his primacy,) wherof the naturall and cleare sense must needes be, that he represented the Church, because he was Primate, or chiefe of the Apostles; wherin the cause, and the effect are signifyed to concurre, as the King representeth the Commonwealth, because he is King or Head therof, and not because he being made King, is afterwards deputed to some such office of representation; but being King, he doth consequently, and by nature of his Regal office, and dignity beare the person of the Common wealth, that is to say, he doth conteine, & cōprehend in himselfe the whole authority, dignity, maiesty, & power of the Commonwealth, which floweth from him, as from the head into al the members, & parts of the political body.

20. This coniunction, & concurrence of these two (although it is cleare inough in this place wherof we now treate) yet may be confirmed by another place alleadged by me before out of S. Augustine serm. 13. de verb. Dom. where he sayth, that Peter taking his name
from a Rocke was happy, bearing the figure of the Church, hauing the principality of the Apostleship. Which manner of speach expresseth a concurrence of three thinges. The first, that he was made the foundation of the Church, which is signifyed by the change of his name taken frō a Rocke (alluding to the words and promise of our Sauiour Matth. 16. Thou art Peter, & vpon this Rocke will I build my Church) The second is that he represēted the church. The third, that he had the principality of the Apostleship. And of those three thinges, the two later are necessary consequent of the first; for being the foundation of the Church he was consequently the head therof; and being head of the Church, he represented the whole body thereof, and consequently was Prince, and chiefe of the Apostles: so as all those do so necessarily include one another, that they cannot be s •
parated.

21. And that S Augustine his meaning was that S. Peter bare the persō of the church because he was the foundation, or head of it, he signifyeth euidently inough in his commentary vpon the 30. psalme concio. 2. where discoursing vpon the words spoken to S. Peter in the acts of the Apostles, macta & manduca, he applyeth the same to S. Peter,
and the Church, Cuius personam (sayth he) gerebat Petrus &c. VVhose person S. Peter did beare, when the dish full of all kind of beasts was let downe vnto him from heauen; and then he addeth further, that our Lord did therin prefigure his Church that it should deuoure, & conuert all Nations into her owne body; and that therefore he sayd: Ecclesia, hoc est, Petre (quia super hanc petram aedificabo Ecclesiam meam) macta & manduca. O Church, that is to say Peter (because vpon this Rocke I will build my Church kill & eate. So he. Wherein you may see that he calleth Peter the Church, or rather the Church Peter, because he bare the person of the church, and yealdeth thereof this reason, because C • rist sayd vnto him: Vpon this Rocke will I build my Church Signifying that he represented the Church, because the same was founded vpon him, that is to say, because he was made head of the Church (for as I haue sayd before, the foundation in a building representeth the head in a politicall body, or Commonwealth;) wherupon it also followeth, that the representatiō of the church and the primacy therof were inseparable in S. Peter, the one including the other. And therefore M. Collins his supposition that the one was before the other, is both friuolous, and false, and most repugnant to the meaning of S. Augustine.

22. No lesse friuolous, yea and fraudulent also is his affirmatiō, which I noted before concerning the separation of Peters primacy from his receauing the keyes, saying, that the Primacy was the motiue cause why the keyes were promised him. First the primacy, and then the keyes, whereas els the Primacy, and the keyes had gone togeather, and as soone the primacy, so soone the keyes. So he. And then he concludeth, that the keyes were promised him, not for his office, but for some speciality in him. Al which he groūdeth vpon the place and words of S. Augustine before alleadged. But I would gladly know of him, where he findeth in those words, & in that place, that the keyes were promised to S. Peter, for his primacy. That which I find there, and al that can be found is, that S. Peter represented the Church, or bare the person of it for his primacy, which signifyeth plainely, as I haue shewed already, the concurrence of S. Peters bearing the person of the Church with his primacy (as of a necessary effect with the cause) but of promising the keyes, & much lesse of giuing them before, or after his Primacy, sooner, or later, there is not so much as one word in that place of S. Augustine; and therfore he may be ashamed to say, as he doth, to wit, that S. Augustine sayth: The keyes were promised
him, propter Primatum, seeing that he neither sayth, nor meaneth it. And his conclusion is not only as false, as his premisses, but also ridiculous. For he sayth: But now (the keyes) are promised him for some speciallty in him, and not for office then, as you would haue it. So he, distinguishing, as you see, betwixt some speciality in S. Peter, and his Office, and concluding that the keyes were promised him for the one, and not for the other.

23. But good M. Collins, resolue vs heer what difference you make betwixt that speciality in S. Peter, and his office, which according to your premisses must needes be all one; for you sayd before, that S. Augustine sayes, The keyes were promised to him, propter Primatum, for his primacy; and now you conclude that the keyes were promised him for some speciality in him; and therefore that speciallty must needes be his Primacy, if you will agree with S. Augustine, and your selfe; and if his Primacy was his speciallty, what els was his office, for the which you say, I would haue the keyes to be promised him; truely for my part I can imagine no other speciall office in S. Peter, but his Primacy, yet I must tel you good Syr, that you mistak me much, if you thinke, as it seemes you doe, that I would haue the keyes promised to S. Peter
for his office, that is to say, for his Primacy (supposing as you do, that he had his office before the promise of the keyes,) for in my poore vnderstanding he was no officer before the keyes were both promised, and deliuered him; so as you haue, I will not say belyed both S. Augustine, and me, but truly you haue mistaken vs both very much. This may suffice to the fifth note.

24. The sixt, and last note is this. As Iudas (sayth he) sustayned the person of the wicked (
• ost • uit, a more powerfull word then gestauit, and much more then significauit, which is sayd heere of Peter, and yet but quodam modo, so shye is S. Augustine, so far from the iurisdiction, you build vpon
• ullyes offices) so Peter of the Church, as Iudas of the one, so Peter of the other, sayth S. Augustine, which was no authoritatiue primacy, you may be sure except Iudas shall haue a generati • on of successours now as well as Peter, and which is more damnable of holy Scriptures institution So far M. Collins, with a great deal • of more trumpery • ollow ng, wherin he disgorgeth himself of a great • art of his malice against the Pope, whi • h I omit as not worth the answering, seeing the force of his argument consisteth in that, which I haue heere layed downe already.

25. Now then to say somwhat therto,
I let passe his idle parenthesis concerning sustinuit, gestauit, and significauit, tending only to fortify his peruerse, and willfull misconstruction of my Text, touching S. Peters bearing the person of the Church, wherof I haue sufficiently treated, and discouered his malice, and fraud therin cap. 1. num. 4. & 5. whereto I remit my Reader; and will now examine the force and weight of his argument, which is, that according to S. Augustin, Iudas did beare the person of the wicked Iewes, as Saint Peter bare the person of the Church. And therefore if S. Peter by reason of his representing the Church, had a Primacy of power, and authority ouer the Church, Iudas must haue also the like primacy, and power ouer all the wicked Iews; or if Iudas had no such primacy, then neither hath S. Peter any such.

26. But who would not wonder to • ee such an argument proceed from a Doctor of Diuinity? For what petty Sophister knoweth not the nature of an argument drawne from a similitude or comparison? To wit, that it holdeth not in all pointes, • ut in that, or those pointes only for the which the similitude, and comparison was made? Otherwise because Christ is compa
• ed to a Lyon in the scripture Apoc. 5. he must
be like a Lyon in al things; and being compared also to a lambe Ioan. 1. he must be in 〈◊〉 thinges like a lambe: whereupon it woul • follow that these two beasts being of mo •• contrary nature, and condition the one t • the other, Christ being in all things like t • them both, must be most vnlike, or rathe • contrary to himselfe; and seeing that no • only Christ, but the Diuell also is likene • to a Lyon 1. Petr. 5. Christ must be like th • Diuell. Do you see what would follow o • M. Doctour Collius his Logike? In like manne • argued they, who as we read in S. Augusti •• serm 35. de verb. Dom. sought to proue by the • parable of the wicked Steward, Luc. 16. tha • it is lawfull to robbe or steale with intention to giue almes, because the Steward is cōmended for purchasing friends to himself • with his Lord, and maisters goods; whera • our Sauiour propoundeth that similitud • only to incite vs to be as diligent, and industrious in procuring our saluation by the good imployment of our owne goods in almes, & pious works as the wicked Steward was to make friendes by the fraudulent imployment of his Maisters goods. And he that would apply this parable to other purpose might ground therupon a most dangerous doctrine to teach Stewards, & Officer •
to cozen their maisters. And therfore Theophilactus vpon this parable sayth notably well thus: Non oportet omnes &c. we must not ouer curiously search into all partes of parables, but so farre forth as they serue for the purpose; for the rest are to be passed ouer, as seruing onely for the composition, and connexion of the parable. Thus sayth Theophilact.

27. To declare therfore in what this similitude, and comparison betwixt S. Peter, and Iudas holdeth; it is to be vnderstood that S. Augustine compareth them onely in two things: the one in that, as Peter bare the person of the Church, in a figure propter primatum, for his primacy amongst the Apostles, so did Iudas beare the person of the wicked Iewes quodam modo (sayth S. Augustine) after a certayne manner; giuing to vnderstand therby, that Iudas did not so properly figure, and represent the wicked Iewes as S. Peter figured and represented the Church, but onely quodam modo, in a certaine manner: as who would say that Iudas being, as it were, the Captayne and ringleader of Christes enemies (in respect of his exorbitant, and excessiue malice, wherin he surmounted thē all) might therfore be said to haue a kynde of primacy or superiority amongst them, and so to beare their person, or to represent them, as S. Peter did truly beare the person of the Church, in
respect of the true, and reall primacy which he had amongst the disciples of Christ.

28. The other thing, wherin they are compared is, that as certaine things which were spoken to S. Peter, and did properly belong to him, can haue no cleere sense, but when they are referred to the church, so in like manner some things which we read in the 108. psalme concerning Iudas, and are properly spoken of him, may be conueniently vnderstood also of the wicked Iewes, as hauing relation to thē; & in this later point consisteth the chief force of S. Augustins comparison betwixt S. Peter, and Iudas; and therfore, it were most absurd to inferre a p • rity betwixt them in other things, not intended either at all, or not so principally by S. Augustine; as namely betwixt S. Peters reall, and true Primacy (which S. Augustine acknowledged him to haue had amongst the Apostles) and that kind of Captaynship (as I may tearme it) which may be imagined in Iudas (for really he had none) amongst the wicked Iewes; so as, albeyt there may be some comparison in respect of the Analogy, or proportion, which we may conceiue betwixt them; yet a reall, proper, and true parity, or equality there can not be otherwise then in imagination.

29. Furthermore if M. Cellius will stand to his argumēt he must needs acknowledge that Iudas had primatum loci, & ordinis, a primacy of place and order amongst the wicked Iewes, seeing my Lord of VVinchester and he do graunt the same to S. Peter; to which purpose they must also imagine some reall election of Iudas to that primacy, and that the wicked Iewes made their assembly, wherin Iudas was to haue the first place, as S. Peter by their concession was to haue in Synodes, or Councels of the Apostles: for this must needes follow if their argument be good against vs; seeing that this comparison, maketh as much against S. Peters primacy of place, & order (which M. Collins graunteth) as against the primacy of power which wee acknowledge in S. Peter, & he denieth. Loe then what a learned doctour we haue heere of M. Collins, who with his potent argumēt ouerthroweth himself as much as his aduersary.

30. But for the more full and cleere cōfutation of this Cauill of his (albeyt this which I haue already sayd might suffice) I will lay down another obiection, & argument of his, of the same nature, which he vrgeth mightily afterwards, spending therin 4. or 5. whole pages; the answere wherof,
I hope, will not onely satisfy the Reader for both obiections, but also stop M. Collins his mouth, seeing that as well the answere as the obiection shalbe taken out of himselfe, who some leaues after this his argumēt grounded vpon S. Augustin his comparison of Iudas with S. Peter, bringeth the very like out of him also, vpon a comparison which he maketh betwixt S. Iohn the Euangelist & S. Peter, comparing S. Peter to the temporall life, and S. Iohn to the eternall, making them figures therof, and to represent, or signify the same, as you haue heard he said before of S. Peter, that he signified, or represented the church.

31. Of this point M. Collins sayth thus pag. 24. num. 19. I am a fraide (sayth he) of giuing the Reader a surfet in a case so euident but yet I must not omit this one passage that sollowes in the for said tractate of the Father vpon S. Iohn, because our aduersary hath quoted it. He sayes then, that as there is a twofold state of the church, one in misery, and in exile, another in glory, in royalty, in blisse, so Peter was made a figure of the former, Iohn of the later, by our Sauiour Christ: so as n • t onely Ioannes a • e • onitur Petro, Iohn in the one of these is preferred before Peter (as S. Aug. words are) but simply Iohn surpasseth Peter, as much as the life that wee shall lead in blisse, excelles this miserable that wee heere liue; for therafter as the liues are, so are the figures
of them both, which are heere sayd to be the two apostles, Peter of the militant church, Iohn of the triumphant, as hath beene shewed. But shall wee say trow you, that Iohn is a Monarch in the triumphant, or beares any rule, or regiment amongst the blessed, where the sonne himself resignes his kingdome, or submits it at least to God the Father. 1. Cor. 15? or i •
Iohn hath no such monarchy by vertue of his figuring and representing that state; why then should Peter clayme any in earth because he stands for a figure of the militant? Thus sayth M. Collins, and then layeth down a good part of S. Augustins discourse still vrging it to the same purpose that you haue heard, and maketh also an ample comment vpon it; impugning, and reiecting S. Peters supremacy ouer the church militant, because S. Iohn hath no supremacy ou • r the church triumphant.

32. And not content with this, he resumeth againe afterwards the same comparison betwixt S. Iohn and S. Peter, out of Origens second homily in diuersa; but with much more fraud, as shall appeare after a while. Thus then M. Collins sayth in his 5. cap. pag. 203. Are you aduised (sayth he) what priuiledges Origen heapes vpon S. Iohn there, not inferior to Peter, not to any? for it is not for nothing that Iohn still crosses Peter: though th'one set out former, yet th'other arriued first at his iourneyes end.
Ioan. 20. Cui donatum est (sayes Origen) quod tibi donatum est? O beate! To whome was it euer giuen, that which to thee hath beene giuen? O Thou blessed creature! Dic quaeso cui talis, & tanta donata est gratia? I pray thee tell me, To whome was euer such & so great grace conferred? feare ye not least he deface the virgins garland, not onely Peters? and as Peter is a rocke by interpretation (as you tell vs) so Iohn (if we beleeue Origen) latinè quod donatum est, as if a packe of gyftes were couched in him, and the speciallest gyft that euer befell a man (either the Monarchy, be like, or aboue the Monarchy, another one in degree, to whom that may befit 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , you know the place. So he. With a great deale more which I omit, not to tyre thee, good Reader, and my self with such impertinent stuffe, as you will fynd this to be, when you shall haue heard what he fraudulently dissembleth in this very place.

33. But first I can not but note heer, by the way, how this poore man is ouertaken, no lesse in his comparison of S. Iohn with S. Peter, then in the former of S. Peter with Iudas; seeing that his argumēt, if it be good against S. Peters supremacy, or (as he calleth it) Peters monarchy in the church militant, it ouerthroweth also that primacy of place, which he graunteth to Peter except he will say that S. Iohn hath the first place in heauen, which
I thinke he will not be so bold to determine, or so impudent to say that S. Augustine had any such meaning.

34. But to proceed to what I intended, thou shalt vnderstand, good Reader, that M. Collins afterwardes speaking of another matter in his 6. chap. pag. 224. doth open the way, and giue a good occasion to find out the resolution of this doubt; for hauing cyted a place of S. Augustine out of this Treatise of his vpon S. Iohns Ghospell, in confirmation of another place of Origen, taken out of his second homily vpon the same Ghospell, he sayth thus: The very same hath S. Augustine, almost totidem verbis, vpon the same Text of S Iohn tract. 44. that you may know one Father borrowed of another, specially the Latin of the Greeke. So he, wherin he sayth true, & very well to our purpose; it being very euident that S. Augustin in this his comparison of S. Iohn with S. Peter, & of the two different liues, which they represent, imitateth Origen in his homily vpō the ghospel In princio erat Verbum, which is the same homily out of which M. Collins taketh, & vrgeth the foresavd comparison; wherin neuertheles this difference is to be obserued, that Origē treateth of the actiue, and contemplatiue life, & S. Augustine of the temporall and eternall life.

35. Now then Origen will giue vs good light what was his meaning, and consequently S. Augustines, who doth imitate him in the comparison betwixt S. Peter and S. Iohn. Therfore Origen hauing (in the place which is alleadge • , and v • gen by M. Collins) proposed S Peter as the figure of fayth, and action; and S. Iohn as the type and figure of contemplation, and the vnderstanding, and hauing compared them togeather in such sort that he giueth farre greater aduantage, and preheminency to S. Iohn, explicateth himselfe notably, and cleareth all this difficulty, saying: Nemo nos existimet &c. Let no man thinke that we preferre Iohn before Peter. VVho would so do? For which of the Apostls was higher in dignity then he, who is, and is called, Vertex eorum, their head? So Origen. And a little after: Non praeferimus Petro Ioannem &c. &c. VVe do not preferre Iohn before Peter, but compare contemplation with action &c. for we do not now consider the dignity of these Apostolicall persons, but do search for a notable difference of the diuine M • steryes. Thus sayth Origen • Wherein you see he is so farre from derogating any thing from S. Peters primacy by his comparison, that he doth plainly acknowledge it, and vtterly disclaime from al meaning, and intention to impugne, or contradict it: whereby M. Collins may well vnderstand,
if it please him, that S. Augustine might also make the like vse of this comparison that Origen doth, without any preiudice to the primacy of S. Peter.

36. What conscience then hath he, who seeing this in Origen (as he must needes do, when he culd out of him so many sentences as you haue heard him alleadg out of the same place) would neuertheles so seriously, and vehemently vrge, and exagerate this comparison, flatly against the meaning and intention of the Author? How can a man trust any allegation of his, further thē he • ryeth it, seeing he is so false, and fraudulent as you see? Therefore, to conclude concerning his sixt note, thou seest, good R ader, how conforme it is to the former, all of them notably discouering the folly, and fraud of the Author, who, as you haue heard, argueth most simply, corrupteth, & peruerteth most impudently as well S. Augustines text, and meaning, as myne, contradicteth himselfe shamefully, & finally with a •• ared cōscience dissembleth Origens cleare, and expresse wordes, which doe wholy ouerthrow the inferrence, & argument that he draweth out of him in the same place.

37. And now to say a word, or two (as I promised) concerning his imputation
of fraudulent dealing to me in the allegation of S. Augustines text (because for gestauit I had gessit, & pared off, as he sayth, the words in figura) truly I thinke he would haue beene ashamed (as little shame as he hath) to haue obiected this to me, had he not first wholy dissembled my text, and peruerted, and falsifyed my meaning touching the sense of gerere personam Ecclesiae in S. Augustine, which as I haue amply shewed in the beginning, I do expresly expound to represent, and signify the Church, taking persona for figura; so as no difference can be imagined in that place betweene gerere and gestare, nor any want of the words in figura. Albeit alleadging onely a piece of the text for breuityes sake, I left out these words as needles, being necessarily vnderstood, and included in the word persona (which I translated sometymes person, or figure) and was also otherwise sufficiently signifyed, and expressed by me in all that discourse. Which if thou dost not remember, good Reader, I beseech thee to tak pains to reuiew it in the first cap. num. 4. & 5. and thou shalt see how notably he hath sought to cozen thee, and abuse vs both: and therefore, I say vnto him with the Psalmist: Erubescant impij, deducantur in infernum, muta fiant labia dolosa: Psal. 30.

div.head: M Collins his answere to another place of S. Augustine is examined. Three reasons which he vrgeth against the primacy of S. Peter are proued to be most ridiculous; the first being nothing to the purpose, and the other two being as forcible against our Sauiours Supremacy, as against S. Peters. CHAP. III.
div.p:
MAISTER D. Collins will now take in hand pag. 14. num. 10. another place, which I alleadged out of S. Augustine to proue that S. Peter did beare the person of the Church in respect of his primacy and his meaning is to retort it vpon me, or at least to shew that it auaileth me nothing. You quote further (sayth he) S. August. in his 13. serm. de verbis Dom. secundum Matth. out of which you haue these words: Petrus à petra cognominatus
&c. which moreouer you English thus. Peter taking his name from a Rocke was happy, bearing the figure of the • hurch hauing the principality of the Apostleship of which anone, as it serues your turne. In the meane tyme you may see what variety of words S. Augustin •
hath to set out the meaning of his gere • e personam, both heere, and els where, though heere he doth not vse so much as the word personam, but figuram only, which is a great deale lesse, or rather makes all besides, to be iust nothing. So be. And then after scrapeth togeather a great many of places out of Saint Augustine, to proue that gerere personā, doth signify in him only to figure, signify, or represent, which he prosecuteth for fiue or six pages togeather speaking to me diuers tymes by the way, & telling me of my construction of gerere personam out of
• ullies Offices, by regere, and potiri rerum, as though I had sayd so; wheras this place it selfe maketh it cleare, that I take persona for figura, seeing that I alleadge it to proue that S. Peter did beare the person of the Church, albeit there is no mētion there of persona, but of figura, vsed insteed of it, which therefore I must needs vnderstand for persona, or otherwise the place should serue me to no purpose; and so prolixe, and tedious is this idle Doctor in this discourse, that he is fayne afterwards to excuse himself
to his Reader pag. 17. num. 12. saying: VVe • e too long vpon this place, but discouer one of our dis
•• uerers trickes, and discredit all. So he. And do • ou see how he hath discredited me hither
• o? Or rather how he hath disgraced him
• elfe, discouering his owne falsity, and folly?

2. But what sayth he now in conclu
• ion to the point, that is in controuersy be
• wixt vs, for the proofe whereof I produ
• ed that place of S. Augustine? Truly he shoo
• eth at it, • s I may say three boltes; I wil not • all them fooles bolts (because he is they say 〈◊〉 Doctor of Diuinity) but I may well say • hat neuer wise Doctor shot so much at rā
• dom, or more foolishly thē he, as it shal euidently appeare. Thus then he sayth pag. 16. • lleadging these wordes out of S. Augustin:
• l • um videte P • trum, qui tunc erat figura nostra. Consider sayth he) that Peter, who was then our figure bare not our person, that is, bare rule ouer vs, •• e neuer liuing in S. Peters tyme, and his regency being expired before we were borne, but (as I haue sayd often standing for the Church by the way of type and figure, and so he represented for vs, and for the Church vntill the worlds end, whereas he could gouern no more, then liued in his owne dayes. Thus he. Full wisely, as though we held that S. Peter doth gouerne the Church still in person: for what els proueth, or concludeth he heere,
but that neither we liued in Peters tyme, no • he in ours; and that he doth not personally gouerne vs now, which no man denyeth. And therefore I thinke neuer any wise ma • shot a bolt further wide from the marke, then M. Collins hath done heere.

3. For how doth it follow of all this, which he hath sayd, that S. Peter whiles he liued, was not supreme head, & gouernour of the Chu • ch, or that his successours do not lawfully gouerne vs now, by the vertue of that power, and authority which they receaued then in him? Do not Kinges at this da • lawfully exercise that Regall power, which was giuen them in their first predecessor (albeit he himselfe could not personaly gouerne more those which liued in his owne tyme) and the reason why his successors doe still lawfully gouerne, is, as I haue sufficiē • ly declared before, because he being the type and figure, as well of his successors, as of his whole kingdome, receaued the regall power both for himselfe, and for them. And the like is euident • n S. Peter, whose authority is iustly acknowledged in his successors, because when the Ecclesiastical Monarchy was first erected in him, he was their t • pe, or figure, or bare their person by reason of his primacy, as S. Augustin affirmeth,
and therefore receaued his authority both • or himselfe, and for them.

4. This the Bishops of the Councell of Chalcedon acknowledged in their acclama
• ions to the letters of Pope Leo. Act. 2. Petrus (say they) per Leonem locutus est, Peter hath spoken by Leo. And for this cause S. Augustine sayth to the Donatists of the succession of the Roman Bishops: Numerate sacerdotes, vel ab ipsa Petri se
• de, & in illo ordine Patrum, quis cui successit videte; • psa est Petra, quam non vincunt superbae inferorum • ortae. Count the Priests euen from the seate of Peter and see who haue succeeded one another in that row of Fathers; That is the Rocke which the proud gates of • ell do not ouercome. Thus sayth S. Augustine
• n Psal. contra part. Donat. applying to S. Peters
• uccessors that which was spokē personally • o him, because he bare not only his owne person, but also theirs, which will yet more euidently appeare by my answere to M. Collins his next obiection taken also out of S. Augustine. Thus then he proceedeth.

5. Againe, sayth he, pag. 16. to vrge significat against this mans magnificat, which he singes to Peter, but afore he know what it meanes, In eo quod dixit Petrus; Tu es filius Dei vini, firmos significat (sayth S. Augustine:) In eo quod trepidat &c. infirmos Ecclesiae significat. Is this to be construed also by Tullyes offices, of gouernement?
