or doth not S. Augustine speake it s • gnificantly inough without we turne the Iesuits dict ••
nary? doth a magistrate signify the Citty which he gouernes: or was Peter at one tyme gouernour of t •• strong, namely when he belieued and confessed Christ; and another tyme of the weake, namely when he sta •
gered? How then was he euer vniuersall Gouernou •• For when he dou • ted he confessed not, and when 〈◊〉 confessed he doubted not; so neuer was he Gouerno •• of the • od • altogeather, neuer did he gerere personam in that sense. I thinke you see cause to repe •• your con ••• uction, vnles you be weary of vniuersall dominion. T • us shooteth M. Collins his second b •• , as wide as the former. For wheras he vrg • th his significat against my magnificat (as he termet • it) you haue heard sufficiently be • ore how shamefully he peruerteth my meaning, & you see how he iangleth now, harping stil vpon the same false string. And as for his argument against S. Peters vniuersall dominion, it is right worthy of such an acute Doctor, as M. D. Collins, hauing as much force against the vniuersal dominion of our Sauiour Christ, as S. Peters.

6. I doubt not but that his Doctorship will acknowledge our Sauiour to be head of his Church; and if he so doe, he may learne out of S. Augustin (vpon whome he seemeth wholy to rely for this question) that
the head may not only be a figure of the body, but also signify different partes thereof for different respects, which S. Aug. teacheth expresly of our Sauiour Christ in his exposition of the psalmes 21. and 68. Vpon the • ater he sayth thus: Christus non solùm caput sed • orpus est; ex ipsis verbis agnoscimus. Christ is not on
• y the head, but also the body; we know it by his owne wordes. So sayth S. Augustine, calling our Sauiour the body as well as the head, because he was a figure of his body, the Church: in which respect he sayth a little after. Vnde • amquam aliquid inuitus patiatur sic clamat? whence commeth it that he cryeth out so, as if he suffered somwhat agaynst his will? Nisi quia caput, membra sua praefigurat. But because being head, he doth prefigure, or signify his members. And agayne a little after. Praefigurans ergo & transformans in se nos ipsos, hoc • it, Saluum me fac Deus: Prefiguring therfore, and • ransforming vs into himselfe, he sayth thus, Saue me O God &c. So he; who also vpon the psalme 21. sayth, that Christ hanging vpon the Crosse did keep personam veteris hominus; The person, or figure of the old man, That is to say, of our corrupt nature. And afterwards: Corpus suum (sayth he) gerebat, id est, Ecclesiam: He bare • is body, that is to say, the Church. Which was in effect as much as if he had said gerebat perso
• am Ecclesiae, he bare the person, or figure of
the Church. Finally to omit other places he sayth vpon the same psalme, that Christ did signify both the weake, and the strong in his Church. Ossa sua sirmos suos dicit; he calleth 〈◊〉 bones his strong-ones; Ventrem suum dicit infirmos i • Ecclesia sua; His belly he calleth the weake in his Church. Thus sayth S. Augustine. But whether our Sauiour signifyed the strong and weake as head of the Church, or for some other particuler respects, I shall haue occasion to declare after a whyle in my answere to M. Collins his third argument, num. 9.

7. In the meane tyme we see according to S. Augustine that not only S. Peter, but also our Sauiour himselfe represented and signifyed the whole Church, whereof he was head, as also the diuers members, and partes thereof, to wit the weake, and the strong. Will then M. Collins aske vs now of our Sauiour, as he doth of S. Peter, whether he could signify the Church, which he gouerned? And whether he was at one tyme Gouernour of the strong, and another tyme of the weake? and lastly then how he could be an Vniuersall gouernour of his Church? I hope he wilbe better aduised, & learne by this, that as our Sauior Christ was & is the Vniuersall Gouernor of his Church, though he represented the same, and signified also
the weake, and strong therin: so also S. Peter might be Vniuersal gouernor of the Church vnder Christ, & beare the person, or figure therof propter primatum (as S. Aug. saith) albeyt he figured sometims the weake & sometims the strong. Therfore I may well say to M. Collins of our Sauiour, as he sayd to me of S. Peter pag 16. I thinke you see cause to repent your construction, or argument, except you be weary of Christs vniuersall dominion.

8. But now let vs see him shoot his third bolt taken also out of S. Augustines quiuer, and I warrant you aswell, and as wisely shot as the two former; for wheras S. Augustine in his tract. 123. vpon the Ghospell of S. Iohn sayth thus; That all we, which are indued with this hope, may know that by the seauenfould number of the disciples, which were present at our Sauiours repast after his resurrection by which number our whole company may seeme heere to be figured) we are both partakers of that mystery, and fellowes in that blisse; M. Collins obserueth in these wordes of S. Augustine pag. 18. num. 13. First that figurari is there also vsed by him in the former sense; and then addeth that, As ere-while Peter figured the Church, so now those 7. disciples figured the Vniuersality of Gods people, that is, the Church, and yet I hope they are not made therby regents of the Church. So he. And then after an
impertinent, foolish and false digression agaynst the Iesuits (which I purposely omit, as not worth the setting downe, and much lesse worthy the answering) he concludeth thus pag. 19. The seauen figures heere are not seauen gouernours, no more then is. Peter figuring the Church, or bearing the figure of the Church, or what • oeuer els soundeth that way. So he; imagining belike, that we hold all figures of the Church to be gouernors of the Church; for otherwise he proueth nothing agaynst vs. And truly he might haue added examples, and instances inough of this kind, out of the Scripture • , & Fathers as out S. Austine vpon psalme 21 where he saith that the woman, who entred with the oyntment, when Christ was feasted in Symons house, portabat typum Ecclesiae, Did beare the type, or figure of the Church; yea, and that the lynnen-cloath that was let downe from heauen to S. Peter, with foure corners, was also a type, and figure of the Church: wherupon he may cōclude as wisely, as he hath done heere, that because, neyther the woman, nor the lynnen cloath were gouernours (though they were figures therof) therfore neyther S. Peter, no nor our Sauiour Christ himself was gouernour of the Church, albeyt they did both of them represent it, and consequently
were figures of it.

9. But he is to vnderstand that although all heades of Cittyes, or Commonwealthes do represent the same, yet all that represent them, are not heades therof; for • o euery Proxy, or Deputy in a Parlament for a Citty hould be gouernour of it: and as • ome senselesse thinge may in respect of • ome propriety, which it hath, be a figure of the Church; so may also a man in some one, or a few things figure and represent it, and yet be no gouernour of it. And there
• ore not only S. Peter, but also our Sauiour himselfe might some way figure, and represent the Church, not as heades therof, but for some particuler respectes, relation, or resemblance, which may be noted betwixt them, and the Church; as when our Sauiour, and S. Peter are sayd by S. Augustine to figure the strong, and the weake in the Church, they might be sayd so to doe, for some particuler actions of theirs, which might haue relation to the strong, or the weake; whereby neuerthelesse they were not excluded from bearing the person of the Church propter primatum, which S. Augustine acknowledgeth in S. Peter, and M. Collins. I am sure, will not deny of our Sauiour. Whereby he may perceaue how wisely
he hath argued, denying the supremacy of S. Peter, because the 7. disciples were not gouernours of the Church, albeyt they were figures of it, as well as S. Peter; which reasons make as much agaynst our Sauiours supremacy, as agaynst S. Peters. So as thou seest (good Reader) what a good archer this doughty Doctour is, seeing that of three boltes which he hath shot, the first fell cleane wyde from the marke, and the other two so farre ouer, that insteed of S. Peter, at whome he shot, he hath hit out Sauiour Christ, and wounded him deeply, depriuing him of his Primacy, and gouernement of the Church, if his argument be good agaynst S. Peter.

div.head: M. Collins his answere to a third place of S. Augustine is confuted, with the disco •• ry of his foolish, and false glosse vpon it, and his childish ignorance in impugning still our Sauiours Supremacy, no les • then S. Peters. CHAP. IIII.
div.p:
THERE remayneth yet to be discussed one of the 3. places alleadged by me out of S. Augustine tract. 124. to proue that S. Peter bare the person of the Church Propter primatum, In respect of his primacy. I • lleadged it thus; Cuius Ecclesiae Petrus Apostolus propter Apostolatus sui primatum figurata generalitae personam &c. Of which Church Peter in respect d the primacy of his Apostleship did beare the person figuring or representing the generality therof Fo if we respect what did belonge properly to himselfe, • e was by nature one man, by grace one
Christian, and by a more aboundant grace vnus idem{que} primus Apostolus: One and he the chiefe Apostle. But when it was sayd to him, Tibi dabo claues, I will giue thee the Keyes &c. he signified the whole Chur • h. Thus farre I alleadged S. Augustines wordes. Now M. Collins discourseth very amply vpon this place, making, as it were, three notes, or obseruations thereupon, which I will lay downe, and answere by the way, as they come to hand. Thus then he sayth pag. 20 num. 17. Come we now to the 124. tract. out of which he vrgeth this Roc agi • Ecclesia spe beata in hac vita aerumnosa, cuius Ecclesiae Petrus propter Apostolatus sui primatum gerebat figurata generalitate person • m; which the • asier to cleere we may sort out by parcells that whic • makes for them; first gerebat personam, which his m •• thinkes to be as much as tenebat regimen, his of that before. To omit how it is qualified with figirata generalitate, his bearing the person being but figuring, signifying, and representing still with S. A • gustine which is short of Magistracy. So he; singi • g, as you see, his old songe being nothing els but false descant vpon my playne song of geere personam, which is playne inough, if • e out of his peruerse, & malitious humour had not peruerted, and corrupted it, as you haue seene so sufficiently before, that this needeth no further answere.

2. He proceedeth thus pag. 21. Secondly (sayth he) propter Apostolatus sui primatum, whi h the better to conceiue, heare we further S. Augustine, heare you too good Syr, that accuse the Bishop o • laming places, as if no man were such a legall reciter of them as you selfe. Quod enim ad ipsum prop •• e pertinet (speaking of Peter) natura vnus homo erat, gratia vnus Christianus, abundantiore gratia vnus idemq́ue primus Apostolus. Sed &c that is, for as concerning himselfe Peter was by nature but one m • n, by grace one Christian mā, by a greater measure of the same grace one, and a prime Apostle. But &c. you w • ll say perhaps, that this is a third kind of aduantage, and authority more then euer you were aware of for Peter, Vnus idemq́ue primus Apostolus: But there is more in it then so. S. Augustine knowes but three steps of condition heere, in Peter: a man, which he was by nature, a Christian which by grace, but by height of grace, by excesse of grace, an Apostle; yet vnus Apostolus, but one Apostle, not virtua •• as you would haue it, the whole quire, or colledge of them. Our Sauiour was not so poore as to haue but one Apostle, sayes Irenaeus lib. 3. agaynst them that taught Paul was the only man. So farre off was Peter then, that scarse be was thought to be one of the number. Indeed twelue as I shewed you before, for great cause: but concerning Peter, vnus Apostolus (sayes S. Augustine) but one Apostle. As for the prime we • raunt you, as you haue
beene often tould, and (to content you the more) more then in one regard of primacy; An excellent sloure he was in that garland, what would you eis! Thus sayth M. Collins: wherin thou mayst note, good Reader, a great deale of impertinent stuffe.

3. For what can be more idle, yea & false then his note vpon Vnus Apostolus, wherein he seemeth to charge me, or rather all Catholikes to hold & teach that S. Peter was virtually the whole quire, or colledge of the Apostles; in such sort, as that he was the only Apostle, and that the rest were not Apostles as well as he, for els why sayth he, that indeed there was 12. and alleadgeth also out of Irenaeus, that Christ was not so poore as to haue but one Apostle, which (sayth M. Collins) Irenaeus sayd against those, that taught Paul was the only man. But did euer any Catholike hould that Peter was the only man, in that sense? that is to say, the only Apostle? or that there were not 12. Apostles? or that euery one of them was not as truly an Apostle as S. Peter? we hold indeed that he was the head of the Apostles, and of the whole Church, and that therefore he had virtually in himselfe the authority of them all (as the head hath virtually all the power, and authority conteyned in the body) and so we
also teach concerning the Bishops of Rome,
• uccessors to S. Peter, that being heads of the Church, and of all the Bishops therof, they haue virtually in themselues the authority, and power of them all; yet not so, but that euery Bishoppe lawfully created in the Church, is as truly a Bishop as the Bishop of Rome, or S. Peter himselfe was; how idle then, friuolous, and false is all this? Furthermore I beseeth thee, good reader, to note in like manner his sleight, or rather falsity, in translating primus Apostolus, to wit a prime Apostle, not the prime, or rather chiefe Apostle, as indeed it signifyeth; his desire being that his reader should conceiue that S. Augustines meaning was no other, but that S. Peter was a principall Apostle, that is, one of the principall, or chiefe Apostles, but not the principall, or chiefe of all, which S Augustine meant, when he sayd that S. Peter was vnus idem{que} primus Apostolus.

4. This may easily be gathered by the precedent wordes, to wit, propter Apostolatus sui primatum, For the primacy of his Apostleship, which he expresseth more plainly in the other place debated before de agone Christ. cap. 30. where he saith that S. Peter bare the persō of the Church propter primatum quem in discipul • habuit, For the primacy which he had amongst the
disciples; giuing plainly to vnderstand, that he had a primacy, or preheminency aboue the rest, which also M. Collins himselfe is forced to gra ••• in some sort, both before, as you haue heard, and now also, saying heere that 〈◊〉 , and his fellowes do graunt (as he hath often told vs that S. Peter was the prime more then in regard of one primacy, wh • ch neuerthelesse he minceth, and extenuateth in the n • x • wordes following, saying an excellent flower he was in that garland: and then asketh me, what wold you els • ? Mary▪ good M. Collins I would h • ue you speake out of the teeth, and confesse that he was the chief flower in that garland, and to english primus
• o that it may haue the cleare sense that S. Augustine doth meane, yea, and according to the dictionaryes both English, and Latine to translate it the chiefe, and not a prime, as you do, when fo •
Vnus idem{que} primus Apostolus, you giue vs in English, one and a prime Apostle, which prime is neyther an vsuall word in English, neyther yet with the article, (a) can signify the chiefe, but one of the chiefe: so as thou seest, good reader, how he hath iuggled, and iangled hitherto in the exposition, and translation of this place.

5. But now let vs heere how he proceedeth, That this primacy, sayth he, was distinct
from your supposed magistracy of maiesty Ecclesiasti
•• ll (as you would infere ou • of gerere personam)
•• are what followes. S. Augustine hauing recoun
•• d the th • ee former degrees of Peters condition, he •• o • eeds to a • ourth neyther coincident with the rest, •• r yet contayning any such principality, as you talke, 〈◊〉 me •• l • aff • arded him of our Sauiors free bounty in •• gard to his excellent worth amongst his fellows. Sed 〈…〉 dictum est, • ibidabo claues regnicaelorum, & quod •• {que} ligaueris super terram, erit ligatum & 〈◊〉 caelis & quodcum{que} solueris super terram, erit solu
• um & in caelis, vn • uersam significabat Ecclesiam, •• res S. Augustine, he stood for the Church; it was • ayd to him in the person of the Church, not as chiefe • agistrate, not as primus Apostolus, the first wheele in • he clocke, but in a sense distinct from the former 3.
• egrees therefore he sares sed quando • yet happily the • ather for his aforesayd worthynes, our Sauiour put his part vpon him, honoured him with the represen
• ation of the Church, made him to signify Ecclesiam • niuersam (S Augustins words) but only to signify • t, and that not as an Apostle, but in a fourth conside
• atiō which helps you nothing, rather spoiles you of al. Thus far M. Collins.

6. Where you see he proposeth vnto vs a fourth consideration as he calleth it (distinct from the 3. degrees before mentioned) why our Sauiour made S. Peter to signify his vniuersall Church; which consideratiō,
he sayes, helps vs nothing, but rather spoil •• vs of al, for so you see he concludeth, & dot • not tell vs clearly what this fourth consideration is, but only what it is not (at least i • his conceipt) to wit, that S. Peter did represent, or signify the Church, not as chief magistrate, not as primus Apostolus, yea not as 〈◊〉 Apostle, but in a fourth consideration; making S. Augustine clearly contradict himselfe who sayeth expresly, as you haue heard, eue • in this very place now in hand, that S. Pete •
bare the person of the Church for the prima • of his Apostleship. And agayne de agone Christia • c • p. 30. for the primacy which he had amongst t •• disciples. And lastly in his 13. serm de verb. Dom. that he b • re the figure of the Church, hauing th • principality of the Apostleship. Now then can any man declare his mind more plainly then S. Augustine doth, why S. Peter did signify, or represent the Church? to wit for his primacy, and because, he was the chiefe Apostle, or Prince of the Apostl • s? How then can M. Collins his glosse (not as primus Apostolus) stand with S. Augustines text & meaning?

7. But will you heare how he seekes somwhat to qualify the matter, or rather to cast a mist before his Readers eyes? he graunteth that this fourth consideratiō, wherof he speaketh heere, was affoarded to S. Peter
by our Sauiour in regard to his excellēt worth amongst his fellowes; and after agayne that our Sauiour honoured him with the representation of his Catholike Church, happily the rather for his aforesaid worthines; so as now the principality of the Apostleship, and primacy amongst the Apostles (which S. Augustine ascribeth to S. Peter) is reduced only to an excellēt worth amongst his fellowes, and yet that also with a perhaps, sa • ing, happily the rather for the foresayd worthinesse, so as perhaps it was no part of the consideration at all; do you see then to what passe he hath brought this matter at last by his glosse? Eyther excluding wholy S. Augustine his constant, & serious doctrine in this point, or els making him to cōtradict himselfe? and if he say that by this fourth consideration he excludeth only such a principality as we talke of (for so much he insinuateth at the first) as if he allowed S. Peter (as he doth elswhere) a principality, & primacy of place, he then contradicteth himselfe, seeing that he affirmeth heere expresly that S. Peter did not signify the Church, eyther as the chiefe Apostle, or yet as an Apostle, saying that Christ made S. Peter to signify the vniuersall Church, and then addeth, but only to signify it, and that not as an Apostle, but in a fourth consideration. So he: wherin you
see, he is so far frō including in this fourth consideration any respect of S. Peters primacy or place, amongst the Apostles, that he excludeth his very Apostleship, and all respect of his being an Apostle; thus doth the poore man wynde, turne, and intangle himselfe most absurdly, not knowing, as it seemeth, what he sayth; so as whiles he hopeth to turne S. Peter out of his primacy, he turneth him selfe out of his witts.

8. But perhaps he will say that if this 4. consideration should include his primacy, or any respect of his Apostleship, it would be coin • ident with the third degree mentioned by him before, to wit with Vnus, idem{que} primus Apostolus; One and the chiefe Apostle, which sayth M. Collins cannot stand with sed quando in S. Augustine, who thereby addeth a fourth consideration distinct from the former, and not coincident therto. But then why doth he not tell vs what this fourth consideration is, if it be so distinct from the former, as that it doth not any way include it? belike he remits it to the day of iudgement to be knowen, when all other secrets shal be reuealed as you haue heard him say before cap. 2. num. 2. But in the meane tyme to giue some satisfaction to the Reader in this point, he shall vnderstand, that this great doubt, and
difficulty that M. Collins maketh heere is sufficiently solued, and cleared by me before cap. 2. num. 4. & 5. when I answered his obiection of the comparison made by S. Augustine betwixt some things spoken by our Sauiour to S. Peter, and other thinges spoken in the Scripture of Iudas, which did properly belong to their owne persons, & yet had a further relation: as Tibi dabo claues, spoken to S. Peter, had a relation not only to him, but also to the Church; and other thinges sayd of Iudas in the 108. Psalme, were to be referred aswel to the wicked Iewes as to Iudas himselfe.

9. By the occasion of this I haue signifyed cap. 2. num. 7. & 8. that S. Peter did represent, and figure the Church in a very peculiar manner, not common to euery Gouernour, but as the first Gouernour therof, in whose person the Ecclesiasticall Monarchy (which was to ēdure to the worlds end) was erected, and instituted; in which respect those things which were sayd to him, expressing the power and authority giuen him (as Tibi dabo claues, Pasce oues meas, and the like) were spoken in regard aswel of the Church for euer, as of his owne person; for otherwise the sayd authority had dyed, & ended in him, and with him, & had not
descended to his successors, & to the whole Church for euer, as it did; and therefore S. Augustin in this place considereth the primacy of S. Peter, and his representation of the Church two wayes: the one as it was to be considered in his owne person, and for his owne tyme, abstracting from his successors, & future tymes. In which respect S. Augustin sayth he was primus Apostolus, that is to say, primate or head of the Apostles, and consequently head also of the Church, which Church he therfore represented not as the first Monarchy, or Gouernour thereof, but as euery King, or Prince representeth his whole commonwealth during his owne raygne, hauing al the Authority therof virtually in himselfe.

10. But now by the other way, or consideration of S. Peter his primacy, and representation of the Church (to wit as he was the first Gouernour thereof, in whose persō the Ecclesiastical Monarchy, or Kingdome was first erected) he represented all his successours, and the whole Church to the worlds end, and therfore of this manner of primacy, & representation of the Church S. Augustine speaketh in this place, when he sayth, that Tibi dabo claues, was sayd to S. Peter, as he signifyed the vniuersall Church,
because it was sayd to him, to declare the authority giuen not only to him, and the Church for his tyme, but also to his successors, & the whole church in al future times, and ages vntill the end of the world. And this M. Collins may take (if it please him) for a fourth consideration distinct from the other, which he mentioned; & acknowledg withall, that it doth not spoyle vs of all (as you heard him say in his conclusion) but rather confirme all our doctrine concerning this point.

11. But who would imagine that this Doctor had so little wit, as seeing himselfe so puzled, that he is forced to scamble, and wrangle (as you see) to shift off thes • places of S. Augustine with most false interpretations, and absurd glosses, would yet farther hazard, and venter as well his owne reputation, as the credit of his cause in vrging still agaynst vs the doctrine of S. Augustine in this place, albeyt he cannot but see (if he haue any wit) that it vtterly ouerthroweth him. But, qui semel verecundiae fines transierit, gnauiter impudentem esse oportet: He which hath once passed the bounds of modesty must be impudent in good earnest, & therfore this silly mā being already ouer the shooes, seeth now no other remedy but to
runne ouer the eares, and is not ashamed to prosecute the matter still, continuing the same for 7. or 8. pages, with such a deale of tittle tattle, as truly if I should alleadge his whole text, and answere euery thing particulerly, I should be too to tedious not only to my selfe, but also to my reader, and therefore I will only lay downe so much of his text, as shalbe to any purpose, and briefly touch the rest so farre as shalbe needfull.

12. First he obserueth pag. 22. num. 18. that S. Augustine teacheth, that Petrus à petra, sicut Christianus à Christo, and not è contra (sayth he) that our boast should not be in men, but in the liuing God. And who denyeth this? was there euer any man so mad to say, or thinke the contrary? But then he proceedeth. And yet in truth more plainly in this place, which may serue, if any thing to open their eyes that dare build vpon a mā, as the foundation of their Church, though it were Peter himselfe, that I say not how vnworthy creatures now in his Roome. Thus he; so as now you shal see he will open our eyes with a place of S. Augustin, which therfore he alleadgeth thus. Ideo quippe ait Dominus &c. For therfore sayth our Lord, Vpon this rocke I will build my Church, because Peter had sayd, thou art Christ the sonne of the liuing God; I will therfore build my Church, sayth he, vpon this rocke, which thou hast confessed. For the
rocke was Christ, vpon which foundation euen Peter himselfe was sayne to be built. For another foundati
• n can no man lay, besides that which is layed, which • s Iesus • hrist. So he out of S. Augustine.

13. But to what purpose? perhaps he meant to gul some very simple reader, in making him belieue that when we teach that the Church was built vpon S. Peter, we vnderstand that it was not built vpon Christ, or that Christ was built vpon Peter, & not Peter vpon Christ, which obiection is so triuiall and s • ale, and hath beene so oft answered • y Catholikes, that he may be ashamed still to obiect it, and to take no knowledge of the answere which is giuen out of S. Augustine himselfe; who albeit in the place before alleadged, and also elswhere, he doe vnderstand those words (super hanc petram) to be spoken by our Sauiour of his owne person, yet doth neuer deny, but teach expresly that the same may also be vnderstood of Peter (though not as the only and first foundation, which must needs be Christ) but as a secondary foundation built vpon Christ.

14. To this purpose it is to be noted, that hauing in his 13. Serm. de verb. Dom. expounded those wordes thus, Id est super meipsum filium Dei viui aedificabo Ecclesiam meam. That is to say, I will build my Church vpon my selfe
the sonne of the liuing God, he addeth presently, super me aedisicabo te, non me super te: I will build thee vpon me, and not me vpon thee. And in his first booke of retractations cap. 21. he acknowledgeth that place to receiue both the interpretations; I meane to be vnderstood literally aswell of Peter, as of Christ, yet not so of Peter, as to exclude Christ from being the chiefe and principall foundation, whereof neuer any Christian man, and much lesse any Catholike euer doubted.

15. Therfore S. Augustine hauing signified that he himselfe had interpreted the same both wayes, and that the one way (viz. to make Peter the rocke) was at that tyme so cōmon, that cātatur (saith he) ore multorum &c. it is song in the mouthes of many, in an hymne of the blessed Ambrose, he conc • udeth; harum duarum sententiarum quae sit probabilior eligat lector; of these two opinions (concerning the litterall interpretation of these words) let the reader choose whether he thinketh more probable. So he; being so farre from reiecting the interpretation of Peter to be the rocke, that he not only vsed the same himselfe, but also fortifyeth it heere, as you see, with the authority of S. Ambrose, and the publike approbation therof in those dayes, and finally remitteth it to the choice, and election of the reader
to follow the one, or the other; which he neuer wold haue done, if he had held either of them to be false; and albeit be held that the word Petra (in that place of the 16. chap. of S. Mathew) was to be referred principally, and immediatly to Christ, yet he doth no way contradict the other exposition, wherby the sayd word is referred secondarily to Peter, by which meanes both the interpretations do stand good.

16. But now let vs see how he proceedeth with S. Augustins text pag. 23. num. 18. Ecclesia (sayth he) quae fundatur in Christo &c. The Church which is founded in Christ, receiued of him the keyes of the Kingdome of heauen in Peter, that is, the power of bynding, and loosing sinns for that which properly the Church is in Christ, the very same by signification is Peter in the rocke: by which signification Christ is vnderstood to be the rocke, Peter to be the Church. This Church therfore which Peter signifyed &c. Thus farre M. Collins alleadgeth S. Augustins wordes. And then glosseth them thus. I say nothing (sayth he) of signification, whereof inough before, and euery lyne in S. Augustine is fraught with it. But is not this strange, that Peter, whome euery where they aduance for the head, S. Augustine should still take for the body? So he, wherin you see he still harpeth vpon his old stringe, vrging agaynst me S. Aug.
his vnderstanding of gerere personam Ecclesia •
As that it is only to signify, and represent the Church; wherof he saith also very truly that he hath sayd inough before, for so he hath indeed, yea and more then inough, & with shame inough, hauing so peruerted my sense and meaning, as you still see he doth.

17. But wheras he hath found out heere one of the 7. wonders, to wit that S. Augustine should take still S. Peter for the body, whom we aduance euery where for the • ead; I can tell him a farre greater wonder in S. Augustin, to wit that he takes Christ himselfe very often for the body, whome we all worthily acknowledge to be the head; to which purpose thou mayst remember, good Reader, what I haue alleaged before out of S. Augustine cap. 3. num. 6. to shew that S. Peter was not excluded from the Gouernment of the Church vnder Christ, because he represented, and signified the Church, seeing that the same argument if it were good agaynst S. Peter, would exclude our Sauiour also frō being head therof, who as S. Augustine sayth, non solum caput, sed corpus est; It is not only the head, but also the body. And that he exclaymed in his Passion, as if he suffered somwhat agaynst his will, quia caput membra sua praefigurat: Because
being bead he doth prefigure his members. And • a • tly, that Corpus suum gerebat, id est Ecclesiam; he •• are his body, that is to say, the Church. Which (as I signifyed before) was as much in e
• fect, as if he had said, gerebat personam Ecclesiae, he bare the person of the Church, which was his body.

18. And this being so the greatest wōder▪ that I see heere is, that so great a Doctor of • iuinity as M. Collins is, and so conuersant in S. Augustine should be so ignorant of his doctrine, as to make it a strange matter, that we should aduance S. Peter for the head, whome S. Augustine takes for the body, seeing that S. Augustine maketh not only him, but also our Sauiour himselfe to signify the Church, quia caput membra sua praefigurat, because the head doth prefigure his members; Et propter primatum (sayth Augustine of S. Peter) quem in discipulis habuit; In respect of the primacy, which be had amongst the disciples. So as I see no other cause of this wonder in M. Collins, but his notable ignorance, as little children, & fooles wonder at euery thing, by reason of their little knowledge & experience. There followeth in M. Collins a friuolous, and most idle digression about an argumēt, which he sayth some of ours make for the primacy of S. Peter, out of our Sauiour his wodes sequere
me, as it it were, follow me in the gouernement of the Church, which he sayth is a strange probleme of desperat pleaders. But he cyteth no author of ours, & sure I am he fyndeth no such argument in my Adioynder, and therefore I let his answere therto passe without answere, as not worth the labour to write it.

19. After this commeth his ample discourse, and commentary vpon S. Augustins comparison of S. Peter with S. Iohn, making them figures, the one of the temporall life, and the other of the eternal, of which cōparison, and M. Collins his foolish argument deduced from the same agaynst S. Peters supremacy, I haue largely treated before (in the 2. chap. num. 22. 23. &c.) by occasion of the like comparison made not only by S. Augustine betwixt Iudas and Peter; but also by Origen betwixt S. Peter and S. Iohn, which later is alleadged and vrged also by M. Collins himselfe cap. 5. pag. 203. And I haue already in this treatise cap. 2. num. 33. sufficiently discouered his impudent malice in concealing, and dissembling Origens cleare doctrine of S. Peters primacy in the same place, which he alleadgeth, and vrgeth agaynst it; besides that I haue also shewed there, that Origen doth in the same place expresly disclayme
from derogating in any sort from the supreme dignity of S. Peter, when he prefer
• eth S. Iohn (as a figure of the contemplatiue • i • e) before Peter (as a figure of the actiue life) whereby M. Collins might learne (as I signified there) that S. Augustine (who imitated Origen therin) might make also the like comparisō betwixt S. Peter and S. Iohn (as figures of the temporall, and eternall life) without any preiudice in the world to the primacy of S. Peter; so as I shall not need to trouble thee, good reader, with any further discourse concerning that comparison, but only to make some reflexion vpon his conclusion thereof pag. 29. num. 20. wherin he seemeth to preoccupate an obiection, which he supposeth I may make against him.

20. Agaynst this (sayth he) I know what M. F. • . will say (for he sayth no more then out of the mouth of his best Maysters) as Iohn really, so Peter really, as the one lay vpon our Sauiours brest, and it was no fiction, so the other receiued the keyes of the Kingdome of heauen, and it was more then a bare representation. VVho doubtes but S. Peter receiued the keyes, as well as Iohn leaned on Christs bosome? But Peter receiued the keyes in the person of the Church militant, because our Lord would honour vnity &c. And Iohn rested, and repasted himselfe on his sacred bosome, as a figure of the triumphant, to shadow
out vnto vs the estate of glory, and blessed immortality &c. So he: and a little after. In this (sayth he) stands the answere that both Peter receiued, & receiued for himselfe (for he had a part in the keyes as well as others we deny it not but
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , not
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
portionally, & particulerly, not wholy & intirely, sa • e only as he stood in the Churches roome to grace vnity, And this proues no vniuersall authority, as not Iohn in the triumphant, as not Iudas in the malignant, so neyther Pe • e •
in the militant; but so much may suffice to haue spoken thereof. Thus farre M. Collins.

21. In this his discourse I wish two thinges to be noted; the one, that he sayth Peter receyued the keyes in person of the Church militant, because our Lord would honour, and grace vnity, which, sayth he, proues no vniuersall authority. The absurdity whereof I haue shewed before cap. 2. nu. 14. & 15. by 3 reasons. The first, for that it is a simple, & an absurd manner of arguing to impugne, and contradict one truth by an other, as to deny that S. Peter representeth the Church for his primacy, because he doth it, to shew the vnity therof, seeing that both respects may, and do stand well togeather; and therefore are both of them taught by S. Augustine. The second reason was, that M •
Collins making S. Augustine exclude, and deny S. Peters primacy, because he represented the
vnity of the Church maketh him flatly cō
•• adict himselfe, seeing that he affirmeth • xpresly (as hath been oft declared) that whē 〈◊〉
Peter receiued the keyes, he represented the • hurch propter primatū & therfore not to ho
• our, & grace vnity only, as M. Coll. wil needs • aue S. Aug. to teach; so as if he will belieue • im in the one, he must belieue him in the • ther, or els make him ouerthrow the one • y the other, and contradict himselfe. The • hird reason was that the consideration of • he vnity of the Church represented by S. Peter is so farre from preiudicing his prima
• y, that it doth notably fortify, and proue • t, as I haue shewed amply in my Adioinder cap. 3. num. 1. 2. 3. 4. & 36. out of S. Cyprian, and S. Hierome, & haue also signifyed it heere before cap. 2. num. 17. & 18.

22. The other thing which I wish to be noted in M. Collins his Conclusion is, that he now alloweth to S. Peter a part in the keyes, aswell as to the other Apostles, graunting that he receyued them really for himselfe, aswell as for the whole Church, yet not so for himselfe, but that the other Apostles had their part therin, which no mā denyeth; but that which I note herein is that he doth manifestly contradict his own former assertions, hauing taxed vs before
pag 12 num. 8. for affirming, that what is g •
uen to Peter is giuen to the Church, & wh •• to the Church the same to Peter; wherupo • it followeth that he holdeth it for an erro • in vs to teach that the keyes which wer • giuen to the Church in Peter, were giuen also to Peter; and therfore he laboureth to confute this out of S. Augustine in the same place (though by a frandulent, and false construction of him) saying that according to hi • doctrine, Tibi dabo claues, can haue no pregnā • construction but of the Church: which fraude of his I haue discouered before cap 2. num. 3. And agayne a little after in the same page, & paragraph he saith, that we would haue the keyes so to be ingrossed by S. Peter, as if they had beē personally deliuered him, & in his own right; which he taxeth also as an error of ours controled by S. Austin; wheras neuerthelesse he affirmeth now, that the keyes were really giuen him; whereupon it followeth that they were giuen him personally, that is to say to his owne person, and for himselfe, & so he also confesseth heere.

23. Furthermore in another place pag. 9. lin. penul. I tell you (sayth he) that Peter representeth the Church no otherwise then a proxy doth him that he standes for to be admitted; wherby he signifyeth plainly that Peter receaued not in
any sort the keyes for himselfe, seeing that 〈◊〉
proxy receiueth nothing for himselfe, but • ll for him that he standeth for; and this deuise of a proxy pleaseth him so much that he vseth the same afterwards agayn, calling Peter the image or proxy of the Church pag. 34. nu. 22. and then addeth to iustify the same, for I feare not, sayth he, to vouch that name by him, which hath euery where so good grounds in S. Augustine as you haue heard. So he, meaning by those good grounds, which we haue heard, al that which he hath hitherto so much vrged out of S Augustine touching the representation of the Church in S. Peters persō, wherby he will haue S. Augustine to teach, that S. Peter receyued the keyes, no otherwise then as a proxy for the Church, and consequently that he receiued nothing for himselfe.

24. Neuerthelesse hauing now better be thought himselfe, he graunteth, that S. Peter receyued the keyes really for himselfe: whereupon I inferre that he receiued them otherwise then a proxy: besides that followeth also thereupon, that receiuing the keyes for himselfe, he receiued power, & authority, which is signifyed by the keyes: and seeing this power, and authority was giuen him (according to S. Augustine) as he represēted the Church propter primatum, for his
primacy, and that the sayd primacy was giu •• him no other wayes then by the keyes, an • the Commission of the pastor; it is euide •• that the primacy) which S. Augustine acknowledged in S. Peter) was a primacy o • power, and authority, and not of place, order, and excellency only; as M. Collins (following my Lord of Winchester) would haue it to be thought, the absurdity whereof I haue she • ed more at large before in the 2. cap. num. 15. So as this filly man hauing striuen, and struggled all this while, hath so intangled himselfe (as I may say) in the snares, and limetwigges of his own contradictions, absurdityes, and follies that he is forced in the end to graunt so much, that the primacy of S. Peter, which he most impugneth, doth necessarily follow therof.

div.head: A fourth place of S. AVGVSTINE is debated, which M. Collins chargeth the Adioynder to haue alleadged lamely, and fraudulently. The imputation of fraude is cleared. A false glosse of M. Collins vpon S. Cyprian is disproued. Fiue or six notable fooleryes of his detected; with his manifest corruption, and falsification of the sense, and text of the Adioynder. CHAP. V.
div.p:
2. The place is in S. Augustines Treatise de agone Christiano cap. 30. and I alleaged it in my Adioynder thus. Non enim sine causa inter omnes Apostolos &c. For not without cause doth Peter susteyn the person of the Church amongst al the Apostles. For to this Church the keyes of the Kingdome of heauen were giuen, when they were giuen to Peter, and when it was sayd to him, Dost thou loue me? feede my sheepe, it was sayd vnto all; and therfore the Catholike Church ought willingly to pardon her children, when they are corrected, and strengthned in piety, seeing we see, that to Peter himselfe bearing the person of the Church, pardon was graunted, both when
he had doubted vpon the sea &c. and when he had • hrice denied his Maister &c. Thus far I alleaged S. Austine, & then I obserued therin that the reaso why Pasce oues meas (which our Sauiour • poke to S. Peter) was sayd to all the Church (according to S. Augustine) was because S. Peter bare the person of the Church, which he did by reason of the supreme authority, that he had ouer the Church; and this I proued • atter by those three places of S. Aug. which haue hitherto been debated, betwixt M. Collins and me, by which places it is euident (as you haue seene) that S. Peter did beare the per • on of the Church propter primatum quem in disc • pulis habuit; for the primacy which he had amongst the Apostles. And therefore for as much as my Lord of VVinchester, alleadged out of this place only these words, Cùm Petro dicitur, ad omnes dicitur pasce oues meas: when it was sayd to Peter, it was sayd to all, feede my sheepe; (the true meaning whereof in S. Augustine was to be deduced out of the circumstances of the place, especially out of those wordes, that S. Peter did sustayne and beare the person of the Church, which my Lord of VVinchester dissembled) I therfore worthily charged his LP. with the lame quotaion of it.

3. Now let vs see what M. Collins findeth wanting in the forsayd place, as I alleadged
it, & with what reason he chargeth me with clipping the text to my aduantage. The place, as I haue layd it downe before endeth as you may see with 2. etcaetera's, signifying that for breuities sake I omitted to cite that which followed, being to no other purpose, thē that which I had already alleadged conteyning certayne errors, & faults of S. Peter, wherof I layd down 2. the one his doubting vpon the sea, & the other his three denials of our Sauiour, which two might suffice to make the sense of the place perfect; the rest which I left vncited eyther importing nothing to the matter in question, or making rather for vs then against vs. Now M. Coll. pag. 35. num. 23. to giue the more colour to his imputation of fraude in me, doth not only seriously lay downe those faultes of S. Peter, which I left vnmentioned, but also maketh ample commentaryes vpon them, stuffed with no lesse impertinent, & idle matter then you haue seene in the former.

4. The faultes alleadged by him, & omitted be me are three: the first his diswading our Sauiour frō death, for the which our Sauior called him Sathan, but of this he hath little, or nothing to say, but that Christ did giue it a heauy censure: the second is the
snipping off (as he tearmeth it) of Malchus his • are, with his sword, which he sayth; I
• urst not so much as once to mention, it maks so harsh 〈◊〉 sound; and why trow you? forsooth because • e hath found out a deuise to apply this to • he Popes sword, yea and telleth vs of some • hat he hath heard of, who thinke that for Peter to draw his sword at Malchus (because Malchus in Hebrew signifyeth a King) was eyther a presage, or iustificatiō of the Popes practises at this day. Thus sayth M. Collins; and giueth thereby a great blow to some indiuiduum vagum, of whom he hath heard this reported, for he nameth no man, eyther in his text, or his margent, as no doubt but he would haue done if he could. But why he shold say that I durst not so much as mentiō this, truly I see not, seeing that this ridiculous cōceit of his (if it should be any of ours) could make nothing agaynst vs, but ra her much for vs; & therfore I must leaue it to the reader to iudge of the depth of his conceit, which for my part I cannot penetrate. The 3. fault of S. Peter omitted by me, was his simulation at Antioch, for the which S. Paul reprehended him, which he sayth pag. 37 nu. 25. I thought good to leaue out, caelans peccata sicut Adam, eyther because it drawes so neere an errour in sayth, or at least for subiecting the Monarchy of the
whole world, to the open resistance, and reproofe of a • abortiue. So he.

5. Heere you see he alleadgeth two reasons, why I omitted this fault of S. Peters; the one because it drawes so neere to an errour in fayth; and the other because I feared to subiect therby S. Peter (whome we hold for the Monarch of the world) to S. Paul, a latter Apostle. As for the former he may be ashamed truly to draw it neere to an errour in fayth, which some of the Fathers do excuse from al errour, holding that this reprehension of S. Peter by S. Paul, touching his dissimulation with the Iewes in the obseruation of their Ceremoniall law, grew vpō an agreement betwixt them two; to the end that the Iewes seeing S. Peter receiue with patience a rebuke at S. Paules hands, and acknowledge an error, might the more easily be withdrawen from the superstitious obseruation of their law, to imbrace the Christian perfection, wherto they were so hard to be induced, that the Apostles were forced not only to permit them to abstayne from bloud, and strangled meates, but also to ordeyn, and commaund it to the Gentills in their first Councel, as appeareth in the Acts of the Apostles cap. 15.

6. For this cause, I say, diuers auncient
Fathers, namely S. Chrysostome, Theodoretus, Theophilactus, Oecumenius vpon the epistle to the Galathians, Cassianus col. 17. and S. Hierome in his 89. Epist. to S. Aug. (where he also citeth for the same opinion Origen, Didimus, Apollinar • s, Eusebius Emissenus, and Theodorus Heracleotes) do all of them teach that S. Peter, & S. Paul mad • a compact, and couenant betwixt themselues, that S. Peter should suffer himselfe to be reprehended in that mannner for the cause before specifyed: and albeyt S. Augustine and others were of opinion that S. Peter condescended more then he should haue done to the infirmity of the Iewes, and that therfore he was reprehensible, as S. Paul sayd of him Gal. 2. yet neyther he, nor any other Father thought, that eyther it was an errour in fayth, or yet that it drew neere vnto it, as M. Collins saith it did, against all reason, seeing it consisted only in his cōuersation with the Iewes, which was no matter of fayth, but an act lawfull in it self, though reprehensible in respect of some circumstances, to wit for the scandall that the Gentills might take thereby; so that the errour was not in fayth, but in prudence, (yea a materiall, and no formall errour, as the Schoolmen speake, & cōsequently voide of sinne) and yet, as I haue sayd, blame worthy
in respect of the inconuenience which might haue grown of it, if it had passed vncontroled.

7. But I would gladly know heere of M. Collins, what he should gayne by it, or we loose more then he, if he could proue it to be an error in fayth; for this being only a priuate error of S. Peters person, it could not preiudice the authority of our Popes publik decrees (which is the marke that M. Collins aymes at) for we hold not, that the Pope cānot erre in his priuate actions, & opinions as a priuate person, but that he cānot erre in the publike decrees, which he maketh, and proposeth to the whole Church. Besids that if S. Peter did, or could erre in fayth, we might doubt whether his epistles were Canonicall Scripture, or S. Markes Ghospell a true Ghospell, which S. Marke wrote by his relation, & instruction; wherupon it would also follow, that all the Apostles, & Euangelists might erre in faith, who had no greater warrant then S. Peter, neyther yet so great, seing that our Sauiour (as he signified himselfe Luc. 22.) prayed expresly for him that his fayth shold not fayle, which we do not read that he did so particulerly for any other of the Apostles; & therfore M. Collins must eyther graunt that S. Peter did not erre in faith,
but in fact only, & so proue nothing against our Popes; or if he say heerred, or could erre in faith, he shaketh the authority of all the new testament, no lesse then the authority of all the Popes decrees: so as you see how impertinently he bableth to proue some fraud in me, for the omission of this errour in S. Peter. And thus much to his first reason why I omitted it.

8. His second is, that I thought good to leaue it out, least I might therby subiect the Monarch of the world to the open resistance, and reprehension of an abortiue, that it to say, least I might subiect S. Peter to S. Paul who was a later Apostle, and according to our doctrine inferiour and subiect to S. Peter: but in this M. Collins must needs speak agaynst his owne knowledge, and conscience, see ng that he saw afterwards in my Adioynder, that I was so farre from fearing any preiudice to S. Peters primacy by this his error, and by S. Pauls reprehension therof, that I held, and proued it to be confirmed, and fortifyed therby, according to the collection and inference that the auncient Fathers made therof, namely S. Cyprian, and S. Augustine, whose places I vrged, & cited to that purpose; and M. Collins answered them so miserably, that he could not but see the
force thereof, and know in his owne conscience that they made wholy for vs; and therfore to the end that thou mayst see, good Reader, his sleight, and insufficient answere therto, and consequently the little reason he hath to charge me with fraudulent dealing for hauing omitted this fault or S. Peter, I will lay downe what I sayd in my Adioynder, togeather with his answere, and make thee iudge of both.

9. The occasiō which I had to treate of this point there, was, that my Lord of VVinchester cap. 8. pag. 218. charged Card. Bellarmine with fraud, because he alledged certayne wordes of S. Cyprian ep. ad Quintum, to proue that our Sauiour foūded the church vpon S. Peter, & omitted that which followed. The words alledged by the Cardinal were these. Petrus quem Dominus primum elegit, & super quem fundauit Ecclesiam; and that which my Lord of VVinchester accuseth him to haue fraudulently concealed is that which followeth in the same place, & concerneth S. Paules reprehension of S. Peter, wherin S. Cyprian signified, that S. Peter did not challenge any thing insolently to himselfe, nor take vpon him arrogantly to say, that he had the primacy, or that he ought to be obeyed by thē that were yonger, and later then he. Vpon
which words of S. Cyprian my Lord of VVinchester inferred that the mynd, and sense of S. Cyprian seemed to be, that it Peter had said, that he had the primacy, he had insolently challenged somewhat to himselfe, and that therefore the Cardinall suppressed that part of the text &c. Wherin his L • . giueth the reader to vnderstand, that S. Cyprian doth therby affirme that S. Peter had not any primacy, or preheminency, and that therfore he should haue shewed himselfe very insolent, and arrogant if he had challenged any such thing to himselfe.

10. For the confutation wherof I produced a place of S. Augustin alleadged also by the Cardinall in his Controuersies, to proue that S. Cyprian acknowledged therin S. Peters Primacy; for that S. Augustine hauing layd downe those very wordes of S. Cyprian lib. 2. de Baptis. cap 1. sayth thus: Ecce vbi commemorat Cyprianus &c. Behold how Cyprian doth shew that Peter the Apostle (in whome the primacy of the Apostles is preeminent, with such an excellent grace) was corrected by Paul a later Apostle, when he dealt concerning circumcision otherwise then truth required &c. So sayth S. Augustine, wherby it euidently appeareth how he vnderstandeth S. Cyprian, to wit, that albeit Peter was preeminent, and farre excelled the Apostles
by reason of his primacy, yet whē he erred, he patiently suffered himselfe to be corrected by S Paul, and did not insolently & arrogantly defend his errour, standing vpon the authority of his primacy, and challenging obedience of S. Paul, and others. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder, with more concerning this matter, whic • I shall haue occasion to lay downe also after a while: but by this it is euident inough that M. Collins seeing this in my Adioynder could not with reasō charge me to haue dissēbled this errour of S. Peter traudulently, as making much against the primacy of S. Peter, when he knew that not only Card. Bellarmine, but also I myselfe had made vse of it, & vrged it for confirmation of S. Peters primacy, according to the sense, and m • nde of these 2. ancient Fathers.

11. But now M. Collins will say perhaps, that in his 3. chap. he hath answered this amongst other thinges. Let vs then see what he sayth; first, he vndertaketh cap. 3. num. 3. pag. 131. to answere our obiection out of this place of S. Cyprian, & saith thus. Now in the Epistle ad Quintum what fynd we? Petrus quem primùm Dominus elegit, & super quem aedificauit Ecclesiam suam. As if one of these did not expound another; for our Sauiour is sayd to haue built his Church vpon Peter, in that he chose him first, not
chose him to be first, primùm eligit, non elegit in primatem, as preuenting him with the promise, and honouring him with the exhibition of the keyes before the rest &c. Thus sayth M. Collins, who you see will needes haue primum, in S. Cyprian, to signify first chosen, and not chosen to be the first, or c • iefe; which exposition of his S. Augustine doth euidently controle, expounding (as you haue heard) primum, in S. Cyprian, by a preeminent primacy of the Apostleship, in which respect M. Collins, when he commeth afterwards pag. 133. to say somewhat to S. Augustine his place, is faygne to charge him with some defect of memory, saying thus. S. Aug. albeit he alter the words of S. Cypriā (as is soone done in allegations of memory) yet he keeps the sense, and sauours you nothing; the primatus Apostolorum excellenti gratia praeeminens, standing in dignity, and quality (let the word gratia help to perswade you) not in authority. So he.

12. In these few lines of his 3. or 4. egregious fooleries may be noted. The first, that he would perswade his reader, that S. Augustine so much trusted to his memory in the allegation of S. Cyprian, that eyther he had not his epistle, or at least did not looke vpon it, when he alleadged it, and thereby altered the words therof for lacke of memory; wheras it cannot be thought with any
reason that S. Augustine writing then against the Donatists (who relied vpon the authority of S. Cyprian) and alleadging so much out of him as he did (both in the place which is now in question, and also afterwards) was not very wary, and careful both to haue the epistle it selfe, and also to consider it well, hauing to deale with such subtile and captious Aduersaryes as he had; and therefore this is but a simple, and very absurd shift, worthy of M. Collins, shewing rather great want of wit in himselfe then any defect of memory of S. Augustine.

13. The second foolery is, that he saith, that albeit S. Augustine do alter the wordes, yet he doth not alter the sense of S. Cyprian, wherin he sayth very truly & condemneth himselfe vtterly. For the sense of S. Augustins words are most clearely to be vnderstood of S. Peters preeminent primacy: wherupon it followeth by M. Collins his owne confession, that the sense of S. Cyprians wordes is the same, though S. Augustine for lacke of memory perhaps altered them. Where then is M. Collins his construction of primùm in S. Cyprian, as if he meant that S. Peter was first chose, & not chosen to be the first or chiefe? Primū elegit (sayth M. Collins) and not elegit in primatem; wheras S. Augustine reteyning S. Cyprians
sense (as M. Collins confesseth) acknowledgeth a preeminent primacy in S. Peter. Do you see •• nē how this seely man contradicteth him
• elfe, and ouerthroweth his owne exposition?

14. The third foolery is, that he saith S Augustine fauoureth vs nothing, by acknowledging the primacy of S. Peter, because the sayd primacy standeth in dignity • nd quality, and not in authority. But this deuise of his, I haue answered sufficiently before cap. 4. num. 24. and more amply cap. 2. num. 15. & 16. where I haue proued out of • he ancient Fathers, that the Pastorall commission, and power of the keyes giuen to S. Peter by our Sauiour for himselfe, and the Church, did consist in authority of gouernement, and not in a bare preeminence of • lace, order, or excellency, which also may • e confirmed, euen by this place of S. Cypri
• n now in question, seeing that he acknow
• edgeth therein, that our Lord built his Church vpon S. Peter, saying Matt. 16. super •• uem aedificauit Ecclesiam suam; for albeit M. Col
•• ns saith that our Sauiour is said in S. Cyprian to • aue built his Church vpon S. Peter, because he chose • im first, and that S. Cyprian doth therby ex
• ound his precedent wordes, quem Dominus •• imum eligit; yet he hath not any other reason
for the same, but that it is his pleasure 〈◊〉 to say; whereas the analogy, and proportion which is betwixt the foundation in a building, and the head in a commonwealth or community, doth cleerly shew, that our Sauiour made S. Peter head of his Church, in building the same vpon him, besides that S. Cyprian in saying that our Sauiour buil • his Church vpon S. Peter, had relation, n • doubt, to our Sauiours promise made to S. Peter, when he sayd Mat. 16. super hanc Petr •• aedificabo Ecclesiam meam, vpon this rock I wi •• build my c • urch, which promise was mad • long after his vocation, or election to the Apostleship, and therefore signifyed some future thing to be performed afterwards, an • not the vocation which was already past▪ for no man promiseth a thing past, especially that which cannot be reiterated, or recouered; whereby M. Collins his childish folly i • most euident in affirming that our Sauiou •
is sayd to haue built his church vpon S. Peter, becau •• he chose him first, seeing that his election w •• (as I haue sayd) before that the building o • the Church vpon him was so much as promised him.

15. The fourth foolery is, that he sait • the word Gratia, may help to perswade me, that the primacy of S. Peter was not a Primacy
of authority, but of dignity: but truly I shalbe very hardly so perswaded, except he cā perswade me first, that the same word in the title of the Kings maiesty, and of other Christian Kings (who are sayd to be Kings by the grace of God) do depriue thē of all their authority, and leaue them only a title of dignity; for I cannot conceiue that the wo • d Grace, hath any more force, or other sense in the one then in the other, signifying in both a particuler fauour of Allmighty God, proceeding of his meere bounty, and goodnes, being called gratia, quia gratis data, because it is giuen freely without our merit, or desert: which grace, and fauour in this case is so much the greater, by how much the spirituall dignity and soueraignty of S. Peter excelleth the temporall dignity, or soueraignty of any temporall Prince. And therfore S. Augustine sayth in this place, that the primacy of S. Peter was preeminent by an excellent grace; as also we haue seene before cap. 4. num. 1. that he sayd in like manner that S. Peter was by nature one man, by grace one Christian, and abundantiori gratia vnus, idemq́ue primus Apostolus, by a more aboundant grace, or fauour of God, one & he the chiefe Apostle. So as M. Collins his note of the word Grace, in this place serueth him to no purpose,
except it be to put the reader in mind to pray to God to send him more grace, and wit, hauing great want of both, as you haue seene sufficiently already, and shal see more abundantly hereafter; yea presently in two other notable fooleries of his, ioyned with falsity, and fraud, in that which followeth concerning this matter.

16. In his fourth §. of the same chap. pag. 133. he sayth that I quote out of S. Augustine, that Peter did otherwise then truth required, yea and in so great a point as Circumcision was; and that afterwards also I say more plainly num. 14. that he erred. Wherupon he sayth to me thus. VVould you euer write thus if you were in your wits, striuing for Peters primacy to impute errour to him, and errour in fayth, which you know cannot be without the grand perill of the vniuersall Church? So he. But would he write thus if he had eyther wit, grace, or his senses? for where fyndeth he in my Adioynder that I impute error of fayth to S. Peter? seeing that those words which he himselfe alleadgeth, as quoted by me out of S. Augustin (to wit that Peter did otherwise cōcerning Circumcision then truth required) do manifestly shew that the errour which I acknowledge in S. Peter was only an errour in fact, and not in fayth, Vitium, as Tertullian sayth, conuersationis, non doctrinae: A
fault of conuersation, and not of doctrine, lib. de praescrip cap 23. Which therfore I call afterwards num. 16. pag. 109. an erroneous act, saying, That if Peter should haue stood vpon his primacy, in defense of his erroneous act, he should haue done insolently. With what conscience then can this man say that I charge S. Peter with an error in faith? Or how can he be thought to be in his right witts, who be lyeth me so grossely, that the very wordes which he himselfe cyteth out of me, may suffice to conuince him.

17. Yet much more fraudulēt is the other foolery which followeth presētly after n. 5. pa. 134. where he sayth thus. I might likwise ask you what manner of primacy you call that, which excuseth not the superiour from the lawfull rebuke of the inferiour; but so as if Peter should haue refused to follow, and to obey Paul (they are your owne wordes num. 16) he should haue done insolently. Call you that a primacy (specially a Popish one) which must be patient of controule, lyable to the obedience euen of his vnderling, if it will auoyd pride? Thus sayth M. Coll. relying, as he sayth, vpon my owne words; or rather belying both me and my words, as it will euidently appeare by that, which I say in that place of my Adioynder, which he quoteth, to wit, cap. 3. num. 16. where I note a great difference to be obserued, betwixt
insolenter, & falsò, insolently, and falsely; for a man may (sa • d I) take vpon him a true authority, and speake of it insolently (that is to say, without iust cause, or in defence of some euill act, and yet not falsely, because it is true that he hath the authority that he pretendeth. And therfore I say, that if S. Peter should haue stood vpon his primacy in defense of his erroneous act, and sayd that Paul ought to obey him therin, because he was the primate, and head of the Apostles, he had both sayd and done insolently, which neuerthelesse in the defense of a truth, or vpon some other iust occasion he might both say and do without al note of insolency, yea iustly, and necessarily, because he had indeed the primacy, and therefore was to be obeyed, and followed in all good, and iust actions. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder.

18. Wherby 2. notable frauds may be discouered in M. Coll. the one that he dissembleth in his answere this discourse of myne, as if it were nothing to the purpose, for the explicatiō of S. Cyprians words now in question, which I leaue to the iudgement of the indifferent reader. The other fraud is a flat corruption, and falsification of my text, which he layeth downe in a different letter thus: If S. Peter should haue refused to follow, and to obey S. Paul, he should haue done insolently; and these wordes he sayth plainly are myne; wheras my wordes are these: If S. Peter should
haue stood vpon his primacy in defence of his erroneous act, and sayd that Paul ought to follow, and obey him therin because he was the primate, and head of the Apostles, he should both haue sayd, and done insolently. So I; wherin thou mayst note, good Reader, a notable difference: for I doe not say, that Peter should haue done insolently, if he had refused to obey Paul (for thereby I should haue acknowledged a superiority in S. Paul by the word, obey, which alwayes presupposeth a duty, and subiection) but I say, that Peter should haue done insolently, if he had sayd that Paul ought to obey him, because he was primate of the Apostles.

19. Therfore I doubt not, good Reader, but thou seest the difference, and how notably he hath corrupted, and falsified my text, to ground thereupon his foolish demaund, to wit, Whether I call that a primacy, which must be patient of controule, lyable to the obedience euen of his Vnderling, if it will auoid pride? To which wise question, grounded vpon his owne corruption of my text, I shall need to say no more, hauing discouered the weaknes, and falsity of his ground; only I will add, that no primacy can exempt any man from the fraternall correction, and admonition of his inferiour, when the same is giuen necessarily,
and with due circumstances: neyther is the same primacy preiudiced therby; for albeit the Superiour do follow the aduise of his subiect in such case, yet he cannot be sayd properly to obey him therin, for that obedience, supposeth (as I haue sayd) superiority, and authority to commaund, which the subiect hath no • ouer the Superiour, though he may admonish, counsell, and aduise him with more or lesse liberty, according to the quality, and importance of the cause. In which respect S. Cyprian acknowledging, not only the reprehension giuen to S. Peter by S. Paul, but also S. Peters primacy, commendeth S. Peter that he did not alleadge his primacy to defend his erroneous act.

20. And S. Augustine debating this matter with S. Hierome ep. 19. commendeth thē both: S. Paul for his liberty, and freedom, & S. Peter for his humility; and albeit he hould that S. Peter was reprehensible, yet he sayth he left a more rare, and holy example to posterity (not to disdaine a reprehension of their errors from their puisnes) then Saint Paul did by his act, quo confidenter auderent, sayth he, etiam minores maioribus pro defendenda Euangelica veritate, salua fraterna charitate resistere: Wherby the inferiors might be moued to
resist their Superiours, though it were euen for defence of the Ghospell, and without breach o • brotherly charity. Wherby S. Aug. acknowledgeth that S. Paul was Minor, & S. Peter Maior, which he must needes be vnderstood to haue sayd in respect of that primacy, which you haue heard him say before, was preeminent in S. Peter, tam excellenti gratia, with such an excellent grace and fauour of almighty God. And therfore Saint Gregory in Ezechiel lib. 2. cap 18. commendeth greatly the humility of S. Peter, for that being primus in Apostolatus culmine, the chiefe in the height of the Apostolicall dignity, se minori fratri ad consensum dedit, he was content to yeald to his yonger, or inferiour brother; yea and so notorious was this primacy of S. Peter to the very Paymins that Porphirius the Philosopher did blasphemously taxe S. Paul with procacity or sausines, quòd Apostolorum principem ausus est reprehendere, that he durst be so bould to reprehend Peter the prince of the Apostles, as S Hierome testifyeth epist. 89. And to conclude this point, this is most euident, euen in that place of S. Cyprian, which is now in question, and was vrged by my Lord of VVinchester agaynst Cardinall Bellarmine, as lamely quoted by him.

21. For wheras my Lord inferred
vpon S. Cyprians words, that if S. Peter had sayd, he had the primacy, he had insolently challenged something to himselfe (that is to say more then was due vnto him) & that therefore the Cardinall suppressed warily that part of the text (because it made little for the primacy) the contrary may be cleerly inferred thereon, if the wordes of Saint Cyprian be well noted, who sayth that Saint Peter, when he was reprehended by Saint Paul, did not arrogantly say that he had the primacy, or that he ought to be obeyed by those that were later Apostles then he; wherin two preheminences are noted in S. Peter, the one that he was primate of the Apostles; and the other that he was the elder Apostle; of which two my Lord of VVinchester, and M. Collins will not deny (I am sure) the later to haue been truly in S. Peter (to wit he was the elder Apostle) how then can they deny that he had the • ther as truly, seeing S. Cyprian speaketh of them both a lik • , as who would say, that albeit S. Peter was both Primate of the Apostles, and called to the Apostleship long before S. Paul, yet he would not in defence of his errour insolently challenge Obedience of S. Paul in respect of the one, or of the other.

22. Therfore wheras my Lord of VVinchester groundeth his argument agaynst the primacy vpon the words insolently, and arrogantly (as if S. Cyprian should meane that S. Peter should haue done insolently to challenge a primacy, because he had none,) I would gladly know why S. Cyprian should make mention of S. Peters Primacy, aswell as of his • ldership, if he had not the one, aswell as the other; to which purpose it is to be obserued, that as the words insolently, and arrogantly do not derogate any thing from the truth, and realty of his Eldership, no more can they derogate from the truth, and realty of h • s primacy, according to the meaning of S. Cyprian, who as I haue sayd, speaking of bot • these tytles, and preheminences alike, only signifyeth, that it had been insolency, or a • rogancy in him to haue stood vpon thē in defence of his errour, or to haue exacted obedience of S. Paul in regard therof, albeit he might in a iust cause haue challenged them, without any note of insolency, or arrogancy, as I haue signifyed before.

23. This then being the cleare sense, and meaning of S. Cyprian, it is euident; first, that this place of S. Cyprian (togeather with the exposition of S. Augustin which you haue heard before) doth notably confirme the
primacy of S. Peter; secondly, that my Lord of VVinchester taxed the Cardinall with the lame quotation of it, without iust cause, seeing it made much for the Cardinall and agaynst my Lord of VVinchester; thirdly, that S. Pauls reprehension of S. Peter did nothing preiudice the primacy of S. Peter; which primacy you see is acknowledged by these two Fathers, euen whiles they treate of his errour, & of S. Pauls reprehension thereof; fourthly, that M. Collins had no reason in the world to charge me with the fraudulent cōcealing of this errour of S. Peter; seeing that he saw in my Adioynder, that I made vse of it there to confirme S. Peters primacy in such sort, that he had beene forced in the answere therof to dissemble, wrest, falsify and corrupt my text, besides diuers notable fooleryes, which he hath committed by the way, as I haue sufficiently shewed; so hard, or rather impossible it is to mayntayne one errour, without committing many. What then hath the silly fellow gayned by the ample & large quotation of S. Austin, wherin he glorieth oft, & triūpheth exceedingly, although it hath serued him (as you see) to no other purpose then to discouer his folly, & the weakenesse of his cause?

24. Neuerthelesse the poore man knoweth
not, when to make an end of his bab
• ing, but wil needes go on stil with S. Aug.
• is discourse, and his Comment thereon, wherein if I would follow him, & examine • he weight, and worth of his glosse, & his • rguments, as hitherto I haue done, I should • yre thee, good Reader, no lesse then my selfe with his absurdityes & malicious abuse, as well of S. Augustine and other auncient Fa
• hers, as of the Iesuits, agaynst whome he • pitteth euery where his venime, and spite • boundantly, belying them, and their doctrine without all respect of conscience, or • hame; wherof I may perhapps haue some better oportunity to speake hereafter, and • herfore hauing now for the present answered as much as he hath sayd of importance, to the places which I alleadged out of S. Augustine, I will passe to another place cyted al
• o by m • Lord of VVinchester out of S. Ambrose, to the same purpose; which shalbe debated in the next Chapter.

div.head: M. Collins his answere to 2. places, the one of S Ambrose, and the other of S. Leo, is proued to be exceeding fraudulent: and by the way many fooleries, and ridiculous absurdityes are discouered therin. Finally M. Casaubon (to whome M. Collins remitteth his Aduersary) is found to be very defectiue, and absurd; iniurious to Car • inall Bellarmine, and opposite to M. Collins. CHAP. VI.
div.p:
WE haue seene how wel M. Collins hath behaued himselfe in answere of those places, which I alleadged out of S. Aug. concerning the cōmission of chiefe pastour giuen by our Sauiour to S. Peter, when he said vnto him pasce oues meas; and, that there hath passed nothing hitherto,
wherin he hath not committed some notable fraude, or folly. Now there remayne yet to be debated touching the same point, 2. places of S. Ambrose, the one alleadged by my Lord of Winchester (which I charged his Lord P. to haue alleadged corruptly) and the other quoted by me to iustify my exposition of the former. And I must needs say that M. Collins hath had much better lucke in the former, then in the later; for I do very willingly acknowledge that he hath fully cleared his LP. of the imputation of corruption, wherwith I charged him, seeing he hath produced diuers printes, which haue the place, as my Lord alleaged it, of which printes if I had found but any one, when I wrote my Adioynder, I would not haue charged his LP. as I did, following certayne copies, which I had then agreeing with my allegation, as M. Collins himselfe confesseth pag. 45.

2. Neuertheles I would not haue thee, good reader, to thinke that the place, as his LP. hath it, doth proue his intention, or make any thing against vs, or yet that it needeth any other answere then that which I gaue him in my Adioynder; where the question being, whether S. Peter was supreme pastour of the whole Church, my
Lord of Winchester produced 2. places for the negatiue, the one out of S. Austine de agone Christiano (which you haue heard allready debated) and the other out of S. Ambrose de dignit. Sacerd. cap. 2 in these words. Eas oues non solum beatus suscepit Petrus, sed & nobiscum eas suscepit, & nos cum illo accepimus omnes, that is to say: Those sheepe not onely the blessed Peter receiued, but allso he receiued them with vs and we al receiued them with him: wherupon my Lord of VVinchester saith in his answere to Cardinall Bellarmines Apology pag. 16. nempe dictum est illi. Pasce &c. for it was sayd to him, feede as well in the person of others, as in his owne. Wherby my Lord giueth to vnderstand that S. Peter had not (according S. Ambrose) any more authority, or power, giuen him by our Sauiour (when he said vnto him pasce oues meas) then the rest of the Apostles had, or then all other Pastours in the Church haue, seeing they all receiued their pastorall authority in him, and with him.

3. To this I answered first pag. 6. num. 6. that my Lord had corrupted the text of S Ambrose, adding th • se words therto: Et nobiscum eas suscepit, and he receiued the same sheepe with vs: which words were not in the copies which I followed; of which imputation I do now acknowledge his L P. to be
cleare. Secondly I answered pag. 7. num. 7. that the doctrine of S. Ambrose is very conforme to S. Augustins in that point, signifying nothing els, but that all the pastors of Gods Church receiued theyr pastorall authority ouer their flockes with S. Peter, because he being the head of the church represented the person of the whole church, and therfore did not receiue that pastorall authority for himself alone, but also for the church, and all the pastors thereof.

4. And to proue that S. Ambrose had no other meaning, but this, and no intent at all to deny therby the supreme authority of S. Peter, or the different degrees of Pastorall authority in the Church, I produced an euident place out of S. Ambrose in the 10. book of his cōmentary vpon S. Luks Ghospell cap. 24. where hauing said that our Sauiour asked Peter thrice, whether he loued him (not to learne, sayth he, any thing of him, but to teach him, whome he meant to leaue vs, veluti amoris sui vicarium, as the vicar of his loue) he alleadgeth our Sauiours wordes to S. Peter, Simon the sonne of Iohn doest thou loue me &c. pasce agnos meos: Feede my Lambes. And then shortly after he inferreth therupon thus. Et ideo quia solus profitetur ex omnibus, omnibus antefertur. And therfore because he alone of all the rest professed his
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
loue, he is preferred before them all. And after a while he concludeth, that our Lord asked him the third tyme whether he loued him: Et iam, sayth he, non agnos vt primò q • odam lacte pascendos &c. and now Peter is commaunded not to feede Lambes with a certayne milke, as the first tyme, nor to feede the little sheepe, as the second tyme; sed oues pascere tubetur, perfectiores vt perfectior gubernaret; he is commaunded to seede the sheepe, that he being more perfect might gouerne the more perfect.

5. Thus farre I alleadged S. Ambrose in my Adioynder, to explicate, and answere the place alleadged my L. of VVinchester out of him, & I doubt not but it is euident by S. Ambrose his owne exposition of the words pasce oues meas, that when he sayd that all Pastours receyued Christs sheepe togeather with S. Peter, he had no meaning to impugne, or deny therby S. Peters primacy (which you see he expresly affirmeth, and teacheth heer) but rather to confirme it according to S. Augustines doctrine, and explication; who vsing the same manner of speach that Saint Ambrose doth, as you haue heard, doth also yield the reason thereof, to wit, that for as much as S. Peter represēted the Church propter primatum quem in discipulis habuit, for the primacy which he had amongst the disciples, therfore the Apostles, and all other Pastours
