receiued their pastorall authority in him, and with him.

6. But now M. Collins taketh hold of my owne words, and vrgeth them against me, because I said pag. 7. num. 7. that the words of S. Ambrose, to wit, nobiscum eas suscepit (which I haue charged my Lord of VVinchester, to haue added to the text) do inforce a greater equality betwixt S. Peter, and other pastors, then euer S. Ambrose did imagine; but my meaning was, that to the ignorant reader it would seeme so, & therfore I said afterwards pag. 9. lin. 13. that these words make a greater shew of parity, or equality. But if they be well considered, the sense is all one, be the words either as he, or I alleadged them; for as I had them, they signify, that we receaued the sheepe with Peter; and as his LP. alleadged them, they signify that S. Peter receiued thē with vs, and wee with him, which is in effect all one; for if we receiued them with him, then he receiued them with vs; and if he with vs, then wee with him: and this, as I haue said, is true in respect of his primacy, wherby he represented al the pastors of the church to the worlds end, as I haue signified amply before cap. 2. num. 7. by the similitud of a first Monarch, or king, of whom it may
truely be said, that all his successors, & the magistrates subordinate to him, and them, receiued their authority with him, and he with them. Thus much concerning the place alleadged by my Lord of VVinchester.

7. Let vs now see what M. Collins sayth to the place of S. Ambrose which I produced to interprete the other, in which place S. Peters supreme pastorall dignity is clearly acknowledged, and taught by that ancient, and learned Father. The place is laid downe by me a litle before as I alleadged it in my Adioynder pag. 7. num. 8. where I also added num. 9. three thinges to be noted therein. First that he called S. Peter, Vicarium amoris Christi, the Vicar or substitute of Christes loue. The second that he said of him, quia solus ex omnibus profitetur, omnibus antefertur. The third, that by the distinction which he made of lambes, litle sheepe, & sheepe (recommended to the pastorall care of S. Peter) he giueth to vnderstand that al sortes of Christians (euen the most holy, learned, and perfect, yea the Apostles themselues) were committed to his charge, and gouernement, and that therfore S. Ambrose concluded thus, oues pascere iubetur, perfectiores vt perfectior gubernaret.

8. Thus said I in effect, but somwhat more amply in my Adioynder pag. 8. num 9. where you see plainly, that S. Ambrose doth in his conclusion expound pascere by gubernare, which I desire thee good Reader, to note, that thou mayst the better discouer M. Collins his notable coggery, who vndertaking to answere to this place, euen by piece-meale (as I may say) sayth somwhat to the rest, but dissembleth that conclusion: and to the end he may the better do it, he doth not lay downe the whole place, neither yet my text, but toucheth only some such partes therof, as he supposeth he may best shift off, with some colourable answere. First he layeth hold vpon the words, Quia s • lus profitetur, omnibus antefertur, saying pag. 48. anteferri is one thing, praeponi another; the later may be of authority, the first of any excellency; so so as he will not graunt that S. Ambrose acknowledged any authority in S. Peter more then in others by the word anteferri, but only a kind of excellency, which he sayth a few lines before pag 47. lin. antepenult. is that primatus praestantiae, by the which my L. of VVinchester foyled my friuolous obiection euen before it was batched. And he asketh me by the way, whether he doth not seeme to me too grammaticall? Wherto I answere that truly
I thinke he hath more Grammer, then wit to vse it well, and yet no more grammer neither, then he hath need of, as may appeare by his correction of my translatiō of obstrepere, and repraesentare in his preface; & what good vse he maketh of his skill in grammer, yea and of this difference which he maketh heere betwixt anteferri, and praeponi thou shalt see, good reader, heerafter in his answere to a like place of S. Leo, wherin praeponi is vsed in the very same sense, which heere he signifieth, and yet it will not suffice to perswade him, that S. Peter had any authority ouer the rest of the Apostles; as shall appeare after in this chapter num. 36.

9. But to proceed, he telleth me, that anteferri is to be esteemed, or graced before another; and to shew his copie and plenty of Latin, he sayeth it is like anteire, antecellere; and afterwards giueth 3. instances of S. Peter excellencies. The first, that he was bid to feede, as one, in whose person others were exhorted: & the Church represented The second, that he was promised martyrdome in these words, cùm senueris. And the third, that he had a priority like charity amōgst other vertues, which is, sayth he, to be principall indeed, but not to rule; and addeth for the proofe therof, that the Vertues of the prosequutiue part, rule not the
intellectuall, but are ruled rather. So he: and now do you not se how this pedant, to exclude S. Peter from all authority, and rule, doth out of his Grammer rules labour to ouerrule, and controlle S. Ambrose, contradicting flatly his exposition of our Sauiours words? which, as you haue heard, he vnderstandeth clearly of rule, & gouerment, saying: oues pascere iubetur, perfectiores vt perfectior gubernaret: that is to say, S. Peter is commaunded to feed the shepe, to the end that he being more perfect, might rule, or gouerne the more perfect. Wherby he signifieth plainly what he meaneth by anteferri, to wit, that S. Peter was preferred before the rest in authority, rule, and gouernment: had not this fellow reason, thinke you, to nippe off, or at least to dissemble those words of S. Ambrose to make good his Grammaticall conceit?

10. The like may also be said of his discourse, which followeth num. 33. concerning Vicarium amoris, in S. Ambrose, wherupon he maketh an ample comment, ouer long, and idle to be set downe heere, but the summe, and scope of all is, to proue by diuers examples, that the title of Vicari • s Christi hath been applyed to diuers other as well as to S. Peter, which no man, I think will deny; neither would I haue vrged
that title if it had beene alone without these circumstances, & the subsequent discourse, & especially the conclusion which fortifieth the rest, and expresseth S. Ambrose h s meaning in all the premisses.

11. But now M. Collins goeth on with his extrauagant discourse to impugne an obseruation which I make out of S. Ambrose, and he out of his Doctorall grauity calleth it a graue obseruation, and me a Noddy for my paines. My words are thes •
pag. 8. num. 9. VVheras S. Ambrose obserueth 3. degrees of Christians, to wit lambes, little sheepe, and sheepe, all commended to the care of S. Peter, he giueth to vnderstand, that all sortes of Christians were committed to his charge and gouernement, and not the weake onely, but the most holy also, learned, and perfect, yea euen the Apostles themselus, and therfore he saith, ones pascere iubetur vt perfectiores persectior gubernaret. Thus said I, which M. Collins doth curtall thus pag. 50. num. 34. There is yet behind, sayth he, an other graue obseruation out of S. Ambrose, that Peter is not bid to feede the lambs, or little sheep, but oues ipsas, that is the more perfect. So he, dissēbling that, which most importeth t • uching gouernment, though expresly set down by S. Ambr. & related by me, to wit, vt perfectiores persectior gubernaret; which words were too hoat for M. Collins to touch, because
they signify clearly, that S. Peter was commāded to feede the sheep (that is to say the more perfect) that he might gouerne them, which he in his glosse vpon anteferri denyeth to be meant by S. Ambrose, as you haue heard, acknowledging onely a certaine priority to be allowed by S. Ambrose to S. Peter, such a one as Charity hath amongst the vertues, that is to say to be principall, but not to rule; which word rule, he also putteth in a different letter, to be the better noted, as no way intended by S. Ambrose.

12. But if gubernare be to gouerne, and to gouerne be to rule, S. Ambrose affirmeth it, and teacheth it expressly, and M. Collins doth not only fraudulētly conceale, & dissemble it, but also if I may be so bould to say it to so graue a Doctor) belyeth S. Ambrose, denying flattly his sense and meaning; and yet forsooth to giue some colour to this fraud of his, he insinuateth that the text of S. Ambrose should be read otherwise, saying. I might send this Noddy to M. Casaubons late monument, or rather mirrour of Excercitations to Baronius his Annales to be informed of S. Ambrose his reading this text, and the vprightnes of it. So he; without declaring any particuler therof, being surprised, as it seemeth with such a suddaine pange of sorrow for the death of
M. Casaubon, that he abruptly crieth out. VVo is me, for that diuine man M. Casaubon, that speaking of his monument, I should speake ambiguously of his tombe, or of his writings; but what that hath deuoured, these shall eternize, and now is no ty • e to bewaile our losse.

13. Thus doth kind M. Collins ease, & disburden his tender hart of some part of his sorrow conceaued for the lamentable lo • se of diuine M. Casaubon, which truely made me the more willing to enquire after that worthy monument, & mirrour of exercitations, which I had neuer seene, nor I thinke should euer haue cared to see, had it not beene by this occasion; and hauing at last got a sight of it, I turned to the place cyted by M. Collins, and found the diuine man scant honest in his allegations, and in • erpretations of the Fathers, and other authors euen in that Exercitation, and chapter, which M. Collins citeth, viz. Exercit. 16. cap. 133. where he digresseth from Cardinall Baronius, to haue a fling at Cardinall Bellarmine, for his exposition of pasce oues meas, wherin the Cardinall followeth S. Ambrose in this very place now in question.

14. And albeit he is so saucy with S. Ambrose, as to censure him for vsing ouiculas insteed of agnos, and making a difference
betweene diligo, and amo: yet I thinke good to omit it for breuityes sake, as not importing any way the matter in question betwixt M. Collins and me, which consisteth not in the different sense, or reading of diligo or amo, or yet of euiculae, or agni, but in the true sense of pasce oues meas, whether the same doth include in it a primacy of gouernement, or no; about which words (I meane the true reading of them in S. Ambrose) M. Casaubon maketh no question at all; and therefore M. Collins sheweth himselfe, I wil not say a Noddy (as he tearmeth me) but a very inconsiderate Doctor to send me to him to be informed of the vprightnesse of S. Ambrose his text, for matters that do not cōcerne our present question: besides that I make no doubt but that the text of S. Ambrose wilbe held for vpright, and currant inough throughout the Christian world, notwithstanding the idle censure of these two pedanticall Grammarians.

15. Neuertheles I cannot omit to obserue somewhat in M. Casaubon, as well to shew his honesty, as for the better instruction of M. Collins, whereby I hope, it will appeare who is the Noddy, either I, whome he sent to M. Casaubon, or he for sending me to him. Thou shalt vnderstand therefore,
good Reader, that Maister Casaubons chiefe quarrel against Cardinall Bellarmine in that chapter, is about the Cardinals explication of those words, pasce oues meas, which he explicated thus, id est regio more impera (as M. Casaubon sayth) who therforce wisheth to be noted in the Greeke text of the Euangelist, that in the 3. tymes that our Sauiour sayd pasce, according to our latin translatiō, the Greeke hath twise 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and but once 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and neuerthelesse, sayth he, Cardinall Bellarmin neglecteth wholy the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and vrgeth mightily the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ratio est, sayth M. Casaubō, quia vt Theophilactus obseruat,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
curam mitiorem significat;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
acrioris imperij videtur habere significationem. The reason is, because, as Theophilact obserueth, the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 doth signify a more mild care, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a more seuere commaund, or gouernement. And to this M. Casaubon addeth the Greek text of Theophilact thus: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

16. Heerein M. Collins may note that according to Theophilact, the Greeke of pasce in this place (be it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) doth include authority, & gouernment, though the one signify a more mild gouernement
then the other. This is euident in the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which doth signify in this place Imperium, and is applyed to both the verbes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 & 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , though with different adiectiues, the one signifying more mild, & the other more seuere; so as the true sense of the greek in Theophilact is this, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signify • th a more seuere gouernement, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a more mild gouernement. This I note by the way for the instruction of M. D. Collins, to the end he may learne, not only by the place of S. Ambrose, which is now in question, but also by this of Theophilact alleadged by his diuine M. Casaubon, that pasce, in the words pasce oues meas doth signify to gouerne; of which point, I shall haue occasion to say somewhat more to M. Collins heereafter num. 25. 26. 27. & 28. by the testimony of M. Casaubon himselfe.

17. In the meane tyme, for as much as M. Casaubone, to whome M. Collins sendeth me, remitteth me, & others his Readers to Theophilact (saying vide Theophilactum) concerning the vnderstanding of the word pasce, according to the greek Fathers (who he sayth do note that Christ did admonish the Apostles by the two wordes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that they should haue care as well of the meane and litle sheep, as of the great,
and that they should so behaue themselues towards the one, & the other, as their need should require) for this cause, I say, I haue taken the paynes to see Theophilact, as M. Casaubon hath willed me; and I find euen in that place, wherto he remitteth me somwhat more then he mentioneth, yea much more then he and his disciple M. Collins wil well disgest; for thus he sayth in cap. 21. Ioan.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 &c. VVhen dinner was ended, Christ recommended to Peter the gouernment of the sheep of all the world, and he did not deliuer it to any other, but to him. Thus sayth Theophilact, not denying that this pastoral commission was giuen to the rest of the Apostls, and to the whole Church; but that it was not giuen principally, and immediatly to any, but to him, who being the supreme Pastour, and gouernour of the Church, receaued that commission not only for himselfe, but also for the Apostles, and for the whole Church bearing the person therof, propter primatum quē in discipulis habuit, for the primacy which he had amongst the disciples, as hath been sufficiently proued heertofore out of S. Augustine.

18. To the same purpose Theophilact sayth also afterwards:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. he gaue into the hands of Peter the prefectship
of all the faythfull; for although Iames receiued the chaire, and throne of Hierusalem, yet Peter receaued the chayre, and throne of the whole world. So he: giuing to vnderstand that neither Iames, nor any of the Apostles had the supreme charge and gouernement of all the faythfull, as Peter had; and that as Iames was truly the pastour, and particuler gouernour of the Church of Hierusalem; so Peter was truly the chiefe Pastour and Gouernour of the whole Church. In like manner afterwards Theophilact hauing demaunded why the Euangelist S. Iohn doth make mention of his owne layning on Christs breast, and of the question which he asked of our Sauiour, who should betray him; sayth thus:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. It was not don without mystery, or by chance, to the end he might shew Peters liberty, or freedome of speach after his deniall; for he that durst not before the crosse (or passiō) aske concerning the traytor, but committed the question to another, he the selfe same receaueth the prefectship of all; and not only those things which belonged to him were not committed to any other, but also he asketh for the best beloued disciple, and is made a mediator for him to their Lord.

19. Thus farre Theophilact; imitating therin S. Chrysostome, who in his homily vpon the same ghospell, and words of our
Sauiour hath the very same in effect, expounding pasce oues meas, by suscipe curam fratrum tuorum, take the charge of thy brethren, that is to say, of the Apostles, as it appeareth euidently by the circumstances in S. Chrysostome, who noteth as Theophilact doth, that albeyt S. Peter durst not presume at Christes last supper to aske him, who was he that should betray him, yet, Commissa sibi fratrum cura, sayth he, vicem suam alteri non mandat, sed ipse magistrum interrogat: The charge of his brethrē being committed vnto him he doth not delegate any other, but asketh their maister himselfe. So sayth S. Chrysostome, giuing plainly to vnderstand that S. Peter hauing by the pastorall commission receaued the charge, and gouernemēt of his brethren the Apostles, was more confident, then before, and would not vse the interuention of any of them (because they were vnder his charge) but asked our Sauiour himselfe; and therefore Theophilact abridging S. Chrysostome in this place (as he doth in a manner throughout al his homilyes vpon the Ghospells) insteed of curam fratrum in S. Chrysostome hath 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , praefecturam omnium, the prefectship of all.

20. This also may be confirmed out
of Euthymus, another greeke Father, who vpon the same chapter, and place of S. Iohn sayth, that our Sauiour asking S. Peter three tymes, whether he loued him, & commanding him stil one thing (to wit to feed his sheep) did manifestly signify, that he most highly esteemed praesidentiam super omnes discipulos, the presidence, or gouernmēt (which he gaue him) ouer all his disciples; and therefore I cannot omit to note heere by the way, how impertinently M. Collins answereth the place cyted a little before out of S. Chrysostome alleadged by me also in my Adioynder pag. 22. num. 31. wherat he scoffeth thus pag. 84. num. 52. That Peter (sayth he) had the care of his brethren committed to him, as if we imagined Peter such a Cain, that cryed, what haue I to looke to my Brother? Thus sayth M. Collins, as who would say, that the charg which S. Peter had ouer his brethren, was but only a brotherly care, that one brother should haue of another: which sense cānot stand either with the meaning of S. Chrysostome (as any man may easily see in the place before cyted) or with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Theophilact, which as I haue sayd, signifyeth a prefecture, or charge including iurisdiction, and authoriry of gouernement, such as he acknowledged in S. Peter, when preferring
him before S. Iames, he sayd, as you heard before, that Iames had the throne of Hierusalem, but Peter had the throne, or chayre of the whole world, which S. Chrysostome also in the same place affirmeth in like manner, who hauing demaunded, why Iames was made Bishop of Hierusalem and not Peter, answereth that our Sauiour preferred Peter to be the Maister of the whole world.

21. Whereby he signifyeth plainly that albeit S. Iames, and all the other Apostles had expresse commission from our Sauiour to preach euery where throughout the whol world (in which respect he saith also himselfe in the same place, that the care of the whole world was recommended vnto them) yet his meaning was that Peter had it in a far more eminent manner then they, because he being Princeps Apostolorum, & vertex totius caetus, prince of the Apostles, and head of the whole company (for so he calleth him in the same homily) had the charg and gouernement of them, as well as of all others that belonged to the sheepfold of Christ; whereupon it followeth that he alone was the supreme pastour of the whole Church, and that the rest of the Apostles, being the sheep of Christ, were also subiect to him; which S. Chrysostome signifyed euidently
when he expoūded pasce oues meas, by suscipe curam fratrum tuorum, take the charge or thy brethren, wherby it appeareth what a ridiculous glosse M. Collins maketh theron, when he taketh it only for a brotherly care.

22. But now, to returne for a while to M. Casaubon, you haue seene how little the greeke Fathers, on whome he seemeth most to rely, do fauour him, and specially Theophilact, vnto whome he appealeth by name; in so much that it is hard to say, whether his fraude, or his folly be greater, his fraude in abusing his Readers with a false shew of auncient Fathers, when they make nothing for him; his folly in appealing to such, as do flattly condemne him; so as M. Collins who hath deifyed him, calling him the diuine man, might rather haue noddified him, and himself for company, when he meant to noddify me. But he that will see what a diuine man M. Casaubon is, let him read F. Andreas Eudemon-Ioannes his castigatiōs of that mirrour of Exercitations (as M. Collins tearmeth it) wherto he remitteth me, and he shall fynd the diuine man, so farre from a good Deuine, that he is neither good Philosopher, nor good humanist, nor yet good Grammarian, either for the Latine, or for the Greeke, wherin he
most glorieth, and this euidently appeareth as well by the obseruation of his errours made by F. Andraeas himself l 2. cap. 2. as by those other which he layeth downe in his third chap. of the said booke, noted by Mathaeus Cariophilus: wherto may be added his many barbarismes in the latine long obserued euen in one onely epistle of his by Gaspar Schiopius, to say nothing of his impostures, abuse of the holy fathers, and other authors, and his manifold lyes, of all which the said F. Andraeas giueth manifest example; so as wee may see how worthily M. Collins hath deified him, and how true the latin Prouerbe is, Mulus mulum scabit, One mule clawes another.

23. And allthough it may perhapps seem a needles labour to enlarge my self in this place further vpon M. Caesaubon, yet because I fynd (euen in that chapter of his Exercitations, whereto M. Collins hath sent me) that he notably abuseth Cardinall Bellarmine, I cannot omit, for the honour I beare the worthy Cardinall, to say somwhat therto, and much the rather, because it may serue me also to some good purpose, to rectify the iudgement of M. Collins in the present Controuersy betwixt him and me. Therfore it is to be vnderstood that wheras
the Cardinall in his 4. booke de Rom Pont. cap. 16. sayth, that when our Sauiour said to S. Peter, Pasce oues meas, he vsed vocabulo Regio, a Kingly word; and in his recognition of all his Workes speaking of that place, sayth, that it may be gathered by the words of our Sauiour, that he gaue to S. Peter authority to gouerne regio more, after the manner of a king, remitting his Reader for the further explication therof to his first booke de Rom. Pont. cap. 15. (where he bringeth diuers places of the holy Scriptures, and some out of profane authors to proue that pasce, is oftymes vsed for regere, to gouerne, as well in the Greeke, as in the Latin;) M. Casaubon willfully, & maliciously misconstrueth the Cardinals meaning, vrging and exaggerating his words further, then euer he meant to extend them.

24. For his intention was no other, but onely to signify that the gouernement of the Church is by the institution of our Sauiour truly Monarchicall, that is to say a lawfull, iust, and moderate Gouernement vnder one head, such as is the gouernement of a iust, and good King, who seeking (according to Aristotle) the good of his subiects, and not his owne, may truely be called, Paeter patriae the Father of his country,
the refuge of the poore, the defence of the innocent, and the comfort of all his distressed subiects, such as Dauid, & Moyses are described to be in the holy Scriptures; yea such as the very Paynim Philosophers (who treat of the office, & duety of a good king) require him to be; that is to say, not onely to be the minister of Almighty God, to administer iustice, but also to be most like him in innocency, liberality, longanimity, patience, mercy, and in all vertue, and goodnes, as Plutarch, following Plato, teacheth notably in his treatise de doctrina Principum, and in the life of Aristides.

25. This then being so, and the Cardinals meaning no other (when he speaketh of a kingly gouernmēt in the church) what reason, or honest meaning hath M. Casaubon to stretch the Cardinals words, & intention to a tyrannicall gouernment, & to inueigh against him for the same, as he doth? to which purpose it is also to be noted, that whereas the Cardinall produceth diuers places of Holy Scripture, and prophane Authours (as I haue signified before) to proue that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in greeke, and pascere in Latine, are many tymes vsed for, regere, to gouerne; M. Casaubon himself expoundeth these places to signify
only, that the office of a King is to gouerne his people with such tendernes, sweetnes, and louing affection, as sheepheards are wont to gouerne their flockes, which was also the Cardinalls meaning, who in acknowledging a Kingly manner of gouernement in the Church, and producing those places for the proofe thereof, had no other intention, then to denote the most iust, sweet, moderate, and pastorall gouernement that may be. But seeing that M. Casaubon is scandalized with the wordes regium, and impera, I meruaile how he doth brooke and digest the vse therof in the holy Scripture, as 1. Petr. 2. where our priesthood is called Regale sacerdotium, a kingly Priesthood. And in the Apocal cap. 1 & 5. Fecisti • os Deo n • stro regnum, & sacerdotes, & regnabimus super terram: Thou hast made vs to our God, a kingdome, and Priests, and we shall raigne vpon the earth. And in S. Paul to Titus cap. 2. Argue cum omni imperio, reproue with all imperious command; which seemeth to be much more, then regio more impera; for omne imperium, includeth not only, the regall, and imperiall authority, but also the Despoticall; wheras, Regio more, being added to impera, in the Cardinall, doth so qualify, & moderat the rigour of the word
that it signifyeth a most iust, milde, and moderate gouernement, that is to say, the gouernement of a iust, and good King; in which sense the Cardinall taketh it, as I haue declared before.

26. Neuertheles I must aduertise M. Casaubon by the way, that although the gouernement of the Church ought to be pastorall, that is to say most moderate, and sweet; yet not so moderate, gentle, and sweet, but that the pastor may, when occasion requireth, vse his pastorall staffe to correct a straying sheep, and beate him into the fould; & if there should be a scabbed sheep in the flock, though perhaps he were as good a Grammarian as M. Casaubon, or as great a Doctour as M. Collins, yet the sheepheard might with his sheep-hooke draw him by the legg out of the fould, yea and if he were incurable he might giue him into the butchers handes, least otherwise he might infect the whole flocke. And this I thinke could not seeme to any reasonable man, either tyrannicall, or vnfit for the office of a good Pastour described (as M. Casaubon sayth) by S. Gregory Nazianzen orat. 1. saving: Pastor non vtitur multùm pedo, fistula verò plurimùm: the Sheepheard doth not much vse his staffe, or sheep-hooke, but his whistle very much, that
is to say, he vseth more lenity, then seuerity, oftener preaching and exhorting, then punishing, yet punishing sometymes euen with seuerity, when there is iust occasion for a publike good.

27. For what more seuere punishmēt can there be, then S. Peter vsed to chastice Ananias and Saphira, whome he stroke with suddain death Act. 5? Or then S. Paul vsed in the punishment of the incestuous Corinthian deliuering him to Satan 1. Cor. 5. punishing him thereby as well in body, as in soule? And this M. Casaubon himselfe seemeth not to deny, when he sayth in the end after his long inuectiue against the Cardinall: Neque hoc dicimus, sayth he, quod putemus &c. Neither do I say this, because I thinke that the spirituall pastor doth lacke spirituall power to punish his rebels after a spiritual manner &c. meaning, no doubt that he may punish by way of excommunication, and censures; which albeit, they do principally concerne the soule, yet do consequently induce many tymes bodily or temporall punishment; but whether they do, or no, the only spirituall is more seuere, and terrible, then any bodily, or temporall punishment in the world; and therefore no man that hath such esteeme of spirituall punishments (especially of excōmunications,
and Ecclesiasticall censures) as a good Christian ought to haue, can deny but that the spiritual pastor may vse rigour, and seuerity, when occasion requireth.

28. Well then, this I haue touched briefly by occasion of M. Casaubons malicious censure, and reprehension of the Cardinal; and as I haue sayd before, I haue don it the rather, because it may serue me also to some good purpose for the instruction of M. Collins, who sent me vnto him. For whereas M. Collins hath denyed, as you haue heard, that S. Peter had, by the wordes pasce oues meas, any authority giuen him to gouerne, or rule, but only to seed (for which cause he also suppressed the words of S. Ambrose, who expounded pascere by gubernare) he is clearely conuinced by his diuine man M. Casaubon, who (albeit he exclude tyranny, or great seuerity frō the pastoral office) yet granteth, that the spirituall Pastor hath • ot only praesecturam, that is to say a Prefectship, or gouernement (though omnium mitissimum, sayth he, the most milde, and gentle of all other, which no man denyeth) but also spiritualem potestatem animaduertendi in rebelles; power to punish his rebellious subiects; and that Pastor castigat pedo, the Pastor punisheth
with his Pastorall staffe, or sheep-hooke (but not with Virga ferrea, sayth he, the yron rodde (about which point I will not stand now to dispute with him, thogh I know not what yron rodd can be so grieuous as an excommunication,) but it sufficeth me for M. Collins at this present, that his diuine man M. Casaubon graunteth to the Pastor authority of gouernment, thogh most gentle, and milde, partly approuing Theophilacts exposition of the Greeke word 〈◊〉 signifying, or denoting imperium mite, a milde gouernement, and partly allowing S. Hilaryes interpretation of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , who expoundeth it by pastoraliter regere; wherupon M. Casaubon himselfe also sayth: En lu
•• l • nter à magno Doctore expositum &c. Behould how a great Doctor expoundeth clearely, what Pastor, and pascere, do signify, when they are spoken of the gouernours of the Church.

29. Now then I inferre heereupon against M. Collins, that seeing our Sauiour Christ when he gaue the pastoral commission to S. Peter vsed a word, which signifyeth pasce, as our Latine hath it, and is expressed in the greeke by 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he gaue him authority not only to feed, and direct his sheep with doctrine, but also to gouerne, and chastise them, according
to the iudgment as well of the diuine Casaubon, as of the two Fathers S. Hilary, and Theophilact alleadged by him.

30. And if M. Collins seeke to escape heere by his wonted distinction, that S. Peter did not receaue this commission for himselfe, but as a proxy for the Church, M. Casaubon hath so hemd him in, as I may say with the authority of Theophilact, that he cannot start out: for Theophilact declareth plainely euen in the same place, which M. Casaubon cyteth, that Christ gaue the gouernment of the sheepe of all the world to Peter, and not to any other but to him That is to say, to none principally, and immediatly but to him, albeit he gaue the same in him, and by him to the whole Church, which he represented, being supreme Pastor, & head thereof, as hath beene sufficiently declared & shewed before, throughout all the precedent Chapters.

31. Therefore I leaue it now, good Reader, to thee to iudge who is the Noddy, I, whome M Collins calleth so, and sendeth to schoole to M. Casaubon; or he, for sending me to such a Maister, who as you see vtterly confoundeth him, partly by Theophilact, and partly by his owne doctrine, teaching that pasce, as it was spoken by our Sauiour
to S Peter, signifyeth to gouerne, which M. Collins flatly denyeth, as you haue heard hitherto, and shall heare further in that which followeth. For whereas he endeauoureth to answere my former obiection out of S. Ambrose, viz. that S. Peter was commanded to feed all kind of Christians, that he might gouerne as well the perfect, as the vnperfect, and weake (yea the Apostles thēselues, as being comprehended amongst the more perfect) M. Collins spendeth, or rather spoyleth a great deale of Rhetorike to peruert S. Ambrose his meaning, and cozen his Reader. And after he hath flaunted a while, after his fond fashion, he goeth on thus. Do we looke that it should haue been sayd, feed all saue the Apostles? Or all saue Princes? Why should Princes, & Apostles not pro • it by Peter? Why should they be denyed the benefit of his feeding? Why should not all the Apostles feed al the world? Why should not one Apostle feed another, Peter his fellowes, and they Peter? So he, dissembling altogeather the mention of gouernement in S. Ambrose, and reducing all by degrees to a bare feeding, as that S. Peter should feed the Apostles, and yet no other wayes, thē as they should feed him, one Apostle (saith he) should feed another, Peter his fellowes, & they him.

32. But this deep deuise of his is vtterly dashed with those few wordes of S. Ambrose (which he listed not to see, but most fraudulently dissembleth, to wit, vt perfectiores perfectior gubernaret) as also with the authority of Theophilact, and S. Hilary, before alleadged, and approued by M. Casaubon, who vnderstand, and acknowledge the authority of gouernement in the pastorall cōmission giuen to S. Peter; besides the testimonyes, which you haue heard also before in the second chap. num 16. out of S. Augustine, expounding pascere, by docere, & regere to teach, and gouerne, and now also in this chap. out of S. Chrysostome, & Euthymius, teaching expresly, that Christ gaue vnto S. Peter the charge, and gouernement of the Apostles, or disciples, whē he bad him feed his sheep.

33. And now to those I will yet add one other testimony out of S. Leo, which I obiected in my Adioynder pag. 24. nu. 22. and M. Collins vndertaketh also to answere pag. 85. num. 53. and this I will do the rather, because he vseth therin the same fraud and cozenage that you haue already seene in his answere to the place of S. Ambrose. S. Leo's words are these serm. 3. in assump ad Pontif. Peter was chosen out of the whole world to haue
the chiefe charge of the vocation of the Gentills, and of all the Apostles, & of all the Fathers of the Church, to the end, that albeit there be many Priests amongst the people of God, and many Pastours; omnes tamen propriè regat Petrus, yet Peter may properly gouerne them all, whome Christ doth also principally gouerne. Thus sayth S. Leo, teaching expresly that S. Peter had the gouernment, as well of the Apostles themselues, as of all other Pastors of the Church vnder Christ, who is the principall gouernour of them all.

34. And what sayth M. Collins to this trow you? Marry forsooth he layth downe part of the place, thus: Peter was chosen out of the whole world to haue the chiefe charge of the vocation of the Gentills, and of all the Apostles, and of all the Fathers of the Church. Thus much he alleadgeth, and then sayth, that there is nothing heere for my turne, saue that Peter was chosen to haue the charge of the Apostles, & therfore in answere therof sayth a little after. Neither doe we deny, that Peter might haue the charge of the Apostles, yet no commaunding charge but either as ferrum acuit ferrum, one yron whets, and sharpens another (so the face of one brother to quicken another by his encouragements, confirma fratres) or bono vnitatis, preferred for his maturity to preuent schisme, and disorder, as
hath beene tould you; though the name (Apostles) is common to some without the company of the twelue, and the Scripture vseth it so Philip. 2.25. whome Peter might be charged with, and with the other fathers of the church (as Leo calls heere the Bishops of their making) without derogating from the Colledge of them properly so called. So he, granting three thinges, with certaine limitations, whereby he would seeme fully to haue answered me for this place; the first is, that Peter might haue the charge of the Apostls, but no commanding charge. The second that he was preferred before the rest, only, for the good of vnity, and in respect of his maturity (for the which he remitteth me to what he hath told me before.) The third is, that he might haue the charge of such, as were tearmed Apostles, and were none of the twelue.

35. But if M. Collins had beene as honest a man, as a Doctor of Diuinity should be, I meane, if he had alleadged the whole place of S. Leo, as he found it in my Adioynder (& cannot be denyed to be the true words of the Authour) I thinke he could not for shame haue sayd any of these three things; for you may see in the place before alleadged, that after the wordes of S. Leo, layd downe by M. Collins, there followeth
immediatly this: Vt quamuis in populo Dei multi sunt sacerdotes &c. that albeyt there be many Priests among the people of God, and many pastors; yet that Peter may properly gouerne them all, whome Christ doth also principally gouerne. Thus sayth S. Leo, which quite ouerthroweth M. Collins his glosse, who acknowledgeth that S. Peter had the charge of the Apostles, but no commāding charge; wheras S. Leo speaketh expresly of a charge of gouernement, that is to say, a commaunding charge. Againe, M. Collins graunteth that S. Peter was preferred before the rest in respect of his maturity, and for the good of vnity; and S. Leo telleth vs, what S. Peters preferment was, viz. that he did properly gouerne all the Pastours of the Church, whome Christ doth principally gouerne.

36. But heere I cannot forget, good Reader, to put thee in mind by the way of what hath passed before in this very Chap. num. 8. in his answere to the place of Saint Ambrose pag. 48. where he obserued (out of the depth of his Grammaticall science) agreat difference betwixt anteferri, and praponi. Anteferri (sayth he) is one thing, and praeponi is another; the later may be of authority, the first of any excellency. So as if S. Ambrose, had vsed praeponi, as he did anteferri, Maister Collins would haue graunted, as it seemeth, that he
had acknowledged in S. Peter a preferment of authority, and gouernement; which therefore I must desire him to graunt me now in this place of Saint Leo, who for the wordes, which I translate, to haue the chiefe charge of the Apostles, hath in Latin praeponatur omnibus Apostolis, which no doubt M. Collins saw in the Latin (for I make no doubt but he would examine the place in S. Leo) and yet you see he will not graunt to S. Peter any authority more then to the rest of the Apostles, so as praeponi hath now no more force with him, then anteferri; and therefore I leaue it to thy iudgment, good Reader, what credit his Grammaticall obseruations deserue to haue with others, seeing he maketh so little account of them himselfe.

37. But now to proceed with his 3. note vpon the words of S. Leo, wheras he hopeth to finde a starting hole by the name (Apostles) because it is sometymes applyed to those, which were none of the 12. or of the colledge of the Apostles, S. Leo's words do deb • r him vtterly from that eu • sion, speaking of al the Apostles, & not of some, omnibus Apo • tolis praeponatur sa • th S. Leo, which cannot be vndestood of some in particuler, and specially of such, as onely were so
called, and were not of the number of the 12. Besides that S. Leo his conclusion, which M. Collins fraudulently concealed (as he did before, that other of S. Ambrose) doth vtterly marre his market: for if the 12. Apostles were to be comprehended (as no doubt they were) amongst those Priestes, and pastors whome Christ doth principally gouerne, he must needs graunt, that according to S. Leo they were all gouerned properly by S: Peter.

38. Behold then what an absurd answere he hath shaped vs heere, besides the notable fraude that he hath vsed therin; so as I may well say, that if he answere argumentes no better in the publick actes, & commēcementes at Cambrige, he will shame the Vniuersity, and deserue to be hyssed out of the Schooles. I omit what he idly cyteth out of S. Leo, which doth no way contradict that which I haue allready alleadged out of him, but might serue notably to conunice him, if it were needfull, or that I would stand longer vpon it; but it sufficeth for the present, that hi • fraude in this is most euident, and inexcusable. And wheras he insinuateth an exception, which he might take to S. Leo's testimony, to wit, because he is our o • ne Pope (as he tearmeth him) and not a little addicted to the
amplysying of the Philacteryes of his owne sea. And againe, that it was easy for Leo to Rhetoricate at Rome in prayse of Peter. I may well say to M. Collins, that it is a signe of a very bad & desperate cause to take exceptions to the testimonyes of such as all antiquity a • mired, and held for testes omni exceptione maiores; for so I may truly say of Pope Leo, who was so famous in his tyme both for learning, wisedome, and sanctity of life, that he was honoured with the title Leo Magnus, & hath beene euer since held and honoured by the whole Church for a Saint; besids that, such was the integrity of his fayth & doctrine, that the whole Councel of Chalcedō (which was the fourth generall Councell, and is allowed by his Maiesty for Oecumenical) gaue notable testimony thereof in an epistle, which the sayd Councell wrote to the Em • erour Martian, affirming that God had prouided for them in Pope Leo, impenetrabilem in omnem errorem propugnatorem; an inuincible defender against all errour, and prepared him for victory: doctrinis eum per omnia veritatis astringens &c. binding him with the doctrine of verity in all things, to the end that he fighting with seruent affection, as Peter did, may bring all sense and vnderstanding to God. Thus wrote that famous & auncient Councell of Pope Leo, shewing
their constant opinion and iudgment touching the infallible verity of his doctrine, by whose conduct and authority they assured themselues that God did guide them to all truth, and defend them from all errour; in which respect they also acknowledged themselues to reuerence in his person the authority of S. Peter, as appeareth further by the applause and acclamations of the whole Councell to an epistle of his; Petrus say they, per Leonem locutus est; Peter hath spoken by Pope Leo, wherby they testifyed the reuerend respect they bare, aswell to him, as to S. Peter, and to the sea Apostolike, which he gouerned, as S. Peters successor. Who then would not detest the audacious temerity of M. Collins, and his fellowes, who because they cannot answere the pregnant places which are alleadged out of him for the proofe of the Popes Supremacy, do seek to calumniate and disgrace him with the imputation of ambition, and pride, whom all antiquity, and the famous and ancient generall Councell of Chalcedon reuerenced, and admired, as a mirrour of learning & sanctity.

39. But now to returne to the place of S. Ambrose, from the which I haue a little digressed, and to come to the conclusion
of M. Collins his discourse, it were truely a wonder, if it were any whit wiser then the rest; seeing that he hath one special vertue, or quality, which is, that he is semper idem, & sui similis, alwayes the same man, & like himselfe, as wise in the end, as in the beginning, alwayes impertinent, alwayes ridiculous, yet more heere, if more may be, then hitherto, as thou shalt see, good Reader, in this vpshot of his answere to the place of S. Ambrose, which I will therefore giue thee in his owne wordes.

p.q:
Nay, how if the Iesuite (sayth he) haue so mistaken himself in his curious distinction betwixt Lambes, and Sheep, that he hath cleane exempted both Apostles, and Kinges from Peters iurisdiction? to bring whom in, and to raung them within the compasse of that supreame power, the distiction only was at first deuised: for if oues & agni only be S. Peters walk, & he the shepheard, wher are arietes? where are the rammes? the rammes being the Apostles by Turrians exposition, or the successors of the Apostles, that is, the Bishops, and againe, the rammes being meant by kings, as Tolet witnesseth vpon the 15. of S. Iohn annot. 3. Two Iesuits, you see, I bring him, and the one a Cardinall made for his learning, which I think will neuer be his lot; but hath he not spunne a faire threed, I say, shutting out both Apostles, & kings, whom by that very trick he would haue shut
in? And so much of his answere to the first exception, that the byshop makes against the argument drawne from pasce oues meas, consisting in the authority of S. Augustine, and S. Ambrose.

div.p: 41. Wherein three notable fooleryes are to be ob • erued. First that he sayth, the Iesuit deuised this distinction of lambes, & sheep, to bring the Apostles, and Kings vnder S. Peters iurisdiction; wheras you see, that the distinction was made by our Sauiour himselfe obserued by S. Ambrose, & only related by me without any mention of Kings in particuler, but of al Christians in generall; and albeit I mention the Apostles, I do it not so much by reason of the distinction of sheep, & lambes, as by the occasiō of S. Ambrose his comment therupon, who vnderstandeth by sheep the more perfect, amongst whome I include the Apostles. Secōdly M. Collins seemeth to exclude rammes from the sheepfold, seeing that he will not haue them comprehended in the distinctiō of sheep and lambes, nor to be reckoned in the number of sheep; perhaps this great Grammarian hath noted, that ouis, for a sheepe is of the feminine gender, and that therfore a Ramme cannot be a sheep.

42. But then, I would know whether
a Wether be a sheep, by M. Collins his grammer, and if he be, why a Ramme may not be a sheep also; & againe whether because Agnus is of the masculine gender, there be any she lambes, and consequently whether they were vnder Peters iurisdiction, when our Sauiour sayd vnto him pasce agnos meos, and if they were, why then the male sheep, that is to say the Rammes, and Wethers could not be included in pasce oues meas, and in the number of those sheep, of whom the Royall Prophet sayth: oues & boues, & pecora campi &c. psal. 8. and of those of whome he sayd also 2. Reg. 24. Isti qui oues sunt, quid fecerunt: these which were sheep what haue they done? And finally when our Sauiour shall place the sheep vpon his right hand, & the goats vpon his left, if the Rammes be not sheep, where shall they stand? Do I seeme to you M. Collins too grāmatical, as you sayd to me whyle ere? But truly if you were not more seely then a sheep, you would neuer haue denyed Rammes to be sheep, as you do, excluding them from the distinction of sheep and lambes.

43. But now to come to the third foolery (which truly I know not whether it be more foolish or fraudulēt:) Arietes, sayth he, are (by the opinion of two Iesuits Turrianus,
and Cardinall Tolet) to be vnderstood to be the Apostles, or Bishops their successours, and Kings, who therfore being neither sheep, nor lambes, are excluded from the dominion of Peter: and so (as he sayth) I haue spunne a faire threed to shut them out whome by that very tricke (he meaneth the distinction of sheepe and lambes) I would haue shut in. How faire the threed is, that I haue spunne, I leaue it to the iudgement of others; but sure I am, that of my faire threed (if it be a faire one) he hath wouen a very foule, false, and weake web, arguing as simply, and ignorantly, as you haue heard him before chap. 2. num. 25. & 26. out of a similitude, or comparison betwixt S. Peter, and Iudas, applying it to other purpose then it serueth for, wherein he is so much the more inexcusable heer, for that he hath taken this out of Tolet vpon the 15 chap. of S. Iohn annotat. 3. who treating of the false application of similitudes, and of the weaknes of arguments grounded theron, bringeth this example, that Christ is compared in the Scripture to a lambe, and Kings to Rammes: Neuerthelesse sayth he, it doth not follow theron, that Kinges are greater then Christ, because ramms are greater then lambes, Id enim tantùm ex parabola
petendum est, ad quod significandum est proposita for that only is to be drawne, or taken from a parable, or similitude, for the which it is proposed. Thus sayth Tolet.

44. Now then M. Collins taketh out of
• olet, that Kings are cōpared to Rammes (as indeed they may well be, because they are, as it were duces gregis, the leaders of the flocke) and applyeth it cleane contrary to his mind, and to the instruction, which he giueth with that example; for Kings were neuer compared to rammes in the Scripture with any relation to S. Peter, no more then with relation to Christ; and therefore, as the argument was not good, and worthily reproued by Tolet, which referred them to Christ, no more could any argument be good, that should any way referre them to S. Peter, because as I haue sayd, the comparison of rammes with Kings was not made, nor is vsed in the Scripture to any s • ch purpose; but if such an argument coul • be good, M. Collins would be vtterly spoyled with his comparison; for seeing that the Rams (albeit they are leaders of the whole flocke, yet) are no lesse subiect to the sheepheard, then the meanest sheep in the fold; it would follow directly, that Kinges are no lesse subiect to S. Peter (to whom Christ
gaue commission to feed his sheep) then the poorest Christian in their kingdomes.

45. Thus thou seest, good Reader, what a faire threed M. Collins hath spunne in shutting in both Apostles, and Kinges within the iurisdiction and gouernement of S. Peter, by the very same tricke, wherby he thought to shut them out, and so remayneth foyled euery way, euen by his owne argument, besides his notable abuse of S. Ambrose, and S. Leo, as you haue heard a little before; and now of Cardinall Tolet, whom he alleadgeth directly contrary to his own meaning, which must needs be against the light of his owne conscience, if he haue any, wherew • th you heard him charge me once, and call me wretch, when neuertheles not I, but he himself was taken tardy with it, in the same place, as you may see before cap. 1. num. 10. & 11. If therefore he had found me halting in this manner, how would he haue triumphed, and treated me thinke you? What names, and titles would he haue bestowed vpon me, as he doth many tymes without any cause calling me, VVretch, Noddy, Hobbyhorse, Mastiff Dogge, Curre false Theef, a souterly fellow, & what not? But for my part I will say no more of him, but that he is a great Grammarian, and a deep
Doctor of Diuinity, and that if he may stil be imployed for a writer, the Vniuersity of Cambridge will haue much honour by him, Kings College a notable Ornament, and the Clergy of England a great light, the Ghospell great increase, my Lord of VVinchester a doughty, and worthy Champion, all his friends a singular comfort, and only I, poore wretch, and the Catholikes are like to haue a terrible, and a potent aduersary, God help vs; for, Si Deus nobiscum, quis contra nos?

46. But now to conclude this matter, and Chapter, you haue heard what he hath thought good to say to my answere to the first exception that my Lord of VVinchester makes against our argument drawne from pasce oues meas, consisting in the authority of S. Augustine, and S. Ambrose, and I doubt not but you haue clearely seene three thinges. First that the charge of a lame, and fraudulent quotation of S. Augustine which I layd vpon my Lord of VVinchester, remayneth good, for ought that M. Collins hath beene able to say to the contrary, seeing I haue shewed clearely that the wordes, and circumstances of the place alleadged by my Lord (to proue that S. Peter had no more authority by pasce oues meas, then the rest of
the Apostles) did proue the contrary; signifying expresly that those wordes were sayd to S. Peter, as he bare the person of the Church, which he did (according to S. Augustins expresse doctrine) propter primatum, in respect of his primacy; & that therfore S. Augustine sayd, that which my Lord of VVinchester obiecteth out of him, to wit, Cum Petro dicitur, ad omnes dicitur, pasce oues meas, when it was sayd to Peter, it was sayd to all, feed my sheep; because he being primate, and chiefe pastor of the Church, receaued that commission for himselfe, and for the whole Church; so as my Lord of VVinchester obiecting the wordes of S. Augustine contrary to his meaning, and dissembling the reason thereof (which was expressed sufficiently in the same place) was worthily charged by me with a lame, and fraudulent quotation, wherof you see M. Collins hath no way discharged him.

47. Secondly whereas M. Collins following my Lord of VVincester hath expounded the primacy, which Saint Augustine acknowledgeth in S. Peter, to be a primacy of place, or excellency, and not of authority, or gouernement; you see I haue proued the contrary, as well out of S. Augustine and other Fathers in the precedent Chapters, as
now in this out of S. Ambrose, and S. Leo, who teach S. Peters primacy of gouernement so expresly, that M. Collins had no way to answere them, but with a fraudulent silence, and dissimulation of that which most imported, as you haue seene so lately that I need not to repeate it.

48. Thirdly, you haue seene also how M. Collins hath quit himselfe in his answere to my Adioinder, so farre as yet we haue gone, wherein you may haue noted such a number of follyes, absurdityes, contradictions, falsifications, and abuse of Authors, that you may guesse, with what manner of ware the rest of his great pedlars packe is stuffed; seeing that nothing hath passed from him, of all that which I haue hitherto examined, wherein he hath not beene notably ouertaken: and in one thing specially he surpasseth all other ignorant, and foolish Scriblers of this age (at least those which I haue seene) that he hath not the wit to vnderstand when he argueth against his aduersary, or against himselfe, whereof you haue seene diuers examples. And therefore I may with great reason say vnto him, for the conclusion of this Chapter, and Controuersy, Obmutesce Samuel, for shame, obmutesce.

div.head: The Author passeth to another Controuersy touching Prayer to Saints, and the Veneration of their relikes: and for breuityes sake vndertaketh from henceforth to discouer only M. Collins his falsityes fraudes, and manifest lyes; omitting his absurdityes and fooleryes. AND In this Chapter M. Collins is conuinced to • aue shamefully abused not onely the Author, but also S. Hierome, S Basil, the Councell of Gangra, S. Ephraem, S. Gregory Nazianzen, and S. Epiphanius. And by the way, Answere is returned to my Lord of Winchester, of a message which he sent to the Author by M. Collins. CHAP. VII.
div.p:
FOR as much as this my reply is already growne to a greater Volume, then at the first I determined, I will take a shorter course from henceforth, & therefore hauing hitherto ventilated, and
debated with M. Collins only the matter of the Popes supremacy; and now meaning, in the ensuing Chapters, to treat of another Controuersy, to wit. Of prayer to Saints, and the Veneration of their Relikes, I will prosecute my first intended course; which is to attend only to the discouery of his cozenages & fraudes in his answeres to the places, and authorityes of the Fathers alleadged by me in my Adioynder, whereby I doubt not, but that his bad conscience, & the weaknes of his cause wilbe no lesse euident, then if I should discouer all his follyes, which truly are so many in this Controuersy, that they would require more tyme, & labour then were fit to be bestowed vpon such an idle companion; besides that they are commonly so connected with his fraudes, and so euident of themselues, that the discreet Reader will easily note many of thē without any labour • f myne to decypher them, or to put him in mind thereof.

2. Well then I will beginne with his sixt Chapter, which beginneth his second part about the Inuocation of Saints (as he himselfe intytleth it.) And because my first question debated with my Lord of VVinchester, concerning that matter, is about the word
Inuocation, whether it belong to God alone (as my Lord affirmeth it to do) or may be applyed also to Saints; I will examine M. Collins his frauds in answer to my Adioynder touching that point.

3. It is therfore to be vnderstood that my Lord of VVinchester labouring to proue that none can be inuocated but God, sayth: Terret nos Apostolus &c the Apostle doth terrify vs, when he asketh this question Rom. 10. Quomodo inuocabunt, in quem non crediderunt? How shal they inuocat him, in whom they beleeued not? Vpon which text he inferreth that we may inuocate none but him in whome we beleeue, which is God alone; wherupon I thought good in my Adioynder to explicate that text, and to that end, I sayd thus, pag. 213. num. 3.

4. A man may wonder how this great Doctor could so grossely erre in a matter so euident as this, seeing that the words of the Apostle immediatly going before, do manifestly shew, that he speaketh there of an Inuocation due to God alone, as to our chiefe Lord; which kind of Inuocation is not communicable to creatures; and therfore the Apostle hauing sayd, that God is Dominus omnium &c. the Lord of all, & rich, or bountifull, towardes all that inuocate
him, he confirmeth it with the saying of the Prophet, Omnis qui inuocauerit nomen Domini saluus erit, euery one that shall inuocate the name of our Lord, shalbe saued. And then he addeth: Quomodo inuocabunt in quem non crediderunt? how shal they inuocate him, in whome they haue not belieued? as who would say, how can they inuocate him, of whome the Prophet speaketh, him, that is Dominus omnium, the Lord of all, except they belieue in him, that is to say, except they beleeue him to be their Lord, and Creator, whereby he doth not signify that none but God can be inuocated in any sort; but that we cannot inuocate God, as our Lord, and our God, except we belieue him so to be.

5. Thus sayd I, and as I hope, this my explication of S. Pauls wordes is so naturall, proper, and conforme to the circumstances of the text, that it cannot with reason be reiected. And this M. Collins saw so well (as it seemeth) that he thoght best to practise his ordinary fraud in dissembling it wholy, & therfor not making so much as any mentiō of it (as any way controuerted betwixt my Lord and me) he applyeth and vrgeth it in the same sense that my Lord doth, taking occasiō to wrangle with me about another question, to wit, whether we may be sayd
to belieue in Saints (which I will debate with him anone) & because I affirmd that it might be truly sayd, that we beleeue in Saints in some sort, and sense, he alleadgeth that text of S. Paul, vrging the generality of it, and expounding, Quomodo inuocabunt in quem, that is, sayth he, in quemcumque non crediderunt, how shall they call vpon him, in whomesoeuer they haue not beleeued: which interpretation of his, that other of myne in my Adioynder (gathered and vrged by me out of the circumstances of the place) doth vtterly ouerthrow, and therefore ought to haue beene answered & confuted by him, before he grounded any arguments or reasons, vpon his owne expositiō, being no other but my Lord of VVinchesters, which I impugned, and confuted by myne.

6. Furthermore I proued also afterwards out of my Lord of VVinchester himself that the word inuocation may be applyed to creatures; for he sayth pag. 45. §. locus autem. That poscereà sanctis auxilium propriè inuocare est, to aske help of Saints is properly to inuocate them; whereupon I sayd in my Adioynder thus pag. 215. num. 6. according to this interpretation of his, we do properly inuocate al those of whome we craue help, and succour,
which we lawfully craue, not only of God, but also of those who by the ordinance of God may, an do lawfully help vs, as Angells, Saints, and men do: whereupon it followeth that we may lawfully demaund their help, and consequently inuocate them, according to M. Andrewes his owne interpretation; whereby it appeareth that he hath not only very idely laboured to fright vs with his terrible Text, but also fondly contradicted himself. Thus sayd I, in my Adioynder.

7. And now I make no doubt, but that thou wilt thinke good Reader, that M. Collins ought in reason to haue taken some notice of this, aswell to iustify his owne, & my Lords applicatiō of the word Inuocation to God alone, (which heere you see is disproued by my Lords own doctrin) as also to deliuer my Lord from the note of contradiction wherewith I charged him. But he dissembleth all this, albeit he sayth somewhat (as idely as he is wont) to the paragraffs that immediatly go before and after, to wit, to the fifth, and seauenth, wheras this, which I haue now cyted, is in the sixt; so as he cannot be excused neither from a fraudulent dissimulation of my Text, nor from treachery to my Lord,
for leauing him in the lurch vndefended, being charged with a flatte Contradiction.

8. But now let vs heare how he iugleth touching the fayth or beliefe which we may be sayd to haue in Saints. First then he sayth, that I acknowledge the inuocation of Saints (but not of God) to be possible without sayth in them, and yet he taketh exception to it, because by that distinction, at least (sayth he) a man might inuocate God though not as the Creator of heauen and earth, yet as some Saint, or demy-God; which how false it is, & how farre from my meaning, you shal see by my owne words after a whyle: in the meane tyme he proceedeth, and sayth that afterwards, I eat my word, and allow fayth in Saints themselues; and albeit he confesseth that I qualify it, saying in some sort, yet he styleth it an egregious blasphemy, & produceth diuers places of holy scripture and Fathers to proue that there can be no fayth but in god; which how little it proueth against me, you shall now see, by my own text, which he fraudently concealeth, and belyeth egregiously.

9. Thus then I said in my Adioynder, touching this poynt pag. 214. num. 4. This doth not contradict the inuocation of Saints in another
Respect, to wit, not as Gods, but as the seruants of God, whom he glorifieth, and by whose intercession, and mediation he bestoweth graces, and fauours vpon mē: in which sense, yt may also be truly said, that we cannot inuocate them, or craue their prayers, except we do in some sort beleeue in them (I meane) so farr forth as we inuocate them, that is to say, except we beleeue them to be Gods seruants, and that we haue also confidence in them, as in those who by gods goodnes may help vs. So as a fayth, & beleife in saints is necessary for the inuocation of them, though yt ys not the fayth that we haue in God, as in our cheif Lord and Creator. And that we may haue fayth in Saints M. Andrews may learne in the Apostle himself, who commendeth the charity, and fayth which Philemon had in domino Iesu & in omnes sanctos, in our Lord Iesus, and in all saynts; vpon which words S. Hierome in his Commentary vpon that Epistle discourseth amply, prouing that wee may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints. Thus said I in my Adioynder.

10. Now then herein yt is euident, first that I do distinguish clerely betwixt the fayth that we haue in God (as our Lord and Creatour) and in Saints, as his seruants
(who by his permission and ordinance, may help and releiue vs) and therefore I say, that we may beleeue, and confide in them, in some sort. And this is most true, not only of Saynts, but also of men. For who wilbe so mad to demaund help or releife at any mans hands, who he doth not beleiue, may and will help him? And this also I do say expresly, is not the fayth, and beleife which wee haue in God, as our Lord and Creatour, because wee do not acknowledge the Saynts so to be; wherby you see how friuolous, and vayne the exception is which he taketh to my assertion, when he sayth, that by my distinction a man may inuocate God, at least, as some Saynt or demy-God, though not as Creatour of heauen and earth; whereas I doe expressely affirme, that aswell Inuocation, as Fayth is due to God in a supreme, and peculiar māner, not cōmunicable to any creatures, to wit, as vniuersall Lord, and Creatour of all, which therefore cannot be so extenuated as to be the honour of a Saint, or demy-God.

11. Secondly it appeareth that the texts of holy scripture and the places of the ancient Fathers which he bringeth to proue, that fayth can haue no other obiect but
God, do proue nothing against me, who do clearely distinguish betwixt fayth in God, and fayth in Saints; wherof the former is properly fayth, hauing only Almighty God for obiect, as he is prima veritas; whereas the fayth in Saints, I sayd is fayth in some sort, implying only a beleif and confidence, that they may help vs by the goodnes of God, whose seruants they are. And therfore yt is manifest, that he hath abused me notably, not only in concealing and dissembling my discourse, but also in misconstruing, and peruerting it most maliciously & arguing against his owne false sense, and construction of it, as if it were myne, as you haue seene him doe many tymes heretofore, and shall see euen now againe in his next Answer to the instance which I brought out of S. Paul to Philemon, and S. Hieromes exposition therof. Thus then he sayth pag. 226. num. 3.

12. He belyes S. Hieromes commentary vpon the Epistle to Philemon, who speakes of no fayth to be reposed in Saints, but credence giuen to their doctrine only. So he, belying S. Hierome manifestly in two things (besides his lye touching me, when he sayth, that I bely S. Hieromes Commentary.) For S. Hierome expounding those words of S. Paul to Philemon, audiens charitatem
tuam & fidē quam habes in Domino Iesu, & omnes sanctos eius &c. saith, that there is no difficulty to interpret that which S. Paul said concerning Philemons Charity, which he had in Christ Iesus, and in all his Saints; but that the difficulty consisted in the interpretation of that which belongeth to his Fayth in Christ, and in his Saynts, and therefore he saith thus.

13. Non hoc quaeritur, quomodo camdem fidem in Christo Iesu habere quis possit, & in Sanctos eius, nor the question is how a man may haue the same faith in Christ Iesus, & his Saints: wherein I must desire M. Collins to note by the way, that S. Hierome makes the question heere not of some kind of fayth, or of fayth in some sort, that may be had in Saints (as I spake reseruedly) but of the same fayth, which we haue in Christ, how that may be also had in Saints, to which purpose S. Hierome also sayth further thus: Ad expositionem huius loci &c. For the exposition of this place, let vs take an example out of Exodus, Credidit populus Deo & Moysi seruo eius; vna at{que} eadem credulitas in Moysen refertur, & in Deum, the people belieued God and Moyses his seruant; one and the selfe same credulity or fayth is referred to Moyses, and to God, vt populus qui credebat in Dominum, aeque credidisse dicatur
in seruum, that the people which belieued in the Lord, may be sayd to haue belieued aswel in the seruant; hoc autem non solum in Moyse &c. and this to be vnderstood, not only in Mo • ses, but in al his Saints. Thus sayth S. Hierome.

14. Wherby it is as cleare as the Sunne, that M. Collins belyeth him grossely, in saying that he speakes of no fayth to be reposed in Saints, when he speaketh not only of some fayth, but also of the same fayth, that we haue in God, and in Christ Iesus; and albeit he explicateth how we may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints, yet he doth not deny that is the same fayth which we haue in God, but confirmeth it (not onely with that place of Exodus before mentioned but also) by the like consideration to be had of Charity, or loue to the Saints, or seruants of God (which is the same loue with the which we loue God, because we loue them for God) and therefore he sayth, that non est in Deum perfecta dilectio & fides, quae in ministres eius odio & infidelitate tenuatur, the loue and fayth in God, is not perfect, which is extenuated with hatred, and infidelity towards his seruants; giuing to vnderstand, that as we loue Gods seruāts, for the loue we beare to God, so also we may be sayd to belieue
in Gods seruants, for the fayth we haue in God; & as we do not loue God, if we loue not his seruants, so also it may be sayd, that we do not belieue in God, when we doe not belieue in his seruants.

15. And although he also explicateth this, yet his explication doth further confirme, that it is the same fayth which we haue in God; for thus he sayth: Hoc quod dico tale est &c. This which I say, is in this manner, or thus to be vnderstood. Doth a man belieue in God the Creatour? He cannot belieue in him except he first belieue that all thinges which are written in the Scriptures of his Saints, are true. So he. And then exemplifyeth the same by the Creation of Adam and Eue, by the translation of Enoch, by the deliuery of Noë from the deluge, by the departure of Abraham from his countrey and kindred, by the oblation of Isaac, and many other particuler historyes, in the bookes of the Iudges, and Kinges, and concludeth thus: Haec & caetera quae de Sanctis scripta sunt nisi quis vniuersa crediderit &c. Except a man belieue al this, and all the other thinges which are written of the Saints, he cannot belieue in the God of Saints. Thus sayth S. Hierome, and the reason heerof is, because God, who is Verity it selfe, & the Author of the Scriptures, is the obiect
of our fayth, and therefore he that doth not belieue what God hath reuealed in his Scriptures concerning his Saints, doth not belieue in God.

16. And this also S. Hierome doth yet further confirme by the sanctity which is in God, and in his seruants, affirming it to be candem sanctitatem, the selfe same sanctity (meaning no doubt that our sanctity is a participation of the diuine sanctity) and then he sayth finally of Philemon: Non putemus leuem esse Philemonis praedicationem &c. Let vs not thinke, that it is a light, or small praise of Philemon, si eamdem habet Sanctos fidem, quam & in Deum, if he had the same fayth in the Saints of holy men, which he had in God. So he. Loe then how cleare it is, that S. Hierome teacheth expresly, that we may be sayd to haue, not onely some kind of fayth in Saints, but also the same fayth that vve haue in God, wherein also it is to be noted, that there is not so much as one word of belieuing the doctrine of Saints, whereof M. Collins sayth S. Hierome speaketh only, albeit afterwards he is better aduised, saying that S. Hierome o • ly meant that the historyes which went of the Saints in Scripture were to be belieued, and credited. And if S. Hierome meant so, yea, and only so, then
truly he meant not (as M. Collins sayd before) only that credence is to be giuen to the doctrine of the Saints, for he could not mean them both, and yet but one of them only, and much lesse both this only, & that only; so as we shall haue some what a do to agree this poore fellovv with himselfe, especially seeing, that hauing sayd in his text (as you haue heard) that S. Hierome meant only, that credence is to be giuen to the doctrine of the Saints, he contradicteth the same with a marginall note iust ouer against it, contayning some part of S. Hieroms text, set down by me before, signifying that a man cannot belieue in God the Creatour, except he belieue that those thinges are true which are written in Scripture of the Saints, as of the creation of Adam, and Eue &c.

17. Whereby it is manifest euen by S. Hieromes owne wordes, that his only meaning was not, that credence should be giuen to the doctrine of Saints: for put the case he had sayd (as he doth not any where) that it is to be vnderstood by fayth in Saints, that their doctrine is to be belieued, yet it could not be vnderstood, that he meant so only, because he sayth expresly that he meant it of credence to be giuen to the verity of the Scriptures concerning Saints: neuerthelesse
M. Collins, concludeth his note in the margēt, with this question to me, VVher is conscience now M. F. T? wheras I may rather aske him, Where is both conscience, and wit now M. Collins? For truely if he had either of both, he would not contradict his text with his marginall note, and besides make no lesse then three notable lyes, within the space of three lines.

18. For first, wheras he sayth, that I belyed S. Hieromes commentary in my Adioynder, you see how false it is, seeing all that I say of S. Hierome is, that he discourseth amply vpon S. Pauls wordes, prouing that we may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints, which is most true, as you haue seene; for he teacheth not only that we may haue fayth in them, but also the same fayth, which we haue in Christ; and what blasphemy would this haue seemed to M. Collins, if I had sayd it, seeing that he accoūteth it an egregious blasphemy in me to say only, that we may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints in some sort, which I also explicated immediatly to consist in a beliefe, and confidence that they may help vs (as the seruants of God) and I added further, that this is not the fayth, which we haue in God, as in our Lord, and Creator; besides that, it is to be noted, that I do not
alleadge S. Hierome to proue or confirme my explication of the manner, how we may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints, because I knew full well, that it may be sayd in diuers respects (as it may appeare by the diuers expositions of the Apostles wordes to Philemon, & M. Collins himselfe setteth down one out of Haymo different from that of S. Hierome;) but I affirmed only that S. Hierome proueth amply out of S. Pauls words to Philemon, that we may be sayd to haue fayth in Saints, which you see is so true & euident, that it is extreme impudency in M. Collins to deny it; and therefore I hope it may passe for a notable lye, that he chargeth me to haue belyed S. Hieromes Commentary.
19. His second lye is, in saying that S. Hierome speaks of no fayth to be reposed in Saints, wheras he speaketh expresly and amply of some fayth, yea of the same fayth we haue in Christ.

20. His third lye is, that he affirmeth that S. Hierome speakes only of credence to be giuen to the doctrine of Saints, whereas he speaketh not one word of it, and much lesse only of it. And now add heerto his contradiction of himselfe in affirming that S. Hierome speaketh of two seuerall thinges with an only to both (which cannot possibly be
true of both; for if he speake only of the one, the other must needs be excluded,) let this, I say, be added to his three lyes, and to his ordinary dissimulation, and false construction of my text, and it wilbe euident that he hath neither conscience, shame, nor wit, in so much that if he vseth to talke, no more wisely then he writeth, it may be wondred that some body hath not begged him ere this to get his liuings, which they say are great; and not vnlike, for as the old Prouerbe sayth, fortuna fauet fatuis: but this shall suffice for this point, and now to proceed.

21. M. Collins doth admonish vs in the title of his sixth Chapter, about the Inuocation of Saints, that the Authorityes of the Fathers of the first and second rancke (according to the Bishops accurate diuisiō of the confused huddle brought by the Cardinall) are examined (for so speaketh very accuratly and pretily fine M. Collins) & therfore to the end you may know, what the accurate diuision of the Cardinalls confused huddle is, and what he meaneth by the first & second Ranke of Fathers; you shal vnderstand that my Lord of VVinchester vndertaking to answere the places of the Fathers alleadged by Cardinall Bellarmine touching the inuocation of Saints, deuideth them into three ranks
Respons. ad Apolog. pag. 39. §. Patrum. The first sayth he, is of those Fathers, qui verè Patres, sed non verè citantur, are truly Fathers, but not truly cited. The second of those, qui verè citantur, sed suspectae fidei, are truly cited, but of no sound credit. And the third of those, qui & verè citantur, sed nihil ad rem, which are truely Fathers, and also are truly cyted, but nothing to the purpose.

22. Thus indeed sayth my Lord of VVinchester more accurately (to vse M. Collins his fine word) then truly, as I haue made it euident inough in my Adioynder, concerning all the Cardinalls allegations, notwithstanding all the false, and fraudulent endeauours eyther of my Lord himselfe in his glosses, and interpretations of the sayd places, or of his Champion M. Collins in defence of his Lordship, wherof I dare remit the Iudgment to any indifferent and learned Reader, that shal read my Adioynder, and compare it with his Answere, and not take my wordes and sense, as he doth deceiptfully giue them, by patches, and snatches, neuer laying downe my whole context, whereby the force of my answers, and arguments are neuer fully or truly vnderstood, as it hath sufficiently appeared hitherto through out the precedent Chapters,
and will appeare no lesse clearely in this, by the examination of his answers to such places of the Fathers, as I haue alleadged in defence of the Cardinall, wherof neuertheles I will examine only such as he hath gone about to answere with some notorious & inexcusable fraud, corruption, or lye; and will omit to discouer, and answere innumerable foole • yes and impertinencyes, as wel in those which I shall examine, as in the rest which I shall leaue vntouched; for otherwise I should make a huge volume, & tyre both the Reader and my selfe.

23. In the first rancke of the Fathers, which my Lord of VVincester sayth, are truly Fathers, but not truly cyted, the first was S. Basil, out of whose oration vpon the 40. Martyrs, the Cardinall cyted a most cleare, & pregnant place for the proofe of prayer to Saints, which my Lord of VVinchester chargeth the Cardinall to haue alleadged falsly and corruptly, because there is some difference in a word or two, betwixt the Greek and the Cardinalls Latin text; where as I haue shewed amply in my Adioynder, not only that the Cardinall cited truly, and exactly the words of the latin translation, but also, that the Latyn expresseth fully the
sense of the Greek, though the words do differ; and for the confirmation thereof, and the proofe that S. Basill did beleeue and clearely teach our Catholick doctrine, concerning the inuocation of Saints, I alledged another place of S. Basill out of an oration of his made in the feast of another holy Martyr, to wit S. Mammas, whereof I do meane now to examine the Answere of M. Collyns. And because he setteth not downe aboue two words of my text (to the end his false glosse theron might seeme the more probable) I must perforce put my Reader to the paynes, to read what I haue cited, and pressed at large out of S. Basill in my Adioynder touching that matter. Thus then I said pag. 223. num. 20.

24. And because M. Andrews may perhaps desire some further proofe that yt was the Custome in S. Basills tyme to pray to Martyrs, yea to inuocate them (for without that word there is no bargayn with M. Andrewes) let vs heare what S. Basil sayth of another holy Martyr, to wit, S.
