Mummas, vpon whome he made also another oration and sayth, as followeth, Memores estote martyris quotquot &c. Be ye myndfull of the Martyr as many of you, as haue enioyed him in your sleepe (he meaneth by some vision,
or apparition) as many as haue euen in this place had his help, to pray for you; or whomesoeuer (nomine aduocatus) he, being called vpon by name, hath assisted in his actions, or works; as many as he hath reduced to the right way when they went astray; as many as haue recouered their health by him; to whomesoeuer he hath restored their Children, reuiuyng them when they were dead; and finally as many of you as haue had your liues prolonged by him; gather all these togeather, and contribute the same, as yt were a common shot to the prayse of the Martyr &c.

p.q:
25. Thus sayth S. Basill, which I haue the more largely layd down, to the end thou maist see, good Reader, not only what benefits the deuout Christians in S. Basills tyme receiued by the intercession & prayer of Martyrs, but also that this holy martyr of whom he treateth did sometyme appeare to men by visions in their sleep, and that men vsed to inuocate him in their necessities, and thereby had his assistance; which is euident euen in the greeke text, where we read, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, whomsouer he (to wit the Martyr) hath assisted in his works, being called vpon by name; which words I hope M. Andrews
cannot deny to expresse a playn inuocation of the Martyr, & the good effect (I meane the help & assistance) that followed therof.

div.p: 26. Besydes that, it is also to be considered heer that S. Basill doth speak not only of assistance giuen by the holy martyr in the place where his reliques were kept (as when he sayth, Quotquot in hoc loco constituti &c. as many of you as heere in this place haue had his help in your prayers) but also of great fauours done by him in other places, as namely to wandring men, that had lost their way &c. And therefore I would gladly know heere of M. Andrewes in what manner these wandring men, or others that were absent from the monument and reliques of the Martyr, obtayned those fauours mentioned by S. Basill; yea and how they knew that the martyr had fauoured, and • elped them, if they had not first inuocated • im, and prayed particulerly vnto him; • or M. Andrewes cannot say in this case, as • e said in the former, that because God did • ew by miracles at the monuments of • e martyrs, that he heard mens prayers • ere, therefore men had, and might haue • course thither to pray to God for help, •• t not of the martyr himself; this deuice • ay cannot serue his turne.

p.q: 27. For how did the way-fayring man (who was far from the monument of the Martyr, and had lost his way) know that he was brought into it agayn by the help of the Martyr, but because he had reposed speciall confidence in him, yea, and recommended himselfe particulerly to his prayers, and assistance? in which respect S. Basill hauing vsed that generall speach, quibusqun{que}, ex nomine vocatus, adfuit &c. to whomsoeuer the Martyr had giuen assistance, being called vpon by name, doth particularize the fauors that many had receiued by the inuocation of him, saying that some had beene reduced to their right way, others restored to their health, others had recouered their dead children, and others againe obtayned prolongatiō of life, al which no doubt were things wel known to S. Basils Auditours to haue hapned in that manner to some or other amongst them, for otherwise he would not haue affirmed the same vnto them so confidently as he did.

28. This then being so, yt is euidēt by the testimony of S. Basill himselfe, that the custome, and practise of faythfull and Catholique people in his tyme, was to inuocate holy Martyrs, & saints by name,
whereupon it followeth that the recourse which Saint Basill saith was ordinary to the 40. Martyrs, included the inuocation of them, according to the common custome of that tyme.

div.p:
29. Thus farre are the words of my Adioynder, which I doubt not, good Reader but that thou seest, to be so pregnant, aswell in respect of S. Basils words, as of my inference thereupon, that thou doest meruaile, and much desire to see what deuise M. Collins will find to answer it, or to shift it of. Thus then he faith pag. 235. num. 14. To your number 29. sayth he (but he should say 20. for so it is in my Adioynder) Mammas was but vocatus, not inuocatus, nor aduocatus, as you translate it. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 saith S. Basill: & that might be by Apostrophe. Or, as if he should say Daniels God, not inuoking Daniel; so Mammas his God; we name his name, but wee do not inuocate him as our patron; only we shew we cōsent in religion with him, and in our ioynt seruice to the common Lord. As he that commaunded all men to worship Daniels God. Dan. 6.26. Does S. Basil say, that Mammas euer helpt him? I warrant you not. what then doth he els, but euen take aduan
• age of the honest peoples affectiō, towards
the deceased Champion, to establish them in the zeale of the true God, whom he serued and suffred for? So he, being very confident, as it should seeme that those who should read this his answer, shold neuer see the obiection in my Adioynder, I meane the words of S. Basill alleadged by me, & my explication thereof; for otherwayes, he would neuer haue beene so symple, & shameles to make this glosse, which S. Basills Text can by no meanes admit.

30. For how can this deuise of the inuocation of Mammas, his God, stand with the wordes of S. Basil
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whomesoeuer he (to wit Mammas) hath assisted in his workes being called vpon by name? Is it not cleare, that he who gaue the assistance was called vpon by name, or inuocated? in which respect S. Basil did particularize the fauours that many receaued of the Martyr, aswel in thei • children, as in their owne persons, and aswell abroad in their iourneyes, as at home and therefore whereas M. Collins doth car • at my translation of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , saying that i • should be vocatus, not inuocatus, nor aduocat •• , may well say, that Nodum in scirpo quaerit, h • makes a difficulty where there is none, a • it wilbe euident by adding that which h •
craftily left out, to wit, the verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth adfuit, that is to say, assisted by his presence; for what els could be vnderstood therby, but that the Martyr did affoard his presence, and assistance being by name deuoutly called vpon, or inuocated to that end? Whereby it is most manifest, that it was not an inuocation of Mammas his God, but Mammas himselfe, who being called vpon by name, gaue assistance by Gods will and ordinance.

31. But then sayth M. Collins, Does S. Basil say, that Mammas euer helpt him? I warrant you not. A wise question truly, and as wisely answered, with I warrant you not. For what if S. Basil did not say, that the Saint had helped him? Did he therfore lye, when he affirmed it of others? Could no man be helped by the Saint, if S. Basil were not? or is it credible, that so graue a Father would so seriously, and confidently haue spoken to the people of such graces and fauours done by the Saint to them, if it had not been notorious that diuers of them had experienced the same in themselues? for els what could he haue expected of them, but that they should haue laughed at him for his paynes? This therefore may passe for a solemne foolery of M. Collins, besides the egregious
cozenage of his Reader, in concealing S. Basils wordes, to make his owne impertinent, and improbable glosse the more probable, and currant; and finally as I concluded in my Adioynder, so also I conclude heere, that S. Basil approued, and imbraced our Catholike doctrine concerning the inuocation of Saints, and that the practise therof was cōmon in the Church in his tyme, and by him recommended to the people that were vnder his charge and gouernement.

32. But let vs now passe further, and see some more of his cozening tricks in the defence of another answere of my Lord of VVinchester, to the place of S. Basil before mētioned num. 23. alleadged by the Cardinall out of his Oration vpon the 40. Martyrs. And this I will examine the rather, because M. Collins chargeth me to haue shamfully belyed the Councell of Gangra, concerning that matter: but thou shalt see good Reader, that the lye will light, and lye so heauy on him, that it would vtterly crush his credit, if he had any. Thus then I said of my Lord of VVinchester in my Adioynder pag. 226 num. 25.

33. Now to say somewhat of his other answere which I mentioned in the beginning
he sayth, Aliud est narrare quid fiat, aliud statuere quid faciendum sit: it is one thing to declare what is done, and another thing to determine what should be done; giuing to vnderstand that albeit S. Basil in the place alleadged by the Cardinall declared that men vsed in his tyme to pray to Saints, yet the same doth not suffice to proue it to be lawful, except it be approued by some decree of S. Basil, & the other Fathers of that tyme: to which purpose he doth often inculcate the same, demaunding still some statute or decree of the Fathers; as I shal haue occasion to shew further heereafter. But heere I would be glad to know what kind of statute or decree he would haue in this question; for if he exact some decree of the Fathers assembled in a General or Prouinciall Councell, he flyeth, as I may say, out of the lists, to another manner of tryall thē the Cardinal offereth in this place, & then he himselfe seemeth to accept. Besides that he must expect such decrees frō the • omes of the Councels, where they are particulerly related, and not from the workes of the Fathers, who are not wont to set them downe, but vpon particuler occasions, now and then occurring.

34. To which purpose it is to be vnderstood,
that there were neuer any Coūcells assembled, or Synodicall statutes made concerning fayth, but by reason of matters controuerted with publicke trouble, scandal and danger to the Church; as the foure first generall Councells were called by reason of the heresyes of the Arians, Macedonians, Nestorians, and Eutychians, which at those dayes did exceedingly molest, and scandalize all the East Church; whereas the Inuocation of Saints being then publikely, and generally practised throughout the whole Church needed not to be confirmed by decrees of Synods, especially seeing it was not expresly denyed by any at that tyme. For albeit an abominable Arian Heretike called Eustachius did then impugne the publike honour done to Saints, by dedicaing Churches to them, & celebrating their feasts (for which cause a prouincial Councell was held at Gangra, where this his heresy, togeather with diuers others of his, was condemned, and all those anathematized who did contemne the Temples, and Monuments of Martyrs, and the assemblyes, & sacred oblatiōs which were made there) yet because this Heretike did not directly impugne the inuocation of Saints, the same was not directly, and expresly confirmed,
or mentioned in this Canon.

35. Thus sayd I in my Adionder. And now that you may fully know the state of the questiō betwixt him & me in this place and iudge therby the better of his fraudulent answere, you shall vnderstand, that whereas I haue sayd heere to my Lord of VVinchester, that if he exact a decree of some generall, or prouinciall Councell for prayer to Saints, in S. Basils tyme, he runneth out of the lists, to another manner of tryall then the Cardinall offereth; the reason is, because the Cardinall vndertooke only to proue by the testimony of the Fathers of the first 400. or 500. yeares, that the fayth of the Protestants touching the Inuocation of Saints, is not the fayth of the old Primitiue Church.

36. This appeareth euidently by the Cardinals owne words of his Apology pag. 11. §. Sequitur, where hauing signifyed that his Maiesty in his Preface admitted the three Creeds, the 4. first generall Councells and the vniforme doctrine of the first 400. (or as it is in the English copy 500. yeares) he declareth that amongst other points of Catholike Religion, his Maiesty condemneth prayer to Saints, and the veneration of Reliques, as superstitious: Whereupon
the Cardinall sayth: Accipiam intercessionem Sanctorum &c. I will take in hand the intercession of Saints, with the veneration of Reliques; which if I can shew to be approued by the vnanime consent of the Fathers of the first 400. or 500. yeares, I shall withall proue, that the fayth of the King of England is not the fayth of the Primitiue Church, but the deuises, and heresies of the late Innouatours. Thus sayth the Cardinall. Where it is cleare, that my Lord of VVinchester demanding a decree of the Fathers, for prayer to Saints, within the first 400. or 500. yeares, flyeth from the tryall which the Cardinall offereth, and my Lord ought to accept, and stand vnto, seeing his Maiesty admitteth it, whom my Lord hath vndertaken, and is bound to defend.

37. This being so, let vs now see, what M. Collins answereth to my Adioynder in his 229. pag. and 9. §. wherein he iugleth notably, not only in dissembling my text (which you see is ordinary with him) but also in wresting the sense & substance of it to far other purpose then euer I meant it, or can be any way gathered of it. Thus then he sayth of me. He sayes, There is no ordinance, or no decree, but in Councells. Let him bring them hardly then, let him cyte the Councels. Are not they Fathers, and multiplyed
Fathers? Wil his Maiesty refuse the Councells, wherin so many speake as one man, that is content to be ordered by the Fathers in singular, if the authority be pregnant, & the antiquity sufficient? Thus sayth M. Collins.

38. And now iudge, good Reader, how substantially he hath answered. I tell him that there needed no Canons of Coūcels for praying to saints at that tyme, yea and that there could be none, because the practise of it was then vniuersall, and there had not beene any such Controuersy or trouble in the Church about that point, that it might cause any decrees or Canons to be made cōcerning the same; & yet he very grauely bids me bring thē hardly then. Besides that, affirming as he doth, that his Maiesty is content to be ordered by the Fathers in singular, if their Authority be pregnant, and Antiquity sufficient; he graunteth that which moued the Cardinall to produce the testimonyes of S. Basil, and other Fathers of the first 500. yeares (to wit because his Maiesty did admit them) in which respect my Lord of VVinchester was also bound to stand vnto them, seeing he vndertooke to answere for his Maiesty; & therefore I had reason to charge him to fly
out of the lists, when he fled from the testimonyes of the Fathers, to the decrees of Councells; but M. Collins hath thought best to conceale all this, and as though I had sayd nothing to the purpose, vrgeth me (as my Lord did the Cardinal) to produce som Canons or Decrees. Can there be greater iuggling then this? Yet this is nothing to that which followeth.

39. He goeth on in the same Paragraf, saying thus of me. But how shamefully does he belye the Councell of Gangra? Neither is there any such thing in the proeme there, nor yet in the Canons. Only a corruption is crept into the Proem, which is nothing material neither, though it wer graunted. See the greeke at Paris, of Tilius his edition, see the greeke copies. And is to meet at Churches, or not to shunne assemblyes in Basilicis Martyrū, all one with the Inuocation of Saints, now become? Why should we not rather thinke their priuate Masse cōdemned vnder a Priest, & his boy in the 6 Canon of that Councell? Thus saith he, and then goeth forward, most idly, cyting 6. or 7. Canons more of that Councell, against some other points of the Catholike Religion, being stale obiections, which haue been answered ouer and ouer by our
writers, and proued no way to concerne vs, as he may see in Cardinall Bellarmine, or any other Catholike Author, that writeth of these Controuersies; for which cause I omit to answere him concerning them, as also because I haue resolued not to deale in this Chapter with his fooleryes, and by-questions (as these are) but only to discouer his fraudes, falsities, and lyes.

40. And therefore now to come to the discouery of this: you haue seene heer first that he doth not set down any one word of my text cōcerning that Councel of Gangra: secondly, that because I quote in the Margent the Proeme of that Councell, and the 20. Canon, he sayth, that there is a corruption crept into the Proeme, thogh nothing materiall; and for the proofe heereof, he posts vs ouer to Paris to see the Greek there, without telling vs what the corruption is, or wherein it consisteth. Lastly he insinuateth that I alleadge this Councell to proue prayer to Saints, saying, Is to meete in Churches, or not shunne assemblyes in Basilicis Martyrum, all one with the inuocation of Saints now become? So he. And afterwards again more plainly: And do they tell vs, sayth he, of the Coūcell of Gangra, in which there is not one sillable, neither in preface, nor bulke of praying to Saints? Thus
sayth he, as if I cyted it to proue prayer to Saints.

41. Now then let vs see, who hath lyed shamefully, I or he; I said that the Fathers in that Councel did anathematize all those who contemned the monuments of Martyrs, and the assemblies, and the sacred oblations which were made there. This is euident in the 20. Canon which is this: Si quis arrogantia v • ens, & martyrum, congregationes abhorrens & sacra quae in eis celebrātur, & eorum memorias accuset, anathema sit. If any man out of arogancy, and hatred to the cōgregations of the Martyrs (that is to say to the Assemblyes, made at the Tombes of Monuments of the Martyrs) do accuse (or condem • e) the holy rites which are celebrated there, and the memoryes of them, let him be accursed. Thus sayth that Canō, wherto M Collins taketh no exception, and therefore it sufficeth alone to iustify my assertion, and condemne him of a monstrous lye, in saying, that I do shamefully bely the Councell of Gangra; wheras I say no more of it, then that which is found there expresly in the 20. Canon. And wheras he sayth that there is no such thing in the Pro • me nor yet in the Canons; if he meane, by no such thing, that there is
nothing there touching the celebration of the feasts, & memoryes of Martyrs (which was all that I affirmed) it is also a lye, nolesse monstrous then the former. And if he say that he meant it only of prayer to saints (as that there is no such thing in the Councell) albeit he say true in that respect, yet he belyeth me shamefully in another, & cozeneth his Reader intollerably, affirming that I alleadge that Councell to proue prayer to Saints, wheras I signify the contrary in expresse words saying, that because Eustachius did not directly impugne the Inuocation of Saints, the same was not directly confirmed, or mentioned in that Councell. Behould then what an impudent fellow this is, who to proue one lye in me, maketh no lesse then two or three himself, as also you see he did the like before, charging me most falsely to haue belyed Saint Hieromes Commentary, when he himselfe made no lesse then three euident lyes within three lynes: so as if he come at any tyme where there is lying for the whetstone, it wilbe his infallibly; for I thinke he will hardly meet with his match in that faculty.

42. But let vs now proceed, and see some more of his legier-de-main, & his notable cozenage, concerning a place of Saint Ephrem, alleadged by my Lord of VVinchester
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
against the Cardinall, and answered by me in my Adioynder, which indeed I would haue omitted for breuityes sake, as I do many other things, were it not, that I stand some way obliged to say somewhat vnto it, because I promysed in my Adioynder to giue further satisfaction, when I should heare further news from my Lord touching that matter, which now I haue heard by M. Collins, who hath not only answered for his Lordship in that poynt, after his wonted manner, but also hath deliuered me a particuler message from him touching my self, which therfore I cannot leaue vnāswered. And forasmuch as M. Collins hath also here (as he is wont) dissembled my whole text, and only picked out of it heere and there a word or two, to carp at, I must be forced as I haue been diuers tymes, to lay down the words of my Adioynder, concerning so much of this matter, as I meane to bebate with him, that is, so much as toucheth the fraud, that both he and my Lord haue vsed therein. Thus then I sayd in my Adioynder Chap. 6. pag. 239. num. 43.

43. Now let vs see what he sayth to the second ranke of Fathers, which he graunteth to be truly cyted, but not to be of sound credit. The first of these is Saint Ephram,
out of whom the Cardinal alleadgeth these words: Precamur beatissimi Martyres &c. we beseech you most blessed Martyrs, that you will vouchsafe to pray vnto our Lord for vs wretched sinners, that the grace of Christ may come vnto vs. To this M. Andrews answereth diuers wayes: first he taketh exception against the translation; both because the Author thereof was one of ours (whose fidelity and credit he saith hath beene long since cracked) and also because the originall (which is in greek) was, saith he, lately taken out of a grot, and therefore is fidei cripticae, of obscure credit. So it pleaseth him to make himselfe merry with the word Crypta, for that Vossius the translatour signifieth in his Epistle to the Reader in the beginning of the first Tome that he had a speciall help for his translation, by two very auncient manuscripts or written copyes of Saint Ephraems works, which are to be seene in Crypta ferrata (a famous monastery neer to Rome called commonly in Italian Grotta ferrata) of which manuscripts the one was written in the yeare of our Lord 531.

44. But what cause had M. Andrews to iest at this? Sure I am that in the iudgment of any indifferent man, it may serue for no smal iustification of the translatour that
he fortifyeth his translation with the authority of such an auncient manuscript, written aboue eleuen hundred yeares ago, and yet extant to be seene so neere to Rome, where his Tomes were printed, especially seeing that there is such continuall recourse, and confluence thither from Rome (by reason of the celebrity of that monastery) that he might well think he should quickly be discouered for an impudent, & notable lyar, in case he should faygne the same. And therefore for his further iustification in this poynt, he also directeth his Reader to the very classe where the said manuscripts are, to be found in the library of Grotta ferrata, to wit, vnder the title of these Greeke letters Ω. and Π. Besydes that he declareth also further that he conferred the same copyes with diuers others which he saw, and are yet to be seene in the Vatican at Rome, and in the library of Cardinall Sforza.

45. So that these particularityes, being considered, no man can with any reason, or without extreme malice, imagine any fraudulent meaning in the Translatour, seeing he remitteth his translation to the examination of so many learned men, as Rome continually affoardeth, who
might withall facility conuince him of fraude, if he hah vsed any: and therefore Maister Andrewes sheweth more malice, then witt, in this exception, as also in that he reiecteth the translation, because the Authour thereof was a Catholique. For albeyt he say; that Catholikes haue lost their credit in matters of that kinde; yet I hope the discreet Reader (who hath already seene by many examples how little credit M. Andrews deserueth) will not easiy beleiue him without some further proofe then his bare word. And this it seemeth he himselfe feareth, and therefore seeketh another shift in these words: Longè aliter Tom • primo germanus Ephraem &c. The true Ephraem in his first Tome, (where he prayeth, and doth not make orations) saith farre otherwayes, calling vpon God alone in euery prayer, not so much as naming any Saint, yea there he speaketh to God in this manner: Ad te. ad praeter te neminem orationem facio, to thee, to none but thee I make my prayer. So he. Not quoting any particuler treatise, or chapter where the words which he cyteth are to be found; which by all likelyhood he omitteth of purpose the better to cloak a peece of cogery, which he may be worthily suspected to haue vsed in this poynt.

46. For whereas he mentioneth the first Tome of a true Ephraem, thou shalt vnderstand, good Reader, that there are no other workes of S. Ephraem extant in Latin, but only the three tomes aboue mentioned set forth by Vossius, except a little pamphlet contayning a few sermons translated by a Monke of Camaldula which cannot deserue the name of Tome; besids that, there is not any such prayer therein as he mentioneth, for ought I can find. And put the case, he could there shew the same wordes, which he cyteth, yet they may be so vnderstood, that they will make nothing for his purpose. For euen as Dauid, when he had cōmitted homicide, and sinned not only against God, but also against his neighbour, sayd neuerthelesse to Almighty God, Ti •• soli peccaui, I haue sinned against thee alone, because all sinne against man doth finally redound to God: euen so, for as much as all our prayer is finally directed to God the Author, and giuer of all grace, and goodnes, we may well say, we pray to none but to him, albeit we vse therein the interuention and assistance of Angells, Saints, or men, by whom we also pray to God, whē we craue, or procure their prayers to him for vs.

47. And in this sense, no doubt that manner of prayer is to be vnderstood, if any such be in S. Ephraem, or in any other ancient Father: for otherwise it should contradict the custome of the Apostle, who vsed to craue the prayers of the Romans, Ephesians, Thessalonians, and others to whom he wrote; as also al good Christians are wont to recommend themselues to the prayers one of another, and are warranted so to do by the Holy Scripture; so as I shall need to say no more concerning his true Ephraem, vntill he giue me further newes by whom he was translated, and published, how many Tomes there are of him, and in what part of his first Tome those wordes which he cyteth are to be found. Thus farre are the wordes of my Adioynder, wherin you see I speake amply (and probably also, as I thinke) in defence of the Latin edition, which we haue out of S. Ephraem translated by Vossius, and deuided into three Tomes, vrging him withall to iustify his allegation of the first Tome of his pretended true Ephraem, which I beseech thee, good Reader to note wel, and remember that thou maist the better iudge of his answere, which is this pag. 241. num 22.

48. Numb. 46. You say a few sermons of Ephrem
cannot deserue the name of a Tome; yet
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and resoluit Tomum, or scidit Tomum, often in the Councells, not for a huge Volum, but what scrole soeuer. VVhy may not the Bishop speake after that manner? Though you cannot de • y, that Ephrems edition is distinguished by Tomes, as they are properly so called, vnles you be a very stranger to the matter. And giue vs leaue to suspect your Criptik Authors of your owne editions when we call for Fathers, that is, no bastard Fathers to determine Controuersies. So he. With more which you shall heare anone. In the meane tyme you see heere how he iugleth, and cauilleth about the word Tome, whether it may signify a little booke, or a huge volume; asking me why the Bishop may not call a little pamphlet or booke, a Tome; as if my Lord had spoken of a Tome in that sense, and that I had quarrelled with his Lordship for the same: whereas you see his Lordshippe quoted, the first Tome of the true Ephraem, wherby he signifyeth euidently, that is was not some single Pamphelet, but a worke that cōsisted of more Tomes then one; els what meant he by the first Tome? in which respect I sayd, that there are not extant any workes of Ephraem in Latin, but only the three Tomes translated by Vossius, except a little pamphlet of Sermons &c. and yet M.
Collins tells me, that I cannot deny that Ephraems edition is distinguished by Tomes, vnlesse I be a very stranger to the matter. Do you see then how idlely he tatleth, and what strang newes he tells me? to wit, that Ephraems works are distinguished by Tomes, as if I doubted of it, when I tould him so expresly my selfe, saying also that there are three Tomes of them, translated, and set forth by Vossius? Do you thinke this fellow is well in his wits?

49. But you will say, that he taketh exception to those Tomes, as being cripticae fidei. It is true indeed, for so he doth; but why then doth he not tell vs some particulers of the true tomes of true Ephraem which my Lord quoted, and he acknowledgeth? Why then doth he not tell vs who translated them, or who set them forth, or where they were printed, or where they are to be found, if they be not those of Vossius, which is the matter in question betwixt my Lord and me; for his Lordship cyteth the first Tome of a true Ephraem, and I tell him that there are none but the three tomes set forth by Vossius, and desire to heare newes of the other if there be any such. And now M. Collins tells me newes, of an edition of Ephraem distinguished by Tomes,
whereof he saith I cannot be ignorant: so as by that reason be meaneth the Tomes set forth by Vossius, for I tould him before, and so I tell him stil, that I know no other (neither can he in truth meane any other, because there are no other extant) whereupon it should follow also that the first tome which my Lord quoted should be the first of those three before mentioned; which neuerthelesse, both my Lord, and he do reiect as being cripticae fidei. So as you see how distractedly he talketh contradicting himselfe, and my Lord, except he can tell me of some other edition of S. Ephraems works deuided into Tomes then that of Vossius, which yet he neither doth, nor euer shallbe able to do.

50. But will you see how he defendeth my Lord, or rather how he payeth him home, in that which followeth: The Bishop (sayth he) was not only true in quoting Ephrem, but quoted him out of the originall Arabique that he wrote in. Not in coggery therefore as you call it, but so much the more to be respected, and credited afore your grottae, or criptae. So he. And is it so indeed M. Collins? Did the Bishop (as you call him) quote S. Ephraem out of the originall Arabique wherein he wrote? Ergo not out of the first tome of Ephraem, as his Lordship expresly
affirmed; for his works are not printed in the Arabique tongue, neither are there any manuscripts of them but in Greeke; for ought I could euer find or heare. And wheras M. Collins sayth that he wrote in the Arabique tongue, it is more I thinke, then he can proue, or is probable, seeing he was a Syrian borne, and therefore it is most like, that he wrote in the Syriacke tongue, although some of his workes, or perhaps all may haue beene translated into the Arabique tongue. But it litle importeth for my Lords excuse in what language he wrote, seeing that the allegation of the place, euen out of the Arabique, whence my Lord professeth to take it, is fraudulēt aboue measure, as it shal appeare euen by the Arabique words, which M. Collins setteth downe, giuen him by my Lord himselfe for his iustification in this point. Thus then he sayth pag. 242. num. 25.

51. You aske the Bishop who published Ephrem, how many Tomes of him &c. in which matter we are not scrupulous to shape you an answer to the full, though it were more that you asked: Of Tomes before. So he. Heere note by the way good Reader, what answere he shapeth me, & how wel to the ful, concerning the Tomes of Ephraem, seeing that he remitteth me only to that, which he hath sayd of Tomes before,
wherin how idly he hath iāgled you haue seen, so lately, that I need not repeate it, and therfor to go on with his text, thus he saith further: The wordes are these, which willingly I would set downe both in the Arabique, and the Hebrew, as I haue receaued them from the Bishop, if we had such caracters at hand. But in the Latin thus, both for form, & meaning. Illaica we shaueca lam atlabu. i. Ad te & praeterquā ad te non facio orationē, in English thus, for the satisfaction of euery Reader, your selfe & all, good M. F. T. To thee and but to thee to none, I make my prayer. The Bishop cyted it out of a manuscript, which he keepeth yet to be seene vpon any occasion, called the Diurnal of the Maronits, a certaine kind of Monks in a Monastery on mount Sinah. VVhich booke was printed at Rome Anno 1584. at the commandment of Gregory the 13. by Dominicus Basa in Syriaque caracters, though it be in the Arabicke tongue, vnder the name of the prayer of S. Ephrem. Thus sayth M. Collins, wherin truely he hath don me a great pleasure; for now knowing, where my Lord had his text, I shallbe able as I hope, to shape his Lordship a better answere, and more to the full, then M. Collins hath shaped me a little before, concerning the tomes of Ephraem.

52. You shall therefore vnderstand, that albeit I know not how my Lords text
is in his manuscript (which M. Collins sayth his Lordship keepeth to shew vpon any occasion) yet sure I am, that in the booke, which he calleth the Diurnall of the Maronites, printed at Rome, Anno 1584. I find it farre otherwise, both in wordes and sense; for whereas he alleadgeth the Arabique wordes thus: Illaica we shaueca lam atlabu, the three first are not in the Arabique text of S. Ephraems prayer, in the aforesayd diurnal of the Maronits mentioned by M. Collins, and therefore it seemeth, that because Illaica or rather Ellaica signifyeth ad te: my Lord thought best to adde it to the Arabique text, to iustify his former translation in his answere to the apology, where he hath the Latin thus: Ad te, ad, praeter te, neminem facio orationem, and as for the other two words, to wit, we shaueca, the former, as it is there placed before shaueca, hath no sense, neither serueth to any purpose; for albeit u. (which signifyeth, and) is pronounced, uue, when the word following beginneth with the vowell e. (as it is also pronoūced uua, when the vowell a. followeth immediatly) yet going before a word beginning with a consonant (as it doth heer before shaueca) it is not chāged any way in sound or pronunciation; and therfore it reteyneth the natural sound
and forme of the letter u. so as uue before shaueca hath no sense, or cōstruction: wherby it appeareth, either that M. Collins hath not well learned his lesson of my Lord, or els that my Lord himselfe is but a smatterer in the Arabique tongue; and that therefore meaning to make Arabique to iustify his false allegation of his Latin text, he erred, & made false Arabique. And this may be obserued not only in the word uue, but also in shaueca which followeth it, & is no true Arabique word, although it hath some affinity in soūd at least with suaca, which is in the text of S. Ephraem, as shalbe declared more at large after a while. In the meane tyme thou shalt vnderstand good Reader, that to the end I may speake vpon good ground, I haue vsed extraordinary diligence to find out the sayd Diuinall, and to see, and consider the wordes, and text it selfe with the aduise and iudgment not only of some Italians who haue very exact skill in the Arabique tongue, but also of the Maronits themselues, who doe naturally speake that language, and reside in the College of that Nation heere in Rome, in whole library I found the booke mentioned by M. Collins, printed in the yeare 1534. in the Arabique tongue, thogh in Syriac Caracters: in which
booke I find also the whole passage, which M. Collins hath layd downe (for he cyteth 7. or 8. lines togeather, as you shall heare further after a while) all agreeing very wel with this printed copy, except only those few wordes which most concerne this Controuersy, and a few more immediatly following left out by him, because (belike) they made nothing for his purpose.

53. Therefore to the end, as well the truth as my Lords fraud and his champions, may the better appeare, I will first set downe the whole text of S. Ephraem, as M. Collins cyteth, & trāslateth it, & afterwards I will shew the difference betwixt that, & the true Arabique, as it is in the printed book which M. Collins mētioneth. Thus he sayth: The words before, and after are these: Accipe deprecationem meam o Domine &c. Receaue my prayer, O Lord, not for my righteousnes, but for thy mercyes sakes; and in the multitude of thy bountyes, and of thy compassions, saue my soule, which is taken prisoner of death. Remember me o Lord, and although I haue sinned, and am wounded with deadly wounds, non precor quemquam praeter te, yet do I not pray to any besides thy selfe: but to thy mercy and bounty I betake my selfe, because thou art that Lord God which comprisest (or imbracest) all thinges, and thy power is ouer all that liueth and
breatheth. Thus doth M. Collins alleadge the context with the circūstances of the place cyted by my Lord.

54. And indeed the Arabique agreeth therewith, vntill it come to the wordes, Non precor quemquam praeter te, I do not pray to any besids thy selfe, which are farre different in the Arabique thus, Flam et lob suaca, that is to say, non precabor equalem tibi, I will not pray to any equall to thee: which Saint Ephraem explicateth also further, saying immediatly thus, Vlam absot idai ala alah gairaca, that is to say in English, And I will not stretch forth my handes to any God, besides thee, which last sentence is wholy left out by M. Collins; so as if we add the same to the former which my Lord alleadgeth, & change praeter te, besides thee, into equalem tibi, equal to thee, it wilbe euident that S. Ephraem did not meane to exclude prayer to any, but to the false Gods; for then the whole sentence wilbe this, I will not pray to any equall to thee, neither will I extēd (or stretch forth) my hands to any God besides thee. And then he goeth forward as M. Collins hath it thus: But to thy mercy, and bounty I betake my selfe &c. This then being so, I leaues it to the Reader to iudge, how well M. Collins hath iustifyed my Lords allegation; seeing that now it
falleth out, that as his Lordship did then corruptly translate those wordes, praeter te insted of aequalem tibi; so now Maister Collins hath fraudulently alleadged the whole passage, leauing out that which immediately followed, and is very necessary to make the Reader vnderstand Saint Ephrems meaning therein.

55. And whereas all the controuersy concerning this sentence consisteth in the words, praeter te, as whether the same be truely translated out of the Arabicque; it is to be vnderstood that the word shaueca, which M. Colins giueth vs to signify praeter te, is no Arabique word, as I haue said before, although it commeth neere to the Arabicque; for the true Arabicque word which is in Saint Ephrems Text, is suaca, and signifieth equalem tibi, equall to thee; for sua signifieth equall, and ca being added vnto it, maketh it, equall to thee: and for the proofe thereof it chaunced, that an Italian very learned in the language being demaūded what suaca signified, and hauing answered that it signified equalis tibi, called to him to a Maronite who passed by at the same tyme, and asked him, what signified equalis in his language, & he answered suae, and being further asked what is equalis tibi, he
said suaca, besides that the very Dictionaries of the Hebrew, Syriake, and Arabicke do clearly confirme it, as the Lexicon pentaglotton col. 182. a. where it apeares that the hebrew verbe shaua (which signifyeth aequalis suit) is in the Calday also shaua, in the Syriaque sheua, & in the Arabique saui, and that it hath for the nowne in the Hebrew sheua, in the Calday shaua, in the Syriaque sheui, and in the Arabique sua, all signifying aequalis.

56. Now then by the consonance, & conformity of the other three languages, Hebrew, Calday, and Syriaque, with the Arabique, it is euident that the proper and naturall signification of sua in the Arabique, is aequalis; neuertheles I will not deny but that it is taken sometymes (though vnproperly) for praeter: but why my Lord should leaue the proper, and common signification of the word, to take the vnproper, I see no re • son, especially seeing that gairaca which followeth a little after in the Arabique Text of S. Ephraem doth properly signify praeter te, as in those words, which M. Collins left out, to wit, Non extendam manus meas ad Deum prater te, I will not extend my hands to a God besides thee. There I say, praeter te, is gairaca in the Arabique, and therfore it is likely that if S. Ephraem had meant to say, Non precor quēquam
praeter te, he would not haue vsed suaca, but gairaca, as he did afterwards. Moreouer if suaca should signify there praeter te, the sense should be vnperfect, for so the Latin translation shoulbe Non precor praeter te, without quenquam, which M. Collins addeth, or ad neminem as my Lord translateth it (who hath it thus, Ad te, ad praeter te neminem orationem facio;) whereas in the Arabique text of S. Ephraem, there is no word which signifyeth quenquam, or ad neminem, but translating suaca, aequalem tibi, the sense is perfect word for word, thus, Lam et lob suaca: Non precabor aequalem tibi: lastly the word, which M. Collins hath giuen vs in his Arabique for praeter te (to wit shaueca) may suffice to confound my Lord and him; for shaue (which according to my Lords translation should signify praeter) being no Arabique, but an Hebrew word, signifyeth aeq •• lis and not praeter, being deriued from the root shaua: so as albeit my Lord, or M. Collins, haue erred in the Arabique, yet I may say by the errour, as one sayd by a stone, which he had cast at a dog, & did hit his stepdame, that it did not hit amisse for me, seeing that his Lordship missing the Arabique, & lighting by chance vpon the Hebrew hath confuted himselfe; and therefore I conclude, that by all this
it is manifest, that his corruption of S. Ephraem is inexcusable as well for the text, as for the sense,

57. But now to do my Lord, and M. Collins a pleasure, if I should allow their trāslation of praeter te, what would they gaine therby? Truely nothing at all, for now that we see the circumstances laid downe by M. Collins, it appeareth euidently that my Lord did fraudulently cyte those words of S. Ephraem, concealing the sayd circumstances, to the end he might with more colour apply them to his purpose against prayer to Saints, which is no way preiudiced therby for the circumstances do shew that S. Ephrē did craue of Almighty God the saluatiō of his soule by the cure of his deadly wounds, that is to say, by the remission of his sinnes, and grace to heale the same; and this he craued of God, as of th • Omnipotent Lord of all, who only can giue grace, remission of sinne, and saluation; so as S. Ephraem had great reason to craue it of him only, and therefore might well haue sayd, non precor quemquam praeter te, I do not pray to any but to thee, that is to say, to obtayne remission of my sinnes, not knowing any equall to thee, or any other God but thee, and therefore to thy only mercy, and bounty I betake
my selfe, because thou art the Lord God of all, & hast power ouer all creaturs. Thus I say, S. Ephraem might with great reason say, and so all Catholikes in like case, neuer demanding grace, or remission of sinnes, or saluation of any but of God himselfe, who is the only giuer thereof; albeit we craue the same of him by the intercession of Saints, and of men; and do also beseech Saints, and men to help vs to obtayne it of him, yea and pray also to Angells, and Saints to fauour, and help vs in such other things as by the goodnes of God are in their power to bestow vpon vs, but not as Gods, or equall to God, but as his dearest seruants, and fauorits, whose ministery and seruice he vseth to the help and comfort of his Creatures; so as to that purpose which S. Ephraem prayed, we pray to none but to God.

58. You see then what good seruice, M. Collins hath done vnto my Lord heereby, laying downe the text of S. Ephraem at large, seeing it appeareth euidently therby that my Lords allegation of those few words which he cyted, was very fraudulent: wherto if we add now his Lordships false translation of suaca, and his addition of Illaica to the Arabique text (which he promised
to alleadg entirely) I know not what more may be desired to shew the egregious fraud, and malice of them both; so as heerby it may be iudged, whether M. Collins had any reason to say afterwards as he doth viz. that this is pregnant inough to iustify the Bishop from being such a falsary, as (I) would make him, & that (I) may rather feare the imputation of it my selfe, as if the two letters F. T. were as many markes in my forhead to know a False Theefe thereby. Thus indeed he sayth, but how reasonably let the Reader iudge, seeing that insteed of iustifying my Lord from the imputation of falsity, he himselfe hath increased the suspition & fortifyed the imputation thereof by his diligent addition of the circumstances, which doe euidently discouer my Lords fraud. And whereas it is his pleasure to make vse of the letters F. T. to marke me in the forhead for a False Theefe, he might haue sayd it with some reason, if he could haue charged me truely to haue stolne so much as one word or syllable, now, or at any tyme, out of any sentence, which might make against me; whereas you see he hath pilfred, and stolne out of S. Ephraems text a whole sentence immediatly following the words which my Lord alleadged, and doe import much for the explication of S. Ephraems
meaning; and therefore I remit it to the iudgment of the indifferent Reader, whether he or I, doe better deserue to be branded in the forhead with the marke of a False Theefe.

59. Although this might suffice to discouer the intollerable fraud of my Lord, & M. Collins; yet to make the same more cleare then the Sunne at noone day, it is to be vnderstood, that there are in the sayd Diurnal (which M. Collins alleadged) certaine salutations, with prayers to the Blessed Virgin Mary, and to S. Michael, almost immediatly before the prayer of S. Ephraem, out of the which my Lord took his sentēce; & in one of the sayd salutations to the B. Virgin (which is to be seen there fol 167.) there are these words towards the end therof pa. 173. Peace be to thee by whome we were deliuered from the fire of hell, O crowne of the faythfull that do combat or fight; peace be to thee, who art the holy shippe, and the port of saluation; peace be to thee to whome the Angell Gabriel was sent, who saluted thee saying reioyce O Virgin, the Lady of womē; reioyce o full of grace, our Lord is with thee, blessed art thou among women, and blessed is the fruit of thy wombe, because he that was borne of thee, is called Holy, & the Son of God. PRAY TO HIM for the remission of our sinnes. Thus endeth that salutation, & prayer
to the Blessed Virgin.

60. In like manner S. Michael is saluted thus pag. 204. Peace be to thee Michael the head of the Angels: Peace be to thee Michael the Lord of great miracles; peace be to thee Michael the Archangell, the intercessour of mankind before the Trinity. Pray for vs, O Michael the Archangell, that our sinnes may be forgiuen vs for thy prayers, which are acceptable to our Lord. And after this there followeth a short prayer to Almighty God fol 205. which endeth thus: Heare our cry by the intercession of our Lady, and pure Virgin, and of S. Peter the Apostle, and of S. Nicholas, and of all Saints. Amen. And immediatly after this followeth sol. 207. the prayer of S. Ephrē, alleadged by my Lord & M. Collins, which prayer also endeth thus, fol. 224: Heare O Lord the prayer of thy seruant by the intercession of thy Saints, which art eternall, & blessed for euer & euer. Amē.

61. Now M. Collins, I would gladly heare what my Lord and you will say to al this; for if this Diurnall be S. Ephraems work or any part of the first tome of the true Ephraem (which my Lord quoted expresly for the sentence which he alleadged) then either my Lord did not vnderstand Saint Ephraem well, or els S. Ephrem contradicted that sentence in his practise, praying to others besydes Almighty God, as namely
to our blessed Lady, and Saint Michaell. And if this be not Saint Ephraems worke, then it doth not iustify my Lords allegatiō of that sentence, out of the first tome of the true Ephrem; besides that it seemeth strange to me that my Lord could see that one sentence, consisting only of 5. or 6. words, & could not see in the same Diurnal those long prayers to our Blessed Lady, and Saint Michaell a little before. Is not this to be willfully blynd? How well may the saying of our Sauiour to the Pharisees Ioan. 9. be applyed to my Lord, and you: Si caeci essetis &c. if you were blynde, you should haue no sinne, but now that you say we see, your sinne doth remayne.

62. Well then, to come now to the message which it hath pleased my Lord to send me, M. Collins sayth to me thus num. 22. pag. 241. As for Vossius (sayth he) the Translatour, and Prefacer, and setter forth, with whom you are so much delighted; as his name in Dutch (which was his naturall language) signifyes a Fox, so you are the Goose for your labour, if you credit him to farre: and this as I was wished from him that vnderstands these things best, so I tel it you. Thus saith M. Collins, and I accept the message very gratefully; and to the end I may returne the answere to my Lord with speed, by the
same messenger. I beseech you M. Collins as you brought me the message, so also to deliuer the answere, and to signify to his Lordship from me, these points, with all due respect to his person.

63. First, that his Lordship should haue done much better for his owne reputation, to haue sent his message by a wiser man: for as the prouerb saith. He that sends a foole on his errand, must goe after and do it himselfe.

64. Secondly that I rest as little satisfied, as before, concerning the first tome of the true Ephraem, which his Lordship alleadgeth: for albeyt you tell me of an edition of Ephraem, distinguished by Tomes, yet you neyther tell me by whome it was set forth, nor where it was printed, nor where it is to be found; neyther doe you say that his Lordship tooke yt out of the first tome of that edition, but out of a manuscript which was printed in Rome such a yeare, & called a Diurnall, as indeed it may be well called, being but a little prayer book, conteyning diuers prayers for morning, euening, midnight, and the canonicall houres, with the 7. penitentiall psalmes, and amongst the rest there are only 5. or 6. prayers with the title of Saint
Ephraem: so as that Diurnall cannot be called Saint Ephraems prayer, as Maister Collins calleth it, saying: That the Booke goeth vnder the name of Saint Ephraems Prayer; and much lesse is if the first come of the true Ephraem (as my Lord quoted it) and if it be Saint Ephraems worke, then the prayers there to our B. Lady, and Saint Michael, conuince my Lord of inexcusable fraud; and so you may tell his Lordship from me, and that he might haue seene those prayers, as well as that short sentence, if he had not beene wilfully blynd.

65. Thirdly that his Lordships addition of Illaica to the Text, and his translation of suaca, which he interpreteth praeter te, is also most fraudulent; which later indeed I suspected before, albeit I could not charg his Lordship directly with it, vntill now that you M. Collins haue directed where to fynde it, as I haue done by your good help, and therefore how much he is behoulding to you for this, I leaue it to his Lordships iudgment.

66. Fourthly you may also tell his Lordship for his better information, that if he do beleiue that the Maronits (out of whose Diurnall he pretendeth to haue taken the sentence) are Monks in a monastery
on Mount Sinah (as you say they are) his Lordship is much deceiued; for the Maronits are a people dwelling on Mount Libanus many dayes iourney from mount Sinah; and albeit there are monks among them, as also on mount Sinah, yet they are of different orders, and cōtryes; for the Maronits on mount Libanus are of S. Antonies order, and those of Sinah, being Greeks, are of S. Basills order, and are not called Maronitae, but Melchitae. Thus much by the way for my Lords instruction, and yours.

67. Fiftly, that put the case his Lordships translation were true, and that S. Ephraem had said, Non precor quemquam praeter te, yet his applicatiō therof against prayer to Saints, is neither to the purpose, nor voyd of fraud; seeing that the circumstances (which his Lordship concealed, & you M. Collins haue now layd down little to his honour) do manifestly shew, that the place doth nothing preiudice prayer to saints, for the causes signifyed so lately, that I need not to repeate them now: and therefore wheras you M. Collins, make such account of that sentence, that you haue prefixed it before the second part of your book (where you professe to treate purposely of prayer to Saints) setting it downe vnder the title
thus. Ephraem. To thee, and but to thee, to none I make my prayer; you may do well to remoue it from thence, and set it amongst the errours and faults escaped in the print, or rather to put it vp in your pocket, that there may be no more memory of it, nor consequently of my Lords forgery, and your folly.

68. Sixtly, whereas my Lord doth reiect the edition of S. Ephraems workes, translated by Vossius, yea and (as you tell me also afterwards pag. 243. lin. vlt.) his Lordship will auouch it (howsoeuer the first tome of Vossius his edition may be of the true Ephraem) yet the rest are no more Ephraems works then his owne; wheras I say you affirme this in my Lords name, you may tell his Lordship, if you please, that albeit I acknowledg him to be a man of great dignity (as being Counsailour to the Kings Maiesty my soueraigne, & therfore I do beare him all due respect) yet I cannot acknowledge his authority to be so great, that his bare word shall stand for a law, and suffice to censure, controle, & condemne Authors as his pleasure, without yeilding any cause or reason why, especially in this case now in question touching Vossius, seeing that I haue giuen in my Adioynder (as you haue
seene before) sufficient reasons to iustify his edition, which both my Lord, and you M. Collins haue seene in my Adioynder, and neuertheles you dissemble it wholy, and vrge my Lords bare auouchment, and affirmation of the contrary, as though the same were sufficient to confute all that which I haue sayd, or can be sayd in defence of Vossius. Therefore you may tell my Lord, that as yet I see no reason, why the place alleadged by Cardinal Bellarmine, out of S. Ephraems works to proue prayer to Saints, should not stand in full force, notwithstanding the exception which his Lordship taketh to the edition of Vossius; in which respect I will also be bould to make vse of S. Ephraems testimonyes heereafter, out of the same edition, as occasion shall serue, vntill my Lord or you do disproue it, with some better reason, then my Lords bare word.

69. Lastly I would gladly haue my Lord to vnderstand (though I thinke you will be loath to tell him) that he had neuer worse lucke in his life, then when he made choyce of you for his Champion; for you are so farre from performing the office of a good Champion, that you rather play the part of a bad Tinker, who in labouring to stop one hole in a Kettle, commonly maketh
two or three more, & leaueth it much worse then he found it; for truly so doe you heere deale with my Lord, making his cause much worse then it was; so as his Lordship should haue prouided better for his owne honour, to haue let you still be silent, as you were amongst the Canes muti non valentes latrare (of whome the Prophet Isay speaketh cap. 56.) then to set your tongue on talking so much to his owne disgrace, as heere he hath done; and therefore not only I, but also his Lorship hath great reason to shut vp your mouth heereafter with Obmutesce.

70. But now to proceed, I omit a world of fooleryes, and impertinent cauills in his answere to my Adionder touching certaine places of S. Chrysostome & S. Maximus, & will discouer his most fraudulēt answer concerning a place which Card. Bellarmine alleadged in his Apology, of an Oration of Saint Gregory Nazianzen, made in the feast of S. Cyprian, wherein he not only prayed to the Saint saying, Tu è superis nos respice, & populum hunc sanctum dirige: Behould vs from aboue, and direct this holy people; but also recounted the story of a holy Virgin called Iustina, who being extremly tempted by the diuel, and her chastity endangered (by the means
of Necromancy) deuoutly implored the help of the Blessed Virgin Mary, whereby togeather with her other holy endeauours she ouercame the temptation. To this obiection of the Cardinall, my Lord of VVinchester answereth three wayes; first that the Oration of S. Gregory Nazianzen, out of which this testimony is taken, is not liquida fidei, of cleare credit, because it is vncertain who that Cyprian was of whome he made that Oration, as namely whether he was Cyprian Bish. of Carthage (as he should seem to be by the circumstances mētioned therin) or Cyprian Bishop of Antioch, in which respect my Lord of VVinchester sayth: Ita fluctuat res tota, ita perplexa omnia, so vncertaine is the whole matter, and so perplexe, and doubtfull are all things in that Oration.

71. His second answere is, that it was but the fact of a Mayd, and then asketh whether the fact of a mayde be a statute of the Church? And whether a rule of fayth be to be grounded vpon a Mayds act? And lastly he answereth that S. Epiphanius sharply reprehended the selfe same fact in the same Age in the Collyridian Heretikes, when it was done by many of the same sexe. To these three answers of my Lord of VVinchester, I replyed in my Adioynder thus. pag. 252. lin. 6. You
see how substantially he argueth, inferring that the matter, and substance of the oration is vncertayne, because it is doubtfull of which Cyprian the oration was made; wheras neuertheles he cannot with any reason deny but that the oratiō is S. Gregory Nazianzens: wherupon it must needs follow that albeit Nazianzen should be deceiued, and erre in the history, or the person of whome he speaketh, yet the substance as well of the story, as of the doctrine contayned in that Oration, was true in his conceipt, and therfore may serue for an assured testimony of his beliefe, and of the practise of the Church in his tyme (which is the only poynt now in question) and therfore seeing that he not only prayed to a Saynt himselfe, but also signifyed that a holy Virgin did the lyke; it is cleare, that both he himselfe, and also the faythfull people in those dayes, held it to be lawfull, and practised it as occasion requyred.

72. And whereas M. Andrewes addeth concerning the latter poynt (to wit, the prayer of the mayde) that it was but a fact of a mayd, and then asketh whether the fact of a mayd is a statute of the Church? and whether a rule of • ayth is to be grounded vpon a mayds act? I haue sufficiently answered
him already touching the statutes, & decrees of the Church concerning this point; and now tell him agayne, that there was neyther at that tyme, any need of statutes for prayer to Saynts, which then was euery where in practise; neyther is it now in question what the Church decreed then touching the same, but what was then generally practised and belieued, which cannot be better, and more clearely proued by any testimonyes of the Fathers, then by such as witnesse, not only their owne facts, but also the practise of other Christians, eyther in their dayes, or els in former tymes, as this was which S. Gregory affirmeth of that holy mayd.

73. But will you now heare how well M. Andrewes concludeth al this matter? forsooth he maketh an obiection against himselfe, saying in a different letter (as if the obiection were the Cardinals) sed factum non reprehenditur, but this fact of the mayd is not reprehended by S. Gregory Nazianzen: and then he addeth answering to his owne obiection: Immò idem illud &c. yea, but Epiphanius sharpely reprehended the selfe same, in the same age, in the Collyridian heretykes, when it was done by many of the same sexe. Thus sayth M. Andrews, playing his part kindly, as well in his
obiection as in his answere. For in his obiection (wherin he would seeme to speake for the Cardinall, or rather to lay downe his words) he dissembleth altogether what the Cardinall saith to vrge, and fortify that example of the mayde, and therefore forbeareth purposely, as it may be thought, to set it downe in his margent with the rest of the Cardinalls text; who after the words of S. Gregory before related (to wit Virginem Mariam rogauit &c. She besought the Virgin Mary to succour a Virgin in danger) addeth immediatly, ac paulò post resert eam &c. and a litle after (Nazianzen) declareth that her prayer was heard. Vicit, inquit, virgo, vincitur daemon. The Virgin (saith he) ouercame, and the Diuel is ouercome. Thus doth the Cardinall vrge this example, which as you see, is of much more force, then to say only (as M. Andrews saith) that S. Gregory did not reprehend the fact.

74. For albeit his silence in not reprehending it, may serue for an argument that he did not mislyke it, yet the other clearely proueth that not only he, but also God himselfe did notably approue it, seing he saith that she obtayned the effect of her prayer, and ouercame the Diuell: whereto I also add, that when that holy Father beginneth
to recount the history of the mayd, he sayth thus: Audite Virgines, ac simul exultate &c. Harken o ye Virgins, and reioyce also, yea all ye that esteeme chastity in matrimony, and loue Virgins, giue eare, for to both sorts this my narration may serue for an ornament. So he. Whereby it appeareth playnely that he meant to recount that which he would wish to be approued and imitated by others: whereupon it followeth that by this example he exhorted, and encouraged all those whose chastity should be endangered, to craue the help of the blessed Virgin, as that holy mayd did, who thereby (togeather with her other deuotious of fasting, & prayer to almighty God, which S. Gregory relateth) ouercame the Diuell, and escaped the danger of his tentation. And could this holy Father more euidently declare what his faith and beliefe was, concerning prayer to Saints, then not only to relate this fact of a holy Virgin without reprehension of it, but also to signify the happy euent, and successe thereof, yea, and to incyte others to the approbation, and imitation of it?

75. But now sayth M. Andrewes,
• lthough Nazianzen did not reprehend it: yet Epiphanius did sharply reproue idem illud, euen the selfe same fact in the same age in other women.
If this be true, M. Andrews doth indeed say somewhat to the purpose (at least to proue that the Fathers of that age did not with vnanime consent allow prayers to Saynts;) but if it be false, and that he flatly belyeth S. Epiphanius, what shall we think of the mans conscience, and cause? The truth is, S. Epiphanius sharply reprehendeth certayne womē who vsed at a certain time of the yeare to commit Idolatry to the Virgin Mary, adoring her with diuine honour, offring to her certain cakes in sacrifice, as though she had byn a God, or a Goddesse, and they her Priests: whereupon he discourseth amply, prouing first out of the old Testament, that nusquam mulier sacrificauit, aut Sacerdotio suncta est, women haue neuer sacrifyced any where, or executed Priestly function. And then he commeth to the new Testament, where he sheweth also the same, and addeth further, that if women could euer haue byn admitted to Sacrifyce, the Virgin Mary her selfe should haue done it rather, then any other, neuertheles she neuer did: and finally he concludeth, that the body of the blessed Virgin Mary, was reuerà sanctum, sed non Deus, truely holy, but not God,

76. By all which it appeareth, that
these women, which Epiphanius reprehendeth, did not only take vpon them the Priestly function, but also committed flat Idolatry, adoring the Virgin Mary with diuine honour, offring sacrifice vnto her, which is a worship due to God alon. Now then could a man belieue that M. Andrewes, or any man els that hath care of his reputation would be so shamelesse to say, that this is idem illud, that very selfe same thing which, Nazianzen sayth, that holy Virgin did, who only craued help of the Virgin Mary? Is there no differēce betwixt praying, & sacrifysing? betwixt Idolatry, & religious veneration due to Gods Saints, & seruants? Or betwixt the vsurpatiō of Priestly functiō (whereof no woman is capable) & the oblation of priuate prayers, which is as free for women, as men? Doth euery one, or any one that prayeth to Saynts or Angels, crauing their help, and assistance (as that holy Virgin did) doth he, I say, adore them as Gods, commit idolatry, offer Sacrifice, vsurpe the function of a Priest as those women did, whom Epiphanius reprehended? Truly if M. Andrews can iustify this, he may boldly say, and write what he list. So as now you see, that whereas he vndertooke to proue that this testimony of S. Gregory
Nazianzen is not liquidae fidei, of cleare credit, he hath obscured, or rather clearely lost his owne credit, by an euident, and intollerable abuse of S. Epiphanius, without giuing the least blemish, or taint in the world to the credit of the place that he impugneth: by the which it appeareth euidently, that the Inuocation of Saints was vsuall in the time of S. Gregory Nazianzen, seeing that he himselfe did both inuocate Saints, and also testify and approue the practise of it in others, as you haue heard: and this shal suffice for him.

77. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder, wherein you see, I not only confuted my Lord of VVinchesters answere to the Cardinalls obiection, but also charged his Lordship with two frauds, the one in dissembling, and cōcealing wholy that which most imported in the obiection, I meane the circumstances which the Cardinall vrged to confirme the Mayds example in praying to the Blessed Virgin, to wit, the good successe, and effect of her prayers, and other holy endeauours which S. Gregory signifyed, saying: Vicit virgo, & vincitur Daemon: The Mayd ouercame, and the Diuell was ouercome; and the other fraud was, an intollerable abuse of S. Epiphanius in affirming, that he condemned
in the Collyridian Heretiks idem illud, the selfe same act of the Mayd, who prayed only to the immaculate Mother of God (not as to a God, or Goddesse, but as to a creature most acceptable to God;) whereas that which S. Epiphanius condemned in the Collyridian Heretiks, was flat Idolatry, which they committed, offring sacrifice to the B. Virgin, which is due to God alone.

78. Now then I doubt not, but that the Reader expecteth that M. Collins should say somewhat, if not to all my reply vpon My Lords answere, yet at the least to the imputation of the fraudes, wherwith I charged his Lordship, seeing he hath vndertaken to defend him, and to cleare him of the fraudes, falsityes, and lyes, wherewith he sayth in his title, I slaundered his Lordship. But heere, he not only dissembleth that which is most important in my reply, but also is wholy silent to the charge of the two fraudes, dissembling that which he could not answere.

79. And albeit in the ninth Chapter pag. 388. num. 24. he doth enlarge himselfe very much vpon that place of S. Epiphanius, spending no lesse the fiue or six pages, in a large Comment vpon it; neuertheles he maketh no mention at all of any imputation
of fraud, or abuse of S. Epiphanius (wherwith I charged his Lordship) & yet I gaue him sufficient occasion to do it euen in that place, where I recapitulated all my Lords frauds, falsityes, and lyes, & among the rest, charged his Lordship with this in particuler, saying, that he had egregiously abused, and flatly belyed Epiphanius, touching prayer to our Blessed Lady, which M. Collins thought best, to dissemble wholy, and yet to make some fayre florish vpon the place it selfe, because it treated of Idolatry, and seemed to him very fit, to gull some simple Reader, with the help of some false glosse, or comment of his; and this he thought he might doe without any hazard to my Lords honour, who being not so much as named or any wayes mentioned by him, should scape Scotfree for his fraude, albeit the Reader should not be satisfyed with the exposition of the place.

80. But you will say perhaps, that albeit M. Collins doth not name my Lord, nor mention my obiection of fraud to his Lordship, yet it may be hath cleared him sufficiently of the imputation, if he haue proued, that Epiphanius condemned prayer to the Blessed Virgin, no lesse then sacrifice. But how hath he proued it? Forsooth, he
sayth thus pag. 388. num. 24. Epiphanius yo • say, neuer reprehended praying to the Virgin Mary, but sacrifice only in the Colliridian gossipps. And was their sacrifice without prayer? Or could it well be? Remember I pray you, your owne principles; then shew where Epiphanius reprouing sacrifice, excepts praying, and condemnes not all their foppery in grosse: yet he scans the point nicely, and shews what we may giue to the Virgin without offence, what we may not, in all which, of prayer not a word he vouchsafes her. Thus indeed sayth M. Collins, euen as much to the purpose, as if he had sayd iust nothing.

81. For what need I deny either that the prayer of these Idolaters cōcurred with their sacrifice, or that Epiphanius condemned them both? Seeing that (as wel their prayer, as their sacrifice) was idolatrous, being offred to a creature, as to God. As also the like may be said euen of any act of worship or reuerence done to any man, or other creature as to God, either with prayer, or without it, in which respect the Christiās in the tyme of Iulian the Apostata, would not do any reuerence to his Image when it was painted with the Image of Iupiter, because they would not seeme to do an act of Idolatry to Iupiter; wheras they vsed to do
reuerence to the Image of the Emperour, whē it was alone, as it is testifyed by S. Gregory Nazianzen orat. 1. in Iulian. And no doubt the Collyridian gossips did acts of worship, & veneratiō togeather with their sacrifice, & prayer to the Blessed Virgin; which acts, were in like manner condemned by S. Epiphanius in grosse withall their soppery (as M. Collins saith very well) and yet I hope, he will not say, therefore that all acts of worships or reuerence done to creatures are vnlawfull: wherby you may see how wisely he argueth, and how like a Doctor of Diuinity, to reiect all prayer to Saints, because Idolatrous prayer is to be reiected, not prouing prayer to Saints to be idolatrous, which neither he, nor his fellow Ministers shall euer be able to proue.

82. For as sacrifice may be lawfull, and vnlawful, so also we may say of prayer. Sacrifice offered to God is most lawfull, but offered to a creature is most vnlawfull, yea abominable; so also prayer made to almighty God as God, or to a Saint as a Saint, (that is to a creature acceptable to God) is lawfull, and behouefull; but made to a Saint, or to any other creature as to God, is idolatrous and execrable: so as my Lord of VVinchester ought to haue made a great
difference betwixt the prayer of Iustina the holy Mayd in S. Gregory Nazianzen, and that other of the Collyridian Gossips in Epiphanius; for the former was made to the Blessed Virgin, not as to God, but as to a creature (yet the Mother of God) and so was lawfull and good, whereas the other prayer was made to her, not as to a creature, but as to God, and consequently was vnlawfull and detestable; and therefore my Lord (if I may be bould to say it) ouerlashed very much, and greatly abused S. Epiphanius, when he said that, Epiphanius reprehended the prayer of Iustina in the Collyridian Gossips and M. Collins did very wisely to passe it with silence, and become dumbe, when he could not tell how to defend, or excuse it.

83. And this might suffice for this point, were it not that his glosse vpon S. Epiphanius is not only most false, and absurd, but also most iniurious to the blessed, and immaculate Mother of God; in which respect, I cannot omitte to discouer as well his impiety as his absurdity therin: and because he is so ample in it, that it cannot be confuted in a few wordes, I will make it the subiect of the next Chapter.

div.head: An impious and absurd glosse of M. Collins vpon a discourse of S. Epiphanius against the Collyridian Heretikes is examined, and proued to be partly repugnant to the text of that holy Father, and partly opposite to the beliefe, and doctrine of his Maiesty; and finally blasphemous, and most iniurious to the immaculate Moth • r of God, whose honour is defended throughout the whole Chapter. CHAP. VIII.
div.p:
BEING now to examine M. Collins his absurd, and impious glosse vpon S. Epiphanius against the Collyridian Heretikes, I find to be verifyed in him, that which our Sauiour sayd Matth. 7. that as he is wise who builds his house vpon a rocke,
so is he a foole that builds it vpon the sand, (that is to say vpon a weake and false foundation) as M. Collins hath done heer, hauing founded all the frame of his building (I meane al the weight and force of his arguments) vpon two false suppositions. The one, that the honour which we giue to the Blessed Virgin is idolatry. And the other, that the adoration, which S. Epiphanius denyeth to her, is the adoration, and honour that we doe yield her; which two points are most false; for S. Epiphanius (whome he gloseth) impugneth, & condemneth only the Idolatry of the Collyridian Heretikes, against whome he wrote, and by the way, inueigheth against the Idols of the Paynims, vsing throughout all his discourse, the word adoration for diuine honor, wherin he doth not touch vs at all, who do not giue any diuine honour to the Blessed Virgin, and much lesse to her Image, or to any creature; so that a • our Sauiour sayd of the fools house, that the winds blew, and the house fell, so may I say of M. Collins his braue building, that one puff or blast of a bare denyall will ouerthrow it. And therfore he should first haue proued his grounds soundly, before he made his inferences vpon them, and so his large Comment vpon S. Epiphanius might
haue seemed at least, to haue beene to some purpose; whereas now it serueth to no other end, but to discouer his folly, and his impious, & blasphemous humour against the most blessed, and glorious Mother of God; in which respect I will take a little paynes to examine it briefly, and to defend the due honour done to her by Catholikes, so farre, as his Comment shal giue me occasion: and to that end I most humbly craue both her leaue and assistance with this versicle of the Church; Dignare me laudare te Virgo sacrata, da mihi virtutem contra hostes tuos: Vouchsafe to giue me leaue, Holy Virgin, to prayse thee, & giue me force (or strength) against thy enemyes.

2. Now then to the end it may appeare, that S. Epiphanius forbidding the adoration of the B. Virgin, meaneth only diuin adoratiō, or worship, is it to be vnderstood that these foolish women (of whome he wrote) held her to be God, and therefore speaking of them haeres. 78. he sayth, that Sanctam semper Virginem pro Deo introducere sluduerint, they laboured to introduce the holy euer Virgin for God. And that therefore they vsed to do sacrifice vnto her; in which respect he sayth also afterwards: Cesset ita{que} error seductorum, ne{que} enim est Deus Maria, ne{que} de
Caelo corpus habens &c. let the errour of these seduced people cease; for Mary is not God, neither hath she a body from heauen, but by the conception of a man and woman. And againe afterwards haeres. 79. Reuerà sanctum erat corpus Mariae, non tamen Deus &c. truely the body of Mary was holy, yet not God, she was indeed a Virgin, and honourable, but not giuen vs to be adored, but she adoring him, who was borne of her in flesh. So he. Whereby it is euident, that he denyeth her only that ador • tion, which she gaue vnto her sonne, that is to say, diuine honor as to God.

3. And to this purpose he sayth further, that God the VVord tooke flesh of the Virgin, yet not to the end that she should be adored, nor to make her a God nor that we should offer sacrifice in her name; nor that she should find wom • n priests & she sacrificers after so many Ages. In all which it is manifest, that those foolish women, held the Blessed Virgin to be God, and adored her with sacrifice (which is diuine honour due to God alone.) And therfore S. Epiphanius proueth also very amply, as I haue signifyed before in the last Chapter num. 74. that it was neuer heard, or read of in the ould or new Testament, that there were women-priests, which might offer
sacrifice. Finally in the same sense, and to • he same purpose, he saith all the rest touching Adoration, which M. Collins alleadgeth • nd obiecteth to vs, as, Mariam nemo adoret,
• et no man adore Mary: Deo debetur hoc mysterium, this mistery is due to God; etsi pulcherrima est Maria & sācta, & honorata, at non ad adorationem, albeyt Mary be most fayre, & holy, and honourable, yet not to be adored; & lastly, Maria in honore sit, Dominus adoretur, let Mary be honoured, and our Lord adored.

4. All this saith Saint Epiphanius, and M. Collins alleadgeth it, with certaine other sentences, which shall also be considered after a whyle: but by all this which I haue cyted, it is euident, that those Collyridian gossips, holding the blessed Virgin for a God, committed flat Idolatry, offering sacrifice vnto her, as her Priests; and that therefore Saint Epiphanius worthily forbiddeth all such adoration to be exhibited to her, or to any other creature; teaching neuerthelesse, that she is to be honoured as the mother of God, though not to be adored as God: whereby it appeareth that M. Collins, hath belyed Saint Epiphanius notably, whom he affirmeth not to adiudge to her any adoration at all of what kynde soeuer; for if she be to be honoured, she is to receiue
some kynde of adoration, seeing that the word adoration signifieth not only diuine honour, and worship (in which sense Saint Epiphanius taketh it here) but also religious, and ciuill worship, as I haue proued so amply, and clearely in my Adioynder, out of the holy scriptures, and fathers, that M. Collins himself graunteth both the different vse, and acception of the words, and also the different kynd of worship, or honour signified thereby; for he graunteth the ciuill adoration, though absurdly he denyeth the religious, calling that ciuill which is testified in the scripture to haue beene done to Angells, and holy men, as I shall haue occasion to shew amply, and to discouer his folly withall, in the tenth Chapter. But that which I wish to be noted for the present, is, his detestable impiety, seeing that in excluding the most blessed mother of God from all adoration of what kind soeuer, he doth not only exclude her from the religious worship, & adoratiō which the church doth yeild her, but also from the ciuill adoration, which he himself graunteth may be giuen to mortall, and sinfull men: so as yf shee should appeare to any (as she hath done to many) she might not be adored so much as ciuilly, with cap, and knee, or bowing of
the body, which is a kind of ciuil adoratiō, that may be vsed to any man of quality.

5. But will you heare how Saint Epiphanius himselfe checketh this fellow, haeres 78. writing against such others as he, I meane certaine hereticks called Antidicomarianitae, that is, sayth he, Aduersarij Mariae velut inimicitiam aduersus Virginem habentes, & gloriam illius extenuare volentes &c.
