The Aduersaryes of Mary, bearing, as it were, emnity agaynst the Virgin, and desyring to extenuate her glory &c. to whome he sayth thus: VVho is he that out of the aboundance of an affected madnes, would frame some blasphemous opinions, open his mouth, and loose his tongue out of a wicked mynd? Immò pro hymnis & gloria, yea insteed of Hymnes, and glory, inuent, and vtter drunken, and contumelious speaches against the holy Virgin? Et vas honoratum non colere, and not to honour (or worship) that honorable Vessell &c. Thus sayth Saint Epiphanius. For the better vnderstanding whereof, yt is to be considered, that he wryteth this against certaine Heretikes, who did teach that the Blessed Virgin, was not allwayes a Virgin, but that she had children by S. Ioseph after the byrth of Christ: to which purpose I wish 3. things to be noted.

6. The first, that if M. Collins be not of the
same opinion, he is not far from it according to the principles of his maister Caluin, Beza, & other sectaryes, who teach that the B. Virgin made no vow of chastity, or it she did, that she was not bound to obserue it: so as according to their doctrine she might haue done (if not better, yet) at least as wel to haue had the company of her husband, (being marryed) as to cōserue her virginity, which they hold to be of no greater merit then mariage; wherupon it followeth that if M. Collins agree in opinion with his maisters Caluin, Beza, & other Sectaries (his brethrē in the Lord) he hath no small affinity, & participation with the Antidicomarianita, whom Saint Epiphanius confuteth, and condemneth for enemyes to the Blessed Virgin, and most blasphemous heretiks.

7. The second thing which I wish to be noted is, that albeit S. Epiphanius, make no particuler mention of any other dishonour that those hereticks did her, eyther in word, or deed; yet it may be gathered by this, which I haue here alleadged out of him, that they refused to do her publick honour, and seruice, with hymnes, and glory, as the Church vseth, which you see, he blameth and vtterly condemneth, not only in them, but also consequently in M. Collins,
and all his fellows, who do in that poynt fully participate with them.

8. The third is, that it is euident by this place of S. Epiphanius, that he is so farre from denying to the Blessed Virgin all adoration of what kind soeuer, that he expresly condemneth those which do not honour, and glorify her with Hymnes and Prayses, which is part of the worship, and adoration that the Church doth exhibite vnto her, and is denyed her by M. Collins, who therefore is heere ouertaken euery way, & proued not only to be one of those blasphemous Heretiks (or at least cozen-german to them) but also to haue shamefully belyed S. Epiphanius, in making him deny to the Blessed Virgin all adoration.

9. Lastly, it is cleare by all the premises, that S. Epiphanius denyeth no other adoration or worship of the Blessed Virgin, then all Catholikes do, that is to say diuine adoration, in which respect he condemneth, and worthily derideth the Idolatry of those fantasticall womē who made her a God, & did sacrifice to her as her priests, which we should no lesse detest, and deride, then he, if any vsed the like at this tyme.

10. But perhaps he will say, that although we do not worship her with diuin
adoration, yet we giue her more then is doe vnto her in the opinion of S. Epiphanius, who alloweth lesse honor vnto her, thē to holy men, and farre lesse then to Angells. This indeed M. Collins laboureth to proue out of S. Epiphanius; and as he is very ready to take hold of euery thing that may seeme any way to diminish the honour, and glory of the Blessed Virgin, he first obserueth, that S. Epiphanius wisheth it to be noted in the holy Scripture, that our Sauiour called her VVoman Ioan. 2. at the Marriage in Cana of Galilee, saying to her (whē she tould him that there wanted wine) Quid mihi & tibi est mulier? Nondum venit hora mea VVhat haue I to do with thee woman? My houre is not yet come: to the end that some might not thinke that the holy Virgin was more excellent, as it were foreshewing what should happen in the world by sects, and heresies, that some through too great admiration of that holy woman, might not slyde into heresy, and the dotage thereof; for in very truth all this passage is nothing els, but a meere mockery, and an old womans tale.

11. Thus sayth S. Epiphanius cyted by M. Collins, wherein there is nothing that may iustly be taken, as sayd in disgrace of the Blessed Virgin, if we consider that S. Epiphanius, writing against those giddy headed women, who made her God, had reason
to vrge what he could, concerning the infirmity of her nature, & sexe, to correct their exorbitant conceipt of her diuinity; as he that would make streight a crooked sticke, doth bend it backe the other way, as farre as he may without breaking it: & therefore when he wrote immediatly before against those which were her enemyes (to wit the Antidicomarianitae (M. Collins his Cozen-germans) he vrged her eminent dignity in being the mother of God, and called her Matrem viuentium, the Mother of the liuing, & causam vitae, and the cause of life to all true Christians, detesting the blasphemy and drunken madnes of those which sought to extenuate her glory, as I haue partly signifyed before, and shall haue occasion to declare further heereafter.

12. Therefore whereas our aduersaries are wont to make great vse of those wordes of our Sauiour to his Blessed Mother, to proue the little esteeme he made of her, in calling her woman, and saying vnto her: Quid mihi & tibi est mulier? We may well say, that if the whole passage and story be wel considered, it maketh exceeding much for her prayse, and proueth cleerely the force of her prayers, & intercession for vs; seeing it appeareth thereby, that the only
insinuation of her desire to haue the want of wyne supplyed (though it were by a miracle) was so powerfull with our Sauiour, that he was content to satisfy her desire, the tyme being not yet come, for the working of that miracle, which he signifyed, saying, nondum venit hora mea, my tyme is not yet come, and therfore I say it may wel be thoght, that to the end it might appeare how much he esteemed and honoured her, and of what force her intercession should alwayes be with him, he ordayned to doe his first miracle, as it were out of tyme, and at her suite and request, or rather vpon the very insinuation of her desire, for she sayd only to him, Vinum non habent, they haue no wine. This may be confirmed out S. Ambrose serm. 16. in psal. 118. S. Cyril. lib. 2. cap. 23. and S. Chrysostome hom. 21. who affirme that our Sauiour did that miracle sooner then otherwayes he would haue done, at the request of his Mother,

13. But then you will aske me, why did he reprehend her saying: Quid mihi & tibi est Mulier &c. what haue I to do with thee woman? Wherto I answere, that it may well be gathered by that which followeth that it was no reprehension, but an honour to her; and therefore S. Iustinus sayth
quaest. 126 Non verbo matrem obiurgauit, cùm eam sacto honorauit, Christ did not chide, or reprehend • i • mother, when he honoured her with the fact. Also S. Cyril sayth lib. 2. cap. 23. Quantus honor parentibus &c. Christ shewed how great honour is due to parēts, seeing that he presently did the act (that is to say, he wrought the miracle) propter Matrem for his Mother; besides that it may wel be thought that if he had reprehended her for it, she would not haue persisted in her desire, and much lesse would she haue insisted vpon the performance of it, as she did saying presently to the seruants: Quodcum{que} vobis dixerit sacite, do whatsoeuer he shall say vnto you; whereby it appeareth that she and our Sauiour vnderstood one another well inough, and that he was so farre from reprehending her, that he graunted her request, and that she knew it (notwithstanding that answere,) and also knew that he meant to giue order to the seruantes to doe somewhat for the execution of it, and therupon she sayd to them, Doe whatsoeuer he shall command you, as S. Cyril teacheth expresly vbi supra cap. 24. saying thus: The Mother of Christ was not ignorant, that he did deserre, or attribute great authority and dignity vnto her, who hauing perswaded (or induced him to do the
miracle) in such manner as was conuenient, did dispose, and exhort the seruants to do all that which he should command them. So he.

14. Therefore albeit there are different opinions, and interpretations of those wordes Quid mihi & tibi est mulier? Yet that which is most common & most probable, is, that for as much as she demanded of him a miracle, which surpassed the power of nature, and was to be done by him as he was God, he vsed those wordes, shevving lesse respect vnto her, then othervvayes might seeme conuenient from a Sonne to his Mother; to leaue vs this document, that in things pertaining to Almighty God and to his seruice, no respect is to be had to flesh and bloud; and therfore S. Bernard obserueth very well serm. 2. Dom. 1. post octan. Epiphan. that Christ vsed that manner of speach, non propter Matrem, sed propter nos, not for his Mother, but for vs, that is to say, for our instruction; for which cause also he seemed to make small accompt of his Mother and kinsfolkes, when some interrupted his preaching, and tould him that his Mother and brethren sought for him Matth. 12. Quae, sayth he, est mater mea &c. who is my Mother, and who are my Brethren? And then holding out his hands towardes
his disciples, he sayd: Behould my Mother, and behould my brethren &c. In like manner he seemed to speake to his Mother, and to S. Ioseph with small respect Luc. 2. when they found him in the Temple, & tould him that they had sought him with sorrow: Quid est, sayth he, quod me quaercbatis &c. Why did you seeke me? Did you not know, that I must imploy my selfe in those things which belonge to my Father? And yet the Euangelist testifyeth in the same place presently after, that he went with them to Nazareth, & erat subditus illis, and was subiect to them, that is to say, in all domesticall dutyes, and such things as belonged to his humanity. And this interpretation of those words, quid mihi & tibi est mulier? (to wit that he spake to her as he was God, and not as he was man) is conforme to the opinion of S. Augustine vpon this place tract. 119. lib. de fide, & simbolo cap. 4. lib. 2. de fide ad Catechum. cap. 5. S. Gregory lib. 8. Reg. cap. 42. Theophil. Antiochen. lib. 4. allegor. Gaudentius tract. 9. de Euangel. lection. S. Beda & Euthymius in their commentaryes vpon this Ghospell.

15. And as for the obseruation of S. Epiphanius that our Sauiour called her woman, I say, that albeit there want not good Authours, who do expound it rather to her
commendation then otherwayes (as that he called her woman per excellentiam, for the excellency of her person, as being the chiefe woman, in which respect, she is also called only Mary, many tymes, as the chiefe Mary; which I obserue heere the rather, because M. Collins noteth in his margent out of S. Hierome, that he calleth her only Mary, Mary) neuertheles I do not deny but that S. Epiphanius might among other reasons probably conceiue that our Sauiour foreseeing that heresy of the Collyridians (who esteemed & serued her as God) called her a woman, to arme vs against that heresy, and dotage of theirs; but this no way concerneth vs who do know, and acknowledge her to be a woman, and a meere creature of God, as all others both men, and women, and Angells are; and therefore M. Collins sheweth more malice, then wit, to apply this to vs. Besides that, I cannot omit to note by the way, a pretty sleight of his, not voyde of fraud, in his allegation and translation of this place of S. Epiphanius.

16. For wheras that Father alleadging those words of the holy Scripture, Quid mihi & tibi est mulier? addeth therto curae, and hath them thus: Quid mihi & tibi est curae mulier? that is to say, VVoman what haue I, and thou
to do with it? M. Collins setting downe the text of S. Epiphanius at large, leaueth out curae both in the Latin, and in the English, and translateth the Latin thus, what haue I to do with thee woman? Which wordes of our Sauiour, as S. Epiphanius readeth, and vnderstandeth them, not only in this place (alleadged by M. Collins) but also haeres. 51.00 not containe any asperity and sharpnes at all, and therefore M. Collins thought it better to falsify S. Epiphanius, though he himselfe alleadgeth him, then by alleadging him truely to giue some inkling of a more mild exposition and sense thereof; albeit the same is not the interpretation of S. Epiphanius only, but also of Iustinus quaest. 136. Euthymius in his Commētary vpon this Ghospell, and of diuers others both ancient and moderne; but howsoeuer those words are to be vnderstood, they doe nothing preiudice our cause who do not deny our Blessed Lady to be a woman, and much lesse do make her a God: besids that, the whole cōtext of that story which S. Epipha. only toucheth, doth notably proue the great power, and force of the B. Virgins prayers, & intercession to her Sonne, (as I haue signifyed before) and therefore may very well incite, and moue vs to haue recourse vnto
her, that she may recommend vs, and our necessityes vnto him.

17. And now to proceed with M. Collins his comment; after he cyteth these wordes out of S. Epiphanius: Quae verò Scriptura de hoc narrauit? Quis Prophetarum praecepit hominem adorari, nedum mulierem? that is. VVhat Scripture informeth vs heereof? VVhich of the Prophets commanded any man to be worshiped, much lesse a VVoman? See you how he reduceth this Controuersy to Scripture? Yet the Adioynder makes no reckoning of Scripture in this question, so we haue miracles, and traditions, and other obseruations. VVell it was lawfull for Epiphanius to fly to that, Quae verò Scriptura, and Quis Prophetarum praecepit &c. See you also how he prefers not a few before the Virgin? For we must not worship man, sayth he, much lesse a VVoman, belike though it be the Virgin her selfe: Eximium quidem est vas, sed Mulier, & nihil à natura immutata, that is, An excellent Vessell she is no doubt, but yet a woman, and not a whit changed in regard of her nature. Thus sayth M. Collins with more which shallbe examined anon.

18. Now whereas he noteth very seriously in S. Epiphanius, that he reduceth this controuersy to Scripture, and that neuertheles the Adioynder makes no reckoning of scripture in this question, truly he is very
seriously idle in saying so, and the rather because he chargeth the Adioynder, with contempt of Scripture, without telling vs where he fyndeth it, or what the Adioynder sayth to that purpose; and therefore, I omitt to answere it, as one of his fooleryes, not worth the answering, and wish to be obserued in the rest what a friend he is to the blessed Virgin, whome he depriueth of all honour, and worship, yea more then any man, by reason of the naturall infirmity of her sexe, as being stil a woman, and not a whit changed in regard of her nature; which reason as it is vsed by S. Epiphanius, might make it cleare inough to M. Collins (if he were not willfully and malitiously blind) that the worship wherof he treateth, & which he denyeth more to women, then to men, is onely diuine worship; for so the argument of Saint Epiphanius is very good, whereas otherways it were absurd, and he should contradict himself; to which purpose it is to be considered, that diuine adoration, or worship can be due to none, who hath not true diuinity; and for as much as diuinity must needs be naturall (for God is God by nature, and not by grace) it followeth euidently, that if a man, who is by nature
more perfect then a woman, cannot haue true diuinity (nor consequently diuyne worship (much lesse can a woman haue it, and therefore the blessed Virgin being still a woman (though glorifyed) is much lesse capable of diuinity, and consequently of diuine honour then a man; and thus I say the Argument of S. Epiphanius is good.

19. But if we vnderstand worship (not as it is diuine, but as it may be due to creatures (participating of the diuine excellency) the argument of S. Epiphanius will be nothing worth, & so wil become to be the argument of M. Collins as indeed it is, and not of S. Epiphanius: & this I say, because a woman, though she be inferiour to a man by nature, yet by grace may farre excell him, and consequently deserue a farre greater worship then he; so as that learned Father was neuer so simple, to make such an argument as M. Collins would haue him to do, as first to exclude all men from all kind of worship (which were ridiculous) and thē to inferre also thereupon, that no woman ought to be worshipped. For albeit Almighty God had not, or would not bestow so much grace vpon any man, as to make him worthy of worship, yet he might bestow it vpon some woman, or vpon all
women if it pleased him, and consequently make them more worthy of worship, then any man, which is indeed veryfied in the B. Virgin, who albeit by nature she be inferiour to any man, yet by grace she excelleth all men, yea and all Angells, as shalbe declared after a whyle: whereupon it followeth that she deserueth more worship then they all.

20. Moreouer I haue made it manifest allready (and therefore need not to repeat it) that S. Epiphanius teacheth expresly that the most B. Virgin, is to be honoured, or worshipped with hymnes and glory, and that he inueigheth bitterly against those, who refuse to do it, so as he should contradict himselfe most ridiculously if he should exclude her from all worship; eyther in respect of the infirmity of her sexe, or for any other cause whatsoeuer, albeyt he hath reason to debarre her from diuine honour, because neyther she, nor humane nature is any way capable therof.

21. But let vs follow M. Collins a little further, thus then he proceedeth. Honoured she is, but as the bodyes of Saints: & if I may say any more towards the magnifying of her, sicut Elias, sicut Ioannes, sicut Te • la, like Elias, lyke Iohn, lyke Tecla: only herein (sayth
Epiphanius more honorable then Tecla, that she was imployed to be the instrument of the misterious birth of our Lord; but suppose she be like ōly to other Saints may not they be worshipped? sed ne{que} Elias adorandus est, etiamsi in viuis sit; ne{que} Ioannes adorandus, ne{que} Tecla, ne{que} quisquam sanctus adoratur: not only no dead Saints, but not so much as they that neuer dyed may be adored &c. neyther Elias is to be adored, nor Iohn to be adored, nor Tecla nor any Saint is to be adored &c. So he, wherin it is to be obserued.

22. First, that S. Epiphanius doth euen in these words alleadged heer by M. Collins, not only distinguish betwixt diuyne adoration, and the honour due to the blessed Virgin; but also teach expresly, that she, & the Saints, yea & their very reliks are to be honoured, which also is more euident and effectuall in the text of S. Epiphanius thē as M. Collins abridgeth, and glosseth it. For S. Epiphanius hauing asked the question, Quis prophetarum &c. VVhich of the prophets did euer commaund that any man should be adored much lesse a woman? addeth presently touching the blessed Virgin thus: Eximium est &c. truly the is a notable Vessel, yet a woman, and nothing changed in regard of her nature: Verum & intellect • & sensu in honore honorata, sicut corpora sanctorum
&c. but honoured both in vnderstanding and sense (that is to say both with internall, and externall honour) as the bodyes of Saints. Thus sayth S. Epiphanius, with the rest that followeth set downe by M. Collins concerning Elias, Iohn, and Tecla; wherin it is manifest that he denyeth to the blessed Virgin diuine worship only, and acknowledgeth that there is due vnto her an inferiour honour both mentall, and corporall, such as may be done to creatures, namely to the bodyes, or relikes of Saints, to Elias, to Iohn, and to Tecla; affirming neuertheles that the blessed Virgin is more to be honoured then Tecla, because she was the mother of God; by which reason she is also more honorable then eyther Elias, or Iohn, or any other holy man or woman, seeing she had that particuler priuiledge aboue all other creaturs.

23. Therefore for as much as honour is to be exhibited to any one more or lesse; according to the greater, or lesser tytles, & considerations that moue thereto, it followeth that the blessed Virgin hauing the greatest title of honour that euer creature had, (to wit to be the mother of God) is more to be honoured then any other creature, euen according to the argument of S. Epiphanius, yet so, as not to arryue to diuine
honour, and therfore he sayth, sed ne{que} Ec •• adorandus est &c. but neyther Elias is to be adored, neyther yet Iohn, nor Tecla, nor any other Saint is to be adored, that is to say as a God, or with diuine honour; for if wee should take adoration here for any other the diuyne worship, S. Epiphanius should contradict himself in denying to Elias, Iohn, and Tecla, the honour that heere he alloweth them, acknowledging that the blessed Virgin is to be honoured like to them; besydes that S. Epiphanius who was most conuersant in the holy scripture (as appeareth in his workes) should haue forgot himselfe very much in denying to Elias all odoratiō, seeing the scripture doth testify 3. Reg. 18. that Abdias (who although he was steward to the wicked King Achab, yet was himselfe a man that feared God) did an act of adoration to Elias, falling vpon his face before him, which the prophet would not haue permitted if it had not beene lawful; wherto I may add the example of the adoratiō done by the children of the Prophets to Elizaeus when they saw, by his miraculous passage of the Riuer, that God had giuen him the spirit of Elias, adorauerunt eum, sayth the Scripture, proni in terram, they adored him falling flat vpon the ground 4. Reg. 2.
and therefore when S. Epiphanius asketh quis prophetarum &c. VVhich of the Prophets, did euer command that a man should be adored, he meant not thereby to deny to men all adoration, but only diuine worship, for otherwayes Abdias should haue erred greatly in adoring Elias; and the children of the Prophets in adoring Elizaeus.

24. But will you see how well M. Collins gloseth those wordes. Sed ne{que} Elias adorandus est etiamsi in viuis sit, but neither Elias is to be adored, though he be liuing? Wherupon he sayth, Not only no dead Saint, but not so much as they that neuer dyed may be adored. So he. Ful wisely contradicting the text with his glosse, except he take adored there to signify diuine honour; for you see S. Epiphanius, sayth expresly that the Blessed Virgin is to be honoured, as the bodyes of Saints, (that is to say, the dead bodyes of Saints deceased) and albeit he say that Elias is still liuing, yet he acknowledgeth both Iohn, & Tecla to be dead, and yet to be honoured, for otherwayes he could not say that the B. Virgin is to be honoured like to them, if they were not to be honoured at al; thogh it be true that neither they, nor Elias, nor the Blessed Virgin, are to be adored, taking adored to signify diuine honour, as
indeed S. Epiphanius vseth it there, and throughout all his discourse.

25. And as well to the purpose is also another glosse of his shortly after vpon the same words, saying: VVas it not possible, that Epiphanius should light vpon your distinction of diminitiue adoration, that so often, so peremptory denyes it to the Saints, that it is lawfull to adore them, and neuer expounds himselfe? So he. To which wise question of his, I answere, that it was nor only possible, that S. Epiphanius should light vpon our distinction, but also that he did light vpon it indeed, and sufficiently expound himselfe; for when he sayth, as you haue heard, let Mary be honoured, and God adored; and that Mary is holy and honoured, but not to be adored; & againe that she is honoured both by vnderstanding and sense (that is to say, both with internall, and externall honour) and yet not to be adored, he light vpon our distinction of diminitiue adoration (as it pleaseth M. Collins to tearme it) or rather to giue it the right terme, our distinction of dulia, and latria; for by the adoration which he denyeth to the Blessed Virgin he signifyeth latriam, that is to say, diuine honour, and by the honour which he granteth her he signifyeth duliam, that is to say, an inferiour honour due to creatures, for the honour
of God; yea and when he sayth further that she is more honourable then Tecla, because she was the Mother of God, (wherein she excelleth all creatures) he signifyeth hyperduliam, that is to say, superlatiue honour aboue all other, which honour is indeed due, and proper to her in respect of her supereminent dignity, and excellency by being the Mother of God.

26. Therfore when S. Epiphanius sayth that she is to be honoured, as the bodyes of Saints, as Elias, as Iohn, as Tecla, his meaning is not that she cannot receaue a greater degree of honour then they, but that she is to be honoured with the same kind of honour that they are, that is to say with an honour due to creatures, & not with that which is due to the Creatour, she being a creature as well as they, and no more capable of diuinity, or of diuine honour then they.

27. For if we do not vnderstand S. Epiphanius so, we must say also that his meaning was, that the bodyes of Saints, Elias, Iohn, and Tecla, should be all honoured with like and equall honour; as that neither Elias, nor Iohn, nor Tecla could be honoured more or in any greater degree then the dead body of a Saint, nor that they could be honoured one more then another, which were absurd
to say; for as there may be difference of their degree of merit, or participation of the diuine excellency; so may also the degree and measure of their honour be different: to which purpose the Apostle sayth of the glory of Gods Saints 1. Cor. 15. That as one starre differs from another in brightnes, so shal it be in the resurrection of the dead. And our Sauiour also sayth Ioan. 14. That there are many mansions in the house of his Father; giuing to vnderstand that there are different degrees of glory amongst the Saints in respect of their different merits, whyles they were heer on earth; and for this cause the Church doth solemnize the feasts of Saints with great difference, honouring some more then others, yet all as creatures, and seruants of God; in which respect the kind of honour that is giuen them is all one, but the degree and measure thereof is different.

28. The like is also euident in temporall honour due to a King and his subiects; for the King is honoured with kingly honour due to none but to himselfe, and the subiects are honoured with an inferiour honour, such as may be giuen to subiects, and the same also in a different degree, to some more, and to some lesse, as their different quality, or the Kings pleasure requyreth,
and the greatest honour of all, next to the King is giuen to the Kings Mother, yet as to a subiect; Euen so I say of the honour due to God, and to his Saints, and seruants; for the honour due to him, is diuine and peculiar to himselfe, and the honour that is done to his Saints and seruants is of another kind, not extending it selfe further then to the consideration of creatures, whom he will haue to be honoured; and yet within that limit, the degree of honour is different according to their different merits, and glory resulting thereon: and because the Blessed Virgin is the Mother of God, and thereby farre surpasseth them all in dignity and merit, the honour due to her is of far higher degree, and yet of infinite distance from diuine honour, as much as is betwixt the Creatour and the creature; so as neither the Saintes liuing, nor dead, nor the Mother of God herselfe is adored in the sense that S. Epiphanius forbiddeth it, that is to say with diuine honour; and therefore M. Collins his glosse hitherto is most false, and absurd.

30. But first to say somewhat though very briefly, to his preamble therto; wheras he obserueth out of S. Epiphanius, that he held it for a trespasse to worship or adore the creature besides the Creatour, that is, sayth he, to take in the worship of the creature, though we exclude not the worship of the Creatour, there is no doubt, but that it is most true; for God is a iealous God, and cannot endure to haue any fellows, or companions in diuine adoration, that is to say, that any shalbe adored for God, or with diuine honour besides himselfe, and therefore he sayth of all kind of Idolls Exod. 20. Non adorabis ea, ne{que} coles, ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, fortis, zelotes &c. Thou shalt not adore them, nor worship them, I am thy Lord God, strong, and iealous.
And againe, Exodus 34. Noli adorare Deumalienum, Dominus zelotes nomen eius. Do not adore a strange God, a iealous Lord is his name; and what doth S. Epiphanius in effect say more then this? For speaking there of the ould errour as he calleth it of the Pagan Idolatours, he sayth: Coluerunt & adorauerunt creaturam praeter Creatorem, & stulii facti sunt, they worshipped and adored the creature besides the Creatour, & became fools; for whether a man do worship Idols togeather with God as the Kinges of Israell did, or alone without him, as the Pagans did, he committeth most abominable Idolatry, and becomes a foole; and when M. Collins shal proue that we do either of both, we will grant that S. Epiphanius taxeth vs iustly both of folly and Idolatry, no lesse, then the ould Idolatours, or the Collyridian women against whome he wrote; and in the meant tyme M. Collins proues himselfe to be a notable foole to alleadge, and vrge this discourse of S. Epiphanius against vs, whome it no way concerneth.

31. But now to come to his doughty argumēt, which is this: If God wil not haue (saith Saint Epiphanius) the Angells to be adored, how much more will be not haue her, that was borne of Anna, & yet not borne otherwayes, then according
to the nature of all mankind, but euen as all others are by the seed of a man, and by the wombe of a woman. Thus indeed sayth S. Epiphanius, prouing very well and substantially, that which we do not deny, to wit, that the Blessed Virgin being by nature inferiour to Angells, is not to be adored with Godly honour, because the Angells cannot be so adored, neuertheles I would willingly know of M. Collins heere by the way, whether he wil say that S. Epiphanius denyed heerby, that Angells might be adored in any sense, seeing that is most euident (and that holy Father could not be ignorant of it) that Abraham, Lot, and Iosue adored Angels prostrate vpon the ground Gen. 18. & 19. & Iosue 5. as I haue signifyed before; therefore M. Collins must either admit a diminitiue adoration (as he tearmeth it) or charge those holy men with Idolatry, and S. Epiphanius with ignorance, and errour, in forbidding the adoration of Angels warranted by examples in holy Scripture. But taking adoration heer as S. Epiphanius meant it, for diuine honour, it is most true, that Angells are not to be adored, because their nature is not capable of diuinity, or diuine honour, and much lesse the Virgin Mary, who is by nature inferiour both to them, & to men; in which
respect S. Epipha. also made the like argumēt before, à maiori ad minus, betwixt men & her; that because men who were by nature superiour to her, cannot be worshipped with diuine honour, much lesse could she be, & the reason is all one in both.

32. And therefore S. Epiphanius vrgeth heere expresly, that the Blessed Virgin was not other wayes borne, then after the ordinary manner of all mankind, to shew that his Argument is grounded only vpon the nature of men, and Angells; whereby the consequence is very good, that the Blessed Virgin cannot be adored as God, because her nature is lesse capable of diuinity, then is the Angelicall nature, which can admit no such adoration; so as for this point there was no great need that Maister Collins, should say to me arrige aures Pamphile: and indeed it seemeth he thought so himselfe, for he doth not much enforce or vrge it, thogh it is that which most cōcerneth the present question; but he hath found out two other points (yea, two great ones as he tearmeth them) and sayth they are assoyled by Epiphanius in these few words; One, sayth he, that the Virgin Mary was not conceaued, nor borne after extraordinary manner (as the Iesuits affirme) but euen as others are,
which must needs be in sinne, and corruption. This is the first point, which neuerthelesse you must vnderstand to be his owne inference vpon Saint Epiphanius, and not any consequence drawne by that holy Father, who doth not any way cal in question, & much lesse impugne, the immaculate purity of the Blessed Virgin.

33. Now then M. Collins his argument must be this. The Virgin was conceaued, and borne after the ordinary manner of al men and women, Ergo she was borne in sin and corruption; and to make good his argument (which I will deny) he will say, no doubt, that the ordinary manner of the conception, and birth of all men, and women according to Epiphanius, is to be conceaued, and borne in sinne, Ergo the Virgin Mary was also conceaued and borne in sin; but I will still deny his argument, and tell him that S. Epiphanius will teach him how to distinguish the ordinary manner of her conception, and birth; for he signifyeth plainely, that his meaning was no other, but that she had both a Father, and Mother by whome she was engendred, and procreated as all other children are, but whether in sinne, or without sin, he neither sayth, nor insinuateth so much as a word; for he
sayth only: That she was borne of Anna, & 〈◊〉 Ioachim data est Annae, and of Ioachim was giuen to Anna, and not otherwayes ingendred then according to the nature of men, sed sicut omnes ex semine viri, & vtero mulicris, but as all are by the seed of a man, and the wombe of a woman. And then addeth further: That although the history of Mary, and traditions do signify, that it was sayd to her Father Ioachim in the desert, Thy wise hath conceaued, yet not that it was done sine coniugio, nec sine semine viri, without marriage, or without the company of man &c. Thus sayth S. Epiphanius; so as by the ordinary manner of her conception, and birth whereof he speaketh, he signifyeth nothing els, but that she had (as I haue sayd) a Father and a Mother, by whome she was engendred as all other children are, and not conceaued without the company of man, as our Sauiour was; for so he signifyeth also afterwards, saying that he alone was conceaued and borne besides the course of nature, and that soli ipsi natura cessit, nature yeilded to him alone in that behalfe.

34. What then can M. Collins draw out of all this to proue that she was conceaued and borne in sinne? May not all this be truly sayd of Ieremy the Prophet, who neuertheles was sanctifyed in his Mothers
wombe Ierem. cap. 1. that is to say purifyed & purged from originall sin, as the ancient Fathers of the Church do testify, to wit, S. Athanasius serm. 4. contra Arrianos, Origen. ho. 1. in Hierem. S. Ambrose de fide lib. 4. cap. 4. S. Hierom. li. 4. in Hierē. c. 23. The like is also testifyed by all the Fathers of S. Iohn Baptist, as by S. Athan. vbi supra, S. Cyprian. Ep. 73. ad Iulian & ep. 76. ad Magnum. c. 4. S. Hierom. in c. 1. in Hierem. S. Ambrose in Luc. Orig hom 4 in Luc. S. Chrysost. ser. 1. in Luc. S. Gregor. l. 3. moral ca. 4. and many others whom I omit as needles, seing the scripture it self doth clearely witnes the same Luc. 1. where the Angell said of him, before he was borne, & spiritu sancto replebitur adhuc ex vtero matris suae, he shalbe replenished with the holy Ghost euen from the wombe of his mother: whereupon I infer, that as they were sanctified by particuler priuiledge before they were borne, beeing only to be the prophets of God; so might she also with farre greater reason be preserued from sinne, and sanctified in her conception by like priuiledge, being to be the mother of God, and yet be ingendred by her father and mother, and borne after the ordinary manner as they were: for it is not to be doubted but that God did giue to his mother, farre greater
grace, and priuiledge, then he euer gaue to any other creature: therefore Hyppolitus the Martyr sayth well orat. de sanctificat. that, qui dixit honorae patrem & matrem &c. he which said honour thy father & thy mother, did bestow al grace, and honour vpon his mother, to obserue the decree published by himselfe.

35. For this cause Origen 1. ex varijs, calleth her immaculatam & dignam matrem dig • i & immaculati filij, the immaculate, and worthy mother of a worthy, and immaculate sonne. S. Cyprian. lib. de natiuitate Christi, sayth of her, that she was farre different from all other, communicating with them in nature, but not in fault; and afterwards againe, Matri, sayth he, plenitudo gratia debebatur &c. the plenitude, or fullnes, of grace was due vnto her, as to the mother (of God) and more aboundant glory, as a Virgin, who excelled in integrity both of body, and soule. S. Athanasius affirmeth ser. in Euangel. de sanctissima Deip. that she was, semper & vndequa{que} beatissima, allwayes, and euery way most blessed; whereupon it followeth that she was neuer defiled with any sinne originall, or actuall; which he also teacheth more expresly in the same place, a little before, saying that she had the vertue of the holy ghost per omnia tempora etiam conceptus sui; in all tymes euen in the tyme of her conception.
S. Ambrose also ser. 22. in Psal. 118. sayth that she was, Virgo per gratiam, & integra ab omni labe peccati, a Virgin by grace, and pure from all spot of sinne. Sophron in an Epistle of his which may be seene in 6. synodo Act. 11. saith that, she was deliuered from all contagion, of body, soule, and vnderstanding.

36. Lastly to omit many others, S. Austin lib. de natura & grat. c. 36. (where he proueth against the Pelagians, that no man is without sin, no not the very infants, in whom there can be no sinne but originall) sayth that when there is any speach or question of sin, 〈◊〉
will, sayth he, make no question of the Virgin mother, for we know that more grace was giuen to her
• d vincendum omni ex parte peccatum, for the totall ouercomming of sinne, because she deserued • o conceiue, and bring forth him, who, wee know, • ad no sinne. Thus sayth S. Augustine, giuing • o vnderstand, that as our Sauiour Christ • er sonne, was himselfe most pure, and • ree from all spot of sinne, so he gaue her greater purity then euer was giuen to any woman, or infant that she might be free • rom sinne omni ex parte, wholy & fully lyke • o himselfe, that is to say free, as well from • riginall, as from all actuall sinne. For if 〈◊〉 . Augustine did not conclude so, his excep
• ion of her, from the common rule euen of
infants was of no force, seeing that he treated there of sinne in generall, prouing against the Pelagians, that no humane treature, not the very infants, could be wholy free from sinne, and therefore if she were euer soyled with originall sinne (which is the only sinne of infants) she could not be with reason excepted, in that question of sinne, neyther was she free omni ex parto euery way.

37. But although there were no testimonyes of the ancient Fathers to proue her incontaminate purity in this behalf, yet very reason might suffice to teach the same, seeing that it cannot with reason, be thought that Almighty God, would suffer his mother to be at any tyme the daughter of wrath, and consequently slaue to the diuell; whereupon it would also follow, that his own flesh which he tooke of her, was once in the diuels power, and subiect to malediction, which me thinks no piou • eares should indure to heare. If then it be conforme to reason & piety, to thinke that the blessed virgin was conceaued withou • sinne, it must needs be absurd and impiou • to affirme, as Collins doth, that she was n •• only conceaued, but also borne in sinne.

38. For albeit there is, and alway ••
hath beene Controuersy (not yet decided by the Church) whether she contracted originall sinne in her Conception (as all other child • en do) or was preserued wholy from it by a particuler priuiledg, yet it was neuer doubted (except by known Heretiks) but that she was sanctifyed and deliuered from it in her Mothers wombe; so as the Catholike Church hath euer held that she was borne immaculate and pure from all spot of sinne, with a far greater sanctification, then Hieremy the Prophet, or S. Iohn Baptist had. And of this, I say, neither S. Epiphanius, nor any other Father, or good Christian euer doubted, yea, and it is acknowledged by the very Turks, & taught by Mahomet in his Alcoran Aro. 75. in these words: Nullus nascitur de filijs Adam, quem non tangat Satan, praeter Mariam & eius filium. None is borne of the Sonnes of Adam, whome Satan doth not touch, except Mary & her Son: whereto may be added also the constant opinion of the Rabbins of the Iewes, which may be seene in Galatinus contra Iudaeos cap. 7. which I haue only thought good to mention heere, as also the foresayd testimony of Mahomet, not so much to confirme our doctrine, as to shew that euen Turkes, and Iewes haue a more reuerent opinion of the
Blessed Virgin then M. Collins hath.

38. Now then to returne to his argument out of S. Epiphanius; you may iudge by this vniforme and constant doctrine of the ancient Fathers touching the incontaminate purity of this glorious Virgin how impiously he hath argued, that she was cōceaued, and borne in sinne, and corruptiō, because S. Epiphanius sayth that she was conceaued, and borne ex semine viri & vtero mulieris, of the seed of a man, and wombe of a woman, as all other children are, which ordinary manner of conception, and birth we easily graunt not only of her, but also as I haue sayd of Hieremy the Prophet, and S. Iohn Baptist, who neuertheles were purifyed, & sanctifyed in their Mothers wombe, by the testimonyes both of Scriptures, and Fathers; wherupon I say it followeth that seeing it was conuenient (as S. Anselme sayth lib. concept. Virginis cap. 18.) that the Blessed virgin, who was to be the Mother of God, should shyne, and be endowed with so great a purity, as a greater vnder God cannot be imagined, a greater sanctificatiō was due to her, then either to those Prophets of God, or to the very Angels: in which respect the 7. Synod act. 3. doth style her not only immaculatam, immaculate, but also omni sensibili, & intellectuali ••
tura
puriorem, more pure then any sensible or intellectuall nature. Loe then, how one of the two great points, which M. Collins sayth is assoyled by S. Epiphanius, proueth to be a very little point, and not worth a pynne, only it hath serued to discouer his beastly, and blasphemous humour in labouring in vayne to stayne the vnspotted purity of the most blessed and glorious Mother of God.

49. Now let vs examine the other great point which he inferreth vpon S. Epiphanius his words, that the Blessed Virgin is not so exalted in heauen as we belieue she is, but that she is inferiour to Angells; and this he sayth because S. Epiphanius affirmeth that if God will not haue Angells adored, much lesse will he haue her to be adored which was borne of Anna, whereupon M. Collins sayth: That if she were not inferiour to Angells, the consequence were not good, if not Angells much lesse Mary the daughter of Anna. So indeed argueth he, but not S. Epiphanius in that sense, whose consequence is very good to the purpose he maketh it, but not as M. Collins applyeth it. You heard before the force of this consequence which S. Epiphanius drew from that ground; to wit that because the nature of Angels was vncapable
of diuinity, and consequently of diuine adoration, therefore the nature of the blessed Virgin being inferiour to the nature of Ang • ls, was lesse capable of both, whereupon it followeth that she is neyther God, nor to be adored with diuyne honour: but how doth this make her now inferiour to Angells in glory, seeing shee is not glorifyed by nature, but by grace, whereof there is neyther mention, not question in this place of S. Epiphanius?

41. For albeyt she could not be God eyther by nature, or by grace, yet she might be, yea and was by grace capable of glory according to the measure of the grace, wherwith Almighty God did endow her, and therefore for as much as she was not only gratia plena, ful of grace, and blessed among al women by the testimony of the Angel Gabriel, but also dignified with a greater title of honour then euer any creature had, being made the mother of God (whereby she was both more neere, and deere to God her sonne then any other creature) therefore she is most worthily exalted in glory aboue all creatures, as well Angels as men.

42. This is clearely and aboundantly testifyed by the ancient Fathers, who I
thinke are as well to be belieued as M. Col
• ins. The ancient Liturgy of S. Iames doth cal • e • : Omnibus modis irreprehensam, honorabiliorem • uam Cherubim, & gloriosiorem quàm Seraphim. VVholy irreprehensible, more honourable then the Cherubim, and more glorious then the Seraphim.

43. S. Gregory Nazianzen in his Tragedy de Christo patiente, saluteth her thus: All hayle gratious mayd, Mother, and Virgin of all other the highest, and fayrest, more worthy then the heauenly Armies, Lady, Queene, and Ioy of mankind. And in the same place he doth not only inuocate her, and pray vnto her, but also testifyeth that he had beene relieued, & helped by her, and deliuered from many calamityes which I shall haue occasion to lay downe heereafter num. 56.

44. Theodoret also vpon the Canticles, sayth: Inter tot animas hominum &c. Amongst so many soules of men and women that shalbe saued, that only one is the elected Doue, who brought forth Christ, a Virgin, a Mother, a Mayd, who doubtles did excell in purity both the Cherubim, and the Seraphim.

45. S. Athanasius in Euangel. de sanctissima Deipara, sayth to her thus: All the Hierarchies of the Angells, and earthly creatures doe prayse thee, & holding vp their Hierarchicall hands do blesse thee &c. Pray for vs Mistresse, and Lady, and
Queene, and Mother of God.

46. S. Ephraem in a most eloquent oration, which he made of her, entitleth her: The vncorrupt and most pure Virgin Mother of God, Queene of all men, more sublime, and high then the heauenly inhabitants: more honourable then the Cherubim, more holy then the Seraphim, and more glorious without comparison, then all the rest of the heauenly Armyes; the hope of the Fathers; the glory of the Prophets; the prayse of the Apostles; the honour of the Martyrs; the ioy of the Saints, the crowne of the Hierarchies, of all Saints, and Virgins; inaccessible for thy brightnes; the princesse & guide of all men; a most sacred Mayd; by thee we are reconciled to Christ my God. So he, who doth also inuocate her with exceeding deuotion & feruour thus: Crebris te lachrymis ò celeberrima Materimploro &c. I implore, or inuocate thee O most renowned Mother, & to thee I prostrate my self (O my Lady) humbly crying vnto thee, lest thy sweet sonne, the giuer of life to all, may, for many sins which I haue committed, take me out of the world, and cut me wretch vp by the roots, like the barren figge tree. So sayth this ancient, and holy Father.

47. Lastly S. Gregory the great vpon 4. Reg. cap. 1. affirmeth that, The blessed Virgin (to the end that she might arriue to the conception of the Eternall VVord) did rayse the top of her merits aboue all the quyres of Angells, vntill she came
to the throne of the Deity. Thus sayth S. Gregory, giuing to vnderstand, that she merited so much by the grace which God gaue her, to make her his Mother, that she was eleuated in glory aboue all Saints and Angels to be next to the Deity.

48. I omit many other testimonyes of the ancient Fathers for breuityes sake; for what need I alledge such ancient witnesses, when I haue a moderne testimony that may suffice, seeing I am sure M. Collins neither will, nor dare reiect it, I meane the euident assertion of the Kings Maiesty, who in his Apology for the Oath pag. 37. sayth thus: First, for the Blessed Virgin Mary, I yield her that which the Angell Gabriell pronounced of her, and which in her Canticle she prophesyed of her selfe, that is, that she is blessed amongst all women, and that all generations shall call her Blessed. I reuerence her, as the Mother of Christ, of whome our Sauiour tooke flesh, and so the Mother of God, since the diuinity, and humanity of Christ are inseparable. And I freely confesse, that she is in glory both aboue Angells, and men, her owne sonne (that is both God, and man) only excepted. Thus sayth his Maiesty.

49. Heere then, heer arrige aures, good M. Collins (as you sayd to me a little before) heere, I pray you, lay your hand on your
hart, and examine your conscience, whether your beliefe agreeth with his Maiestyes in this point, yea, and how well you haue performed his Maiestyes will, and commandement, who you say gaue you in charge to confute me; but I thinke his Maiestyes meaning was not, that you should also confute him, against whome your argument is as valide, and potent, as against me: so as it seemeth your beliefe (at least in this point) is flatte contrary to h • s Maiestyes.

50. For his Maiesty belieueth as these ancient Fathers, whome I haue alleadged, and we Catholikes, and all good Christians do, that the most glorious Mother of God is glorifyed not only aboue all men, but also aboue all Angells; but you belieue, and labour to proue by the authority of S. Epiphanius, that she is inferiour in glory to Angells, yea to men; for so it would follow, if your argument were ought worth; for S. Epiphanius doth not say that she is inferiour to Angells otherwayes then in nature; and the same he affirmeth also of her in regard of men, to whome he sayth she is also inferiour in nature, by reason of her sexe; if therfore she be inferiour in glory to Angels, because she is inferiour to them in
nature, she is by the same reason inferiour also to men in glory; & so should the theef that after a most wicked life, was saued in the end by the aboundance of Christs mercyes, be more glorifyed now in heauen, then she, albeit she was alwayes immaculate, and spotles, replenished with grace & all vertues, and chosen amongst all creaturs to be the Mother of God. Doth this consequence please you M. Collins? And yet this must follow of your argumēt, if it be good, therefore I remit it to the Readers iudgement, how well you vnderstand S. Epiphanius, from whome you draw such an impious, and absurd conclusion, as to make the Blessed Mother of God inferiour to Angels in glory, because she is inferiour to them in nature, whereby you also contradict not only the ancient Fathers of the Church, but his Maiesty also, yea and most impiously abuse the most Blessed Virgin, extenuating her glory much more then did those Heretiks her enemyes called Antidicomarianitae, of whome I haue spoken before.

51. For if S. Epiphanius accounted them to be heretiks, and her enemyes, and to extenuate her glory, because they taught that she had children by her lawfull husband after the birth of our Sauiour, that is to
say, because they did derogate from the honour of her perpetuall virginity, what would he say of you M. Collins, that seeke to spoyle her, not only of the honour that is done her in earth, but also of the eminent glory, & soueraingty (as I may say) which she hath vnder her Son our Sauiour Christ in heauen, yea, & do abase, and deiect her euen below the meanest Saints? He would no doubt say of you much rather then he did of them, that which I haue alleadged out of him before num. 5. to wit, That you out of the aboundance of an affected madnes, frame blasphemous opinions, open your mouth, and loose your tongue out of a wicked mind; and insteed of Hymnes and glory (which are due vnto her) inuent, and vtter drunken, and contumelious speaches against her, whereas you should honour, and worship that honourable vessell; to this effect I say, he sayd of those blasphemous Heretikes: and the same he would doubtles say of you, who do her no lesse iniury if not more, then they, & abuse him most abominably, in making him the author, or a fauior of your blasphemy, wresting his words to a farre other sense, then euer he meant, besides the iniury you doe not only to vs Catholikes at this day, but also to the Church of God, in charging vs with Idolatry, for yielding to her the honour
which the whole Church hath alwayes approued, and exhibited vnto her.

52. Whereas our bookes written of that subiect, and our doctrine in scholes and pulpits, do proclaime vnto the world; and our consciences do witnes it betwixt God, and vs, that albeyt we honour her, as the mother of God (and consequently as one that is more worthy, and eminent in grace, and glory, then al Saints or Angells) yet wee hould, belieue, and teach that shee is no God, but a meere creature of God; neyther is the honour which the Church doth yeild her diuine honour, but such as may be giuen to a glorifyed creature whome God will haue to be honoured, according to the testimony of our Sauiour Iohn 12. Si quis mihi ministrauerit &c. If any man serue me, my Father wil honour him, or make him to be honoured; which honour is referred finally, and principally to God, for whose sake she is honoured in respect of the participation of the diuine excellency, and the aboundance of grace, wherewith God hath blessed her more then any other pure creature, so as we are so farre from dishonouring God in honouring her, that we do him speciall honour and seruice therin; for seeing he sayd to his disciples,
qui vos recipit, me recipit, qui vos spernit, me spernit, he that receiueth you, receiueth me, he that despiseth you, despiseth me; much more will he account the honour, or dishonour done to his mother, to be done to himselfe, so as the honour be not diuine honour, called latria, proper to him alone, which we neuer giue her, and much lesse to any other Saint or angell.

53. This being so, and most manifest aswell in our doctryn, as in our practise, how impudent is Collins that would face vs downe, that we make her God, and that we cōmit Idolatry vnto her, yea and coupleth vs therein with the Collyridian women, as if S. Epiphanius reproued vs no lesse then them; to which purpose Collins sayth of them, that they (no doubt) would say as we do now, that they stuck to the liuing God; and yet worshipt the Virgin as the notable instrumēt by a subordinate kind of deuotiō, which he would neuer say, if he had not a brazen face; seeing that it is flatly repugnāt to the expresse text of S. Epiphanius, who testifyeth clearely, as I haue already declared, that they sought to introduce her pro Deo, for God, and that therefore they adored her with sacrifice, which is cultus latriae, diuyne worship, and being giuen to any but to God is flat Idolatry.

54. But such is the craft & sleight of the diuel the enemy of all mankynd that he allwayes couereth his malice with some pious pretext; and therefore enuying the honour that is done to gods Saints (and specially to the mother of God) impugneth the same by his instrumentes vnder colour, and pretence to defend Gods honour: whereby it appeareth that you M. Collins are the true bloud of that wicked serpent, which seduced Eue, verifying in your selfe, that which Almighty God sayd vnto him, Ponam inimicitiam inter te & mulierem, semen tuum, & semen ipsius, & ipsa conferet caput tuum, & tu insidiaberis calcaneo eius: that is to say, I will put enmity betwixt thee and the woman, thy seed, and her seed, and she shall crush thy head, and thou shalt lay wayt to her heele: which words of Almighty God, not only many other Fathers, but also S. Epiphanius in his discourse against those blasphemous Heretikes, witnesseth to be fullfilled in the Blessed Virgin, whom he expoundeth to be the woman that shall bruse and crush the head of the serpent; and further affirmeth that as Eue, was called Mater viuentium, the mother of the liuing, so the Blessed Virgin is also Mater viuentium, because she brought forth the Son of God,
who giueth true life to the world: and that therefore, as Eue was cause of death to men, so Mary was cause of life to men. Thus sayth S. Epiphanius: wherupon it followeth that all those which receaue life by Christ, the seed, and sonne of Mary (who taking flesh of her made himselfe our brother) ought to acknowledge her for their Mother.

55. Therefore it is no marueile, that all true Christians do honour and serue her as their Mother, like good children, and so much the more, by how much the spirituall life which they haue receaued by Christ her Sonne, excelleth the corporall life which they haue by their carnall parents. And againe on the other side, it is no wonder, that the seeds of the serpent, following the nature, and will of their Father, do continually impugne her, and her children, labouring by all meanes possible to disgrace and dishonour her & them; whereby it appeareth, of what good brood you are M. Collins, who imitating the serpent your Sire, a • uisti linguam sicut Serpentis, haue whetted your Serpentine tongue against her, Psal. 139. and when you cannot sting her, yet at least you hisse at her, & lye in wayte to bite her by the heele, and spit
your venime, and poison against her children, who loue, honour, and defend her; but when you shall haue done your worst, you will find, that ipsa conteret caput tuum, she shall crush your head, and the head of the Serpent in you, as Almighty God hath both foretould, and promised, Gen. 3.

56. Pardon me good Reader, I beseech thee, if thou thinkest me ouer sharp with this blasphemous miscreāt, whose impiety and blasphemy against the most Blessed Virgin hath iustly kindled my zeale, and whetted my stile against him in defence of her honour, as well for the common obligation that all good Christians haue vnto her, being the Mother of God, as also for the particuler deuotion, I am bound to beare her, for innumerable benefits and fauours spirituall, and temporall, which I haue receaued of Almighty God by her intercession, and speciall protection; in which respect I may iustly prayse, and thanke her with Saint Gregory Nazianzen, who concluding his Tragedy de Christo patiente, doth salute, and inuocate her with an elegant Hymne, whereof I thinke good to set downe part in Greeke, as he wrote it.

p.hi:
To adorne thee (O Soueraigne) I offer vp a crown gathered out of an vncorrupted meadow, because thou hast bestowed many fauours vpon me, and deliuered me from sundry calamityes, from visible enemyes, & much more from inuisible. Graunt that according as I desired, I may end my life, enriched alwayes by hauing thee Patronesse of my life, and an acceptable intercessour to thy Sonne. VVherefore suffer me not to be deliuered, and become a scorne vnto the deadly enemy of mankind. Assist me, and deliuer me from fire, and darknes, by iustifying fayth, and thy fauour; for in thee hath appeared vnto vs grace from Almighty
God; & to thee I do now offer this hymne of thanks. Hayle O Virgin, full of ioy, Mother Virgin, sayrest, and highest of all Virgins, aboue the celestiall legions. Lady, Queene, Ioy of mankind, be alwayes fauourable vnto man, and to me euery where greatest safeguard.

div.p:
57. Thus sayd that ancient Father (who for learning and sanctity of life was one of the lights of Gods Church in his tyme:) thus I say, did he inuocate, prayse and thanke the most Blessed Virgin for benefites receaued from her; and the like I haue iust occasion to say, & to yield her immortall thankes, and prayse as to my speciall Patronesse, and (as S. Athanasius called her) my Lady, and mistresse, & my heauenly Queen, whome with all humility I reuerence, and honour aboue all other creatures, and in whome I repose my chiefe confidence next after our Sauiour Iesus Christ her Sonne, whome therfore I humbly beseech to giue me grace so to serue him, and her his most Blessed Mother, that I may be some way an instrument of her honour, & prayses, to his greater glory; and finally, that I may both spend, and end the small remnant of my d •• es in his seruice vnder her blessed protection. And now to conclude this Chapter, I will say to M. Collins, as S. Ambrose
sayd to others such as he, Epist. 79. Claudat ora sua perfidia, & obmutescat, nec Matrem Domini aliquo audeat temerare conuitio: let Perfidiousnes (or Infidelity) shut vp her mouth, and become dumbe, & not be so audacious as to seeke to disgrace the Mother of God with any reproach. Thus sayth Saint Ambrose. Therefore obmutesce M. Collins, obmutesce.

div.head: M. Collins is conuinced to haue shamefully abused diuers other ancient Fathers, to wit, S Gregory Nissen, S. Chrysostome, the Councell of Constātinople, S. Augustine, and Theodoret; and to haue left my Lord of Winchester in the Lurch vndefended, touching a most fraudulent abuse of Cardinall Bellarmine, wherwith his Lordship was deeply charged in the Adioynder. CHAP. IX.
div.p:
YOv haue seene how M. Collins hath behaued himselfe in his sixt Chapter, in answering my obiections out of three Fathers of the first, and second rancke (according to my Lord of VVinchesters diuision) to wit, S. Basil, S. Ephraene, and S. Gregory Nazianzen, touching their beliefe, and practise (yea,
and the practise of the whole Church in their tyme) in praying to Saints; I will now passe to his seauenth Chapter, & discouer his frauds in answering some Fathers of the third ranke, that is to say, true Fathers and truly cyted, sed nihil adrem, but nothing to the purpose, as my Lord sayth; but how truly he sayth it, and how substantially, and sincerely M. Collins doth maintaine it, let the indifferent Reader iudge.

1. Amongst other Fathers which the Cardinall cited in his Apology pag. 13. for prayer to Saints, and I alleadged in my Adioynder one, was S. Gregory Nissen, brother to S. Basill; who prayed expressly to S. Theodorus the martyr in an oration made publickly in his feast, where he saith thus: Intercede & deprecare &c. Pray, and make intercession for vs to our common King and Lord, to obteyne vs grace &c. To this, as also to all other places of like quality, my Lord of VVinchester g • ue this generall answer; that such prayers of the Fathers are but figuratiue, and Rhetoricall speaches, after the manner of Orators, who in panegyricall, and funeral orations do commonly vse the figures of prosopopaeia and Apostrophe, speaking to dead men, as though they were liuing, yea, and to senselesse things, as S. Ambrose
(sayth he) doth to the water of baptisme, Eusebius to piety, & Gregory Nazianzen to the feast o • Easter.

2. For the confutation of this answer of my Lord of VVinchester, I vrged 4. reasons, whereof I will debate heere only one, to wit the 4. because the other three were more generall; whereas the 4. concerned particulerly the place of S. Gregory Nissen before alleadged, and most imported for the decision of this question; which I beseech thee good Reader wel to note, that thou maist the better consider of the importance of it, & of M. Collins his honest & sincere dealing in answering it. Thus then I sayd in the 7. Chapter of my Adioynder, pag. 263. num. 8. Lastly to put this matter out of all doubt, and to discouer the impertinent vanity of M. Andrewes in this poynt, let vs consider the circumstances of one of the places now heere in question, betwixt the Cardinall & him, I meane the same place of S. Gregory Nissen which I haue layd downe before, taken out of his oration made in the solemnity of the feast of S. Theodorus the Martyr, wherein S. Gregory hauing first touched the great celebrity of the feast by the confluēce of all sorts of people, farre and neere, moueth them to consider thereby how God
rewardeth the iust man, not only in earth, and thereby also incyteth him further to aspyre to the lyke rewards by the imitation of the vertues of those whome God so honoureth; and to this end he discourseth amply of the great honour that was euery where exhibited to the reliques of martyrs, and particulerly of that holy Martyr in that place, and feast, elegantly declaring the magnificence of the Church where his feast was celebrated, adorned with excellent workemanship of all sorts, and namely with pictures, liuely expressing the particularityes of his Martyrdome; wherin, by the way, we may note, the vse of the pictures of Saynts in Churches in those dayes, yea and that they were held to be very profitable for the instruction of the people, seeing that S. Gregory Nissen sayth also vpon this occasion: Solet enim pictura tacens in pariete l • qui, maxime{que} prodesse: for the picture which is sylent vpon the wall, is wont to speak, and to profit exceedingly. So he giuing to vnderstand, that the sight of the picture, or paynted history did greatly edify the people, and styr them vp to the imitation of the Saynts vertues, and holy lyfe. But to proceed.

3. After this the same Father relateth
the feruent deuotion of the people, greatly desiring to approach to the tombe of the Martyr; Credens, sayth he, contrectationem eius esse sanctificationem, & benedictionem, belieuing that the very touching of it would be a sanctification & benediction; yea seeking to get but some of the dust about the tombe, esteeming the same as a thing of great pryce; & if they could haue the good fortūe to touch the reliques themselues, he appealeth to their owne experience and knowledge, how prosperous and happy they would thinke themselues, and how they would imbrace the sayd reliques, kisse them, and apply them to their eyes, eares, and all the instruments of their senses. Deinde sayth he, deuotionis & affectonis lachrimas Martyri &c. And then powring forth teares of deuotion and affection to the Martyr, as though he were there whole, and aliue, they exhibite their humble petition vnto him, as to the seruāt of God, & as one that being inuocated (for so signifieth the greek word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) receiueth what gifts soeuer he will. Thus sayth this ancient & holy Father, & then cōcludeth: ex hijs omnibus, ô popule pie, discite &c. O pious, or godly people, learne by all this, that the death of. Gods Saynts, is honourable, and precious in his sight.

4. All this I haue thought good to lay downe at large, first to confirme al that
which hath hitherto byn treated concerning the custome of the Church at that tyme, not only in the veneration of holy reliques, but also in the expresse Inuocation of Saynts: secondly that this holy Father making all this discourse in the solemnity of that Martyrs feast, to styrre vp the people as well to deuotion towards God, and the Martyr, as to the imitation of the martyrs vertues (for so he himself professeth) did highly approue all that which he hath heere related; and cōsequently when afterwards in the conclusion of the Oration he himself inuocated the Martyr, he did it of pure deuotion, and not of vayne ostentation of his eloquēce, not as a flanting Rhetoriciā, or Oratour, but as a Religious Deuine, and deuout Christian, a pious Pastour, and teacher of his flock, to whome he preached, for whome he prayed, and whome he sought to moue by his owne example, to concurre with him in the Inuocation of the Martyr.

5. Wherein also M. Andrews may if it please him note the word Inuocation vsed by this Father for prayer to the Martyr, of whome he sayth, that the people prayed vnto him, and called vpon him as the minister of God, and as one that receiued (or obtayned of
God) what gifts he would,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is say being inuocated; for I thinke M. Andrewes wil not deny that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Greeke doth properly signify inuocare in Latin, and in English to inuocate. And therefore because he is so curious to runne to the Greeke in all occasions to examine our citations of the Greeke Fathers, I remit him heere to the Greeke; for that I haue byn in this no lesse (if not more) curious then he, hauing searched the old Manuscripts of the Vatican, where I haue seene two written copyes of S. Gregory Nissen, both of them very ancient, and in them both haue found the Greeke words, as heere I haue layd them downe in the margent, with all the rest, very conforme to the Latin translation; and therefore I hope he can take no iust exception thereto.

6. Thus then sayd I in my Adioynder, and to all this what thinke you will M. Collins say? Your fourth obseruation, sayth he, in the eight number, is petitio principij, & the turning of the wheele, & therfore I will not medle with it: let the Bishops answere be but applyed to your obiection, and it will salue it as before. So he. Professing plainely as you see, that he wil not meddle with it, because forsooth it is petitio principij, and as he tearmeth it the turning of the wheele,
which how true it is, I remit to the iudgment of any man, that knoweth what i •
petitio principij; for how do I petere principium or turne the wheele (as he calleth it) when I doe vrge the circumstances of the place, which is in question, to no other end, but to cōfute my Lords expositiō of it, which is thereby clearely confuted, it being manifest by all the circumstances by me alledged, that S. Gregory Nissen did pray to the Martyr S. Theodorus out of pure deuotion, and affection, and not for ostentation of eloquence, not as a Rhetoritian, or as an Orator (as my Lord affirmed of him, and other Fathers praying to Saints) but as a deuout Christian, and a pious pastour, & teacher of his flocke to whome he spake, & whose deuotion towards the Martyr, and inuocation of him he greatly approued and commended; and this is so manifest in the Oration it selfe (as appeareth by the circūstances layd downe by me) that M. Collin •
had indeed great reason not to medle with it, but to seeke some colour, or shift to auoyd it, albeit he could not haue found a more paultry & improbable shift then this, to charge me with petitio principij, whereof there is not so much as any shew or appearance, in all that which I vrged against my
Lord; and therefore wheras M. Collins sayth as you haue heard, that the Bishops answer will salue the obiectiō, if it be but applyed vnto it, he could not for shame haue sayd so, if he layd downe my Text, as I doubt not but you haue euidently seene; yea and noted withall his notable fraud in concealing it, & refusing to answere it vpon such a friuolous, and false pretence.

7. But will you see how this fellow will play, as they say, small game rather then sit out? For although he sayd that he will not meddle with my obiection, yet he hath found somewhat to descant vpon, which I would let passe for a meere foolery, but that there is notable fraud, and falsity in it. You haue seene before in the Abridgment, which I layd down out of S. Gregoryes Oration, that I noted by the way the vse of the Pictures of Saints in Churches in those dayes, & that they were held to be very profitable for the instruction of the people, seeing that S. Gregory hauing signifyed that the Saints martyrdome was painted vpon the walls, added, Solet etiam pictura tacens in pariete loqui, maxime{que} prodesse. For euen the picture which is silent vpon the wall, is wont to speake, and to profit very much. Wherupon M. Collins taketh occasion
to vtter forth a great deale of goo • stuffe, worthy of him, whose special talen • is, to peruert, falsify, and corrupt all th • Authors that he hath occasion to deale with, whereof wee haue seene safficient proofe already, and shall now see so much more, as no man would imagine could passe from any mans pen in so little space, to wit, in lesse then two pages, whereof, good Reader, I will desire no other Iudge but thy self, be thou neuer so partiall to M. Collins.

8. It is therfore to be vnderstood, that yt was his pleasure to take occasion of my foresaid Parenthesis, touching pictures, & to make a large digressiō, for the confutation therof, labouring to proue, that the vse of pictures in the Church, & especially of Almighty God is vnlawfull. And first he beginneth with a place of S. Chrysostome, alleadging in his margent Tom. 7. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; and because the place seemed to me some what strange, especially with his glosse, and interpretation of it, I was desirous to see it in the Father himself, and not fynding any where in our Latyn editions 7. Tomes of him, or yet that Sermon which M. Collins citeth, I sought for the Greeke Edition of Syr Henry Sauill,
(whome I thought he was most like to follow) and found there indeed, that Saint Chrysostomes workes were distributed by him into 8. Tomes, and in the 7. I found the Oration which M. Collins cyteth, and hauing well considered the title, the substance, the drifte, and the particuler circumstances as well of the whole oration, as of the place, and words which he alleadgeth; I assure thee (good Reader) I was amazed to see the impudency of the man, who is not ashamed to wrest that holy Fathers words, to a farre different sense, then euer he meant them.

9. For the Father seeketh only in that Oration to cure the disease (as he tearmeth it) of such as being ouer curious, busy, and bould to search into the incomprehensible mysteries of gods infinite wisdome, prouidence, and iudgments, are scandalized, because they cannot penetrate, and sound the inscrutable depth thereof, whose folly therefore, and audacious curiosity he sharpely reprehendeth, & amongst many other Arguments, which he vseth to confound them, he proposeth the exāple of the Seraphim, who are described in the holy scriptures to stand before the throne of the diuyne Maiesty, couering their faces with
their wyngs, to signify thereby, that the diuyne essence is so incomprehensible, and his iudgments so impenetrable, that those pure, and celestiall spirits dare not so much as behold his face; wherupon S. Chrysostome inferreth, that those men who presume to diue into the bottomelesse depth of the diuyne prouidence, are exceedingly audacious and temerarious; but in all this discourse, he hath not so much as one word of pictures, or of paynting: whereas M. Collins maketh him inueigh most bitterly against such as had pictures of the Seraphim, for thus he sayth pag. 256. lin. 9. S. Chrysostome, of them that would haue the pictures of the Seraphim, because they appeared in such, and such forme, Esay 6. which is your very pretence at this day, why God should be paynted (not the Seraphim only but God; a most monstrous shame) non te defodis? art thou not ashamed, O thou wretch, sayth he, of such a grosse collection? why doest thou not rather run vnder the ground, & bury thy self alyue? And he addes in the same place, that the Seraphim are said to couer their faces with their wyngs at the appearance of God, only to shew that God is incomprehensible; yet you paynt them for theyr wings, wheras their wings are giuen them by the holy Ghost, sayes Chrysostome, to shew
the secrecy, and that it must not be paynted, which cannot so much as be comprehēded. Thus sayth M. Collins, most shamefully belying S. Chrysostome, peruerting his sense, & corrupting his Text, in so much that three notable fraudes may be noted in these few lynes. For, first he sayth that S. Chrys. speaketh, & treateth of those that would haue picturs of the Seraphim, for this special reason, viz. because they haue appeared in such & such forme Esay 6 al which is flatly false; for there is no mention at all in that place, of the picture of the Seraphim, & much lesse of the reason, why some would haue them, & it seemeth that he addeth that reasō craftily of purpose, to wrest the place the more probably to our paynting of God in the forme wherin he hath appeared; which he therefore exaggerateth for a monstrous shame; though he himself may be ashamed of such a monstrous lye, as he hath made therein.

10. Secondly he not only applyeth the words which he alleadgeth out of S. Chrysostome contrary to his meaning (to wit, to those, that would haue pictures of the Seraphim, of whom S. Chrysostome speaketh not at all) but also he corrupteth his Text, making mentiō in a different letter, of a grosse collection, saying, Art thou not a shamed, O thou
wretch of such a grosse collection, wherof there is no mention in S. Chrysostome? and this he doth most fraudulently to perswade the reader, that S. Chrysostome condemned as well the reason of our painting God, and the Seraphim, as the pictures themselues, albeyt S. Chrysostome doth not so much as speake of eyther of both.

11. Thirdly, he falsifyeth also S. Chrysostom notably afterwards in affirming that he sayes, that wynges were giuen to the Seraphim by the holy ghost, to shew the secrecy; and that it must not be paynted, which cannot be comprehended, whereas that holy Father, hath not one word of paynting eyther God, or the Seraphim, or any thing else; and yet he setteth downe the word paynted in a different letter, as a word specially to be noted in S. Chrysostome, which is rather to be noted in M. Collins for a notable fraud and consenage of his Reader; besides that his folly also appeareth in that this falsification of his, is to no purpose: for put the case that S. Chrysostome had sayd, as he maketh him say, viz. that it cannot be paynted which cannot be comprehended, yet it could not touch vs for paynting the forme, wherein God hath appeared, seing that we do not thereby paynt his Deity (which is indeed incomprehensible,
and therefore cannot be paynted) but we paynt only the forme, wherein it hath pleased him to appeare, which forme is both comprehensible, and visible; so as it is euident that this silly fellow hath neyther honesty nor wit: no honesty in that he corrupteth and falsifieth S. Chrysostomes text, no les then his sense; no wit, in doing it so ridiculously, as you see, without prouing any thing against vs, or helping his cause any thing at all.

12. But to the end that the Reader may euidently see the falsity, and corruption of this place of S. Chrysostome, I will set downe the Greeke text of the Father heere in the Margent out of Syr Henry Sauils edition, which is in English thus:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . VVhy doest thou not hide and bury thy selfe in the bowells of the Earth, that with so great temerity wilt search into the prouidence of the ineffable & inenarable power of God, incomprehensible euen vnto the superiour powers? for all thinges that belong to him, are fully manifest only to the Sonne, and the holy Ghost, and to none els. These are the words of S. Chrysostome, which I pray you confer with that
which M. Collins hath layd downe in a different letter for S. Chrysostomes Text (or for the substance therof at least) and you will cleerely see the difference; and that S. Chrysostome doth addresse his speach to those only that presume to search into the mysteryes of Gods prouidence, without mention of Pictures, either of the Seraphim or of any thing els, and much lesse of any gresse collection touching the same.

13. Therefore I will now conclude this point with M. Collins his owne words applying them to him as he wel deserueth: Non te desodis? Art thou not ashamed, O thou wretch (Collins) at such a grosse falsification of a holy Father, and Doctour of Gods Church? VVhy doest thou not rather runne vnder the ground, and bury thy selfe aliue? This truly may be worthily sayd to this shameles wretch, who hath neither conscience, nor shame; for if he had, he could not possibly haue committed such a willfull corruption, and malicious falsity, as heer he hath done, yea & added so many more, as you shall see now in that which followeth.

14. After this place of S. Chrysostome, he alleadgeth another out of a Synod held at Constantinople thus: I say nothing sayth he, of the forbidding of the Lambe to be paynted, in the Councell
