of Constantinople, which Maldonate your fellow-Iesuit in his Comment vpon Daniel, answereth thus: That the Fathers in that Councell were not rightly instructed, & the Church saw more vpon better consideration in after tymes: Yet you make vs belieue that you reuerence the Fathers, and we censure them. Thus sayth M. Collins; wherin I wish to be noted two things; the one that what he alleadgeth & affirmeth of Maldonate, I find not in his Cōment vpon Daniel, and therfore if his notebooke haue deceaued him, and that he find it somewhere els, I wil answere it heereafter when he shall produce it. The other is a notable fraud concerning his allegatiō of the Councell of Constantinople cyted by him to impugne the vse of pictures in Churches, which vse neuerthelesse was ordayned expresly by that Synod, yea and by that selfe same Canon which he cyteth.

15. For albeit those Fathers that were assembled in that Synod, did not thinke it conuenient, that Christ should be paynted in the forme of a Lambe (which they thought more fit, and proper to the ould Testament, as a figure, and shaddow of Christ, then to the new, wherein the verity is expressed) yet they so far allowed of the Image and picture of Christ himselfe,
in the true form of his humanity, that they ordayned the vse of it expresly, in their 82. Canon, which is the same wherin they forbad the paynting of the Lambe; for there it followeth immediatly thus: VVe command (sayth they) that heerafter the Character, or forme of Christ our God, who taketh away the sinnes of the world, shall be set, or placed insteed of the old Lambe, to the end that we comprehending in our mindes the humility of the word of God, may be moued to remember his conuersation with vs in flesh, and his passion and death, and that the world was redeemed by him. Thus sayth that Canon, not only ordayning, as you see, the vse of our Sauiours picture, but also yielding the true reason, which hath euer moued the Church to vse the same.

16. And if this Canon will not satisfy M. Collins in this point, another may also be produced out of the same Councell much more to the purpose, to proue not ōly the vse of pictures, but also the adoratiō of them: I say the adoration, because M. Collins doth hardly brooke that word when it is applyed to pictures or Images, and yet it is vsed expresly by those Fathers in that Councel, to wit, in the 73. Canon, wherin they signify, that for as much as the Crosse doth shew or signify vnto vs our
saluation, we therefore ought to giue vnto it the honour that is conuenient. Quamobrē say they, & mente, & sermone, & sensu, adorationem ei tribuētes, Crucis figuras quae à nonnullis in solo, ac in pauimento fiunt, omnino deleri iubemus, &c. VVherefore we attributing vnto it adoration, both in mind, speach, and sense, do ordayne that the figures or formes of the Crosse (which by many are made in flooers, or pauements) be abolished, lest the Trophey of our Victory be iniured by the treading or trampling of those that goe vpon it; and therefore we decree, that those who shall heereafter make the signe of the Crosse vpon the ground, shall be excommunicated. Thus sayd those Fathers in that Canon: so as you see M. Collins gaineth nothing by his allegation of this Councell against the vse of pictures, but that he hath notably intangled and disgraced himselfe thereby.

17. Neuerthelesse to doe him some pleasure, and to help him out of the bryers, I am content to acknowledge that this Councel of Constantinople, which made these Canons, is of no force, being a schismaticall Councell assembled, and held by the Schismaticall Bishop of Constantinople called Callinichus, without any consent of the Roman, & Westerne Church; besides that they ordayned, and made diuers erroneous
Canons, among the which I am sure there are some, that M. Collins himselfe will acknowledg to be such, especially if he loue a blacke pudding; for they ordayned that if any man do eate bloud, or any meate dressed or made with it, if he be a Clergy man he is to be deposed, if a lay man, he is to be excommunicated; so as if this Canon be in force, M. Collins I thinke hath deserued to be deposed from the Clergy, and ministry many tymes.

18. I omit for breuityes sake, to lay downe other erroneous Canons of that Synod, which Venerable Bede, in whose tyme it was held, in his booke de sex aetatibus, and Paulus Diaconus de gestis Longobardorum lib. 6. cap. 11. do worthily call Erraticam Synodum: Witnessing further that neither Pope Sergius, nor Pope Iohn the 7. nor Pope Constantine could euer be induced either by force or flattery, or fraud to confirme the same; albeit Iustinian the yonger Emperour in whose pallace it was held, did persecute Pope Sergius for the same, in such sort that he made meanes to haue him taken, and brought prisoner to Constantinople; and had effected it, if the Romans had not rescued and deliuered him. But he that desireth to see more concerning this Councell, and
the inualidity thereof, may receaue full sa
• isfaction by the refutation of M. Ioseph Halls • pologeticall discourse, written by C. E. a • earned friend of myne, who hath amply • reated thereof in his second Paragraph • rom num. 45. to num. 81. and amongst di
• ers other things worthy to be noted, set
• eth downe diuers Canons of that Councell, wherein the doctrine of our English Clergy at this day, is in many points ei
• her contradicted or condemned, and therfore I remit M. Collins therto for his further satisfaction.

19. Now then, two things I hope are euident. The one, that it the authority of this Councell be ought worth M. Collins his cake is dow, aswell for the adoration, as for the vse of pictures. Secondly, that being the Councell valid, or voyd, he hath shewed himselfe a cogging companion in alledging it contrary to the true intent, & meaning thereof: for although he sayth truly that those Fathers did forbid the paynting of a Lamb, yet they did it not to the end, & purpose which he pretendeth (that is to say to forbid thereby the vse of Pictures) but because they thought that such a forme did not sufficiently and worthily expresse the humanity of our Sauiour, whome therfore
they ordayned to be represented and painted in his owne forme and shape. Can any thing then be more for our purpose, or more against him? Thus much for this his fraud; which I am sure you will graunt to be a sound one; and so liberall is M. Collins in this kind, that he will not sticke to giue yet two or three more euen touching this matter of Pictures.

20. The next consisteth in his abuse of a place in S. Augustine which he wresteth in like manner against the vse of Pictures, whereas it doth notably proue the same. Thus then he sayth pag. 257. You may remember what S. Augustine sayth de consensu Euangel. lib. cap, 10. Sic errare meruerunt qui Christum non in codicibus, sed in pictis parietibus quaesierunt. So they deserued to be mockt, that sought for Christ not in written bookes but in paynted walls. Thus farre doth M. Collins alleadge S. Augustine.

21. But now to discouer his cozenage therein, it is to be vnderstood that S. Augustine in that place writeth against certayne Paynims, who feygned that they had seen and read bookes of Magicke written by our Sauiour Christ to S. Peter and S. Paul; for the confutation whereof he sheweth what he cōceaued might be the ground or
occasion of that their fiction: Credo (sayth • e) quod pluribus locis simul eos cum illo pictos vide
• ant, quia meritae Petri & Pauli, propter eundem • assionis diem celebrius & solemniter Roma commendat. I belieue that they had seene them (to wit, S. Peter and S. Paul) paynted togeather with Christ • n many places, because Rome doth with great solem
• ity and celebrity set forth the merits of Peter, and Paul, for that they suffered Martyrdome both in one • ay.

22. Thus sayth S. Augustine, giuing to vnderstand, that those Paynims hauing many tymes seene our Sauiour paynted togeather with S. Peter, and S. Paul, and iudging therby that they were two of his most • amiliar, and best beloued disciples, fayned • hat he directed his books of Magicke, rather to them, then to any other, albeit S. Paul neuer liued with Christ (as we Chri
• tians well know) but was conuerted, and made an Apostle after Christs Ascension. and because those Paynims could not haue beene ignorant heereof, and haue erred so grossely, if they had sought to know the true history of Christ, and his Apostles, by the written Ghospell of the Euangelists, & other bookes of Christians, and not by Pictures only, he added with great reason, Sic errare meruerunt &c. So they deserued, to be
deceaued who sought Christ not in bookes, but 〈◊〉 painted walls.

23. Who now is so senseles, as n • to see that this place of Saint Augustine do • proue euidently the common vse of the P •
ctures of Christ, and his Apostles in t •• Primitiue Church, seeing he sayth th • those Paynims had seene Christ paynte • togeather with S. Peter, and S. Paul in ma •• places? And what sayth S. Augustine heer • to shew, or so much as to insinuate any d • like of pictures, who only condemned, 〈◊〉 worthily derided the folly of those P ••
nims in that they groūded their knowle • of Christ, and consequently their ficti •• vpon pictures only, whereby they wer • & might easily be deceaued; whereas the • might well haue vnderstood the truth b • the historyes written by the Euangelist • and other Christians. And what is this 〈◊〉 the condemnation of the vse of Pictures? 〈◊〉 doubt not therefore, but that this m •• passe also for a fraud, besids his notable folly, still to make rodds for himselfe, by producing places that ouerthrow him.

24. There resteth yet a fourth fraud o • his concerning what S. Gregory Nissen say • of Pictures in the place by me alleadged, and vrged before, whereof he sayth thus,
Nissen speakes of pictures for ornament only, for instruction eyther very fayntly, or not at all. So sayth this honest doctor, who durst not haue said so, if he had laid downe the words of that Father alleadged by me, viz. Solet pictura tacens in pariete loqui, maxime{que} prodesse: the picture which is silent vpon the wall is wont to speak, and profit exceedingly: whereby he signifieth (not fayntely, but resolutely) that pictures in the Churches serue for instruction, yea, & moue to deuotion, and vertue; for els, how could he say that they speak, and are exceeding profitable, but because men are not only taught by the sight of them, what to imitate in the Saints, but also moued, and stirred vp thereby to the imitation of thē, which indeed must needs be very profitable, and auayle very much to the obteyning of vertue. Loe then how liberall, or rather how prodigall this man is of his frauds, who hath bestowed vpō vs no lesse then halfe a dozen, in a discourse wherein he professed to be very briefe, and vpon the occasion only of a Parenthesis of myne concerning a by-question touched by the way; what marueyle then that his whole worke conteyning aboue 550. pages be fraught with so many fraudes, and loaden with so many lyes, that I shall not haue
tyme to discouer the least part of them.

25. But now to conclude concerning the place of S. Gregory Nissen, I doubt not, but that you haue noted therein the euidēt testimony that he giueth of the beleif and practise of the Church in his dayes conforme to ours, aswell for the worship of holy relicks, and vse of pictures in the Church, as for the inuocation of saints; and that M. Collins hath had no other meanes to answer it then by a pretence of petitio principij in me, to take occasion thereby not to meddle with it; whereas you haue seene how false his pretence is, and how well the place deserued a particuler, and substantiall answer, if he could haue giuen any to any purpose. But now let vs see, what he will say to a place of another Auncient Father, to wit Theodoret, which I alleadged also in my Adioynder, pag. 289. nu. 44. Thus then I said.

26. This acient Father writing against the Gentills of his tyme, and prouing by many euident arguments that Christ is God, vrgeth notably the great honour generally exhibited in those dayes to Martyrs in the sumptuous, & manificent Churches that were then dedicated vnto them, wherof he sayth thus: Ne{que} verò ad haec per annum
semel, aut bis &c. We do not vse to come to these only once, or twyce, or fiue tymes in the yeare, but we do often celebrate festiuall dayes in them; we do often euery day sing hymnes, and prayses to the Lord of those Martyrs; and men that are in health do pray to be conserued in it, and those that are sicke do craue health; also barren women and men do desire to haue children, and those that are already Fathers doe seeke to haue their Children conserued. Also trauaylers
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Doe craue the Martyrs to be their companions in their way, and guyds of their iourney; and those that are safely returned, giue thankes, confessing the benefit receiued,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . not comming to them, as to Gods, but praying to them as to diuine men, and beseeching them to be intercessors for thē. And that they do obtayne those things which they piously, and faithfully craue, it is testifyed by the gifts, that are offered by such as haue made vowes, which are manifest tokens that they haue obtayned their desired health; for some do hang vp figures (or representations) of eyes, some of feete, some of hands, all
made of siluer, or gould; and their Lord doth gratefully accept what gift soeuer is giuen, and disdayneth none, though neuer so small and meane, measuring them according to the ability of the giuer. Therefore those gifts being set forth to the publike view of all men, are most euident signes, and testimonyes, that those which giue them are freed from their diseases, & haue recouered their health. These I say, do shew what is the vertue or power of the Martyrs; and the power and vertue of the Martyrs doth declare, that he whome they haue worshipped and serued, is true God. Thus sayth Theodoret.

45. And can any man desire a more cleare, and manifest testimony, eyther that the generall custome of the Church was to pray to Saynts in his tyme, or that God approued it with miraculous effects? Yea, and that the same was held for a speciall argument to proue that Christ was God? Wherein also it is to be obserued, that the vse was in that age (about eleauen hundred yeares agoe) to hang vp votiue Images and representations of hands, feete, eyes, and such like, to testify the miraculous recouery of bodily health by the intercession of Saynts, which therefore is no
moderne custome of these later ages (as our aduersaryes falsely affirme it to be) but an auncient practice of the primitiue Church. Wherupon it also followeth not only that prayer to Saynts is most lawfull and honorable to almighty God, and profitable to men, but also that Saynts hear the prayers that are made vnto them, seeing that they obtayne the grant thereof, and giue succour to the suppliants. Thus said I in my Adioynder.

28. And now I am sure (good Reader) thou longest to see, with what sl •• ght he will • eek to shift of this. The truth is, he vndertaketh to answere it, and that very amply, but with such falsehood, as thou wouldst wonder to see it, if thou hadst not seene so many, and so exorbitant all ready that now it wilbe no wonder vnto thee. First he seeketh to cast vpon me some suspition of fraud, or falsity, saying pag. 273. nu. 23. VVhen I cast myne eyes, sayth he, vpon Theodorets owne text (not as you trenlace, and translate it at pleasure) I see very little to make for you, if ought at all. So he, seeming to charge me with some false translation, albeyt he sheweth nor wherein, eyther heere or els where, no not so much as of any one word; which he would infalliby haue done with
no small tryumph, and insultation if he had found any.

29. But then he goeth forward and tells vs, that Theodoret reports only fashion, and vse, and that not general, which he sayth I promysed in the text of my seauenth Chapter; wherein he saith truly (for so much as concerneth my promise) for indeed I promised there to shew euidently that the Inuocation of Saints was generally practised in the primitiue Church, as well by the ancient Fathers, as by all other faythful Christians; to which purpose I produced amongst diuers other testimonyes this of Theodoret, who sheweth it manifestly as you haue seene, vrging notably against the Paynims the great honour that was done generally to Martyrs at those dayes, to proue that Christ is God; and therefore whereas M. Collins tells his Reader, That Theodoret reports only fashion, and vse, but not generall, he seekes to delude him egregiously.

30. Neuertheles this is but a peccadilio, in respect of that which followeth a few lines after in these words: Neither does Thedoret say that the people made their prayers to the Martyrs, but hauing spoken in the last wordes of the God of Martyrs, he addes immediatly of their praying for all such things as they stand in need of, but specifieth
not to whome they pray for them, whether to God, or to the Martyrs, to whome then rather then to the God of Martyrs? Thus sayth M. Collins; but with what conscience you may easily iudg by reflecting a little vpon the place of Theodoret, set downe by me a little before, wher you see the flat contrary of that which he affirmeth; for wheras he sayth, that Theodoret doth not specify to whome they prayed, you see that he sayth expresly, they prayed to the Martyrs (not as to Gods) but as to diuine men, beseeching them to be intercessours for them; and to the end that there should be no doubt of the translation of Theodorets wordes out the Greeke, I did set downe the greeke Text in the margent of my Adioynder (as I haue done also heere) that the learned Reader might be the better satisfyed of the truth thereof.

31. Now then can any man thinke, that M. Collins hath any conscience at al, or any sparke either of grace, or honesty who saw this, and not only dissembled it, but also affirmed the quite contrary? Yet not content with this, he sayth also afterwards in the next page, that wheras Theodoret sayd that the poore way-fayring mē craued the Martyrs to accompany them in their way, he turned Rhetorical, and meant no other
then only to oppose the exaltation of Christian Saints to the Gentill Gods so farre, as was compatible with Christs true Religion: and how proueth he this? Marry forsooth two wayes; the one with a notable foolery, and the other with a manifest, & shamefull fraud. I omit the foolery to discouer the fraud. Thus then he sayth: Theodoret correct • ng himselfe, is fayne to say
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; not absurdely distinguishing betwixt Dulia, and Latria, as your bray • es crow; but deprecating the scandall which his former words might seeme to imply. So he.

32. But to the end that his fraudulent and bad conscience may the better appeare thou shalt vnderstand good Reader, that immediatly after those greeke wordes, which he alledgeth viz
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (that is to say not comming to them, as to God) ther follow immediatly in the greek text of Theodoret these words: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 &c. (that is to say, but praying to them as to d • uine men &c. which wordes doe quite spoyle M. Collins his deuise, and ouerthrow all that he hath sayd heere.

23. For it proueth, that Theodoret did not turne Rhetoricall (as M. Collins tearmes it) that is to say, he did not speake rhetorica • ly, by the way of Amplification, when
he sayd, that the way-faring men craued the Martyrs to be their Companions in their way, but spake truly as he thought & belieued, seeing that he declareth presently after, in what sort they and the other supplyants of the sayd Martyrs, craued their help, to wit, praying to them not as to Gods, but as to diuine men, beseeching them to be intercessours for them. Heerby also it appeareth what an impertinent and idle glosse he maketh presently after vpon these wordes of Theodoret
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which he sayes, does not force that they prayed to the Martyrs to accompany them, whose company they might beg as well of God, and he licence them. So sayth he, but it appeares by that which you see is dissembled by him, that they prayed to the Martyrs themselues, though not as to Gods, but as to diuine men.

34. Lastly, wheras he sayth, that Thedoret doth not distinguish betweene Dulia, and Latria (as my braynes crow) because he correcteth himselfe, saying 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (that is to say, not comming to them as to Gods) I thinke he was no lesse brainles then shameles, when he wrot so; for albeit those greeke wordes alone (which he setteth downe) do not distinguish betwixt Dulia, and Latria, yet being connected, and ioyned
with the other which immediatly follow (& were by him shamfully dissēbled) they make a plaine distinctiō betwixt dulia and latria though not in formall words, yet in substance, and effect. For when Theodoret sayth, that those supplyants came not to the Martyrs as to Gods, he signifyeth plainely, that they did not giue to the Martyrs diuin honour which is latria, and is due to God alone; and when he addeth, that they prayed to them as to diuin men, beseeching them to be intercessours for them, he gaue to vnderstand, that they exhibited vnto them an inferiour honour due to Gods glorifyed seruants which we call Dulia, and is due to saints. So as you see how false & found he is in euery thing.

35. But yet the silly fellow hath not the wit to make an end heere, but within foure lines after falleth vpon two other greeke wordes of the same sentence of Theodoret, to wit, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, to become intercessours, which he glosseth thus: As for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , let the Saints pray for vs as much as you will, that is nothing to our question of praying to them. So he, whereas two other wordes which immediatly follow those that he alleadgeth, do vtterly cōfound him; for there followeth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , so as the sentence is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, and beseeching (them) to be intercessours for them; & is this, trow you, nothing to our question of praying to those martyrs? Besides that the whole period being, as I haue sayd before (to wit, not comming to them as to Gods, but praying to them as vnto diuine men, and beseeching them to be intercessours for them) doth make the matter far more cleare, and doth conuince him of the most willfull, and malicious falshood, & fraud that hath byn cōmitted by any writer of this age, thogh it aboundeth with men of his coate, and profession, that excell in that faculty.

36. But let vs yet see some more of his iugling. There followeth presently after in my Adioynder, a place of S. Augustine in his book de cura pro mortuis, first alleadged by my Lord of VVinchester pag. 46. to proue that the Saints do not heare our prayers, or know our actions, because S. Augustine sayth that the dead are not present at the affayres of men; in answere wherof I sayd in pag. 291. num. 47. that his Lordship might haue learned in that booke of S. Augustine, which he cyteth, That albeit the dead do not naturally know what passeth in earth, neither are ordinarily conuersant with vs, yet they may know our actions as well by the relation of Angells, as by diuine reuelation, yea,
and that they may be present with vs, and help vs, per diuinam potentiam, by diuine power. Thus sayd I, alleadging for the same S. Augustine, de cura pro mortuis.

37. And will you now see, what M. Collins sayth to this? Truely he thought good to say somewhat to it, & to do his best to proue that Saints: Do not know our prayers by the relation of Angells. But because he imagined that his reasons would weigh farre lesse in the iudgment of his Reader, if he should seeme to contradict S. Augustine, he thought it best to make no mentiō of him at al, but to lay all his battery against me, as though I alone had sayd it, and of my own head: so as now I must be beaten for S. Augustine, or rather he in my coate, & skyn, but you, I thinke, will wonder what potent reasons could make this silly Doctour so confident as to contemne and impugne the authority of one of the greatest Doctors of Gods Church. You shall heare them, for albeit I had determined, and promised to meddle no more with his fooleryes, yet for as much as these are accompanied with a continuall fraud, in that he dissembleth & impugneth S. Augustine his doctrine, throgh out the whole as if it were only myne, I hould my selfe obliged to answere for S.
Augustine, and withall as well to discouer his folly, as his fraud.

38. Thus then he sayth p. 276 n. 26. VVheras you say num 47. that the Saints know our prayers by the relation of Angells. First, how shall the Angells know them to relate them? By reuelation from God, you will say: but he that reueales to the Angells might reueale to the Saints, eadem opera; what needs this reuelation then? Sic fieri per plura, quod potuit per pauciora. Thus sayth this deepe Deuine, who you see demands how the Angells do know our prayers to relate them, and assures himselfe (as it seemes) that I will say, they know them by reuelation.

39. But truly he is much deceaued as sure as he makes himselfe; for albeit I doe not deny, but that they may know our prayers by reuelation, yet it were great folly to thinke that they need reuelation to know those things which they see & know by ordinary meanes. Hath not this great Doctour trow you, read in the holy Script • res Haebr. 1. that the Angells are all Administratorij spiritus &c. Ministring spirits sent for them, which shall receaue the inheritance of saluation, whereby he may vnderstand, that they are cōtinually imployed by Almighty God
heere in earth for the benefit and good of his elect? Or can he be ignorant of that which our Sauiour himselfe doth teach vs, Matth. 18. to wit, that Angeli eorum &c. The Angells of his little ones do alwayes see the face of his Father, which is in heauen? Vpon which place and diuers others in the holy Scriptures (which I omit) the ācient Fathers do teach both the continuall presence of Angells amongst vs, and also that euery man hath a proper Angell for his guardian or keeper.

43. So sayth S. Hierome lib. 3. comment. in Matth. S. Ambrose lib. de viduis. S. August. Tom. 10. serm. 8. de natali Domini. S. Basil. in psal. 48. & contra Eunom. lib. 3. where he proueth it by diuers places of Scriptures. The like doth S. Chrysostome hom. 40. in cap. 21. Matth. Also Origen hom. 33. in Luc. Ioan. Cassian. coll. 13. Cyril. contra Iulian. lib. 4. and to omit others, S. Bernard serm. 12. vpon the psalme Qui habitat; where he aduiseth vs to yeild to our proper Angells, deuotion for their beneuolence, loue for their care, and reuerence for their presence, and continual assistance. Whereby M. Collins may fall into the account of his own beastly ingratitude, towardes his proper Angell, and all other holy Angells, seeing that he doth not acknowledge the continual benefits, that he and all other men receaue
by them, but also blasphemously impugneth the respect, reuerence, & honour that is due vnto them. Well then this being so, what need haue the Angels of an extraordinary reuelation from Almighty God, or know our prayers, and actions which they vnderstand, and see continually being amongst vs?

41. Furthermore he cannot be excused of a wilfull, and fraudulent dissimulation of S. Augustins discourse in this place concerning this poynt, confirmed by him with the Authority of the holy Scripture, and therefore I think good to lay downe S. Augustins words heere. Possunt, sayth he, & ab Angelis, qui rebus quae aguntur hic praesto sunt, audire aliquid mortui &c. the dead may also heare by the Angells (which are present here at such things as are done) some such thing as he, to whome all things are subiect, doth iudge fit for euery one of thē to vnderstand, for if Angells could not be present in the places both of the liuing, and the dead, our Lord Iesus would not haue said thus: It came to passe that the poore man dyed, and was carryed by Angels into the bosome of Abraham; therfore they may be sometimes heere, and sometymes there who by the will of God carryed (Lazarus) from hence thither. Thus sayth S. Augustine.

42. And might not this haue sufficed
to informe this Doctor that S. August. did not only hold that the Angells may know our actions by being present with vs, but also that he confirmed the same with the authority of Scripture? wherto if I should add al the places of the ould, & new Testament, which do testify the ordinary imploymēts, & ministery of Angels on earth & their intercourse in humane affayres, it might seem incredible that a Doctor & a publick professor of diuinity should be so ignorant of it, as to thinke that they cannot know our prayers, but by reuelation.

43. But put the case yt were so, how would it follow that the reuelation were needles as he inferreth? Marry sayth he, because God might reueale to the Saints eadē operâ, and so auoyd the inconuenience of doing the things per plura, which may be done by pauciora. But how absurd, & ridiculous is this? for so should all secondary causes cease, as needeles, because Almighty God might do all things by his omnipotent power, without vsing any instrument or meane; so then was it needeles and superfluous, that an Angell should be sent to the bl • ssed Virgin, or to Zacharias Luc. 1. or to S Ioseph; because God might haue reuealed his will vnto them himself imediately;
so also was the ministery of Angels superfluous, and needlesse, when they were imployed, and sent by Almighty God in the ould Testament to the Patriarches, & Prophets; and to insist also vpon the example alleadged by S. Augustine, it was needles that the Angels should carry the soule of Lazarus into Abrahams bosome, whither Almighty God might haue transported it by his only will, or word, by the which he made heauen and earth, and all things els.

44. Finally, if M. Collins will tye Almighty God to do nothing per plura, which he may doe per pauciora, he most needes confesse, that it was superfluous, and in vayn, that 7. dayes should be spent in the Creation of the world, which God might haue made in an instant; and the like may be sayd of our Redemption, and of the gouernement of the Church: & of the whole world, wherein wee see God doth effect very many things, or rather all things by the ministery of his seruants, and other Creatures, which he might do by his owne power immediately, if in his diuine wisdome he thought it conuenient.

45. Do you see then what a wise Doctor we haue, who argueth so substantially,
as not only to deny to Almighty God the seruice, vse, and ministery of his Creatures (because he may do his will without them) but also to controle the manner of our Creation, and redemption, because frustra fit per plura quod fieri potest per pauciora. But let vs see some more of his arguments. Secondly sayth he, VVho makes that the Angells worke to be offerers of our prayers to the Saints in heauen? Is this worthy of them? Is it a fit work to imploy Angells about? So he: wherto I answere, that S. Augustine was belike much ouerseene in assigning to the Angells so meane an office: but perhaps the ouersight may be rather in M. Collins, who measuring the Angells by himself, imagineth that those celestial spirits are as proud and vncharitable as he, who if he were an Angell (as he is neuer like to be, except perhaps some bad Angell, and one of the worst) he would disdaine to be so imployed; but seeing that their humility, & charity is such, that they vouchsafe to vndertake the guard and protection of men in earth (yea of the greatest sinners) S. Augustine had great reason to think, that they refuse not to do all the charitable offices, that are any way requisite for the good, and comfort of the elect, for whose saluation
they are sent, and imployed heere in earth, as I signifyed before out of the Apostle to the Heb. cap. 1.

46. But will you heare how he confoundeth S. Augustine, and ouerthroweth him quite? He goeth forward thus: And surely if this be once entertayned, that the Angells acquaint the Saints with our prayers, which els they should not know but for them, will not the Pagan opinion which S. Ambrose hissed out (and you with him euen now) returne; that God should be ignorant also of our affayres vnlesse the Angells reuealed them? For you make the Angells to offer our prayers to God, to a iust reward of your peruerting so the Apocalyps cap. 5. vers. 8. Thus sayth M. Collins like a deep Deuine and a terrible Logician, in so much that S. Augustine was neuer so put to his trumps by any aduersary of his (were he Manichaean, Donatist, or Pelagian) as he is now by M. Collins; but because S. Augustine cannot answere for himselfe, I will be so bould as to answere for him, and say somewhat briefly to this powerfull argument.

47. Therfore, first it is to be considered that Saint Augustine sayth not, that the Saints cannot know our prayers but by Angells (as M. Collins seemeth falsely to suppose) but that the Saints do not naturally know what is done in earth, and yet that
they may know it, either by the Angells, or by reuelation from Almighty God. And put the case that S. Aug. had sayd as M. Colli ••
relateth that they do not know our prayers but by Angells, how would it follow, that the Pagan opinion (hissed out by S. Ambrose) would returne (to wit, that God should be ignorant of our affayres, if the Angells did not reueale thē to him?) Would any man be so absurd to thinke that the infinite wisedome, and knowledge of God doth any way depend vpon the limitted knowledge of Saints, or Angells, and to inferre thereupon, that God cannot know some thinges without the reuelation of Angels because the Saints cānot? VVho euer heard the like inference? Which therefore may wel be hissed out with the Pagan opinion, and M. Collins also, for supposing, that any Christian man would be so simple, and absurd to make it.

48. Yea, but (sayth he) you make the Angells to offer our prayers to God too? What then M. Collins? VVill that bring in the Pagans opinion, that God can know nothing but by Angells? We make also the Priest (when he offereth sacrifice at the Altar) offer vp our prayers to Almighty God, and must we needes thinke therefore that
God could not know them but by him? The office of the Bishops, & Priests in the ould Law was to offer to God the sacrifice, and prayers of the people (as mediatours betwixt God and them) but was there euer any so ridiculous to thinke, that they did it, because God could not other wayes vnderstand the necessityes and prayers of the people but by them? Yet this forsooth is the Club, wherwith this great Hercules hoped to beat downe S. Augustine.

49. But what he meaneth by his conclusion, That this is a iust reward of our peruerting the Apoc. cap. 5. vers. 8. I know not for my part, neither how we peruert that place in the Apocalyps, neither how we are rewarded for it; the place is cleare to proue that the Angells offer vp the prayers of the holy men on earth, by the interpretation of S. Iohn himself, saying that the 24 Seniors had euery one golden Phialas, plenas odoramentorum, quae sunt orationes sanctorum, full of sweet odours, which are the prayers of the holy; which words can haue no other litterall sense, but that the Angells offer to God, orationes Sanctorum, the prayers of holy men. So as M. Collins, and his fellowes may be ashamed to deny it (what mysticall sense soeuer is, or may be drawne out of it) therfore
when he shall tell vs, what other litterall sense it hath, and how we peruert it, I will answere him further.

50. In the meane tyme he may vnderstand if it please him, that it is no new opynion of the Catholicks at this day, that the Angells do offer vp our prayers to God, seeing that S. Hilary teacheth it in his exposition of the Psalme 129. alleadging the example of the Angell Raphael in Tobias: the like doth S. Hierome vpon the 10. of Daniel, expounding the Angels wordes to Daniel thus: I am that Angell, which offers thy prayers to God. Also S Augustine in his Epist 120. cap. 92. affirmeth expresly that the Angells doe not only signify the benefits of God to vs, but also represent our prayers to him: and finally to omit others, S. Bernard serm. 7. in Cantica, sayth: Credimus sanctos Angelos &c. VVe belieue that the holy Angells are present with men when they pray, and offer their prayers to God. Therfore to conclude this point, 2. things are euident heerein; the one, that M. Collins hath impugned S. Augustine most ridiculously, and childishly; the other that he hath done it with great fraude, and craft vnder my name only, whereas the discourse and doctrine which he taxeth, is S. Augustines, & as his only alleadged and related by me.

51. The like he hath done also afterwards with much more fraud, touching another place of S. Augustine in the same booke, de cura pro mortuis, which I cyted in my Adioynder to proue the apparition of Saints, and the help they affoard to their supplyants; the occasion was, that the Cardinall alleadged the words of S. Augustine testifying the apparition of S. Felix in the siege of Nola, thus: Audiuimus non incertis rumoribus, sed certis testibus &c. VVe haue heard not by vncertaine rumours, but by assured witnesses, that the Confessour Felix hath appeared not only by the effects of benefits, but also to the sights of men. Thus farre the Cardinall alleadgeth Saint Augustines wordes. VVhereto my Lord of VVinchester answered in his Apology cap. 8. pag. 178. that, de Felice Augustinus nihil praeter auditum habet &c. Concerning Felix Augustine hath nothing but by hear-say, and whether it were done by the very presence of the Martyrs, or by Angells taking the shape of the Martyrs vpon them, or perhaps by both these wayes, Augustine dare not determine, so vncertaine is he touching this question of apparitions. Thus sayd my Lord: wherto I replyed in my Anioyder, that it appeared euidently by the wordes of S. Augustine before recyted, that he giueth another manner of assurance of this apparition, then my
Lord acknowledged in his answere, who maketh it a matter very vncertayne, as depending vpon a bare heare-say, whereas S. Augustine excludeth all vncertainty of rumours, and fortifyeth his relation, with the testimonyes of assured witnesses. Thus sayd I, pag. 394. num. 42.

52. And now that you may see how substantially M. Collins answereth this, and how faythfully he relateth the substance of my reply, you shall heare his owne words; thus then he sayth pag 383. num. 20. To your numb. 42. & 43. What we heare from witnesses, yet we do but heare, when you haue made the most of it, so as the Bishop might well say: Augustinus nihil praeter auditum habet, Augustine hath nothing more then hear-say, meaning, he reports not this of his owne knowledge, though he would not seeme to deny credit to those witnesses; which many a man to say truth is loth to do, I mean to detract any thing from the credit of the reporters, euen then when he scarse belieues that which is tould. Thus sayth M. Collins.

53. But could he (thinke you) haue sayd this for shame, if he had set downe S. Augustines wordes alleadged, and vrged by me, as before you haue seene? S. Augustin testifyeth
the apparition not vpon vncertaine rumours (as he himselfe sayth) but by the testimony of assured witnesses, confirmed also by the effects of benefits, no lesse then by the sight of men; and M. Collins maketh it doubtful, whether S. Augustine belieued it or no; as if out of courtesy, and good manners only he would not derogate from the credit of the reporters, though he scarce belieued it; for so M. Collins insinuateth, though he do not affirme it directly of S. Augustin, but of many a man, which neuertheles he would haue you to suppose of S. Augustine in this case; for els why doth he say it? May not this passe as well for a fraud, as for a miserable & poore defēce of my Lord of VVinchesters bare heare-say? But let vs proceed to the rest of my Lords answer touching the manner of such apparitions, wherof I sayd thus, pag. 394. num. 43.

54. Whereas M. Andrews addeth, that S. Augustine was so vncertayne of this matter of apparitions, that he durst not define, whether they were made by the Saints themselues, or by Angels in their lykenes, he saith true, though I know not what he can inferre thereon for his purpose, seeing that S. Augustine maketh no question of the verity of apparitions (and much
lesse of the benefit and help which deuout people receiued thereby) but only of the manner how the same was performed, & therefore he saith in the beginning of that discourse, Ista quaestio &c. This question surpasseth the force of my vnderstanding, how Martyrs do help those, quod per eos certum est adiuuari, who it is certayne are helped by them. So he. And then proceedeth with the question, whether the Martyrs are themselus present in so diuers places, and so far asunder at one tyme, or whether Almighty God do satisfie the deuotion of the people by the ministery of Angels, through the merits of the Martyrs, or els whether it be done both waies. This he saith he dare not define, confessing and teaching euidently as much as we require in this matter, to wit that deuout people are certainly helped by the Martyrs. Neyther is it to be wondred, that S. Augustine would not take vpon him to determine how the same was wrought, saying that euen in ordinary and naturall things, the effects are euident and certayne, and yet the causes are many tymes eyther vncertayn, or els wholy vnknowne, which is to be graunted much more in supernaturall and miraculous euents, as I haue shewed euidently in the
last Chapter, where I haue confuted such another ridiculous argumēt of his against Prayer to Saints.

55. For albeit he had resolued, that the Saints themselues do not appeare or assist at their tombes, but Angels in their shape and lykenes; yet it could not be sayd but that apparition is theirs, being made by Gods expresse ordinance for their merits, in their name & lykenes, for the benefit of those that expect & craue their help; especially seeing it is vsually said in the holy Scriptures, that God spake & appeared to Abrahā Gen. 18. & Moyses Exod. 3. when neuertheles it was done by the ministry of Angels, and not in any shape that could represent him; and therfore S. Augustine had great reason to say, that S. Felix appeared, & that the Martyrs per diuinam potentiam viuorum rebus intersunt, are by the diuine power present at the doings or affaires of men: although afterward he moueth a question concerning the manner of it, and doth not deny, but that it may be done by the ministery of Angels. Hereby then it appeareth, that this place of S. Augustine so clearely proueth the Apparition of Saints, & that men are helped by their prayers and merits, that M. Andrews had no other way
to shift it off handsomly, but to omit the wordes of S. Augustine as of small moment, & testifying only a sleight matter o heare-say. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder.

56 To all this M. Collins answereth thus pag. 384. lin. 15. But is not that pretty, number 44. that though the Saints appeare not in their own persons, yet the apparition may wel be called theyrs, viz. because Angells appeare for them in their name and likenes; as if the diuell did not counterfeit their name and likenes too, and therefore he appearing, they may be sayd to appeare, as well, as when the Angells, by this reason. So he: wherein it is to be noted, first that he passeth ouer with silence all S. Augustines discourse, without so much as mentioning it or him, to the end that he might seeme to impugne me only, and not him: secondly that which he setteth downe in a different letter, as my words (or at least as the substance therof) is farre different from myne, which cannot by any meanes admit that diuellish example which he bringeth of the Diuell appearing in the name, & likenes of a Saint.

57. For the reason which I gaue, why the apparition of an Angell in the name, and likenes of a Saint, may be called the apparition of the Saint, had three grounds, to
wit, because it is made first by Gods expresse ordinance, secondly, for the merits of the Saints, and thirdly for the benefit of those that expect, and craue his help; of which three respects or considerations, the • wo later do exclude all diabolical illusions • nd therefore M. Collins doth not mention any of them in the words before alleadged by him, as myne, but maketh me say; that the Angells apparition is the Saints appa
• ition, & this for no other cause, but because Angells appeare for the Saints in their name, & like
•• es, as, sayth he, the Diuell also doth. But when or where the Diuell doth it, or hath done it, he doth not tell vs: neuerthelesse I do not deny, but that the Diuell may do • t, if God will ordaine, or permit it, in which case I graunt also that his apparitiō may be called the apparition of the Saint, as in the opinion of some (especially of the Heretickes of this tyme) Samuel is sayd in the Scripture 1. Reg. 28. to haue appeared, when neuerthelesse they say the Diuell appeared in his likenes; so as (according to their opinion) M. Collins his diuellish instance maketh directly for me, and against him.

58. And therefore he goeth the more boldly forward striking stil at me by name
(but lighting indeed vpon S. Augustine) carping at one of those considerations of his, which before he omitted, and concealed, to wit, touching the Saints merits, whereof he sayth thus: yet ridiculously you add, that Angel • appeare for the Saints merits, and so the Angells apparition is the Saints apparition. So he, making S. Aug. ridiculous (or to say truely himself rather) especially considering how he peruerteth S. Augustins sense, concerning the Saints merits; for thus he sayth: But first we haue tould you our mind about merits, in the former part of this book, which if any were in this life, yet none in the other, none in Patria where the saints are. They haue done meriting, and yet to merit for others is more abominable then for ones self. But for men to merit that Angells should come, and do offices in their names is most absurd of all, and therefore worthy of F. T. whatsoeuer he is.

59. Thus sayth this graue Doctour, as if I had sayd, that the Martyrs, or Saints did merit in heauen, whereas I only relating briefly the substance of S. Augustines discourse, do make mention of the merits of the Martyrs in the same sense that S. August. doth, who deuideth the questiō into two members, or parts: the one, whether the Martyrs themselues are present at their memoryes
or tombes, where the supplyants • eceaue help or comfort, or whether they • eing loco meritis suis congruo, in a place āsw
• rable to their merits (meaning no doubt • heir merits whilest they liued on earth) • nd praying generally, pro indulgentiae suppli
• antium, for the need of the supplyants; Almighty God hearing the prayers of the said Martyrs, doth giue comfort, and reliefe by • he ministry of Angells, & out of his mer
• eilous, and ineffable power and bounty,
• uorum merita Martyrum commendat, doth cōmend or illustrate the merits of his Martyrs where, when, and how he will, and espe
• ially at their memories, Quoniam hoc nouit • obis expedire ad aedificandam fidem Christi, pro • uius confessione sunt passi, because he knoweth • hat this is expedient for vs, for the edifica
• ion, or confirmatiō of the fayth of Christ, • or the confession whereof they suffered. Thus saith S. Augustine.

60. And albeit he sayth, that he dare not take vpon him to determine how the Martyrs do giue help, & comfort to those, quos per eos certum est adiuuari, who it is cer
• aine are helped by them, as whether it be done by one of these two wayes before specifyed, or by both; neuertheles 4. thinges are euident heerein.
61. The first, that he acknowledgeth expresly, that the help is giuen by the Martyrs, saying certum est, it is certain that me • are helped by them.

62. The second is, that both thes • wayes, are in his opinyon not only probable, but also most conforme to the Catholick verity and fayth: for otherwayes he would not haue supposed that God would giue succour or help by eyther of them.

63. The third is, that he holdeth, & teacheth here, that God doth these fauours aswell in respect of the prayers of the Martyrs, (exaudiens, sayth he, Martyrum pretes hearing, or graunting the Martyrs prayers) 〈◊〉 also in regard of the merits of his Martyrs Commendans suorum merita martyrum, commending his Martyrs merits, that is to say, shewing or testifying their merits to the world.

64. Lastly, it is manifest, that by which way soeuer the benefit be done (eyther by the presence of the Martyrs, or by Angells in their shape or likenes) the apparition may (in S. Augustins opinyon) well be called the apparition of the Martyrs, in which respect he sayth plainely that S. Faelix appeared in the seige of Nola; albeyt he is doubtfull, as you see, whether he appeared
himselfe, on an angell for him, for by occasion of that apparition S. Augustine maketh all this discourse.

65. This being so, I must beseech good M. Collins to auert his wrath, and indignation from me, and to lay it vpon S. Augustine, who is better able to beare it, and deserueth it more then I, seeing that all this discourse & doctrin is his, as well touching the merits of Saints, as the benefits which God bestoweth vpon men to testify the same; & therefore if I be ridiculous and absurd, (as M. Collins termes me) for relating only S. Augustines opinion and doctryn in this poynt, much more ridiculous, and absurd is S. Augustine himselfe for houlding and teaching it; but howsoeuer the matter passeth with S. Augustine and me, M. Collins is ridiculous, and absurd aboue measure, not only in beating (as I may say) Iack for Iill (I meane me for S. Augustine) but also in doing it sciens & volens, wittingly and willfully; whereby it may easely be iudged, that notwithstanding the pretence, and shew he maketh, much to respect, and reuerence the auncient Fathers, as if his and his fellowes doctryne were all togeather conforme to theirs (thereby to deceiue and seduce the vnlearned
Readers) yet in truth he beares them no respect at all, but rather a great tooth, and spleene, and that he would shew it euidently if he durst, seeing that he doth it with such virulency, when he can do it by indirect meanes, and couertly as here you see he hath done.

66. But now good Reader there remayne yet two or three words more to be fifted concerning this matter, wherin we shall see (I know not how to terme it) eyther a most foolish fraud, or a most fraudulent foolery. It followeth in M. Collins thus: At last, you graunt (sayth he) in the same number, that not only Saints may appeare i • the shape of Angells, but that God himself hath done so de facto, as Genes. 18. Exod. 3. to Abraham, and Moyses, yet before you sayd, that the Angell whom Abraham worshipped was a created Angell num. 14. how does this hang togeather. Thus sayth M. Collins, but how truly, I report me to my owne Text, which you haue seene before nu. 55. cyted out of my Adioynder, where I said the cleane contrary to that which he setteth down as myne. For I said, that Angells might by Gods ordinance appeare in the likenes of the Martyrs, suscipientes (as S. Augustine sayth) personam martyrum, taking vpon them the
persons, or shapes of the Martyrs, and not that the Martyrs or Saints might appeare in the shape of Angells, as M. Collins affirmeth, turning as I may say, the cat in the pan.

67. Also to proue that such apparitions of Angells, may be called the apparitions of the Saints, I added that the like manner of speach is vsuall in the holy Scripture, where it is said, that God spake and appeared to Abraham Gen. 18. and in Moyses Exodus 3. when neuerthelesse God himselfe did not speake, and appeare, but vsed therein the ministery of Angells, who spake, and appeared for him; whereas M. Collins maketh me say the contrary, to wit, that God appeared in the shape of Angells. So as that which I said before in the 14. number (to wit that the Angell which appeared to Abraham was a created Angell) hangs very well togeather, with that which I say heer; for I signify in both places, that a crea • ed Angell appeared to Abraham for God, although it is said in Scripture, that God appeared.

68. Behold then the humour of this honest man, who sometymes dissembleth my whole text, or that which most importeth in it, and sometymes peruerteth it, that he may haue somewhat to say with
some shew of probability, to cozen, and deceiue such at least, as shall not see my Adioynder, which he knoweth few haue done, and are like to doe, by reason of the prohibition of Catholike bookes in England; sed veritas temporis filia, but truth is the daughter of tyme; and as our sauiour said, nihil est opertum quod non reuelabitur, nec occultum quod non scietur. Matth. 10.

69. But forasmuch as this very place of S. Augustine touching the interuention of the dead in the affaires of men, hath beene yet further abused by my Lord of VVinchester in another place with no small abuse also offered to Cardinall Bellarmyne (wherewith I chardged his Lordship, very deeply in my Adioynder) I wil therfore now lay it downe here, and then consider how well M. Collins hath discharged his obligation to my Lord, in clearing him therof. Thus then I sayd pag. 410. nu. 62.

70. Vpon the occasion of certaine places of the Fathers alledged by the Cardinall, to shew the custome of praying to Saynts in the primitiue Church, M. Andrews goeth about to proue that Saynts do not know what we do heere on earth, eyther by seeing the same in God, or by seeing themselues present among vs; & hauing alleadged
3. or 4. authorities for the former point (which he may see sufficiently answered in Cardinall Bellarmines Controuersies) he saith for the letter, mortuos autem rebus nostris non interuenire sensit Augustinus. Augustine was of opinion that the dead are not present at our affaires, for the which he quoteth no place of S. Augustine, but addeth, quis hoc refert? Cardinalis. Who relateth or affirmeth this? the Cardinall: and for this M. Andrews citeth in his margent the Cardinalls treatise of the beatitude of Saynts, in his bookes of Controuersies, where indeed the Cardinal handling that question, and laying downe the obiection of hereticks, hath amongst the rest a place of S. Augustine in his books de cura pro mortuis, where he affirmeth that the dead are not present at mens affaires, neyther yet do know what is done vpon earth; neuertheles afterward the Cardinal answering the same obiection in the same Chapter, proueth out of the very same treatise of S. Augustine (from whence the obiection is taken) that albeit the dead are not vsually present at mens affaires, nor do naturally know what is done vpon earth, yet they may know it, not only by Angells, but also supernaturally, to wit, by diuine reuelation, yea and that the holy Martyrs,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
and Saynts are present amongst men, per diuinam potentiam, by the diuine power.

71. And to shew this, the Cardinal alleageth these words out of the said treatise of S. Augustine, Non ideo putandum est &c. It is not therfore to be thought that euery one of the dead may be present at the affayrs of men, because the Martyrs are present in the healing, & helping some men; but rather it is to be vnderstood, that because the dead cānot be present among men, by their owne nature, therfore the Martyrs are present at mens affayres by the diuine power. Thus saith S. Augustine: where you see he distinguisheth betwixt naturall, and supernaturall meanes, and betwixt the glorified Saynts of God (for such are the Martyrs of whome he speaketh) and other dead men, granting that the Martyrs do that by supernaturall, & diuine meanes, which other dead men cannot naturally do; and this is the same in effect that al Catholikes hould concerning the knowledge that the glorified Saynts haue of things done in earth, to wit, that they do not know the same naturally, but by supernaturall meanes, whether they see it in seeing the diuine essence, or know it otherwise by reuelation; so as, thereby it is manifest that M. Andrewes hath notably abused both S. Augustine and the Cardinall; S. Augustine, in making him to
affirme of glorified Saints, that which he spak of other dead men, as if he made no differēce betweene the supernaturall knowledge and power of the one, and the naturall of the other, which he euidently distinguisheth. Also he abuseth the Cardinall in taking hould of his obiection, and dissembling his solution, which is one of the most grosse and palpable frauds, or rather fooleries that may be imagined in this kind.

72. Thus said I in my Adioynder: wherto M. Collins sayth not one word, and therfore I remit it to the readers Iudgment, whether it was not conuenient for my Lordes honour, that his Feed-man, Aduocate, & Champion (who saw him heere so deeply charged) should haue dischardged and cleared his Lorship of this imputation if he could considering as well the confidence which my Lord hath reposed in him, as also his Maiestyes expresse commaundement imposed vpon him (as he himselfe confesseth) for the repulsing, sayth he, of the lewd slaunders of a nameles Papist, and to redeeme the credit of a renowned Bishop: if this therefore be a lewd slaunder, why doth not M. M. Collins repulse it (to vse his owne phrase) & if it be none but a true obiectiō of fraud and falsity in my Lord (as indeed it is)
why doth he not labour at least to redeem my Lords credit, either by some colourable excuse, or some pretty fraud, or legier-dumain, as he is wont to do? For so at least he should haue shewed his good will, and desire to serue my Lord, as he is in duty boūd hauing beene well payd for his paynes, as the report is, which may well be presumed to be true, my Lords liberality and bounty considered; but it seemeth that this fraud is so grosse, and palpable that it passeth M. Collins his skill, either to excuse, or colour it handsomly; and therfore he thought best to smother it with silence, as he hath done diuers others heeretofore, besides many more, which I could lay downe, if I had tyme; but I do now make so much hast to end, that I meane to add but some few fraudes more concerning the Reliques of Saints, and the veneration, and reuerence due to them; wherof I will say somewhat with what breuity I may in the ensewing Chapters.

div.head: A manifest discouery of M. Collins his fraud in corrupting the Text, and peruerting the Sense of the Adioynder, touching the adoration of holy Relikes; he belyeth Gregory de Valentia, whom he vnderstandeth not: He abuseth egregiously S. Hierome many wayes, in belying him, in clipping his text, in peruerting his sense, and incalumniating him. Lastly he is proued to be most ignorant euen in Grammar. CHAP. X.
div.p:
HAVING giuen thee, good Reader, in the precedēt chapters some tast of M. Collins his treacherous dealing touching prayer to Saints, I wil giue in this, some examples of the like in his answeres concerning the adoration, or veneration
of holy Reliques, and for the better discouery therof, I thinke best first to say some what (by the way of preamble) touching the word adoration, and the controuersy, concerning the same, as wel betwixt the Cardinall and my Lord of VVinchester, as b • twixt M. Collins and me.

1. To this purpose it is to be vnderstood that as my Lord of VVinchester admitteth no Inuocation, but of God only; so he affirmeth the same of adoration pag. 49. And therfore to answere the Cardinals obiection out of S Hieroms epistle to Marcella (wherin S. Hierome speaketh of the adoration of the ashes of Elizaeus, and Abdias) my Lord sayth that S. Hierome did not speake there properly, but figuratiuely. Vpon which occasion I treated somewhat amply in my Adioynder pag. 371. num. 13. of the three kinds of adoration, specifyed in the holy Scripture; the one due to God alone, which we call Latria, the other due to Angells, Saints, or holy men, as to the seruants of God, & for the honor, & loue of him (which being an act of Religion, I called a religious adoration, & is commonly called by our Deuins Dulia) the third is a meere ciuill worship or reuerence exhited to men for some ciuill or temporall excellency.

2. And of these three kindes of adoration I alleadged very many examples and testimonyes of holy Scripture, and for the proofe of the two later (to wit, of the religious, and ciuill adoration) I produced aboue twenty places, and might haue done many more, if I had thought it needfull; & then I obserued therupon pag. 375. num. 16. that the word adoration is to be vnderstood diuersly, as it is diuersly applyed, either to God alone, or to Angels, holy men and holy thinges, or els to men of dignity; and that the same is to be obserued in the hebrew word sachah, which signifyeth adorare, and is diuersly vnderstood of ech of these three kinds of adoration, according to the different application therof, in so much that it cannot be otherwise distinguished in reading, but by the circumstances; and for as much as in the corporal exhibition of it the same exteriour acts of submission, and reuerence are common to all three kinds of adoration, therefore they are diuersifyed, and distinguished only by the intention, and will of him, that doth performe them; and finally I concluded, that is is not to be wondered, that as well the ancient Fathers, as the Catholiks of these dayes, following the custom, & phrase of the holy Scripturs, do vse
also the word adoration in the same different manner, and sense that the Scripture doth.

3. And albeit M. Collins in answere of this doth fondly cauill about religious adoration, yet he denyeth not the ciuil adoration; yea and sayth also pag 360. lin. 26. that my Lord graunteth it, and that his Lordship denyeth only the sacred, or religious adoration; in so much, that he maketh the adoratiō, which Abraham, Lot, & Iosue vsed to Angells, to be ciuill adoration, most absurdly; seeing that there was not therein any ciuill or temporall respect (which cannot be vnderstood to exceed the bounds of nature) the motiue of their adoration being a supernaturall excellency, including also a sanctity and holynes, which is euident in the example of Iosues adoration of the Angell, who besides his falling prostrate vpon the ground before the Angell, was commanded by him to do more reuerence, to wit, to put off his shooes, because the place where he stood was holy, which place (as I sayd in my Adioynder) was not otherwayes holy, but in respect of the Angels presence, so as this adoration, hauing a supernatural respect, and consideration (that is to say, the sanctity of an Angell, & the place) cannot be called ciuill without great absurdity.

4. The like is to be sayd of the examples which I produced also in my Adioynder of the adoration exhibited by Abdias to Elias; and of the children of the Prophets to Elizaeus, of whome I sayd thus, pag. 372. Al • hough Abdias was in temporall dignity 〈◊〉 greater man, and more worthy then Elias the Prophet, yet he fell vpon his face be
• ore Elias (3. Reg. 18.) acknowledging • hereby the spirituall excellency of Gods Prophet, and did therein an act of religion, • s also the children of the Prophets did the • he like to Elizaeus, when they perceaued by his miraculous passage euer the Riuer, that God had giuen him the spirit of Elias, ado
• auerunt eum, sayth the Scripture, proni in ter
• am, they adored him falling flat vpon the • round 4. Reg. 2. Thus sayd I in my Ad
• oynder, expresly specifying a supernatural • espect, and motiue of this adoration, which • herfore cannot possibly be ciuill; & this I • aue thought good to note by the way, the • ather to shew you by this occasion, a fine • iece of legier-du-main in M. Collins his an
• were to these two examples of Abdias, and • he children of the Prophets. For thus he • ayth of the first pag. 354. lin. 12.

5. Abdias, you say, was a man in temporall • ignity, far greater then Elias, and yet Abdias
fell vpon his face before him; and therin did an act of religion to Elias. Belieue it who list. So he. Leauing out some wordes of my Text, vpon the which I inferred that he did an act of Religion. For I sayd thus of Abdias; he fell vpon his face before Elias, acknowledging thereby, the spirituall excellency, and sanctity of Gods Prophet, and therein did an act of Religion; whereas M. Collins maketh me say only, that Abdias did an act of Religion, because he fell vpō his face before him, without specifying the spirituall excellency, and sanctity of the Prophet, wh • ch being a supernatural guift of God doth not import any temporall, or ciuill consideration, but a religious respect.

6. The like cosenage he also vseth i • the other example, saying thus: Likewise the children of the Prophets worshipt Elizaeus wit • religious adoration, because they saw him passe th • riuer by miracle, a thing which euery damned wretch might haue done, to haue wrough • a miracle, and yet this must chalenge religious adoration. So he. Concealing the reason which I gaue, why the children o • the Prophets adored Elizaeus, which was because they perceaued by his miraculous passage 〈◊〉 the riuer, that God had giuen him the spirit of Eli ••
so that the bare miracle was not the cau ••
why they adored him, but because God had • iuen him Elias his spirit, and made him • is Prophet, which spirituall, and super
• aturall excellency surmounted all ciuill • espects, and belonged to religion, & ther
• ore was acknowledged by them, with a • eligious adoration.

7. And to these I may yet add ano
• her like fraudulent deuise of his in his an
• were to the reason which I giue in my • dioynder why the adoration of Saints, and • oly men is religious; for wheras I sayd in • he 14. Paragraph (which he citeth pag.
• 54.) that such adoration is an act of reli
• ion, because it is exhibited to them, as
• o the seruants of God, and for the honour and loue • f him; M. Collins, answereth thus: Lastly,
• ayth he, to your quiddity, that the worship of • aints is religious worship, because yielded to Saints • or their religious sake, I deny your reason. As well might you say, that the worshipping • f a wodden Image is a blockish worship, • ecause done to a blocke &c. Thus sayth M. Collins. Wherein you see that the reason which he giueth (and sayth it is myne) why the worship of Saintes is a religious worship, is, because it is yeilded to them for their Religious sake, as though it had no further • elation but to them, whereas I speake not
a word of their religion, and do expresly referre the worship of the Saints, to the honour of God, whose seruants they are; for my wordes are (as you haue seene before) that the second kind of adoration is an act of Religion, exhibited to Angells, Saints, or holy men, as to the seruants of God, and for the honour, and loue of him; so as the adoration, or worship relieth not in them, but hath a speciall relation to Almighty God, being ye • lded to them for his sake, because they are his seruants, and to the end to honour him in them, which therefore must needes be a religious act; wherby it is euident not only that he hath falsifyed my text (referring the worship of the Saints to the Religiō in them) but also hath argued most idly vpon his owne false ground, saying that I might as wel say that the worshiping of a blockish Image is blockish worship, because done to a Blocke.

8. For indeed if the worship should haue no further relatiō, thē to the wood, or to the Image as it is wood, it were a woodden worship, bu • the worsh • p being don to the Image o • Christ, or of a Saint, to honor Christ, or the Saint therein, the worship is religious; for otherwayes M. Collins must con • esse, that he hath done in his dayes woddē or blockish worship, when he hath
stood bare in the presence Chamber before the Kings Chaire made of wood. And I doubt not, but he will say, that he hath honoured the King in his Chayre, and not the wood wherof it was made; and therfore as this may be called ciuill worshippe, because it is yeilded for a ciuil respect (that is to say to honour the King) so also, the other which is yeilded to an image, or a Saint, for the honour of God, may well be called religious worship, because all religious acts are of their nature referred to the honor of God. So as you see M. Collins hath made a very blockish and woodden argument, worthy of his woodden wit, besides his falsity, as well in corrupting my Text, as in peruerting my sense.

9. No lesse vayne and idle, is the instruction which he taketh vpon him to giue me presently after, saying: Rather say (it is religious worship) because it springeth from the vertue of religion in the mind of him that yeildeth it as the originall of his act; and yet imperant only, not elicient, dirigent, not exequent, as your Schoole men loue to speake. Thus sayth he, flourishing in his Schoole-tearmes, as though he could play the schoole-mā if he list, whē the poore fellow prattles like a Parrat, not vnderstanding what he sayth, as you shall
see after a while by the good vse he maketh of Gregorius de Valentia his doctrine against me, euen for this poynt. But for the present I wish it to be noted that had he not falsifyed my words, he should haue had no cause, nor colour to tell me that Religious worship springeth from the vertue of Religion in the mynd of the doer, for I say nothing at all to the contrary, as you may see euidētly by my owne words cyted by me, a little before out of my Adioynder, so as he is no lesse vayne, and idle, then false almost in euery thing.

10. Moreouer as friuolous, vayne, yea and false is that which he affirmeth of Valentia pag.
• 60. Who, he sayth, doth flatly deny that the worship of Saints is properly religious worship, which is properly, and flatly a lye; for Valentia doth not deny, that it is religious worship propriè, properly, but proximè, or immediatè immediatly, as it appeareth by 3. or 4. places which M. Collins himself cyteth out of him; as when he sayth of the proper act of religion, Actus propriùs virtutis religionis diuinam gloriam spectat proximè, & idcirco ad Deū proximè pertinet, the proper act of the vertue of religion doth respect immediatly the diuine glory, and therefore it doth belong to God immediatly; and then he addeth concerning
the veneration of Saints; Actio verò qua veneramur sanctos &c The action whereby we do worship Saints, hath not any ether imediate scope, or end, but the esteeme, or respect which is conuenient, and fit to be giuen to an excellent Creature, and this esteeme say • h Valentia is procured for Saints immediatly not by religion, but by a peculiar obseruāce: for so he tearmeth that kind of honour, or worship, which we giue to Saints, and is (as he sayth) really, & alltogeather distinct from Religion.

11. And this difference, and distinction, he sayth, the Catholike Doctours do signify, and expresse by the words Latria & Dulia; applying Latria to the worship of God, and Dulia to the worship of Saints, & finally he concludeth (as M. Collins himselfe obserueth) Exposuimus quemadmodum honor Sanctis, non per virtutem religionis proximè, sed per aliam longe diuersam exhibeatur, we haue shewed now honour is giuē to Saints not immediatly by the vertue of Religion, but by another vertue altogeather different. So he. Which M. Collins vrgeth hard against me as directly impugning my assertion of a religious worship due to Saints, because Valentia teacheth that the honor due to Saints proceedeth from a vertue altogeather different from Religion.

12. But I must desire M. Collins by his leaue to note, that Valentia doth not deny that honour is exhibited to Saints by religion, either properly or at all, but that it is not giuen to them immediatly by religion, because religion doth respect the honour of God immediatly, and doth cause the honour of Saints remotè or mediatè, that is to say, by the meanes of that kind of obseruancy, which we commonly call dulia, & is moued by the vertue of Religion imperatiue, whereupon it followeth that the action resulting thereon, is a religious action and this M. Collins himself doth plainly acknowledge: for hauing tould me the distinction of imperant, elicient, dirigent and exequent, he addeth, that many acts not done to Religious persons, or done to them, not for their religious sakes, are neuerthelesse accounted religious actions, because they proceed from the vertue of religion in the doers.

13. And either to perswade or to conuince me in this point, he goeth forward thus: As euen your owne man acknowledgeth Gregory de Valentia Tom. 3. disput. 6. quaest. 11. &c. denying flatly that the worship of Saints is properly, or immediatly religious worship, yet he addes in this wise, quamquam non est negandum &c. though it is not to be denyed, that we
may be moued, as to other offices of sundry vertues, so 〈◊〉 yeild the Saints the honour of obseruancy, out of • e vertue of religion towardes God in our hartes. Thus farre M. Collins alleadgeth Valentia his words, and then glosseth them thus: So as • eth he would haue Religion to be only towards God, • nd yet an exciter, or setter on of our reuerence to • aints, per modum imperantis, as I sayd be
•• re. So he: To proue against me, euen • ut of Valentia himselfe, that I should haue • rawn the worship of Saints from the ver
• ue of Religion, in the mind of him, that • oth exhibite it, and not to haue made the • use therof to be the religion of the Saint, • r holy man that is worshipped.

14. But this you see is nothing els, but vayne flourish to shew his skil in schoole • arning, without any other ground or • ause then his owne falsification, as well of • y Text, as of the sense therof. And as for
• alentia his doctrine in this point, it is most • ue, and confirmeth my Assertion, that the • orship done to Saints is religious wor
•• ip, seeing that the power of religion is •• ch, that it commandeth the actions of all • ther vertues, to the glory, and honour of • od, wherby they become Religious acti
• ns. In which respect S. Iames in his Ep c. 1. • yth of a worke of Charity, or mercy, that
it is religion: Religio munda (sayth he) & ••
maculata apud Deum, & Patrem haec est, visitare p •
pillos, & viduas in tribulatione corum &c. This i • a cleane & immaculate religion with Go • and the Father, to visit pupills, and widdowes in their tribulations; thus sayth S. Iames, calling this worke of charity religi •• , because it is a religious action, proceeding from the vertue of religion imperatiuè, and done for Gods honour.

15. And this may truly be sayd not only of all the actions of other vertues, but also of such actions as are of their owne nature indifferent which religion commandeth, as occasion serueth, for Gods glory, and maketh them both good, yea and religious actions, because (as M. Collins sayth) they proceed from the vertue of religio • in the doers, and are referred to Gods honour, and seruice.

16. This then being true concerning as well indifferent, as vertuous actions, much more it is to be granted of such actions, as haue a more particuler relation to religion or connexion therewith, by reason of some particuler respect or consideration in the obiect, as it is euident in the worship done for Gods honour to Saints, or holy men, who being made (as the
Scripture sayth) consortes diuinae naturae 2. Pet. 1.
• artakers of the diuine nature, haue in them a • upernaturall excellency, which deserueth a supernaturall honour or worship (I meane a greater honour then any respect of ciuility, or nature can challenge) and therfore I say, that such honour springing originally from the vertue of religion in them that yeild it, and being exhibited to Saints, as hauing the foresayd participation of diuine excellency, cannot be ciuill, but must needes be religious. And this as I haue sayd, is not d • nyed by Valentia, who affirmeth only that this honour it not exhibited to Saints by the vertue of Religion proximè, immediatly, but imperatiuè, by the interuention of a different vertue called dulia, which doth immediatly respect the honour, and worship due to Saints, and is commanded by the vertue of religion, so much the more properly, by how much more it is subordinate thereto, and hath more Analogy, and proportion with it, then other vertues haue.

17. But for the better vnderstanding of Valentia, it is to be considered, that the great difference which he affirmeth to be betwixt the vertues of dulia and of religiō, consisteth in this, that dulia respecteth only
the excellency of the Saint, resting therein without further relation to the participation of the diuine excellency by me before mentioned; for so indeed, it is wholy distinct, and different from the vertue of religion, which doth not rest in any creature, but doth immediatly respect the honour due to God; but if we consider the honour of the Saint, as not resting in him, but as hauing a further relation to the diuine excellency, which the Saint doth participate: so there is no need to distinguish the sayd honour from religion, euen according to Valentia his grounds, who also is so farre from condemning the other opinion that he rather defendeth it against Caluin, to be no way derogatory to Gods glory, as it appeareth by that which M. Collins noteth very absurdly for a cōtradiction in Valentia, who sayth he seeth not how Gods honour is any way impayred (as Caluin sayth it is) if we giue one honour to God, and another to Saints, by one and the selfe same vertue of religion; for as, sayth he, we loue God, with the selfe same vertue of Charity, with the which we loue our Neighbour in his degree (without any iniury to the diuine Maiesty:) so also we may without any iniury to God, giue him his owne honour intierely, and to Saints theirs, eue • by one, and the same vertue of Religion.

18. Thus sayth Valentia; giuing to vnderstand, that whereas there is a question amongst the Deuines, whether the honour that is giuen to God, and to his Saints, proceedeth from one, & the selfe same vertue of Religion (as some hould it doth) or from two different vertues (which is Valentia his opinion) there is no preiudice, or iniury done to Gods honour either way; because those who hould it to be one, and the same vertue of religion, which giueth honour to both, do not conceaue that the honour giuen to the Saint resteth in him, but that it hath relation, & passeth to that diuine excellency, which the Saint participateth, and is immediatly respected by religion; wheras Valentia, and those which hould, that they are two different vertues (whereby God, and his Saints are honoured) cōceaue the honour giuen to the saints to rest in a certaine degree of supernaturall excellency of the Saint, without further relation to the excellency of God, and that the vertue which giueth the sayd honour to the Saint respecteth his excellēcy proximè and elicitiuè; wheras the vertue of Religion respecteth it only imperatiuè and mediatè (as I haue signifyed before) that is to say, b • the interuention of this other vertue of Dulia,
or obseruancy (as he calleth it) which the vertue of Religion commandeth and vseth to Gods honour, as it might do an act of charity, Piety, Iustice, Temperance, or any other vertue.

19. And heereby it appeareth, that there is no contradiction in Valentia either to himself (as M.
