Collins absurdly imagineth) or yet to the other opinion of the Deuines, for as much as concerneth Gods honor (which Caluin falsly saith is impayred therby) & much lesse doth Valentia deny or contradict my assertion of religious worship done to Saints; which is true according to both opinions; for according to Valentia doctrine (take it how you will) the honor done to the Saint is religious, imperatiuè at least and mediatè, and according to the other opinion clicitiuè and proximè; yea and if we vnderstand all with formall relation to the diuin excellency participated by the Saint (as I haue signifyed before) so the honour done to the Saint may be religious also proximè and elicitiuè in all opinions. And thus thou seest good Reader, how little M. Collins hath gayned by playing the Schooleman, yea, and how notably he hath played the foole, bewraying his owne ignorance and folly, aswell in alleadging and vrging
Valentia against me, when he maketh for me, a • also in controling, and impugning him; seeing it is euident that the silly fel
• ow doth not vnderstand him, & doth notably abuse vs both.

20. I haue thought it not amisse, good Reader, to say thus much by the way of a preamble to the discouery of his fraudulent answers to my Adioynder, concerning the veneration of holy Reliques; partly to explicate thereby the state of the question betwixt vs, and partly to lay open vnto you diuers petty fraudes of his, which as you haue seene, haue occurred by the way, hauing forborne not only to display many solemne fooleryes (wher with his discourse about this matter is enterlaced) but also to answere his obiections out of some of the Fathers, as wel not to passe my prescribed limits of medling only with his frauds, as also to auoyd prolixity which hath euer been my special desire from the beginning, albeit his extrauagant impertinēcyes haue extorted from me a farre larger reply, then at first I determyned.

21. Now then to come to the matter, you may remember, that I signifyed in the beginning of this Chapter, how my Lord of VVinchester answereth a place alleaged by
the Cardinall out of S. Hierome to Marcella, touching the adoration of the ashes of S. Iohn Baptist, Elizaeus, and Abdias, saying that S. Hierome doth not vse the word adoration in that place properly, but figuratiuely; wherof he giueth two reasons, the one, because S. Hierome sayth also there that Marcella might puluerem lingere, licke the dust, Quare vt hoc, ita & illud non propriè, sed figuratiuè, wherefore, as this, so also that, is not properly spoken, but figuratiuely. And albeit I confuted this at large, yet because the matter it selfe is not of much importance, I omit the examination of what M. Collins answereth therto, except only of one point wherin he giueth vs a tast of his great skill in Grammer, which also I thinke good to differre vntill I haue discouered his notable fraud in answering my reply to my Lords second reason, and by occasion thereof lay downe very important matter for the tryall of the truth in this Controuersy. Thus then I said in my Adioynder pag. 376. num. 21.

22. His second reason why adorare is taken figuratiuely in that place of S. Hierome is this. Vbi verò, saith he, propriè ei loquendum erat &c. For when S. Hierome was to speake properly, to wit, to Vigilantius his aduersary (who pressed him strictly, and would
not suffer him to speake at large) then he denyeth it earnestly, saying, Nos autem, non dico Martyrum reliquias &c. VVe do not worship and adore (I do not say) the Reliques of Martyrs, but neyther the Sunne nor the Moone, nor the Angells, nor the Cherubim, nor the Seraphim. Thus saith M. Andrewes out of S. Hierome, ending his citation there; because that which followeth would marre all his market, as you shall see after a while, & in the meane tyme he concludeth thus, VVhat I pray you will the Card • nall say here, seeing that the old Fathers of the Church do crie out, we do not adore the reliques of Martyrs? heere the Cardinall is held so fast that he cannot slip away. Thus triumpheth M. Andrews before the victory, or rather hauing lost the victory, being himselfe a Captiue, and hauing no other remedy left him, but to brag and face out the matter.

23. For thou shalt vnderstand good Reader, that S. Hierome heere speaketh (as the Logicians say, ad hominem, that is to say according to the sense and meaning of his aduersary Vigilantius (one of M. Andrews his worthy progenitours) who impugning the adoration of reliques in the same sense that that M. Andrewes doth, held it for no other then Idolatry, as S. Hierome testifieth in the same Epistle to Riparius, which M. Andrews
alleageth. Ais, saith S. Hierome, Vigilantius &c. You say, that Vigilantius (as we may say M. Andrews) openeth againe his stinking mouth, and casteth forth a most filthy sauour against the Reliques of holy Martyrs, and calleth vs, who reuerence them, and worship the bones of the dead, Cinerarios, & Idolatras, worshipers of Ashes, & Idolators. So he. And in his tract. against Vigilantius himself, he setteth downe Vigilantius his owne words thus: Quid necesse est &c. VVhat need hast thou not only to honour with so great honour, but also to adore that (I knowe not what) which thou worshipest, carrying it in a litle vessell from place to place, and why doest thou kisse and adore dust lapt in a linnen cloth? And againe a litle after, VVe see you, according to the custome of the Gentils &c. euery where kisse and adore I knowe not what little dust carried in a litle vessell, & lapt in a precious linnen cloth. Thus wrote Vigilantius.

24. Whereby you see how he charged the Catholicks of those daies with flat Idolatry, for worshipping, or adoring the Reliques of Saynts, taking adoration for worship due to God alone, in which respect he calleth the Catholiks Idolators. And therefore S. Hierome answering him in the same sense, saith that which M. Andrews alleadgeth, to wit, Non adoramus reliquias
Martyrum &c. VVe do not adore the reliques of Martyrs (that is to say, we do not giue diuine honor to the reliques of Martyrs, committing Idolatry as Vigilantius chargeth vs:) but, honoramus (saith he presently afterwards) reliquias Martyrum, vt eum cuius sunt Martyres adoremus &c. VVe honor the Religues of Martyrs, that we may adore (or yield diuine honor to) him whose Martyres they are. Honoramus seruos &c. VVe honour the seruants, to the end that their honor may redound to the honour of their Lord, who said, He which receiueth you receiueth me. Thus saith S. Hierome; which M. Andrews thought good to dissemble, as if he had not seene it, for that it fully explicateth the state of the question betwixt S. Hierome and Vigilantius (as also betwixt Maister Andrews and vs) and cleareth all the matter. For who seeth not heere that albeit S. Hierome denyeth the adoration of Reliques in the sense that Vigilantius obiected it, as we also doe (to wit as signifying a diuine honour) yet he approueth and teacheth it in the sense of Catholiques, that is, as adoration signifieth a veneration and worship done to Saints, for the honour of God who is honoured and glorified thereby.

25. To which purpose two things are to be noted in this matter, the one, that wheras Vigilantius chargeth the Catholicks to adore & kisse euery where the Reliques of Martyrs, he shewed sufficiently, that the custome of the faithfull was at that tyme to do corporall reuerence thereto, not only by kissing them, but also by inclyning or bowing the body, which the word adoration signifieth, and S. Hierome denyeth not, though he denyeth the inference of Idolatry, that Vigilantius made thereon.

26. The other is, that as Vigilantius did not herein reproue the particuler custome of some particuler men, but the pactice of whole Church at that tyme; so also S Hierome did not impugne him only with priuate reasons and arguments of his owne, but also with publique examples, as of the publick translation of the holy Reliques of S. Andrew, S. Luke, and S. Timothy
• o Constantinople by Constantine the Emperour, apud quas, saith he, Daemones rugiunt &c. at which reliques Diuells do roare, and the inhabitors and possessors of Vigilantius do confesse that they seele their presence. So he, And then produceth also another example that had passed not long before of a most solemne translation of the
Reliques of Samuel the Prophet from Iudaea
• o Chalcedon in Thracia, which were sump
• uously and triumphantly carryed by Bi
• hops in a goulden vessell, and met, recei
• ed, and accompanied by the people of al • he Churches by the way (in so much that • here were, saith S. Hierome, continuall • warmes of people euen from Palestina to Chalcedon, sounding forth the praise of Christ with one voice all a long as they went:) whereupon he asketh Vigilantius, whether • e tooke Arcadius the Emperour (who cau
• ed this to be done) and all the Bishops which caried these reliques, and all the mul
• itude of people which accompanied them • or sacrilegious persons and fooles; and finally concludeth, deryding his folly, thus: Viz.
• aith he, adorabant Samuelem, non Christum, • uius Samuel & Leuita & Propheta fuit. Belike • hey adored Samuel, & not Christ, whose Leuite & Prophet Samuel was. This saith S. Hierome, shewing the absurdity of Vigilantius, who did • hinke that Christ was not adored in al this, but only Samuel. Whereas all the reuerence, honor, and adoration vsed by those Bishops, and people to the Reliques of Samuel, was indeed done to Christ, because (as S. Hierome said before) seruorum hon • s redundat ad Dominum, The honor of the seruants redoundeth to their Lord.

27. So that S. Hierome doth not deny 〈◊〉 that holy reliques may be adored in any other sense, then as M. Andrews (following his progenitor Vigilantius) will needs vnderstand the word adoration, that is, for a diuine Cult, and worship; in which sense neyther S. Hierome nor the Catholiks in his tyme, nor we now do vse, or take it, when it is applied to holy things, but only for a deuout & religious veneration, as S. Hirome himselfe doth also vse it, not only in the place before cited by the Cardinall (touching the adoration of the ashes of S Iohn, and other Prophets) but also when he said of himselfe, Praesepe Domini & incunabulae adoraui. I adored the manger, and cra • le of Christ. And againe expounding that verse of the Psalme, adorate scabellum pedum eius, adore the Foot-stoole of his feet, he taketh the Foot-stoole to be the Crosse, giuing therby to vnderstand that the Crosse is to be adored. And therefore I leaue it to thee, good Reader, to iudge what a vaine vaunt it was of M. Andrews to sa • v • on the former place of S. Hieroms, Tenetur his Cardinalis vt elabi non poffit: heere the Cardinall is taken, and held so fast, that he cannot slip away. Whereas you see, that the whole place and the circumstance, being laied downe with the state of the question
betwixt Vigilantius, & S. Hierome (all which he craftily cōcealed) he is caught himself like a mouse in a trappe, in such sort that he shall neuer be able to get out with his credit.

28. Thus far I haue thought good to lay downe the words of my Adioynder, because they be sufficient not only to answer my Lord of VVinchester fully, and to discouer his fraud in the lame allegation of S. Hieromes text, but also to decyde the Controuersy betwixt the Cardinall, and my Lord (& consequently betwixt M. Collins, and me) which is, What was the fayth, & practise of the primitiue Church touching the veneratiō of holy reliques, which you see heere testified to be the same that we Catholicks professe, and practise at this day, impugned then by the heretike Vigilantius in the same sort, and sense, that now it is impugned by my Lord of VVinchester, M. Collins, and their fellow Protestants of this tyme, and then also defended by S. Hierome in the same sense, and with the same termes, and circumstances, that we Catholiks defend it at this day. Besydes that, it is euident that S. Hierome doth not defend here his own priuate opinion, but the publick practise, and consequently the generall
fayth of the whole Church (from whence the publick, and vniuersall practise proceeded) and this appeareth by the examples which he alleadgeth of the most solemne, sumptuous, & triumphant translation of the holy reliques of S. Andrews, S. Luke, S. Tymothy, & Samuel the prophet with admirable celebrity, applause, and deuotion of infinit numbers of people, singing continually prayses to our Sauiour Christ all the way they went. This then being so, let vs now see, what M. Collins sayth to all this, and how he defendeth my Lord of VVinchesters lame, and fraudulent allegation of Saint Hierome obiected to him by me in my Adioynder: you shall heare all he saith, euen in his own words, and then iudge of it as you shall see cause. Thus then he saith pag. 360. nu. 10.

29. You brooke not, that S. Hieroms adorare cineres Abdiae, in his epistle ad Marcellā, should be expoūded by the same S. Hierom writing to Vigilantius, and that not paulò vigilantiùs, perhaps, by non adoramus; we worship not only not reliques but neither Cherubim nor Seraphim nor any such like: yet if it be true, which wee are often taught by S. Augustine, that Ecclesiasticall writers are not so absolute in their writings, but that they may fall into error now and then, and be reformed by
the Iudgment of after commers, much more may they be corrected by their owne selues in other places, and their suddener, or lesse aduised phrase of speach one while, be qualifyed, and tempered by their more deliberate resolution at another. As heer S. Hierome. Thus saith M. Collins, with more which I will lay downe, when I shall haue said some what to this.

30. First, you see, that hitherto he doth not set downe so much as one word of my text (neither doth he afterward) & the mention he maketh of it, is only this, that I brooke not, that S. Hieromes adorare cineres Abdiae should be expounded by S. Hierome, himself (writing against Vigilantius) by non adoramus. But I wonder where he findeth, or how he gathereth of my text, that I do not brooke it, seeing that I had reason both to brooke it, and to be glad of it, as of that which turneth to M. Collins his confusion, and to the cleare proofe of the Catholick fayth, touching holy reliques. Secondly you see, he saith, that S. Hierome wrote to Vigilantius, not paulò vigilantiùs perhaps, that is to say, not carefully and warily inough, wherby he cōtradicts not only my Lord of VVinchester, but also himself; for my Lord appealeth specialy to S. Hieroms non adoramus,
written to Vigilantius to expound his adoramus written to Marcella, saying, as you haue heard before, that when S. Hierome was to speake properly, to wit to Vigilanti ••
who pressed him strictly, then he denyeth the adoration of reliques with non adoramus, we do not adore them. So as my Lord presumeth that there S. Hierome wrote very warily, which also M. Collins himself affirmeth afterward expresly, saying thus of S. Hieromes writing first to Marcella, and after to Vigilantius.

31. In the full source (sayth he) of his Rhetorique, and when he spake without an Aduersary, or to one that could vnderstand him inoffensiuely, & with discretiō sufficiēt, he speaks for adoring Abdias his ashes, that is, for the zealous resorting to the place of his buriall (for that is all:) but where he speakes before his Aduersary, before Vigilātius, like the Bird which sleeps with the throne at her breast, then more vigilantly, more accurately, and more circumspecth he denyes it vtterly, that they adore either reliques, or things better then relikes, euen those for whose sake the reliques are made much off. So he: affirming expresly that S. Hierome to Vigilantius wrote more vigilantly, more accurately, and more circumspectly, wheras before he sayd, that he wrot to him perhaps not paulò vigilantiùs, not vigilantly, or warily inough: and though
he say it with a (perhaps) yet how it agreeth with that which now he affirmeth, I know not for my part, but I think that perhaps he was scarce awake when he wrote it.

32. But then he goeth forward, and alleadgeth some part of S. Hieromes Text thus. There, error iuuenum, and culpa muliercularum non est imputanda religiosis hominibus; the errour of young men, and the default of light giddy women is not to be imputed to religious persons. There paucorum culpa non praeiudicat religioni, the aberration of some few is no preiudice to religion. Lastly there, non adoramus &c. VVe worship neither Reliques, nor Martyrs, nor Angells, neither any name that is named either in this world, or in the world to come, but God only. Thus sayth M. Collins, seeking notably to cosen, and gull the vnwary Reader and to make him belieue, that S. Hierome not only renounceth the veneration of Reliques with his non adoaramus but also that he attributeth the same as a fault to a few young men and light giddy headed women, whose errour should not be imputed to religious persons, or to Religion it selfe; wherein truly I cannot but admire, and detest the impudent falsity of this fellow.

33. For he not only vseth the same fraud that my Lord of VVinchester did in the
fraudulent, and lame allegation of S. Hieromes text, leauing out that which followeth, and clearely proueth the veneration of Reliques (as you haue seene in that which I haue alleadged out of my Adioynder) but also he craftily dissembleth what the fault was, which Saint Hierome blameth in these young men, and light giddy-headed women, to the end his Reader may conceaue it to be the veneration • f Reliques; wheras the fault was that some delicts of incontinency were committed by yong men, and women in Churches in the night, whyles they watched at the tombes of Martyrs (as then the custome was) which custome Vigilantius impugned vpon pretence of that abuse, and S. Hierome condemning the abuse, defended the custome, as not to be reiected for the fault of a few.

34. And this also would haue beene cleare inough, if M. Collins had not curtalled S. Hieromes Text in two or three places, euen in those few lines which he alleadgeth out of him. For S. Hierome hauing first signifyed that Vigilantius carped at the sayd custome of night-watches in the Churches of Martyrs, sayth thus after a while: Error autem & culpa &c. The errour and fault of young men, and most base women, qui per
noctem sape deprehenditur, which is often discouered in the night, is not to be imputed to religious men, Quia & in vigilijs Paschae tale quid fieri plerum{que} conuincitur, for it is manifest that some such thing is also committed in the vigils of the Paschall Feast, and yet religion is not preiudiced by the fault of a few, qui & abs{que} vigilijs possunt errare vel in suis, vel in alienis domibus, who without watching may offend also either in their owne houses, or in other mens; Apostolorum fidem Iudae proditio non destruxit, & nostras ergo vigilias malae aliorum vigiliae non destruent. The treachery of Iudas did not destroy the fayth of the Apostles, and therefore neither shall the euill watching of others destroy our watchings. Thus sayth S. Hieromes with more that followeth to the same purpose, which I omit for breuityes sake, seeing that this may suffice to shew M. Collins his fraud in nipping, and clipping off heere, and there such pieces of S. Hieroms text, as do shew the matter, whereof he treateth: and this no doubt he doth to the end, that the Reader may be the more easily deluded therwith, and imagine that the veneration of holy Reliques was the abuse which S. Hierome blamed; whereas you see, he speaketh of a farre different matter.

35. And can there be a fyner piece of cozenage then this? But all this whyle, you see nothing answered to all that ample discourse which I made in my Adioynder out of S. Hierome, nothing I meane to the reason why S. Hierome sayd to Vigilantius non adoramus, we do not adore the Reliques of Martyrs (to wit in the sense of Vigilantius who tooke adoration for diuine honour) nothing to Saint Hieromes reason, why the holy Reliques of Martyrs are to be honoured, to wit, that we may adore, sayth S. Hierom (that is to say yeild diuine honour to) him, whose Martyrs they are: we honour the seruants, sayth he, that their honour may redound to the honour of their Lord. Nothing is sayd to the publik practise of the Church expresly testifyed by S. Hierome, with the examples of the most solemne, and sumptuous translation of the holy Reliques, first of S. Andrew, S. Luke, & S. Tymothy in the tyme of Constantine the first Christian Emperour, & after of Samuel the Prophet in S. Hieromes owne tyme, with wonderfull concourse and deuotion of all sorts of Christian people; nothing to the testimony which S. Hierome giueth that the Diuells (the inhabitors, sayth he, and possessours of Vigilantius) did roare at the presence of those holy Reliques. To all this, I
say, M. Collins obmutuit, for he sayth not one word.

36. Neither doth he seeke to defend, and much lesse doth he cleare my Lord of the double fraud, wherwith I charged his Lorship; double I say, as well in changing the state of the question about the word adoration, as in the lame allegation of S. Hieromes Text, cutting it off there, where it would haue euidently conuinced him, if he had alleadged it. And it is no marueile, though he laboureth not to cleare my Lord of that cryme, seeing he falleth into it himselfe, alleadging the same wordes that my Lord did, with the same fraud, as if I had not discouered it in my Lord, and charged his Lordship directly with it. Can there be greater falsity, & impudency then this?

37. Neuertheles, that you may see, how narrowly he hath pryed into my discourse vpon S. Hierome, to the end, to take some aduantage, if he could. You shall vnderstand that for lacke of better matter he taketh exception to my translation of two or three words, saying to me thus pag. 361. num. 11. Heere also we haue another cast of your sweet latinity num. 22. Ais, Vigilantius &c. which breaking off, you conster thus: You say that Vigilātius, how fitly for Grammar let the Grammarians iudge.
So he. But is it possible, that he could see these two or three wordes to cauill vpon, and not see himselfe, and my Lord notably taxed by S. Hierome (togeather with Vigilantius their progenitour) in that which followeth immediatly, and maketh vp the sense of my words?

38. For whereas my Lord had obiected to me S. Hieromes non adoramus &c. and I had signifyed in my Adioynder, that S. Hierome spake there of adoration, as it signifyeth diuine honour, according to the sense, and meaning of his aduersary Vigilantius (who held the adoration of reliques for Idolatry) my Adioynder hath S. Hieromes wordes to Riparius, thus: Ais, sayth S. Hierome, Vigilantius &c. you say, that Vigilantius openeth againe his stinking mouth, and casteth forth a most filthy sauour against the reliques of holy Martyrs, and calleth vs who reuerence them, and worship the bones of the dead, Cinerarios, & Idololatras, worshippers of ashes, and Idolaters. Thus farre I alleadged S. Hierome, wherin you see what languague he would vse to M. Collins, if he were now liuing.

39. But first to speake a word or two of his exception to my translation, as not fit for Grammer; it is euident that if he saw the text in S. Hierome (as I doubt not but he
did) he could not but see the errour to be in the print, and not in my translation, which is very litterall, according to the true wordes and text of S. Hierome, whose latin is this, Ais, Vigilantium os foetidum rursum aperire &c. which I translate in my Adioyder thus, you lay that Vigilantius openeth againe his stinking mouth &c. by which • ranslation of myne (being most proper) and according to the very letter of S. Hierome, any man may easily see, that the text in my Adioynder (hauing Vigilantius and not Vigilantium) is erroneous, by the negligence of the Printer, for otherwise the fault would haue beene in my English translation, as well as in my Latin text; and therefore M. Collins sheweth himselfe no lesse impertinēt then malicious to take exception to my Latinity for this; but of his translations, and latinity, I shall haue occasion to speake els where, and make no doubt to proue him to be most ridiculous for both.

40. But that which I wish to be noted heere is, that his diligence to search out, & to take hould of such trifles as this doth cōdemne him of willfull malice in balking such an euident testimony of the Catholike truth as heer he saw, and dissembleth, excolans culicem, & camelum glutiens (as our Sauiour
sayd of the Pharisees Matth. 23.) strayning a Gnat, and swallowing vp a Camel. For in this very place which he calleth in question for my translation, he saw three things, which sufficed to confound both my Lord and him. The first, that he and his fellows (who charge vs with Idolatry for the veneration of holy Reliques) are the true brood of Vigilantius the Heretike. The second, that as often, as they inueigh against holy Reliques, they open their stinking mouths, & cast forth a filthy sauour in the opinion of S. Hierome. The third, that S. Hierome meant by his, non adoramus reliquias Martyrum, only to cleare the Catholikes of that tyme of the imputation of Idolatry; & therefore he denyeth that the Catholikes did adore them with diuine honour, but denyeth not the worship and veneration, which the Church vseth, and he expresly acknowledgeth presently after, as I haue amply declared before, & M. Collins himself confesseth it a little after in the same Paragraph though very absurdly saying thus: S. Hierome expounds his adorare, in one place by non adorare, sed honorare in another; when the passion was cooled, & the iudgment awaked. Non colimus & adoramus, sed honoramus &c. lib. 1. cont. Vigil. Thus sayth he. Giuing to vnderstand, that
when S. Hierome wrote to Marcella, and vsed the word adorare, he was in heat of passion, and his iudgment was a sleep; but when he wrote against Vigilantius, his passion was cooled, and his iudgment awaked, & that therefore he tempered it with a more moderate word, to wit, honorare.

41 Heereupon it may be gathered, that in the opinion of M. Collins, S. Hierome being in the heate of his passion, when he wrote to Marcella, vsed adorare to signify diuine worship; and so when he inuited her to adore the ashes of S. Iohn Baptist, Elizaeus, & Abdias, he would haue her to commit flat Idolatry; els why was he more in passion, when he wrote to her, then when he wrot against Vigilantius? For if he vnderstood no more by adorare, writing to Marcella, but honorare (as M. Collins sayth he expounds it in his booke against Vigilantius) wherein did then consist the heat of his passion? Perhaps M. Collins wil say, that it consisted in that he applyed adorare to creatures, which is due only to the Creatour, but if he say so, what will he say of S. Ambrose, S. Augustine, and other Fathers, yea and of the penners of holy Scriptures themselues, who apply it very often to the worship of creatures, as I haue amply shewed in my Adioynder.

42. Besides that M. Collins himselfe graunteth pag. 369. lin. 18. that S. Augustine acknowledgeth in his tenth book de ciuitat • Dei cap. 1. that not only Adoratio, but Religio, and Pietas are wordes equiuocall, or of diuers significations; and he sayth also a little before in the same Paragraph, that adorare is transferred to men whome we adore ciuilly; yea he confesseth afterwards pag. 372. num. 15. and pag. 373. lin 4. that the Crosse may be adored in Kings ciuilly, because S. Ambrose sayth that Helē did wisely to cause the nayle of Christs Crosse to be set in the diademe of the Emperour Constantine her sonne, vt crux Christi adoretur in Regibus, that the Crosse of Christ may be adored in Kinges; and finally he granteth that S. Augustine applyeth the word adorare to the sacrament of Baptisme, and Circumcision, saying to Faustus the Manichee, adoratur in gestante, it is adored in the bearer.

43. Now then, I would gladly know of M. Collins, why S. Hierome is to be thoght more passsionate, or lesse iudicious in applying adorare to the worship of creatures then S. Ambrose in applying it to the Crosse, and S. Augustine to Ba • tisme, or Circumcision; yea, or Maister Collins himselfe, who graunteth it to be applyed to the worship of men; for if it signify only diuine worship,
then they were as much ouerseene as S. Hierome; and if it signify also an inferiour honour (which may be more or lesse according to the different obiects) then truly S. Hierome had as good a warrant to vse it in that sense as any other; so as M. Collins hath shewed himselfe no lesse simple then saucy, to censure so deeply this learned, and holy Father for vsing a word in a sense no lesse frequent in holy Scripture, then in the ancient Fathers.

44. Much more modestly (though absurdly) did my Lord answere this place of S. Hierome, saying that he vsed adorare (not properly but) figuratiuely, and namely by the figure called Catachresis, which I confuted amply in my Adioynder, by the iudgment of Quintilian, and Isidore, who teach that Catachresis doth import the abuse of a metaphore, when there wanteth a proper word, which cannot be sayd in this case; for honorare and venerari might haue expressed S. Hieromes meaning, much better then adorare, if it did properly signify nothing but to yield diuine honour.

45. And now to the end you may see what a good Gramarian M. Collins is, who often carpeth at my little skill it grammer (though hitherto little to his credit) you shall
vnderstand that he answereth to this, pag •
362. lin. 8. that the Grammarians will te •• me, that there is a Catachresis in the verbe sperare, in this verse of Virgil; Hunc ego si pot •• tantum sperare dolorem, albeit there want no words to supply the sense of it, as timere prouidere, metuere &c. So sayth he.

46. But if it please him to take the paines to turne his Dictionaryes, he shall find that sperare doth not signify only to hope, but also to feare; and therefore Virgil vseth it in that sense els where, as sperare Deos, to feare the Gods; and Terence also hath it in the same sense as in Andria Act. 2. Sce • . 3. Quod tu speres propulsabo facile, I will easily deliuer thee from that feare; neuertheles I will not deny but that it doth signify more commonly and properly to hope, then to feare; and therfore Seruius in his Comment vpon that verse of Virgil, sayth sperare dolorem pro timere, is a figure called Acyrologia, that is to say, an vnproper speach, which Quintilian lib. 8. cap. 2. confirmeth saying: Id quod apud 〈◊〉 improprium,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
apud Graecos vocatur, tha • which with vs is called vnproper, is among the Greekes called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; and this he exemplifyeth with those words of Virgil, Tantum sperare dolorem; and presently after distinguisheth the same expresly from Catachresis,
signifying that euery thing which is not proper, is not presently to be counted vitiously vnproper, because many thinges haue no names, eyther in Greek or Latyn, & therfore, saith he, Catachresis is necessary, giuing to vnderstād, that it is necessary for • uch things as haue no proper names.

47. To Quintilian, and Seruius may be added Despauterius de figuris, Calepine, & Thesaurus Linguae latinae, in the word Acyrologia, who do al of thē cite those words of Virgil for an example of the figure Acyrologia, besides that, not only they, but also Donatus, & Festus do expresly require to Catachresis, that the thing expressed by that figure, should want a proper name; so that it shalbe well that M. Collins do, for his own credit, name vnto vs those Grammarians, who, he saith, will tel me that there is a Catachresis in sperare; seing I haue tould him, in the meane tyme, of so many of principall note, who fynd in it another figure, viz. Acyrologia, and do confirme that which I said in my Adioynder of Catachresis, to wit, that the want of a pro
• per word or name is necessary therto; so as M Collins hath now vtterly lost the reputation of a grammarian (wherein he is wont to glory exceedingly, as you may haue seene, by his frequent recourse to Grammar
and Grammarians) and therfore I cannot but wonder how such an ignorant fellow as he, got to be maister of the Chief Chayre in Cambridge, seeing he is not fit to be so much as vsher of a Grammar Schoole, hauing learned no better his Tropes, and Figures, which euery boy (at least in these parts) that is past his Rhetorike, vnderstandeth better then he.

div.head: A serious discourse of M. Collins against the veneration, reseruation, digging vp and carrying about of holy Reliques is throughly examined, and his incredible impudency, fraud, & falshood therin discouered by the manifest abuse of S. Ambrose, Sozomen, Theodoret, S. Chrysostome, Optatus, S. Gregory the Great, S. Gregory of Towers, Origen, Victor Vticensis, and S. Hierome. CHAP. XI.
div.p:
THERE followeth in M. Collins a large discourse, and truly a strang one, partly against the digging vp, and keeping of Reliques, and partely against the translation and circumgestation of them (to vse his owne tearmes) but so fraught with falsity, & folly, as I know not whether of
the two doth more abound therein; and therfore for as much as I make no doubt, but that he hath pleased himself excedingly in it, and beaten his braynes well fauouredly about it, in hope to crush our Cause, and to stop our mouthes eternally for the matter of reliques, I will take a little paynes to examyne it throughout, and answere it as breifely as conueniently I may, not doubting but to stop his mouth, and, besides the discouery of his fraudes (which is my principall intention) to haue sufficient occasion to proue, & confirme the verity of our Catholicke doctryne concerning this Controuersie.

1. Well then he alleadgeth 2. places out of S. Ambrose, the first is lib. 1. de Abraham cap. 9. where he byds vs, saith M. Collins, non diutiùs inhaerere mortuis, but only, officij quantum sat est deferre, that is, in effect to bury the departed, but not to dwell long vpon dead corses: which how can it stand with preseruing of Reliques, I say not, honouring, obseruing & worshipping them? So he; as wisely as he is wont. For wheras S. Ambrose saith that we must not dwell ouer long vpon dead bodies, it is to be vnderstood, that he saith it vpon the occasiō of Abrahās moderate lamētatiō for the death of his wife Sara
insinuated in the 23. Chapter of Genesis, which therfore he proposeth for an exāple to Christians, exhorting them to vse moderation, as well in their mourning, and lamentation for the dead, as also for the tyme that they bestow therein, because no doubt, he had noted in his dayes some great cxcesse in both, as yet also may be obserued in some Countreys far more then in ours. But what is this to the keeping, or worshiping of Reliques, except M. Collins can proue quidlibet ex quolibet? Besides that, he •
seth heere a notable fraud very ordinary with him, and his fellowes, to wit, to change the state of the questiō, from Saints to ordinary dead men, of whome we doe not now treate, as shalbe further declared after a while.

2. His second place of S. Ambrose is taken out of his second booke of Offices cap. 28. where he sayth thus: Nemo potest indignari, quia humandis fidelium reliquijs spatia laxata sunt: nemo potest dolere, quia in sepulturis Christianorum requies desunctorum est. No man can grudge that the ground should be enlarged for the buriall of the bodyes of the faythfull deceased: no man can be sorry, that the rest or repose of the dead is in the buriall or graues of the Christians. Thus sayth S. Ambrose: whereupon M. Collins asketh this
question. Is this man likely, sayth he, to countenance Reliques or the worshipping thereof? Yes truely M. Collins, the man is so likely to do it, and doth it indeed so fully (which you shall see after a whyle) that you may be ashamed to demand this, especially vpon no better ground then vpon this place heere alleadged, which might indeed proue somewhat against such as would deny that Christians ought to be buryed, or affirme, that is it not a worke of mercy to bury the dead, and to prouide Church-yards, or conuenient places for it: but against the worshipping, or preseruing of the Reliques of Martyrs or Saints, S. Ambrose in this place sayth nothing at all, for that he speaketh not of such dead men, but only of the dead bodyes of ordinary Christians, amongst whome very many dye without all opinion of sanctity, and many with doubt whether they be saued or no, & many others, though in respect of their knowne vertue they may haue a great opinion of holynesse, yet because the Church hath not giuen any publique approbation thereof, eyther by their Canonization, or otherwayes, they are not reputed, nor ranked among the Saints whose Reliques are are reserued or honoured, but amongst the
rest of the faythfull deceased; whereas the knowne, and canonized Saints are not reckoned amongst the dead, but amongst the euerliuing.

3. For this cause the Church doth celebrate the feasts of the Martyrs, & Saints with the title of Natalis, or Natalitium, their birth day, although it be indeed the day of their Martyrdome, or death, as it is euident not only in the publique office, & seruice of the Church, but also in the Homilyes, and Sermons of the ancient Fathers made in the sayd feasts, and therfore (to omit others) S. Ambrose (of whome we now specially treate) beginneth his Sermon in the feast of the Apostles S. Peter, & S. Paul thus: Natalem beatissimorum Apostolorum Petri & Pauli hodie celebramus &c. This day we celebrate the birth-day of the most blessed Apostles S. Peter and S. Paul.

4. The like he sayth of the feasts of the Saints Cantius and Cantionilla, and diuers others. Whereof he yeildeth the reason, in his foresayd Sermon of S. Peter, and S. Paul saying: Non enim mortui sunt &c. For they are not dead, whose birth we celebrate this day, but being borne againe, they liue with bread, because they are made partakers of Christ, who is the bread of life to all; for although their bodyes were slaine by their
passion (or suffering) yet the order of the liuing is not interrupted thereby; therefore it is not to be called a death, by the meanes whereof we are free from persecutours, and vnited with Christ for euer &c. Thus sayth S. Amboose, whereby M. Collins may see, that when he speaketh in generall tearmes of the buryalls, and graues, or of the bodyes of the dead, he doth not cōprehend the sacred Tombes, shrynes, or holy bodyes, and reliques of the euerliuing martyrs, and Saints of God, whose neuer-dying memoryes the Church doth celebrate.

5. And therefore now to answere to his question propounded before (as you haue heard) whether this man (he meaneth S. Ambrose) was likely to countenance Reliques, or the worshipping thereof? I must needs say, that if he be not ignorant aboue measure, he cannot be excused from exorbitant malice, in making a question of that whereof no man can doubt that is conuersant in S. Ambrose, or S. Augustine, and much lesse a Doctor, & publique Reader of Diuinity; for who knoweth not, if he haue read eyther of those Fathers, that S. Ambrose did not only countenance, but also reuerence, and worship holy reliques, seeing that the holy bodyes of diuers Saints, to wit, SS. Geruasius and Protasius, SS. Nazarius & Celsus,
SS. Vitalis & Agricola, were at three seuerall tymes found out by S. Ambrose (according to the reuelation which he had from Almighty God) and by him translated, and honoured with great pompe, and solemnity; which also Almighty God approued and authorized with manifest miracles, as S. Augustine witnesseth concerning the SS. Geruasius and Protasius, in two of his best knowne, and most vndoubted workes, to wit, in his Confessions lib. 9. cap. 7. and in his 22. booke de ciuitate Dei cap. 8. (which latter my Lord of VVinchester calleth opus palmare Augustini, the principall, or most excellent worke of Augustine) in both which, this holy Father affirmeth, that a blind man was restored to his sight at the translation of the bodyes of SS. Geruasius and Protasius, whiles he himselfe was at Millan.

6. And this miracle he sayth was done when the Emperour was there, & immenso populo teste, and an infinite number of people being witnesses of it: & in his Confessions he addeth, that the blind man hauing touched the Coffin with a handkercheffe and applyed it to his eyes, was presently cured: and sayth further, that those who were vexed with vnclean spirits were disposessed, Cùm propalata & effossa, digno cum honore ad Ambrosianam
Basilicā transferrentur, when the bodyes being discouered, & digged vp, were trāslated to Ambrose his Church, with worthy, or conuenient honour.

7. Loe then how these holy bodyes, and reliques of the Saints were by the authority of S. Ambrose digged vp, and translated with worthy honour frō one Church to another, according to the irrefragable testimony of S. Augustine, who was an eye-witnesse of it; wherof also S. Ambrose himselfe relateth the history very particulerly as well in an epistle to his Sister Marcellina, as also in another to all the Priestes and Cleargy of Italy, wherein he declareth the manner how it was reuealed vnto him, & that the Coffin wherein the holy Bodyes were, lay twelue foot dee • in the ground, that he assembled many Bishops, and the whose Clerg • , and that he himselfe was the first digger of the ground, to find them (primus ego, sayth he, terrae fossor accessi) & that afterwardes all the Bishops digged with him, and finally that they found the coffin and the saints Bodyes therein, as fresh as if they had beene newly put into it, & mir •
• dore fragrantes, and breathing forth a merueilous sweete odour. Thus sayth S. Ambrose, who now you see, is become a digger vp of
reliques, notwithstanding that M. Collinss would perswade vs, that he would haue them confined to the perpetuall obscurity of Sepulchers, and Graues, when he sayd, that in sepulturis Christianorum est requies defunctorum, in the buriall of Christians, is the repose of the dead.

8. But will you see what S. Ambrose sayth further concerning those holy Body • s in his Sermon made to the people at the finding thereof? This may be seene in his Epistle 54. to his Sister Marcellina, wherin he declareth, that he tould the people (& for the proofe of it, appealed to their owne knowledge & eye-sight) that Diuels were expelled out of many possessed persōs, that many diseased were cured of their infirmityes, that some were healed with a certaine shaddowe of the holy Bodyes; that the handkercheifes, and garments, which were cast vpon the most sacred reliques became tactu ipso medicabilia, medicinall euen by touching them, and that therfore all men were desirous, and glad to touch them, & qui contigerit, saluus erit, and he that shal touch them shalbe safe or cured. Thus doth S. Ambrose testify, what great benefits Almighty God bestowed vpon those, that honoured his Saints, and their reliques, or rather him in them.

9. And so farre was S. Ambrose from desiring that the holy reliques of those Saints should be hid againe, and buryed in obliuion (after they were found) that he distributed som parts of thē to his friends farre and neere, whereby many Churches were built in honour of them, not only in Rome, and diuers places of Italy, but also in France, Germany, and Africke, as may be seene in Baronius Tom. 4. Ann. an. 387. And now to shew further how much S. Ambrose reuerenced, and honoured holy Reliques, and for what reason, I will lay downe his owne wordes in his 14. sermon of the two holy Martyrs SS. Nazarius & Celsus, where speaking of the great worthines of their Reliques, he sayth thus.

10. Quod si dicas mihi quid honores &c. If you say vnto me what doest thou honour in flesh now already dissolued and consumed, wherof God hath no care, then wher is that, my dearely beloued, which truth it selfe spake by the Prophet: pretiosa in conspectu Domini mors Sanctorum eius, the death of Gods Saints is pretious in his sight? And againe: mihi autem nimis honorificandi sunt amici tui Deus. O God, thy friends are to be honoured of me exceeding much. We ought to honour Gods seruants of whome it is
sayd in another place, Dominus custodit omnia ossa eorum, & vnum ex his non conteretur: our Lord preserueth all their bones, and one of them shall not be consumed, or perish. I honour therefore in the Martyrs flesh the scarrs or marks of the wounds receaued for the name of Christ. I honour the memory of him that liueth with the perpetuity of Vertue. I honour the ashes that are consecrated by the confession of the name of Christ. I honour that body, which hath shewed me how to loue my Lord, & hath taught me not to feare death for his sake. And why shold not the faythful honor that body which the Diuells do also reuerence; and albeit they afflicted it in punishing it; yet they do now glorify it in the sepulcher. Therefore I honour that body which Christ hath honoured by the sword, and which shall raigne with Christ in heauen.

11. Thus farre I haue thought good to lay downe S. Ambrose his owne words, to perswade M. Collins, if it may be, that this man (as he calleth him) is not ōly likly to coūtenance reliques, and the worshipping of them, but that he also performed it indeed, yea and with great reason, as you haue seene by this his owne pious, & very elegant discourse: how then can M. Collins read this without
blushing? Or henceforth looke any man in face, who he may thinke hath read it, & seene withall what he hath written heere; seeing that it is euident heereby, and by the premisses, that he maketh no cōscience or scruple at all to delude, and deceaue his Reader, with a vaine shew, and ostentatiō of the authority of Fathers, when they are flatly against him, as heere you see, he alleadgeth against holy Reliques some patches, pieces, and scraps, as I may say, of S. Ambrose, nothing at all to the purpose, whē neuerthelesse he knoweth in his own consciēce, that the sayd holy Father doth both in deedes and doctrine, vtterly condemne him; besides that I may note heer the same fraud that he vsed in the former place, to wit, his changing the state of the question from Saints to ordinary dead men, which are of farre different condition, and doe therefore require, and admit farre different considerations.

12. And now albeit I hast to make an end, & am looth to detaine my selfe vpon trifles, yet I cannot omit to say somewhat to a parenthesis of his, in the allegation of the aforesayd place of S. Ambrose, to wit: Nemo potest indignari humādis fidelium reliquijs, spatia esse laxata, which he translateth thus: It is no
fault, nor thing to be grudged at (vnlesse then by the Arians, who carpt at S. Ambrose without cause, and so now by the Iesuits) that the ground is enlarged to bury the remnāts of the faithful bodyes massacred. So he, giuing to vnderstand, by his Parenthesis, that the Iesuits carpe at S. Ambrose now without cause, as the Arians did then; but wherein trow you, do the Iesuits now, or euer carpe at S. Ambrose? truly I thinke that no man but M. Collins euer hard, or imagined any such matter.

13. The Arians carped at him (as he signifieth himselfe in his 2. booke of offices cap. 28.) not because he enlarged Church yardes, but because he brake the Chalices, and siluer vessels of the Church for the redemption of Captiues, by the occasion whereof he giueth 3. instances, when, & in what cases the sacred vessells of the Church may be alienated; to wit, for the redemption of Captiues, for the releife of the poore, and for the enlarging of places to bury the dead when need requireth it. But I hope M. Collins will not be so shamelesse to say, that the Iesuits euer carped at S. Ambrose for any of those things; then let him tell vs for what els, which I am sure he shall neuer be able to do; and therefore you see, how idly he tatleth, eyther not
knowing, or not caring, what he saith▪ so that he say some what to make vp his muck-heape of absurdityes, fraudes, and fooleryes, and by the way to spit out now and then some part of his spite against the Iesuits.

14. But now let vs proceed: he goeth forward in the same veyne, adding examples to the authorityes of S. Ambrose, to proue that the translation and circumgestation of Reliques is alltogeather vnlawfull. His first is out of Sozomen. lib. 4. cap. 20. where speaking of an intent that Macedonius Bishop of Constantinople had to remoue the body of Constantine the Great, out of a Church in Constantinople (where it was first interred) he sayth that the Orthodoxe, & godly Christians opposed thēselues thereto, houlding it sor no lesse a sacriledge to translate dead bodyes, then to breake open tombes violently or feloniously: whereupon M. Collins sayth. And do not these (Orthodoxe Christians) cōdemne the vse of Reliques, which in you is accompanyed with translation, with circumgestation, and such like pompes? So he, as well to the purpose, as before when he alleadged the two places of S. Ambrose; for heere he changeth the state of the question, no lesse then there, from a matter of religion, to a meere ciuill matter.

15. This wilbe euydent by the Circumstances of the history, concealed by M. Collins, though they be set downe by Sozomen himselfe, whom he citeth. Thus then it passed. Macedonius the hereticall Bishop of Constantinople, beying resolued to translate the body of Constantyne the great, from the Church where it was buryed (because he thought it was lyke to fall) was resisted by the people, who neuertheles were deuided in opinion concerning the same; for some of them held it for impyety to translate the body, no lesse then if it should be digged vp agayn; and others thought it not to be a matter of any moment, because (as Socrates saith, lib. 2. cap. 30.) it seemed to them, that a dead body could receiue no hurt thereby. The Catholiks also (saith the history) resisted with common consent, because they held it for an iniury, and dishonour to the Emperour Constantyne, who had been of their Comunion, that is to say a Catholike, as they were, besides other Considerations, which shalbe declared after a while. Neuerthelesse Macedonius remoued the body, though with great bloud-shed, and slaughter of people, that resisted him; wherevpon the Emperour Constantius (who before fauoured Macedonius
very much) was much alienated from him, for the outrage committed in the slaughter of so many, slayn by that occasion, and for the dishonour, and iniury done to his Father; and lastly because it was done without his consent. This is the substance of the history, wherein you see, there is nothing at all that maketh against the translation of Saints bodyes.

16. First, because the motiue which moued Macedonius to translate Constantynes body, was not any respect of holynes therin, or to honor God in his seruants, or for any other religious consideration, but for a meer ciuill, or temporal respect, to wit, because the Church wherin he was buryed, was (as it seemed to Macedonius) in danger to fal, albeit there was no such present danger, as experience shewed, for the Church stood still on foot, and was repayred a hundred yeares after by Iustinian the Emperour.

17. Seconly, the motyues, which moued the Catholiks to resist the translation, might be diuers, whereof one might well be, that they saw no such danger that the Church would full as Macedonius pretended; another cause vndoubtedly was, the great auersion that they had frō the wicked heretik Macedonius their capital
enemy & persecutor, in which respect they were easily induced to adhere to those that withstood him in that action; and the third motiue is declared in the history, to wyt, because they held it for a great iniury to the worthy Emperour deceased.

18. Hereof two reasons may be yeilded, the one because Macedonius being a pernicions heretik, was not of Constantines communion, but sought by that translation of his body, to perswade the world that Constantine was of his sect, which no doubt was most iniurious, not only to the memory of that Catholike Emperour, but also to all Catholicks who were of his Communion; the other reason was because Constantyne had built that Church most sumptuosly in honour of all the Apostles, with intention to be buryed there, to which end, he caused also some of the Apostles reliques to be brought thither, as Socrates witnesseth lib. 1. cap. 26. whereof he yeildeth this reason (which I d •
sire M. Collins to note by the way) least • e (saith Socrates) and other Emperours his successors should be destituted of the Apostles reliques: therfor I say, the Catholicks had great reason to take it for an indignity, and great iniury to that pious Emperour, that his body
should be remoued by an heretike, from such a famous Church built by himselfe for his own buriall, in honour of the Apostles, and enriched with their reliques, to a Church of far lesse note, as that was, whither Macedonius translated it, being dedicated only to S. Acacius the martyr.

19. Furthermore, if Macedonius had meant to haue translated the body of Constantine in quality of a Saints body, with such religious deuotion, and solemnity as is vsuall, and requisite in such translations: neyther the Catholicks, nor yet Constantius the Emperour eyther would or could haue taken it for an iniury to Constantine, who should haue receaued more true honour thereby, then euer he did by his triumphs, or trophyes, or any other secular honour that was euer done vnto him, whiles he liued; so as you see, this case of the remoual of Constantines body, for meer temporall respects, is far different from ours, which admitteth only religious Consideraions, aswell for the motyues, as for the manner and execution of it, all to be intended, & performed with reuerence, and deuotion to the greater honour of God, and his Saints. And therefore M. Collins still shooteth wyde of the marke, and is here aswell beside
the Cushion, as beside the question; let vs then see how he goeth on, which I beseech thee (good reader) well to note, and thou shalt see him play his part kindly, I meane of a notable cozening, and cogging Companyon.

20. Thus then he sayth. When Babylas his body was translated from Daphne to Antioch by Iulians appointment, and the Diuels instigatiō (not by any seeking of the Christian people) they cryed that accompanyed it all the way as they went: confundātur omnes qui adorant sculptilia; confounded be all they that worship carued images. Doth this please you? Thus sayth he. To whom I answere, that truly it doth both please me, & displease me: it pleaseth me, and that very much, that this example of the translation of S. Babylas being truly related, will notably confirme the translation and veneration of holy reliques, wherby M. Collins himselfe may be confounded, no lesse then they that worship carued Images. Againe it displeaseth me exceedingly, that any Christian man (especially one that taketh vpon him to be a Doctor, Teacher, & Preacher in Gods Church for the saluation of souls) is so impudently wicked as to peruert all kind of Authors, Historyes, and examples
to the distruction of such simple soules, as will bel • eue him, whereof you haue had sufficient experience already in M. Collins, and shall haue now further, not only in this example, but also in three, or foure others which follow in him immediatly, concerning this question of holy Reliques.

21. Three thinges you see he seemeth to vrge against vs in this example: the first that S. Babylas his body was translated by the appoyntment of Iulian the Apostata; the second, that it was done by the Diuels instigation (and not by any seeking of the Christians;) the third, that they which did accompany it, cryed all the way as they went, Confounded be all they that worship carued Images. By the two first he would haue his Reader to conceaue, that the good Christians of those dayes, did not seeke to translate the bodyrs of Saints, but that the Diuell suggested it, & Iuliā the wicked Apostata caus • d it to be performed; & by the third he thinketh that he hath giuen a great blow to our worshipping of holy Images.

22. Now then to discouer his treacherous falshood in these three points, it is to be vnderstood, that this S. Babylas, being a very holy man, and Bishop of Antioch was martyred in the time of Decius the Emperour,
and that being buryed in that Citty, his body was held in great veneration there amongst the Christians, vntill the tyme of Constantine the Emperour, when Gallus his sisters Sonne, and brother to Iulian the Apostata, being declared Caesar, and Gouernour of all the • ast parts, translated it into Daphne neere vnto Antioch, vpon this occasion.

23. There had beene in Daphne in ancient tyme a famous temple, and Oracle of Apollo, whereto there was continually great confluence of people, especially of yong men and women, in respect of the pleasant scituation of the place, which gaue occasiō at the first to the Poeticall fable, that Daphne was there turned into a Bay-tree, flying away from Apollo, who was enamoured of her; for which cause also the superstitious Pagans thought that Apollo made speciall choice of that place for his Temple, and Oracle, by the which the Diuell deluded the people for many ages; and for as much as that place, was as it were a nursery, not only of abominable superstitiōs (by reason of the Oracle) but also of all intemperance, incontinence, and ryot (by reason of the deliciousnes of the place) Gallus being a very good Christian, & a pious Prince built
a Church there for the Christians, and translated thither the holy reliques of S. Babylas, hoping by that meanes to purge the place in tyme, as well of the Idolatry, as also of the vice, & wickednes that was continually exercised there; and therefore I must now heere by the way desire M. Collins to note that the Reliques of S. Babylas were translated first by Gallus out of Antioch to Daphne, not by the Diuells instigation, nor by an Apostata, or wicked prince but by a vertuous Prince and a pious Christian, who was moued therto by the inspiration of the holy Ghost,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (Imperatori) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Ex edi. Sauelliana. Deo ipsius animum ad id impellente (sayth S. Chrysostome lib. contra Gentiles) God mouing his mind therto, for the confusion of the Diuell, as it appeared euidently by the euent, which was this.

24. The holy body was no sooner placed in Daphne, but it strocke the Diuell dumbe, which not only Theodoret (whome M. Collins alleadgeth in his margent, and seemeth to follow for this story) but also al other Historiographers doe affirme with vnanime consent, yea and S. Chrysostome, who liued at the same tyme, doth testify in his sayd booke against the Gentils, in these
words: Illi os ita obstruxit, vt vel lapidibus ipsis magis mutus redderetur; he (to wit, S. Babylas) did so stop the Diuells mouth, that he became more dumbe then the very stones: & then after a few words he addeth: He which was wont to deceaue all men euery where, could not endure to see the very ashes of Babylas being dead, Ea enim est Sanctorum potestas &c. for such is the power of Saints, that Diuells cannot endure their shaddowes, or cloathes whyles they liue, and do feare their Tombes when they are dead; therfore if there be any man that doth not belieue those things which are sayd to haue beene done by the Apostles, let him but consider the miracles done at this memory (that is to say, at the Reliques of this holy Martyr) and let him be no longer impudent; for he which in tymes past did triumph ouer all the Gentills being now rebuked (or checked) by the Martyr, as by his maister, was silent, and barked no more. Thus sayth S. Chrysostome. Now doth this please you M. Collins? Do you like it that God moued Gallus to translate these Reliques, and that they were of such force to strike the Diuell dumbe? Doth it please you, that the Diuell, and you are proued heere to be of one humour, seeing that neither of you both can abide holy Reliques? But let vs heare the rest.

25. After this both Gallus and Constantius
being dead, and Iulian the wicked Apostata in possession of the whole Empire, it chaunced, that he being determined to make warre against the Persians, came to Daphne to consult with his God Apollo, touching the issue and successe of the warre, but hauing giuen many Donatiues, and multiplyed sacrifice vpō sacrifice, he could get no other answere, but that there were many dead bodyes there about; which must be remoued before he could answere him, this was presently vnderstood as well by Iulian himselfe, as by Apolloes Priests, that it concerned only the body of S. Babylas; w • ereupon he gaue present order, that the Galileans (for so he called the Christians) shold remoue his body to some other place whither they would, which being vnderstood, a great multitude of men, and women, ould and young flocked thither from Antioch, & placing the holy body in a chariot, carryed and accompanyed it to Antioch with exceeding great ioy and exultation, leaping, dancing, and singing of the Psalmes of Dauid, & often repeating this verse: Consundantur omnes qui adorant sculptilia, confounded be they which adore grauen Images, meaning Iulian and his Paynims, who committed Idolatry to the Statua, or Image
of Apollo, and other false Gods, adoring them with diuine honour.

26. And that this only was their meaning, it is euident by all the Historiographers, & therfore Theodoret (whom M. Collins citeth) hauing sayd that the people continually repeated that verse, addeth: Nam Martyris translatione Diabolū victum existimarunt, for they thought that the Diuel was ouercome by the translation of the Martyrs. Socrates sayth lib. 3. cap. 16. that, Psalmi quos cecinere, reprehensionem Deorum Gentilium, & eorum qui in idola credebant, complexi sunt, the psalmes which they song did conteyne the reprehension of the Gods of the Gentils, & of those who belieued in Idols. Ruffinus, who liued at the same time, witnesseth the same lib. 2. c. 35. saying that all the Church of Antioch did sing that verse in auribus prophani Principis, in the eares of that prophane Prince, for six miles togeather, with such exultation that the heauens did ring with the noyse, and that Iulian was so extreamly offended therwith, that he caused many of the Christians to be apprehended, imprisoned, and tormented.

27. And amongst the rest, there was one Theodorus a young man, who being found to be one of the ring-leaders of that
holy, and deuout dance, was tormented a whole forenoone, with so great cruelty, and variety of tormentes, that Nulla aetas (sayth Ruffinus ibid. cap. 36.) simile factum meminerit, no age hath made mention of the like. Neuertheles God did so miraculously preserue, & assist him in his torments, that he continually song most cheerefully the same verse, which he song the day before, wherewith the tormentors were so astonished that they set him free; and afterwards he tould Ruffinus and others, that he was all the while conforted by a yong man, who stood by him continually, and wyped the sweat from him with a towell, and refreshed him with cold water, which seemed so delectable vnto him, that he was sorry when he was loosed from the Racke. And thus did Almighty God approue al the honour that was don to his Martyrs reliques by a most manifest miracle, testifyed by as many as write this story.

28. By all this then it appeareth: first that the Emperour Gallus translated the holy Reliques of this holy Martyr Babylas from Antioch to Daphne, Deo, sayth S. Chrysostome, ad id animum ipsius impellente, God mouing his mind vnto it. Wherby M. Collins may see that it is no diuellish, or euill worke to
trāslate reliques, as he would haue his Reader suppose.

29. Secondly that the Diuell incited Iulian to remoue again those holy Reliques to his own confusion, because he acknowledged thereby, that he was vanquished by them: whereby M. Collins may also see, how true it is which S. Chrysostome sayth, viz. that the Diuells feare the shaddow of a Saint whiles he liueth, and his ashes when he is dead.

30. Thirdly, that the verse of the Psalme, which the people song, to wit, Confundantur omnes qui adorant sculptilia, did no way concerne the worship, and veneration of holy Images, but the adoration of Idols, to the confusion, not only of Iulian, and the Gentills, but also of the Diuell, and M. Collins: for as that verse triumphantly song in the translation of the Martyrs Reliques did then confound the Diuell, and his instruments (Iulian, and the Gentills;) so also the history of it alleadged by M. Collins, doth now confound the Diuell and him, who by the Diuels instigation, is no lesse enemy to holy Reliques, then Iulian, and the Gentills were.

31. Fourthly, that Almighty God shewed euidently by the miraculous constancy
and patience of Theodorus, that all this honour done to the holy Martyr, and to his Reliques in the translation of them, was most gratefull to his diuin Maiesty, & that therefore it is most true, which you haue heard before out of S. Hierome, Honor seruorum redundat ad Dominum, the honour done to the seruants redoundeth to their Lord.

32. Lastly, it appeareth that M. Collins hath most shamefully abused, and peruerted this history, vrging it so mangled and maymed, as you haue seene against the trāslation, and worship of Reliques; whereas being wholy, and truly related, it doth notably confirme the same. Iudg then good Reader, what consciene, and honesty there is in this man.

33. And that the same may yet more manifestly appeare, I cannot omit to obserue by the way, how he seeketh to delude his Reader with the quotation of S. Chrysostome for this history of S. Babylas, as if that holy Father had applyed it, as he (I meane M. Collins) doth against the vse of translatiō or veneration of holy Reliques; whereas he r • counteth it purposely to shew the wonderfull vertue, and power of Gods Saints, and their Reliques, to proue therby that Christ (whose seruants they are) is
God; so as S. Chrysostome is so farre from denying and impugning the vertue of holy Reliques, that he maketh the same to be an argument of Christs diuinity; besides that he also giueth so cleare, and ample testimony elswhere, of the spiritual benefits which the faythfull, & deuout Christians receaue by holy Reliques, that I thinke good to relate some part of it heer, vpon this occasiō.

34. In his sermon vpon the feast of S. Ignatius (wherin he treateth of the solemne translation of his body from Rome, where he was martyred, to Antioch whereof he had beene Bishop) he sayth thus: All the Cittyes (sayth he) in the way receauing the Saint,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. Ex editione Sauelliana. and carrying him on their shoulders, accompanied him to Antioch, celebrating the praise of the crowned Martyr, and deryding the Diuell, whose craft had succeeded very contrary to his expectation; and then truly the Saint was beneficiall to all those cittyes, and hath enriched this Countrey, euen vntill this day, non aliter quam thesaurus quidam perpetuus &c. no other wayes then as a certaine perpetuall Treasure, which is dayly spent, but neuer exhaust, or consumed: so also this blessed Ignatius doth blesse all those that come vnto him, and sendeth them home full of confidence,
alacrity, and comfort; and therefore wee do repayre vnto him not only now, but also euery day, receiuing of him spirituall benefit; for whosoeuer cometh to him with fayth, is benefitted exceedingly; for not only the bodyes of Saints,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. Ex Editione Sauelliana. but also their very Tombes, and monuments, are replenished with spirituall grace. Thus S. Chrysostome, and then hauing confirmed this with the Example of Elizaeus the Prophet, whose bones reuiued a dead body which was cast by chaunce into his sepulcher 4. Reg. cap. 13. he sayth further thus: And much the rather this should be done now at this tyme,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. Ex editione Sauelliana. when the grace of God is more aboundant, and the force of the spirit greater: so as if any do touch but the tombe, or coffin, he may receaue therby great vertue; and therefore God hath graunted vs the vse of the Reliques of Saints, that he may bring vs to him by the imitation of them, & that they may be to vs, as it were, a certaine hauen and a conuenient comfort of those euills, which doe continually afflict vs. VVherfore I exhort you all (brethren) if any of you be pressed with any grief of mind or sicknes of body, or other calamity, that he come
hither with fayth (or confidence) wherby he may be freed from the same and returne with great Ioy, yea and by the very sight thereof, he may haue his conscience more peacable, and quyet. So sayth this holy and auncient Father.

35. Doth this please you M. Collins? Is this man (as you said to me ere whyle of S. Ambrose) like to countenance and patronyze you in impugning holy reliques? and here it is also to be noted, that this solemne translation of S. Ignatius, which S. Chrysostome recounteth, was made in the very infācy, as I may say, of the primitiue Church, to wit, in the tyme of Traian the Emperour within nyne or ten yeares after the death of S. Iohn the Euangelist, and presently after the Martyrdome of this holy Bishop, who (as S. Chrysostome testifyeth in this same oration) conuersed with the Apostles, and was ordayned by S. Peter himselfe to be his successour in Antioch. Besides that, he himselfe witnesseth in his Epist. ad Smyrnaeos, that he knew our Sauiour Christ, both befor & after his resurrection; wherby it appeareth that the solemn, & deuout trāslatiō of holy Reliques is no late inuention, but deryued from the Apostles tyme to ours; whereof I hope M. Collins cannot desire a more substantiall witnes then this holy Father, alleadged
by himselfe, who you see doth not only testify the sayd translation, but also the deuout manner of it, and the spirituall benefits, which did redound thereof, as wel to the Cittyes by the way, as also to Antioch it selfe, where they were reserued: and by the same occasion he doth also manifest his owne beliefe concerning the spirituall graces, and benefits, which faythful & deuout Christians do ordinarily receaue by the holy bodyes and Reliques of Saints, yea, by their very tombes & monuments, and therefore seriously exhorteth his Auditors to haue recourse thereto.

36. Now then, to conclude concerning S. Chrysostome, and the translation of S. Babylas (from the which I haue somewhat digressed) I may well say now to M. Collins, Obmutesce, and bid him be as silent, and dumbe, as Iulians Diuell was at Daphne, by the vertue of S. Babylas his Reliques, which (as you haue heard out of S. Chrysostome) so stopt his mouth, that he was as dumbe as a stone; for what can Collins say to defend or excuse such manifest, and palpable falsity, to wit, his lame, & corrupt allegation of the history, his absurd and false application of it, and his most fraudulent quotation of S. Chrysostome, who you see vrgeth, &
proueth directly the admirable vertue of Holy Reliques, euen by the same history of S. Babylas, for the which Collins cyteth him against Reliques. But let vs now heare what followeth.

37. After this M. Collins telleth vs of a woman called Lucilla, a factious Dame, & special patronesse of the Donatists, of whom he sayth, Optatus recounteth, that she was so wicked, that she would not receaue the Sacrament of our Lords body, and bloud vnlesse she had kissed the Reliques of a certaine Martyr that morning, if at least a Martyr, sayth Optatus: Yet you are (sayth M. Collins) for kissing them very definitiuely in your number 24. And if it be lawfull to kisse them, why not also to beginne the Communion with such a seruice? And may not we say of your Martyrs, as Optatus doth of hers (of Lucilla's I meane) si tamen Martyres, if at least they be Martyrs, eyther your ancient, or your moderne? But Optatus mislikes this doting vpon Martyrs Reliques though true Martyrs, as the place sheweth. Thus sayth M. Collins, wherin there is notable fraud, and a great deale of folly: but I omit the folly, to say somewhat briefly of the fraud.

38. You see, he sayth, that Lucilla vsed to kisse the Reliques of a Martyr euery morning, before she receaued the Blessed
Sacrament of the Eucharist, and he vrgeth it very much against me, because I am, as he sayth, for kissing Reliques very definitiuely. The truth is, that Optatus sayth, that Lucilla (who was a most wicked Schismatike, and therfore like inough to swarue also from the customs of true Catholiks in many things) vsed alwayes before she communicated, to kisse a bon of a dead man, which no doubt as she vsed it, was a most ridiculous, and superstitious ceremony, & was taught her by Donatus the first Author of the Donatistes schisme and heresy, of whome we read in Balsamons Commentary vpon the Councell of Carthage cap. 61. that he did hould, and teach that no man could be partaker of the diuine Mysteries, except he first held a bone in his hand, and saluted it; which doctrine of his she vndoubtedly practised before she communicated, in kissing the bone of some dead man, whome the Donatists held for a Martyr, though perhaps he was none, at least nondum vindicati, sayth Optatus, not so approued to be.

39. Therefore this being a most superstitious act, it was worthily noted, and deryded by Optatus; but what proueth this against the kissing of Reliques? Yes sayth M. Collins, for if it be lawfull to kisse them,
why not also to begin the Communion with such a seruice? Wherto I answere, that albeit there is no doubt, but that we may lawfully kisse Reliques before we cōmunicate, yet to thinke that the worthy receauing of the diuine misteryes depēdeth thereon (as no doubt she did, according to the doctrine of her Maister Donatus) is, not only ridiculous, and superstitious, but also impious; as the like may also be sayd of other good works, if they should be done in the same manner.

40. As for example, if any man would not otherwayes receaue the blessed Sacrament, except he had first giuen almes, with this cōceit that the worthy receauing therof depēded vpon the giuing of that almes, this act no doubt should be superstitious, and vnlawfull: so as M. Collins hath heerein notably peruerted the sense and meaning of Optatus, to the end he might say somewhat with more shew of probability against the kissing of Reliques; because I do approue the same in the 9. Chapter of my Adioynder num. 24. vpon occasion of certaine obiections, which Vigilantius made to Catholiks in S. Hieromes tyme, saying thus: VVe see you (sayth Vigilantius) according to the custome of the Gentills &c. euery where kisse, and adore,
I know not what little dust carryed in a little vessell, and lapt in a pretious linnen cloath. Thus wrote Vigilantius. Whereupon I noted, that it appeared euidently by the obiection of Vigilantius, that the common custome of the faythfull was at that tyme to do corporall reuerence to Reliques, not only by kissing them, but also by inclyning, or bowing downe the body vnto them, which the word adoration signifyeth, and S. Hierome denyeth it not, though he denyeth the inference of Idolatry, that Vigilantius made theron.

41. Thus indeed I said then in the 24. number now cyted by M. Collins, out of tyme, and place; for where I sayd it, he passed it ouer with silence, because he durst not vndertake to answere that which I alleadged togeather with it out of S. Hierome against Vigilantius cōcerning the worship of Reliques, & therfore he fraudulently dissēbled the whole, as you saw before in the the last Chapter num. 29.30: & 35. Neither doth he tell heer what I sayd in particuler concerning the kissing of reliques, but only sayth in generall tearmes, that I am for the kissing of Reliques difinitiuely in the 24. numb.

42. And much lesse will he seeme to remember what I alleadged to the same
purpose in the seauenth Chapter of my Adioynder num. 9. out of S. Gregory Nissen, who in his oration vpon S. Theodore the Martyr speaking of the feruent deuotion of the people in seeking to approach to the tomb of that holy Martyr, appealeth to their owne experience, and knowledge, how happy they did thinke themselues, when they could haue the good fortune to touch his Reliques, and how they imbraced, & kissed them, & applyed them to their eyes, eares, and all the instruments of their senses, to all which M. Collins had not a word to say, where I alleadged it, but did let it slip without answere, togeather with the whole place of S. Gregory Nissen; and now belike he thinketh he hath sufficiently confuted it by this example, which neuerthelesse you see doth make no more against the kissing of Reliques, then against any other good worke, done in the same manner and vpon the like consideration.

43. Yea but Optatus, as M. Collins sayth, mislikes this doting on martyrs reliques, though true Martyrs; so indeed sayth M. Collins, and affirmeth also that the place sheweth it; wherein he belyeth Optatus manifestly, who blameth Lucilla only because she did praeponere calici salutarios cuiusdā hominis mortu • , & si Martyris,
sed necdum vindicati, that is to say, she preferred before the holy cup, the bone of a certaine dead man, who if he were a Martyr, yet was not approued so to be; wherupon it may well be gathered that Optatus accused her, to valew and esteeme more the kissing of that bone, then the holy Communion; and that he signifyed the same by the word praeponere, which doth commonly signify to preferre in worth or dignity; which also is the more probable in this place, because so the sense is cōforme to the foresayd doctrine of her Maister Donatus, who placed the fruit of receauing the holy misteryes in that, or such a Ceremony.

44. And albeit praeponere should be taken only to set before in order or place, as that she did it first, before she communicated, yet it maketh nothing for M. Collins, seeing that Optatus doth not speake at all of a true approued Martyr, but only giueth to vnderstand, that her fault was the greater, because she vsed that ceremōy to a bone of one that either was no Martyr, or at least not receaued, and approued for a Martyr; as who would say, that her superstition had beene yet more tollerable if she had done it to a Relique of a true, and vnapproued Martyr. And therefore M. Collins hath not
only notably peruerted the meaning and sense of Optatus; but also belyed his text, affirming that this place sheweth that he misliketh the kissing of true Martyrs reliques, when neuertheles he doth not speake of a true Martyr, but only of a dead man (as he calleth him) who was eyther no Martyr, or at least an vncertaine Martyr, not receaued and approued to be honoured in the Church.

45. I omit his notable folly, in asking by the way, whether he may not say of our martyrs both ancient, and moderne, as Optatus sayd of Lacilla's martyr, to wit, sitamen martyres, for howsoeuer it may please him to cal in questiō our modern matyrs, yet I see not why he should doubt of our ancient Martyrs, seeing we haue no other ancient martyrs thē such as all the Church alloweth aswell as we, and of whose Martyrdome no true Christian hath hitherto doubted: but I say, I omit this for a foolery, not worthy of further examination, that I may enlarge my self somewhat (as I shalbe forced to do) to discouer his notable falsehood in an obiection which he maketh out of S. Gregory lib. 3. Registr. Ep. ad Constant. August. Thus then he saith of S. Gregory.

46. It amazed him to heare that dead bodyes should be digged vp againe or, as the fashion before had beene (S. Augustine so witnessing, S. Hierome, and diuers more) that the fragments of Martyrs should be carryed vp and downe, vnder pretence of deuotion, but indeed for sale, or for gaze of idle people. Thus saith M. Collins of S.
