Gregory, and by the way also of S. Augustine, and S. Hierome with diuers more. And therefore first to speake of that which he alleadgeth out of S. Gregory, it is very true, that S. Gregory sayth, in that epistle; that he wondred much at a custome which he heard was in Greece (although he could scant beleeue it) to take vp the bones of Saints. And the cause of this his wonder was, for that certayn greeke monks who had been at Rome. 2. yeares before, digged vp in the night dead mens bodyes in a feild neere to S. Pauls Church, and hid the bones thereof vntill they should depart, and being examined after to what end they did it, they confessed, that they meant to carry them to Greece at their returne for the reliques of Saints. Wherupon S. Gregory saith, that he became more doubtful thē before, whether it was true, which was reported, that the Greekes did indeed take vp the bones of
Saints, or that the report only grew of the imposture of such as the aforesaid monks; who meant to haue giuen abroad the bones of ordinary dead men, for the true bones, and reliques of Saints.

47. To this effect doth S. Gregory speak of this matter, worthily dislyking, and reprehending that abuse of the Grecians (if it were true) that the bones of Saints should be ordinarily taken vp, and distributed abroad at euery mans pleasure, which must needes open the way to a farre greater abuse, and giue occasion to euill disposed persons, to deceiue the people with counterfayt, and false reliques, in which respect it is not conuenient, neyther euer was permitted in the Roman Church, that the tombes or graues of Saints should be opened, nor their reliques taken out, without iust cause, and the licence of the Bishops, or other Ecclesiasticall magistrates; therefore that which S. Gregory misliked, and reproued cōcerning the digging vp of Sains bones, was no other, but the ordinary custome of it, without the licence and warrant of Superiors, and without some iust occasion; for S. Gregory was so far frō dissallowing it, when it was done vpon vrgent, and iust cause, with the leaue of
Superiors, that he practised the same himself, both giuing leaue to others to do it, and sending holy reliques himselfe to dyuers persons and places.

48. This appeareth in diuers epistles of his, as in the 11. Epistle of his seauenth booke Indict. 2. wherein he gaue order to seauen Bishops to giue satisfaction to a noble man called George, who had required leaue of him to haue some Reliques of such holy Martyrs as were buryed in their diocesses, with promise to build a Church in their honour, at his owne charges; also ep. 73. lib. 9. Indict. 4. he gaue the like order to the Bishop of Hidruntum, to giue some Reliques of the body of S. Leontius (which was buryed in his diocesse) to the Abbot of the Monastery of S. Leontius, because certain Reliques of the sayd Saint had been stolne out of that Monastery. Also epist. 50. l 5. Indict. 14. he wrote to Palladius Bishop of Xaintonges in France, that he sent him the reliques of S. Peter, S. Paul, S. Laurence, and S. Pancrace, because the sayd Bishop had built a Church and altars in honour of them.

49. In like manner ep. 31. lib. 12. Indict. 7. it appeareth that S. Augustine our Apostle being in England, and finding that the people were perswaded, that the body of S.
Sixtus the Martyr was there (which he thought altogeather vnprobable) required of Pope Gregory to send him some vndoubted reliques of S. Sixus, which he did with this charge, that if there were no miracles don at that body, which was there honoured for a Martyrs body, neither yet that any of the ancienter sort could testify that they had heard of his martyrdome by their parents, then the place where the body lay should be stopped vp, & the reliques which he sent, should be placed a part by themselues, Nec permittatur populus, sayth he, certū deserere, & incertum venerari; & let not the people be suffered to leaue that which is certaine, to worship that which is vncertaine. Thus sayth S. Gregory to S. Augustine the first Apostle of our English nation, by whom we were conuerted from Paganisme to the Christian fayth.

50. And this I wish M. Collins to note for three causes: the first, that he may see S. Gregoryes practise of sending reliques, so far as from Rome to England, to be there held in veneration: the second, that he may also obserue what care as well S. Gregory as S. Augustin had to preserue the people from the worshipping of false Reliques, which care is still had in the Catholike Church, as shal appeare after a whyle: the third, that we
receaued in our Countrey the doctrine, and practise of worshipping holy Reliques, togeather with the knowledge of Christ, and the first rudiments of our Christian fayth, now more then a thousand yeares ago.

51. And he that desireth to see more aboundant testimony of S. Gregoryes fayth, & practise, concerning this point, let him read his Epistle 51. lib. 5. Indict. 14. ep. 12. lib. 7. Indict. 2. ep. 86. 87. & 88. lib. 7. Indict. 2. & epist. 62. lib. 8. Indict. 3. to omit diuers others, by all which it appeareth, that either he himselfe translated and sent Reliques, or els gaue leaue to others to translate or send them for the dedication, and consecration of Oratoryes, or Churches, with order that they should be layd vp, and kept cum reuerentia, & debito honore, with reuerence, & due honour, as he wrote to Brunechilda Queene of France concerning the Reliques of S. Peter, and S. Paul, which he sent her at her request. And this custome of dedicating, or consecrating Churches with the Reliques of Saints, was obserued not only in S. Gregoryes tyme (as it hath beene euer since) but in the tyme also of S. Ambrose, who sent part of the reliques of SS. Geruasius and Protasius to diuers of his friends abroad, by the occasion whereof Churches
were built, & dedicated to those Saints in diuers Countryes, as I haue signifyed before.

52. But to shew the extraordinary respect, reuerence, and deuotion which S. Gregory bare, and thought to be due to holy reliques, there can be no greater testimony then that very Epistle of his to Constantia the Empresse, out of which Maister Collins hath picked this scrapp, whereof I haue hither to treated; and therefore, to the end you may see his bad Conscience, and wilfull blyndenes, I will take a little paynes to giue you the substance of the whole. This Empresse being to build a Church in the honour of S. Paul, wrote to S. Gregory to send her his head, or els some part of his body, to which he answered, that he nei- could nor durst do it, whereof he gaue this reason; because (saith he) the bodyes of S. Peter, and S. Paul the Apostles do shyne with so many miracles, & terrours in their Churches, that none can come so much as to pray there, without great feare; and of this he giueth diuers examples; first of his predecessour, who going about to chaunge the syluer which was ouer the most holy body of S. Peter (at the least 15. foote from it) was not a little terrifyed with a signe or miraculous sight
which appeared vnto him. Sed & ego (sayth he) aliquid similiter &c. And I also was desirous to mend some thing about the most sacred body of S. Paul, and for that it was necessary to digge some. what deep neere vnto the tombe; he who had charge of the place, found there certaine bones somewhat separate from the tomb, and because he presumed to take them vp, and to remoue them to another place, he dyed suddenly, besydes that other dolefull signes, or spectacles also appeared there. Thus sayth S. Gregory of his owne experience.

53. And hauing after related the like miraculous punishment inflicted by Almighty God vpon diuers who presuming to see the body of S. Laurence, died all with in tenne dayes after, he addeth, that the custome was at Rome, when reliques were to be giuē, not to touch the Saints bodyes, but only to apply a handkerchiffe therto, and to keepe yt, cum debita veneratione, with due veneration, in the Church which was to be dedicated, Et tantae (saith S. Gregory) per hoc ibidem virtutes fiunt, ac si illuc illorum corpora specialiter deserantur; and as great miracles are done thereby, as if the Saints bodyes were speically carryed thither; whereupon it hapned (saith he also further) that in the tyme of Pope Leo of happy memory (as we haue receiued by tradition from our fore fathers) he
did cut in sunder such a hand-cherchiffe with a payre of Cyzers for the satisfactiō of certaine Grecians who doubted of such reliques, and there issued bloud out of it; for amongst the Romans, & in all the East parts, it is held to be altogeather intollerable, and sacrilegious to touch the bodyes of Saints; and if any presume to do it, Certum est, quia haec temeritas impunita nullo modo remanebit: it is certaine that their temerity shall not remaine vnpunished.

54. Thus sayth S. Gregory, and concludeth vpon these premisses, that he therfore meruaileth very much, and can scantly belieue it, that the Grecians had such a custome as was reported, to take vp the bones of Saints; and then vpon this occasion he recounteth that which I haue layd downe before, concerning the Greeke Monkes, who digged vp dead mens bones to carry into Greece for reliques. By all which it is euident, that albeit he blameth and greatly disliketh the abuse of the sayd Greeke Monks (which indeed was detestable, and therefore worthy to be blamed, & • euerely punished) yet he acknowledgeth 〈◊〉 manifestly the honour due to reliques, 〈◊〉 if M. Collins did read the Epistle it selfe 〈◊〉 not take the obiection out of some
other mans note-booke without seeing the circumstances) he sheweth himselfe to a a man of no conscience, or honesty, to obiect it against the veneration of reliques, seeing it doth so testify, and proue the holynes of them, that it may rather terrify any man from touching them, for the reuerent respect due vnto them, then moue him to reiect or disesteeme them.

55. But M. Collins will say perhaps, that he alleadgeth this to prooue two thinges, the one, That the fragments of Martyrs are not to be carryed vp & downe vnder pretence of deuotion, for sale, or for gaze of idle people (for so indeed he sayth;) the other, that dead bodyes should not be digged vp againe, or translated: both which points, he will say this Epistle proueth directly; whereto I answere, that if he did acknowledge the truth of S. Gregoryes doctrine in this Epistle, concerning the veneration of holy reliques, he might with more reason allea • ge this other, as he doth; to proue that they should not be translated or digged vp; but seeing he maketh vse of this only, which may seeme to serue his purpose; and not only condemneth the other, but also craftily concealeth it (to make his Reader belieue, that S. Grego • y disaloweth the digging vp of Saints bones,
because he condemneth the veneration of them) this, I say, is an intollerable fraud, and much the more because the circumstāces (which he fraudulently dissembleth) being considered, do plainely shew, that al that which he alleadgeth is nothing to the purpose.

56. For as for the first of the two points for which he produceth this testimony (to wit to proue that the reliques of Martyrs, are not to be carryed about for sale vnder pretence of deuotion) it maketh nothing at all against vs, who condemne the same as much, or more then he, a • he may see by the Canons of the Catholike Church, namely the 62. Canon of the great Councell of Lateran, where it is expresly forbidden to sell holy reliques, as also to expose new reliques to veneration except they be first approued by the Authority of the Pope. And this is also expresly noted by all the Canonists, as may be seene in Panormit. cap. Cum ex eo num. 1. Rub. de reliquijs & vener. Hostien, lib 3. Rubr. de reliquijs. Syluest. verb. Reliquiae & to omit others, Nauar. in sum. cap. 17. num. 169.

57. Finally the Councel of Trent hath had such care to preuent, and remedy all such abuses concerning holy reliques, that
they haue giuen very strict charg & cōmādement sess. 25. to all Bishops to vse all diligence to that end, and in questions, or cases of doubt or difficulty to vse the mature aduise, not only of Deuines, but also (if need require) of the Metropolitans and Prouinciall Councells, and yet so, that no new thing, or custome that hath not beene vsed in the Church before shalbe introduced without the consent of the Sea Apostolik: such care hath the Catholike Church to auoyd all inconueniences, & abuses which may arise either by the inordinate zeale of ignorant people, or by the malice of wicked men. And therefore if M. Collins will condemne the vse and worship of holy reliques, because they haue beene, or may be abused, he sheweth himselfe to be very absurd, and sottish; for he may by the same reason condemne whatsoeuer is good, and holy in the Church of God; for there is nothing which is vsed, but it may be, & hath been at one tyme or other abused. And this shall suffice for this point.

58. As for the other point which M. Collins seeketh to proue by this epistle (to wit that the bones of Saints, are not to be digged vp or translated) it is to be vnderstood, that S. Gregory affirmeth it specially concerning
those bodyes of the Apostles S. Peter, and S. Paul, and of S. Laurence, because Almighty God had shewed by euident signes, and miracles, that it was not his will they should be remoued or touched, as you haue heard, which S. Gregory sheweth also afterwardes more manifestly, saying; that very many Christians came to Rome from the Easts parts (when the Apostles were martyred) to demand their bodyes, as of their Cittizens, or Countreymen, and that going to the place where they were buryed called Catacumbas, two myles out of Rome, they vsed al their endeauour to carry them away, and that they were so terrifyed with extraordinary thunder, and lightning, that they gaue it ouer, and presumed not to attempt it further; whereupon (sayth S. Gregory) Exuntes Romani, eorum corpora qui hoc ex Domini pietate meruerunt, leuauerunt, & in locis quibus nunc condita sunt, posuerunt, The Romans who deserued it through our Lords piety, went forth, and tooke vp their bodyes, and placed them wher they are now buryed. Thus sayth S. Gregory.

59. Wherin it is to be noted, that those holy bodyes being first buryed in Catacumbas, two myles out of Rome, were taken vp, and translated from thence into Rome by the
Romans, which could not haue beene lawfully done, if it were absolutly vnlawful to take vp and translate Saints bodyes. But afterwards when Almighty God had shewed euidently that it was his holy will and pleasure, that they should not only remain in Rome, but also be vnseene and vntouched (in respect of the great veneration wherein he would haue them to be held) S. Gregory had great reason to feare Gods punishmēt, in case he should suffer them to be touched or seene, as King Dauid feared with like reason to touch the Arke, or to bring it into his Citty, after that Oza was strocken with sudden death for staying it, and houlding it vp when it was like to fall 2. Reg. 6. And therefore S. Gregory refused in like manner to send to the Empresse the napkin (wherin S. Paules head was wrapped) saying to her thus: Sudarium quod similiter transmitti iussisti • &c. The winding-sheet which you also cōmand to be sent you, is with his body; and as the body may not be approached, so neither may the sayd sheet be touched: but because the religious desire of so Gratious a Lady ought not to be frustrated, I wil with speed send you some part of the chaynes, which the holy Apostle S. Paul bare vpon his neck, and handes (by the which many
miracles are shewed) if I can get from them any part thereof with a fyle; for it falleth out often that when many come, and demand some benediction from those chayns (by hauing some little part of the filings of them) the Priest standeth by with the fyle; and for some of those who demaund it, some litle is easily and speedily filed of; but for some others, nothing at all can be gotten from the chaynes, though they be fyled neuer so long.

60. Thus sayth S. Gregory; and with this he endeth his Epistle, hauing recounted as you see, so many stupendious thinges, to shew the great respect, and honour due to holy Reliques, that Maister Collins may be thought no lesse senseles then shameles to produce this Epistle, or any thing in it, against the veneration of them, especially, seeing that which S. Gregory sayth also in general (touching his mislike of the taking vp of Saints bones) tendeth only to the greater honour of them, his meaning being no other (as I haue declared before num 42.) but that they should not be taken vp (in respect of the reuerence due vnto them) without iust cause, and leaue of Superiours which is alwayes iustly graunted, when it may be to the greater glory of God, and of
his Saints, in which case S. Gregory himself practised it, as you haue seene in the examples alleadged before out of his owne Epistles in this Chapter, num. 48. 49. & 51.

61. Whereby it appeareth that albeit he neither would, nor durst cōsent that the bodyes of S. Peter, S. Paul, or S. Laurence shold be taken vp, or any reliques taken from thē (by reason of the manifest demonstration, which Almighty God had shewed of his wil, that they should not be so much as touched or seene) yet he gaue leaue that Reliques should be taken from the bodyes of other Saintes, for the dedication of new Churches, and Altars, and other iust respects; yea, and he himselfe sent also to others abroad reliques euen of S. Peter, S. Paul and S. Laurence; such reliques, I meane, as were already separated from their bodyes and had beene in former tymes reserued, as it appeareth in his Epistle to Palladius cyted before num. 48. as also in his Epistle to Brunechilda Queen of France num. 51. and the same is in like māner euident inough euen in this Epistle to the Empresse: for althogh he denyed to send her S. Pauls head, or the linnen cloath wherin the same was wrapped (for the reason before declared) yet he promised to send her some of the fylings of
his chayns, which were kept separate from his body; so as there can be no doubt of S. Gregoryes beliefe, and doctrine concerning the vse and veneration of holy reliques; but it may well be doubted, whether M. Collins hath any sparke of shame or honesty in him, who seeing such aboundant testimony in S. Gregoryes Epistles of the reuerent respect and honour which he bare to holy Reliques, doth neuerthelesse wittingly & willfully abuse his authority against them; and no meruaile, seeing he doth the like with S. Ambrose, S. Augustine, S. Hierome, and S. Chrysostome alleadging them against the translation, and veneration of holy reliques, when they, as you haue already seen do all of them clearely testify and approue the practise thereof.

62. This being so, what need I trouble my selfe, and my Reader, with any other answere to his Parenthesis cōcerning S. Augustine, and S. Hierome, who, he sayth, do witnesse, that the fashion was before S. Gregoryes tyme, to carry fragments of Martyrs vp and downe for sale? For is it not euident by the premisses, that both S. Augustine, and S. Hierome did highly approue the solemne, and deuout translation of holy Reliques? With what face thē, doth this brazē-faced fellow
obiect against vs, their dislike, and reproof of the abuse of holy reliques, which we also condēne no lesse thē they, punishing the delinquents, when occasion requireth? But because he setteth downe in his margent these wordes of S. Augustine: Noui multos sepulchrorum adoratores &c. I know there are many that do adore sepulchers &c. and addeth also afterwardes, a testimony of Gregorius Turonensis, touching one that had a satchel of Rats bones, and Rootes, and teeth of Moales, and the fat of Bears, which he distributed to the people for reliques; S. Augustine himselfe shall answere M. Collins for both in the same place, where he hath the words obiected by M. Collins, to wit, in his first Booke de moribus Ecclesiae Catholicae cap. 34.

63. But first it is to be vnderstood, that the Manicheans in those dayes obiected against the Catholiques (as M. Collins doth now) aswell certaine abuses of ignorant, and superstitious men, as the bad liues of some others, and among other things, that there were some who adored the tombes of Martyrs (eyther with diuyne honour, or with some superstitious Ceremonies, in which respect they called them, sepulchrorum adoratores) which S. Augustine acknowledgeth to be true, and therfore answereth
them, that they should not obiect vnto him such as professe the Christian religiō, and eyther do not knowe the force of their profession, or doe not practise it; neither yet that they should obiect a Company of ignorant men, who eyther are superstitious in religion it self, or so giuen ouer to their lust, and pleasure, that they forget, what they haue promised to God. And he sayth further to the Manichees thus; It is no meruaile, that in such multitudes of people (as professe the Christian religion) there want not some, by whose bad lyues you may deceaue the vnwary, and auert them from the saluation which they may haue by the Catholique faith &c. Nunc autem illud vos admoneo &c. but now I do admonish or aduise you of this, viz. to leaue your rayling vpon the Catholike Church blaming the manners of men, whom the Church it selfe condemneth, and dayly laboureth to correct and reforme as bad Children. Thus sayth S. Augustine to the Manichees; and so say I to M. Collins, to make him capable, if it may be, that neither the abuse of some Catholiques in the exercise or practise of religion, neither yet the bad liues of some others can preiudice the integrity, and purity of the Catholique fayth, and doctryne; and so he himselfe and his fellowes would quickly tell vs, if we should obiect against
them, the mōstrous bad liues of their Ministers (manifest to all England at the publicke Assises, and Sessions) and the manifold abuses committed by diuers of them in the exercise of their function, and ministery.

64. Therefore whereas he obiecteth against vs the foresayd abuses of reliques, reproued by foure auncient Fathers, (S. Augustine, S. Hierome, S. Gregory the great, & S. Gregory Bishop of Towers) we require of him, that as we condemne the same abuses with those Fathers; so also he will acknowledge and approue with them and vs, the veneration of holy reliques, which they acknowledg and approue as you haue seene already in three of them, that is to say, in Saint Hierome, Saint Augustine, and Saint Gregory the great. And the same is no lesse euident in the fourth, to wit, in Saint Gregory Bishop of Towers, who hath writtē two notable books de gloria Martyrū, and de gloriae Confessorum; the substance whereof is nothing els, but a relation of m • nifest miracles done at the Tombes, or by the reliques of Martyrs and Confessors, vpon such as with deuotion, and reuerence had recourse vnto them.

65. Therefore a man may wonder at
the impudency of this fellow, who is not • shamed to make this holy father an abettour of his impiety in impugning holy reliques, only because he doth with detestatiō recount the history of a sacrilegious Nigromācer, who deceiued deuout people with counterfait, and false reliques; in which story neuerthelesse there is most euident testimony aswell of the Authors reuerent respect and deuotion to holy reliques, as also of the praictise of the Church in the veneration of them which I omit for breuityes sake. And therefore whereas M. Collins concludeth his marginall note cōcerning the testimony of this Father, with this question, Is it not pitty, that we Englishmen will not traffike with the Iesuits for such ghostly cōmodityes (meaning rats bones, the teeth of moales, & such like;) I would gladly know of M. Collins what Iesuits (yea or what other Catholique man in this age) he can name that hath euer made traffick with such wares; & if he cannot name any (whereof I am well assured) then I may well aske him, whether it is not great pitty, and shame, that Englishmen should haue such pastors of their soules, such preachers, teachers, and writers, as make no conscience to lye, slaunder, and backbite, quorum os
maledictione, & amaritudine plenum est. psal. 13. whose mouth is full of malediction and bitternesse; whose throate is sepulchrum patens, an open Sepulcher; and the venime of Aspis is vnder their lyps; yea, & voloces pedes eorum ad effundendum sanguinem, their feet are swift to spill bloud, as wee find by experience when we fall into their fingers: but God forgiue them, and send them more Charity, and the light of his grace.

66. There followeth in M. Collins a place out of Origen contra Celsum lib. 8. which he sayth he had omitted, so as it seemed to him to be of such importance, that it might not be passed ouer with silence. VVe haue learned, saith Origen, to recommend honorably to the graue the instruments of the soule reasonable, that is, (sayth M. Collins) the bodyes of men, and the members thereof: Therefore not to make reliques of them. So he; which he might very well haue stil omitted, and kept in store, vntill he had met with some man, who would deny that dead men should be buryed, which we do not; for we do bury not only euery dead man (houlding it for a great worke of Charity) but also the holyest men, albeyt we do also afterwards honour theyr tombs, bodyes, and reliques when Almighty God hath giuen vndoubted
testimony of their sanctity, by miracls, or by the iudgment of the Church; yea and sometymes we take them vp agayn, & translate them with greater honour, and solemnity, for Gods greater glory, and theyrs; so as we do thē honour in burying of them, and more honour in translating them, as it is euident in the examples of the Saints before mentioned; to wit, the Apostles S. Peter, S. Paul, S. Andrew, S. Luke, S. Tymothy, Samuel the prophet, S. Ignatius, S. Babylas, S. Geruase, and Protase, who were buryed honourably by the Christians then liuing, and translated after with farre greater honour to God, and them. And therefore M. Collins his argument out of Origen is such a silly one, as that he might very well haue omitted it, and I also haue let it passe for one of his ordinary fooleryes, but that I note in it the same fraud that he vsed before in the like places of S. Ambrose, whereby he chaunged the state of the question from Saints (of whom we speak) to ordinary dead men, of whom Origen, & S. Ambrose speake; for of them there is to be had farre different considerations, as I haue declared before.

67. Next after this, he addeth two other exampls against Reliques out of Victor
Vticensis de persecutione Vandalica lib. 1. The first of Armogastes, sayth he, a godly Christian who desired Faelix (another of the profession) sepeliri sub arbore siliquae, i. that being dead, he might be buryed vnder a homely tree (if a tree) not with triumph, and fauour, or solemnity. So he. And then addeth further thus: As for the Sarcophagus which appeared, as it were by miracle, in the place by him allotted for his buryall, I impute that to the satisfaction of his godly desire, about a quicke consumption or turning into nothing, then which nothing can be more repugnant to your ceremony of Reliques. Thus sayth M. Collins, telling vs a tale of a tub, speaking of a Sarcophagus, so obscurely, that no man who hath not read the history can tell what it meaneth. Therfore that you may vnderstand the whole, and see his fraud withall, I will briefly relate the matter as it passed.

68. This Armogastes hauing beene many wayes extremely tormented by the Vandalls for the Catholik fayth, and hauing endured the same with inuincible courage, and constancy, was at length made to keep Cattle neere to Carthage, & hauing after a whyle a reuelation from Almighty of his death, to succeed within few dayes, he
most earnestly intreated a friend of his called Faelix (who did often visit him) to bury him vnder a tree, when he should be dea • ; which Faelix denyed to graunt him a long tyme, telling him that he should be buryed in a Church cum triumpho & gratia, that is to say with triumph and solemnity, as was conuenient.

69. Neuerthelesse in the end being charged deeply by him in conscience as he would answere it before God, he promised him to satisfy his desire. Within a few dayes after Armogastes dyed, and Faelix meaning to performe his promise, digged with great difficulty, through the rootes of the Tree, Et tandem (sayth Victor) abscissis radicibus, multò altiùs terram cauans, inuenit Sarcophagum splendidissimi marmoris praeparatum, qualem fortè nullus omnino habuit Regum: And at length digging much deeper, and the roots of the Tree being cut away, he found a Tombe of most bright shining Marble ready made, such a one as perhaps neuer any King had the like. Thus sayth Victor.

70. Now good Reader, I leaue it to thy Iudgment, whether any thing can be iustly picked out of this history against reliques; or rather whether the contrary may not be gathered thereof, seeing it appeareth
thereby, how much Almighty God honored the dead body of this his seruant, for the which he miraculously prepared so rich and magnificent a sepulcher. And whereas M. Collins vrgeth two points therein for his purpose: the one, that Armogastes would be buryed simply vnder a homely tree, not cum triumpho & gratia, not with fauour, and solemnity: and the other, that he desired a quicke consumption, which sayth M. Collins is most repugnant to your ceremony of Reliques, he is most ridiculous in both, and in the later not ōly ridiculous, but also fraudulēt. I say ridiculous, because the contrary of that which he supposeth doth rather follow thereof.

71. For what can be gathered of eyther of both, but that Armogastes was so hūble, that he esteemed himself vnworthy of all honour, & respect, or so much as of any memory amongst men, which made him most honourable, and glorious in the sight of God, according to the saying of our Sauiour, qui se humiliat, exaltabitur, and therfore this humility was so farre from hindring his desert to be honoured after his death, that being testifyed by Almighty God, with the honour of such a miraculous buriall, it made his very memory and reliques
much more venerable and honourable; besides that, what a silly fellow is M. Collins to think that any holy mā doth esteem himself worthy to be held for a Saint, or his body, and reliques worthy of worship after his death, which only conceit might suffice to depriue him of Gods fauour, and grace, & consequently of eternall blisse. Wil he then argue thus; Armogastes desired a homely burial, and to be quickly consumed; Ergo there ought to be no Reliques of him or of any els? Or therefore reliques are not to be worshipped? Who seeth not the absurdity of these consequents? Seeing that which may be inferred vpon those premisses, is this, that he himselfe desired out of his humility that there should be no reliques, nor further memory of him, which as I haue sayd, did greatly increase his merit, and make him much more worthy of honour.

72. But if I should aske M. Collins where he hath found that Armogastes desired to be quickly consumed to nothing, he would tell me (no doubt) that he found it in the Sarcophagus, which Faelix found by digging vnder the tree, because Plyny telleth of a kind of stone found at a Citty called Assus, neere to Troy in Phrygia, the property wherof is to consume dead bodyes, all but the
teeth, within fourty dayes, which stone is therfore called Sarcophagus in Greek compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 flesh, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to eate; so as M. Collins must by this meanes imagine that Armogastes knowing by reuelation, not onely that there was a tombe vnder that Tree, where he desired to be buryed, but also that it was made of that stone, ordayned to be buryed there, to the end he might be presently consumed, and nothing left of him to make reliques off.

73. Neuerthelesse if we should graunt all this to be true, the matter would not not be altogeather cleare; for so Armogastes must also know (if he knew the property of that stone by reuelation) that his teeth would remaine vnconsumed, and in danger to be made reliques, whereby his desire of a totall consumption should not be satisfyed, nor M. Collins his argument against reliques, proued altogeather so sound as he would haue it. But truely, albeit I cannot but cōmend him for his fine deuise, shewing his pretty wit, and that he hath som • smacke aswell in Grammer, as in Plynyes naturall history; yet I must needs condemne him of no small fraud, in that he wresteth the sense of the word Sarcophagus from th • common vse thereof, to a particuler sense 〈◊〉
to wit, to one kind of tombe, made only of that stone, which the very wordes of the Author, and the circumstances doe contradict; for as for the common vse thereof in Greeke or Latin, I report me to the Dictionaryes of either language, as to Henricus Stephanus, and to Scapula for the Greeke, who do expound 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as it is an adiectiue by Carniuorus, and as it is a substantiue, they say it is taken pro sepulchro, for a sepulcher, meaning that it is a generall word for a sepulcher, and therefore they add withall, that it signifyeth also a stone which consumeth flesh speedily. The Latin Dictionaryes, also say the same; & our Latin Authors do vse it likewise for a sepulcher in generall, as Iuuenall speaking of Alexander the Great (Satyr. 10.) sayth Sarcophago contentus erit, and S. Augustin sayth expresly in his 18. book deciuitate Dei cap. 5. that all men do call Sarcophagum, that which in Greeke is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and signifyeth a tombe, wherein dead men are layd; and this I note the rather out of S. Augustine, because he was an African, as Victor was, who writeth this story of Armogastes in the same age, & therfore no doubt vsed the word Sarcophagus in the sense, which S. Augustin sayth was commō to all, as all other Latin Authours of the
ensuing ages haue done, namely S. Gregorius Turonensis, who hath the same words in the same sense.

74. But to put the matter out of all doubt, the very text, and wordes of Victor do expresly exclude this cōceit of M. Collins, seeing he sayth, that Faelix hauing digged very deep, inuenit Sarcophagum splēdidiffimi marmoris, found a tombe of most bright, and shining Marble; and therefore it was not made of the stone called Sarcophagus, which according to Dioscorides lib. 5. cap. 142. is leuis, fungosus, & friabilis, light, spūgy, or soft like a musrumpe, and easily to be crumbled, whereas marble is a most hard and solide stone; and albeit some kind of Marble is soster then other (as the white which is called Alabaster) yet there is none among all the kinds (which Plyny, or any other recoūteth) that is light, spungy, and crumbling as Dioscorides describeth Sarcophagus to be, & therefore Iacobus Delachampius in his annotations vpon Plyny lib. 36. cap. 17. obserueth that some Authours do say, that Sarcophagus or lapis Assius is a kind of the stone called Pyrites, which is of the nature of fire (according to the Etymology of the word) & that others hould it to be a kind of pumishston; which is the lightest, and most spungy stone that
is; so as, in the opinion of all these it is very different from the nature of Marble.

75. And put the case it were some kind of Marble, or might be so called, yet M. Collins should haue no reason to take it in this place for a Tombe made of that one kind of Marble, seeing the word Sarcophagus was (as I haue sayd) at that tyme when the story was written generally vnderstood for any Tombe made of what matter soeuer, and that it was also expressed in the Text of the history, that it was splendidissimi marmoris, of most bright and shining Marble, which cannot be applyed to this stone, wherein there is no splendour or brightnes obserued by Authors. And if M. Collins wil say, that the Etimology of the word (signifying an eating, or deuouring of flesh) might well induce him so to expound it, then why is it not also to be taken so in other places, alleadged by me before out of Iuuenall, S. Augustine, Gregorius Turonensis, & others, where it is euident that it signifyeth a Tombe, in generall? Or rather why doth he take Pon • ifex, and Episcopus for a Bishop, (which according to the Etymology should signify a Bridg-maker) and a superintendent, or ouerseer? or why doth he take Latrones for theeues, and not for such as guard
Princes going by their sides for their defence, as the word did signify at the first?

76. Therefore as he should be held for ridiculous, and a very Asse, that would now leaue the common vse of these words to vnderstand, and interprete them according to the Etimology or first origen therof, so may good M. Collins be held for no lesse, if he will leaue the common vse, and sense of Sarcophagus (which all men take for a tombe in generall) to vnderstand it for a tombe made of one certaine stone, eyther because the Etymology thereof agreeth therewith, or because perhaps at the first it might haue some deriuatiō from thence, which neuerthelesse, is not necessary, seing that any Tombe, or graue may be properly called Sarcophagus, or Carniuorus, because it doth indeed deuoure, & in tyme consume mens bodyes, and turne them to dust.

77. Thus thou seest, good Reader, how much I haue presumed of thy patiēce to debate so largely with M. Collins this question partly Grammaticall, and partly Historicall, aswell to shew his ignorance, both in Grammer, and history, as also to confute his extrauagant conceit, grounded vpon no better foundation then his owne fraudulent dissimulation of the Authours
text and meaning, which being duly wayghed doth rather make notably against him, then any way for him, as I doubt not, but thou hast seene, and noted sufficiently. And this shall suffice for one of the two exampls, which he alleadgeth out of Victor.

78. The other is of a Bishop of Carthage called Deogratias, whose worthy members, sayth M. Collins, the people out of their zeale might haue violently snatcht away, or pulled asunder, Nisi consilio Prudentum nesciente multitudine sepeliretur, 1. vnlesse he had beene buryed, whyles the people did not know of it, at the direction, and suggestion of wisemen; so as to resist your reliquations (the true bankruptures of religion) is wisedome to Victor, & to the ancient Christians that liued before him. Thus sayth M. Collins, alleadging this example much more truly, then he hath done the former.

79. But albeit there is no fraud in the example, yet there is notable folly in his inference theron; for how doth it follow of this act of those wisemen, eyther that it is wisedome to resist our reliquations (to vse his absurd phrase) or that the preseruation, and veneration of reliques are, the bankruptures of Religion? Whereof rather the contrary may be gathered by this example,
seeing it appeareth euidently therby, how much the reliques of holy men were esteemed, and desired at that tyme, although wise men thought it necessary (as it was indeed) not to suffer the ignorant multitude to preuent the iudgment of the Church by their indiscreet zeale, and to reuerence the Reliques (though of neuer so holy men) before the Church had approued them.

80. And therefore as those wise men (of whom Victor speaketh) buryed the body to saue it from the violence of the indiscreet multitude, so the like hath beene full often and is in like occasion practised by Catholikes, whereof we had an euident example a few yeares ago in the funeralls of a worthy man, of whome I am sure, it will do M. Collins good at the very hart to heare, for the loue he bareth to our Society, I meane our last Father Generall Claudius Aquauiua of happy memory, who being thoroughout al his Generalate, no lesse renowned, and famous for his religious, and holy life, then for the Nobility, and worthynes of his lineage (being sonne to the Duke of Atri) was held in such veneration of the people, that when his body was brought forth to be buryed, they pressed with great
violence to approach the hearse, and to get som reliques of him, by tearing the cloaths wherewith his body was vested (as the manner is heere) which they attempted, & violently got his Cap from his head; wherupon the Fathers of the Society were fayne to vse extraordinary endeauour, and diligence to repell them, and to carry away his body from them by force into the Sacristy, and afterwardes to bury it secretly in the night.

81. Now then albeyt this was done no doubt, consilio prudenti, by wise councell or aduise (as Victor sayth of the other) yet I hope M. Collins will not inferre hereupon, that our Fathers did think that the reliques of Saints are not to be kept, & worshipped, or yet that they would not highly esteeme, and reuerence the reliques of their Generall, if the Church had canonized, and declared him for a Saynt, and the same is to be said of those wisemen of whome Victor speaketh.

82. And whereas M. Collins saith, that our reliquations are the bankruptures of religion; truly he is so fyne, and spruse in his language, that I knowe not well whether I vnderstand him or no (for I cannot tell well what he meaneth by reliquations, or by
bankeruptures otherwayes then by ghesse) but if I ghesse aright, & that he meane that by the veneration of reliques, we become bankrupts in religion, what will he say of all those Fathers before mentioned, who cannot be denyed to haue honoured holy reliques, to wit, S. Hierome, S. Ambrose, S. Chrisostome. S. Gregory Nissen, S. Augustine, S. Gregory the Great, and S. Gregory Bishop of Towers, and others; will he say that by their reliquatiōs they were also bankrupts in religion? and if not they, then why we? who do no more then they did, as it is euident by the testimonyes, and examples alleadged by me before.

83. And now to come to his conclusion, he saith, that S. Hierome shall end the matter, who in the lyues of S. Hilarion, and S. Antony testified that they gaue special order before their deaths; the one (to wit S. Hilarion) to be buryed in his Clothes, and not to be kept aboue ground one minute of an houre (because sayth M. Collins, he would not be pickled vp in reliques;) and the other to be buryed priuately, least one Pergamius a rich man might perhaps steale away his body, and put it in a shryne; and then he addeth, The like was done, saith he, to Moyses body for the same cause, God
euery where forbidding to seeke the liuing amongst the dead, as you do playnely in your reliques, worshipping not thē but Christ in them, as you stick not to triumph num 25. of this Chapter. Thus endeth M. Collins his graue discourse, as wisely, as he beganne it, & with the like sincerity that you haue seene him proceed hitherto.

84. Fo • you see he alleadgeth heer S. Hierome against reliques, as if S. Hierome did also impugne them no lesse then he, wheras that holy Father most earnestly defended the keeping, translation, and veneration of them against Vigilantius, in a particuler treatise written expressely for that purpose, as you haue seene amply in the last Chapter, nu. 22. 23. &c. which being obiected by me in my Adioynder, M. Collins passed ouer with silence, to the end, perhaps, that he might the better afterwards make vse of his authority some way or other against reliques, as heere you see he hath done, though most idly; seeing all that which he produceth out of the liues of those two fathers written by S. Hierome, proueth no more then that which you heard obiected by him before nu. 67. out of Victor Vticensis concerning Armogastes, to wit, that those two holy monks were so
lowly and humble in hart, that they thoght themselues al togeather vnworthy of that honour, which they knew had been done to many holy men after their death, and feared might also be done to them, if they did not preuent it; in which respect (as I said before of Armogastes) they were much more honourable in the sight both of God, and man, and therefore were by gods speciall ordinance, (for his owne greater glory and theirs) highly honoured afterward, not only by the celebration of their festiuall dayes in the Church, but also by the veneration, and translation of their holy reliques, which they (out of their humility) sought so much to auoyd.

85. And this is most euident in Hilarion, euen in that place of S. Hierome which M. Collins alleadgeth & obiecteth to vs, which I beseech thee good Reader, to note, that thou mayst withall consider the honesty of the man. For whereas he alleadgeth out of S. Hierome that S. Hilarion gaue precise order at his death to be buryed in his Coat of hayre Cloth, his homely Cloake, and his hood, and not • o be kept aboue ground one minute of an hower, S Hierome hauing sayd so (and presently after declared in a few lynes his death, & speedy buriall) addeth that a deare disciple
of his called Hesychius being then absent from him in Palestina, and hearing of his death, went to Cyprus, where Hilarion dyed, & obteyned to dwell in the garden where he was buryed, and after ten monethes found meanes to steale away his body, & transported it to Mayona in Palestina, being accompanied with multitudes of monks, and people of the townes adioyning, and there buryed it in an auncient monastery, his Coate, Hood, and Cloake, being still whole, & toto corpore, quasi adhuc viueret integro, tantis{que} fragrante odoribus, vt delibutum vnguentis putaretur, and all his body being vncorrupt, and entyre, as if he were yet aliue; and so fragrant with sweet odours, that it might be thought to haue byn annoynted with sweet oyntments. Thus sayth S. Hierome, who also relateth immediately after, the deuotion Constantiae, sayth he, illius sanctissima mulieris, of the most holy woman Constantia, who was wont peruigiles in sepulchro eius noctes ducere, to passe whole nights watching at his tomb, & quasi cum presente ad adiuuandas orationes suas, sermocinari, and to conferre with him, as if he had beene present to help & further her prayers. Finally S. Hierome cōcludeth, that there was a wonderfull contention, euen vntill that very
day betwixt the people of Cyprus & Palestin •
affirming that they had the one his body, and the other his spirit, by reason of the great miracles, which were dayly done in both places, albeit they were more frequēt in the garden of Cyprus: Forsitan (fayth S. Hierom) quia plus illum locū dilexerit, perhaps because he loued that place better. Thus sayth this ancient Father.

86. Now then out of al this, foure things may be gathered. The first, that Almighty God rewarded his seruants euen in this world, with the honour which he out of his profound humility fled, and thought himselfe vnworthy of. The second that his diuine Maiesty did manifestly confirme, the vse, veneration, and translation of holy reliques, aswel by the miraculous preseruation of his seruants body incorrupt, as also by the fragrant odour that issued out of it; for therby it euidently appeared that God of his diuine prouidence ordayned that the body should be taken vp, & translated in such sort as it was; for if it should haue still remained buryed, vnseene, and hidden (as Hylarion out of his humility desyred it should) these miracles had beene in vaine, and to no purpose; which were absurd and impious, to say of any worke of
God, and especially of any of his extraordinary and miraculous workes, which euer tend to his greater glory, and either to the edification, instruction, and benefit of his seruants, or els to the confusion, and punishment of his enemyes.

87. The third thing which may be gathered of this history, is not only that it was the custome of holy & deuout people at that tyme to watch whole nights in cōtinuall prayer at the tombes & monuments of holy mē deceased, but also that Almighty God did satisfy their deuotion, yea, & stir them thereto by frequent miracles, approuing thereby the honour that was done to his seruants, according to our Sauiours promise in the holy Scripture: Si quis mihi ministrauerit, honorificabit eum pater meus, if any man do serue me, my Father will honour him. Ioan. 12.

88. Lastly, by all this it appeareth euidently, that M. Collins hath a deplorable cōscience, that makes no scruple to dissemble such important proofes of the vse and veneration of holy reliques, as these are & to obiect such a trifle as heere he doth, out of the same place, which also rather fortifyeth our cause, then any way impugneth it, seing that it appeareth thereby, that the
Reliques of holy men, were at that tyme had in great veneration; for otherwayes, what should moue this holy man S. Hylari
• n, to feare, that he should be pickled vp in Reliques (as M. Collins prophanly speaketh) but that he knew it to be vsuall in the Church to reserue the Reliques of such as had the reputation of extraordinary sanctity, especially of those by whome Almighty God had done so many miracles, as he had done by him, albeit he for his part esteemed himselfe altogeather vnworthy, as well of the fauors, which he had receaued of Almighty God, as of the opinion which the world had conceaued of him. Thus much concerning S. Hylarion.

89. The like may be sayd of S. Antony, whose holy life was no lesse glorious in miracles then the former, in so much that he was held in his tyme for a miracle, and wonder of the world, as appeareth by the history of his life written by S. Athanasius; & albeit he also ordained to be buryed secretly, & charged his disciples that they should not let any man know the place of his buryall (in which respect it is doubtfull, as S. Hierome witnesseth, whether Hilarion obtayned of them to see it) yet it pleased God to reueale it about a hundred years after, in
the tyme of Iustinian the Emperour, wherby his reliques were found, digged vp, & translated to Alexandria, as testify Ado, Vsuardus, Sigebertus, Marianus Scotus, Crispinian, and S. Bede our Countreyman, who in his Martyrloge 16. Calend. Febr. sayth, that S. Antonyes body being found by diuine reuelation was brought to Alexandria, and buryed there in the Church of S. Iohn Baptist. So he. Loe then how Almighty God honoured the memory, and reliques of him, who whilest he liued desired they should not be honoured; God so disposing (as I haue signifyed before) for his owne greater glory, & the reward of his seruants humility, whereby it appeareth what a silly obiection M. Collins hath made against the veneration of holy reliques seeing it ser • eth for no other purpose, but to testify, & proue the humility of those holy Monks, and withall to shew his weakne • , & want of better arguments to impugne this most ancient custom of Gods Church, acknowledged, and practised by so many ancient, and hol Fathers, as you haue heard already, and confirmed by infinite miracles, yea and sufficiently witnessed, euen by those examples, & in those places of the Fathers, which he ha • h heere produced: what cōscience then hath he, or what honesty, who
seeketh to deceaue, and delude his Readers with a bare shew of the Authority of Fathers, when he himselfe seeth that they are flatly against him, euen in those places, which he alleadgeth.

90. And heerof I may add yet this further proofe that euen in this conclusion of his discourse wherein he promiseth, to end with S. Hierome, he abuseth him notably, not only in dissembling all that which witnesseth the honour done to the reliques of S. Hylarion, and the continuall miracles which Almighty God wrought thereby, but also in carping at him, and reprouing him sharply, thogh he doth not name him, but me, and other Catholiks; as he delt before in the like manner, with S. Augustine, as I obserued cap. 8. num. 37. & sequent.

91. For he chargeth vs heere with seeking the liuing amongst the dead, contrary, sayth he, to the commandment of God, because we professe to worship Christ in Reliques; and for the proofe therof he alleadgeth my Adioynder, saying: as you sticke not to triumph num. 25. In which number neuerthelesse, I do but only relate S. Hieromes discourse against Vigilantius, whom he confuteth notably by the practise, and custome of the whole Church, alleadging to that end two
examples of the solemn translation of holy reliques: the first of the reliques of S. Andrew, S. Luke, and S. Tymothy in tyme of Constantine the Great, and the other of the Reliques of Samuel the Prophet trāslated from Iudaea to Chalcedon in Thracia, carryed by Bishops most sumptuously and triumphantly in a golden vessel, and met, receaued, and accompanied by the people of all the churches by the way, sounding forth (sayth S. Hierom) the prayse of Christ with one voice all along as they went: whereupon S. Hierome asketh Vigilantius, whether he tooke Arcadius the Emperour (who caused this to be done) and al the Bishops which carryed those reliques, and all the people that accompanyed them, for fools, and sacrilegious persons; and finally he concludeth, deryding the folly of Vigilantius, saying viz. Adorabant Samuelem non Christum, cuius Samuel & Leuita & Propheta fuit, belike they adored Samuel and not Christ, whose Leuite, & Prophet Samuel was.

92. Thus far I cyted S. Hierome, and then I concluded, that he shewed therein the absurdity of Vigilantius, who did thinke that Christ was not adored in all this, but Samuel only; whereas all the reuerence and honor done by those Bishops to Samuel was
indeed (according to S. Hieromes discourse) done to Christ, whose Leuite and Prophet Samuel was; because (as S. Hierome also sayd before) the honor of the seruants redoundeth to their Lord; and this is all which I sayd num. 25. Whereupon M. Collins chargeth me, and other Catholiques to seeke the liuing amongst the dead, contrary to the commaundement of God; whereas you see euidently, that I doe but relate S. Hieromes discourse, who therefore is the man that sought the liuing amongst the dead, and not only he, but also those Bishops, who accompanyed the Reliques of Samuel, sounding forth (as S. Hierome sayth) the praise of Christ all the way as they went, & consequently honouring Christ in the Reliques of Samuel, which with M. Collins is to seeke the liuing amongst the dead, contrary to the commandement of God; whereby it appeareth what respect he beareth to S. Hierome, and to the ancient Fathers, when he can vpon any occasion taxe, or contradict them vnder hand, albeit he would haue his Readers belieue, that he honoureth them much, and teacheth no other doctrine, but that which is theirs, or most consonant thereunto.

93. Well then you haue now seene M. Collins his deepe discourse against holy
Reliques, being the very quintessence of his skill, drawne out of the limbecke of an hereticall brayne, and therefore sophisticated with so much fraud, as no man, that should not euidently see it (as you haue done) would belieue it of any man that hath the face, and reputation of an honest man, and much lesse of a man of his profession and quality.

div.head: My Lord of Winchester being charged in the Adioynder with inexcusable falsity in the manifest abuse of S. Augustine, is abandoned by his champion M. Collins: in whome also three notable frauds are discouered • ouching one sentence of the same holy Father; and that he hath shamefully belyed Cardinall Bellarmine Lastly the veneration, and translation of holy Reliques, and the custom to carry them in procession, is clearely proued out of S. Augustine. CHAP. XII.
div.p:
FOR as much as M. Collins hath alleadged S. Augustine to patronize his impugnation of holy Reliques, I will conclude this my reply with the relation of what I debated in my Adioynder with my
Lord of VVinchester, concerning certaine cleare testimonyes of S. Augustines beliefe & doctrine, touching holy reliques; & this I will do the rather, because by occasion therof I charged my Lord with a notable abuse of S. Augustin, & an inexcusable fraud which M. Collins was in reason, and honesty bound to defend, and therefore we will now see how well he hath performed it.

1. Thus then I sayd in my Adyoinder Chap. 9. num. 64. Wheras the Cardinall produceth the euident & cleere testimony of S. Augustine, to proue that many Miracles were done by the Reliques of S. Stephen in Affrick, M. Andrews wisheth the Cardinall to consider how be can well and handsomly reconcile Augustine with Augustine cōcerning those Miracles, and his reason is, because Augustine saith in an Epistle to his Clergie, and all the people of Hyppo, Nusquam hic in Africa, talia fieri se scire: he knew that such things were not don any wher in Africk, which I beseech thee good Reader to note, and thou shalt euidently see the good Conscience of M. Andrews, who abuseth S. Augustine notably two wayes; the one in making him seeme to contradict himselfe most manifestly, yea and to giue himselfe, as it were, the lye, witnessing in one place matters of
fact vpon his owne knowledge, (for so he testifieth those Miracles done by S. Stephens reliques,) and in another place affirming that he knew the same to be false, for so must it needes be, if he knewe that such thinges were not done any where in Africk. The other abuse is, in that he peruerteth the sense of S. Augustines Epistle, as it will easely appeare, if we consider the occasion why S. Augustine wrote the same; which therefore I think good heere to relate.

2. A scandalous quarrell being fallen out betwixt a Chaplaine of S. Augustine, and a yong man concerning an infamous calumnation raysed by the yong man against the Preist (whereof the truth could not be tried or knowne, because the matter depended wholly vpon their owne oathes, and testimonyes) S. Augustin aduised them to goe to Nola in Italy to the body of S. Faelix, where it pleased God ordinarily in like cases to discouer periuries, by the miraculous punishment of the periured person; & of this he thought good afterwards to giue account vnto his Clergie and People for their satisfaction, which he did by the Epistle that M. Andrews citeth, wherein discoursing, by the occasion of this matter, why Almighty God doth such Miracles
in some place, and not in others, he saith, Multis notissima est sanctitas loci &c. Many do verie well knowe the holynes of the place, where lyeth the bodie of Blessed Faelix of Nolae, whither I ordeyned them to go, because from thence I might more easely & truly vnderstād by letters whatsoeuer it should please God to manifest in either of them. So he; and then hauing added, that also in Millan a periured theefe was discouered miraculously at the Monuments of certaine Saints, and forced to restore that which he had stolne, he saith further thus, Numquid non Africa &c. Is not Aff • ick full of the bodies of holy Martyrs? & tamen nusquam hic scimus talia fieri &c. And neuerthelesse we know that such things (that is to say Miracls in this kind) are not don anywhere here in Africk. For euen as the Apostle sayth, that al holy men haue not the guifts of healing, so also he who diuideth things proper, or peculiar to euery one as it pleaseth him, would not haue these things to be done at all the memories or monuments of Saynts. Thus sayth S. Augustine.

3. Whereby I doubt not, but thou seest, good Reader, in what sense he denieth Miracles to haue byn done in Affrick, that is to say, such Miracles as were done at the body of S. Faelix, for the discouery and punishment of periury, & not such as he testifieth els where, to haue byn ordinarily
done at the Reliques of S. Stephen, wherof he recounteth such a multitude, with such asseueration of his owne knowledge therof, and publique testimony of an infinite number of witnesses, and such particuler relation of circumstances, tymes, and places, that a man must hould him for the most impudent lyar, that euer wrote, if they were not most true. Besides, that writing the same, as he did for the proofe of Christian Religion against Pagans, and Infidells, it cannot without extreme folly be imagined that such a learned, wise, and holy man, as he, would be so prodigall not only of his owne credit, and reputatiō, but also of the honour of Christiā Religiō, as to expose the same to the derision of the Paynims, by seking to confirme it by fables and lyes, which euery man in those parts (as well the Paynims themselues as others) might haue controlled, & would haue derided, if they had byn faigned.

4. Finally, these miracles of S. Stephen which M. Andrewes calleth here in question, are testified by S. Augustine in that worke which M. Andrews himselfe so much esteemeth els where, that alledging out of it a sentence which he thought might make for him, he calleth it Opus palmare de ciuitate
Dei, the principall or most excellent worke of Augustine of the Citty of God. And yet now he would faine disgrace it, or rather S. Augustin himselfe by the imputation of a contradiction, which he would the Reader should suppose to be betwixt it, and the foresaid Epistle of S. Augustine; wheras you see (and M. Andrews knoweth it in his owne conscience) that there is no contradiction in the world betwixt them, but that both of them do notably and clearly testify the ancient and venerable vse of holy Reliques, and the miraculous assistance, and helpe that God giueth to his faithfull people thereby, and by the praiers and Reliques of his holy Martyrs & Saints. So that truly a man may wonder at the impudency, and seared Conscience of M. Andrews, who seeketh to delude his Reader with such a fraudulent and inexcusable abuse of this holy Father.

5. Thus sayd I in my Adioynder, wherein I doubt not, but thou seest, good Reader, matter right worthy to be answered by M. Collins for the defence of my Lord of VVinchester, whom I charged deeply with egregious fraud, and abuse of S. Augustine. Neuerthelesse I may well say, that M. Collins obmutuit, is as dumbe as a Dogge, for he
sayth not one word to it, but abandoneth his Lordship quite, leauing him to answer for himselfe, as he hath done before diuers tymes. And whereas my discourse in my Adioynder, contayned also important matter for the proofe of the vse, and veneration of holy reliques (by reason of S. Augustines vndoubted testimony of notable miracles done as well at the body of S. Faelix in Nola, and the monuments of certaine Saints in Millan as also at the reliques of S. Stephen in Afrike) M. Collins is no lesse silent thereto, then to what I obiected to my Lord, omitting all mention of either of both in this place, I meane, in his ninth Chapter. But afterwards in his answere to my tenth Chapter (where I had occasion to alleadge againe the same testimony of Saint Augustine) he thought good to say somewhat thereto, though he doth it with so grosse, and palpable fraud, that I cannot omit to discou • r it, and as I hope shall leaue him speachles. Thus then he fayth pag. 447. lin. 29.

6. S. Augustine, in his whole Chapter de ciuitate Dei l. 22. cap. 8. neuer stands for miracles, to proue new doctrines b • , but only the old (as was decla • ed before) • nd therefore you shall gayne nothing from
thence, who alleadge new miracles to authorize new articles, as praying to Saints, and worshiping of reliques, and such like conceipts, though we should subscribe to all which S. Augustine reports, with no lesse promptnes then your selues, that is more then he may be wel thought to do. For one tyme he confesseth of the aforesayd wonders, that, Non sunt tanta autoritate commendata &c. They are not of such authority, as straight wayes to be belieued, though betweene one faythfull man, and another. Another tyme he sayes: That as soone as they are told they are cleane forgotten, & no body relates them to them that did not heare them, as they were rehearsed de libello, nor no body remembers them any long tyme himselfe. His wordes are: Nec (admodum) innotescunt, neque vt non excidant animo, quasi glarea memoriae crebra lectione tundūtur: wheras if they were diuine miracles, why should they not be diuulged throughout the whole world, euen wheresoeuer the Ghospell is preached, as our Sauiour sayd of the Charity of that good woman that annoynted his feet? Againe: Semel hoc audiunt qui adsunt, plures{que} non adsunt, vt nec illi qui affuerunt post aliquot dies mente retineant, & vix quisquam reperiatur illorum, qui ei quem non affuisse cognouerit, iudicet quod audiuit.

7. Thus farre doth M. Collins alleadge
S. Augustine his text, hoping to perswade his Reader therby, that S. Augustine did not hold those miracles which he related, to be diuine miracles, not to be of such authority as to deserue to be diuulged throughout the world, as diuine miracles ought to be. But to the end that thou mayst see good Reader, how shamfully he seeketh to abuse thee, peruerting S. Augustine his sense cleane contrary to his meaning, thou shalt vnderstand, that S. Augustine throughout all that worthy work of his de ciuitate Dei, wryteth purposely against the Paymins, and hauing vrged in the 22. booke, the conuersion of the world to the fayth of Christ by miracles, he obiecteth against himself in behalfe of the Paynins thus: Cur inquiunt, nunc illa miracula quae praedicatis facta esse, non fiunt? why are not those miracles done now which you say were then done? Wher • o he answereth, that he might say that those miracles were then necessary before the world did beleiue, to the end that it might beleiue, and that whosoeuer would seeke for new miracles to belieue in Christ, now when the whole world belieueth, he is to be held for a prodigious wonder.

8. But, sayth he, The Paynims do say this, for no other cause, but because they do not belieue that
those miracles were then done; thus fayth S. Augustine, and thereupon he vrgeth the cred it, and authority of the holy Scriptures, receaued and belieued throughout the Christian world, whereby those miracles, testifying the diuinity of Christ, are not only published, but also belieued, & authorized euery where: and then comming to that which M. Collins obiecteth, he sayth first thus: Nam etiam nunc fiunt miracula in eius nomine &c. For miracles are also done now in his name, either by his Sacraments, or by the prayers or memoryes of his Saints, but they are not so cleare and famous, as to be published with as great glory as the other; for the Canon of the holy Scripture, which was to be euery where diuulged, doth make them to be read euerywhere, and to be fixed in the memory of all people, but these miracles which are now done are skant knowne by all the Citty or place wher they were done. For it so falleth out very often, that they are knowne but to a few, the rest being ignorant of them, especially if the Citty be great, and when they are tould elswhere to others, the authority which recommendeth them is not so great, that they are fully belieued without doubt, or difficulty, albeit they be related by faythfull Christians one to another. Thus sayth S. Augustine.

9. Now then this being the first part of that which M. Collins alleadgeth (but lamely
as you haue seene) I remit it to any mans iudgment, whether S. Augustine doe heerby deny, either that the miracls wherof he spake, were diuine miracles, or that they ought to be published euery where; seeing all that he sayth is in substance this; that the miracles since Christs tyme, & the Apostles (not testifyed in the holy Scripture) neither are, nor can be so generally knowne, and belieued as those which are mentioned in the Scriptures, because these later miracles, are not knowne, and belieued, but in particuler places, neyther yet so fully belieued of all the Christians that are in those places, or heare of them, as those other which the Scripture relateth, because the Scripture being generally receaued, & belieued euery where as infallibly true, giueth also vndoubted credit, and authority euery where to the miracles which are witnessed, and related therein.

10. How then doth it follow heerō that these later miracles are not diuine miracles? For he that should say so, must also say that Almighty God neuer did miracle since the Apostles tyme, because later miracles are not related in Scripture. But S. Augustine contradicteth this expresly, for hauing recounted a great number of miracles done at
the reliques of S. Stephen he concludeth thus: Fiunt ergo etiam nunc multa miracula, eodem Deo faciente, per quos vult, & quemadmodum vult, qui & illa, quae legimus fecit: Therefore there are now also miracles done, the same God doing them, by whome he will, and as he will, who also did those which we read (in the Scripture.) Thus sayth S. Augustine, whereby it is euident that he acknowledgeth those miracles which he had related to be diuine miracles, no lesse then those which are mentioned in the Scripture, seeing that they were wrought, as he sayth, by the same God who wrought the other.

11. What extreme impudency then is this in M. Collins to inferre vpon S. Augustines words that the miracles recounted by him were not diuine miracles, when S. Augustine flatly affirmeth that they were? Wherein it is also to be noted that those wordes of S. Augustine, wherein he affirmed it, went immediatly before those, wherupon M. Collins inferreth the contrary. For S. Augustine hauing sayd, that many miracles are don also now by Almighty God, addeth: Sed nec ista similiter innotescunt &c. which later wordes, M. Collins layeth downe, omitting the former, & then glosseth the later thus: VVheras (sayth he) if these were diuine miracles, why should
they not be diuulged throughout the world &c. signifying that the later miracles (whereof S. Augustine speaketh) were not diuulged ouer all the world, because they were not diuine miracles; whereas neuerthelesse S. Augustine sayd immediatly before, that they were done by Almighty God, who did those other also which were read in holy Scripture, so as he only maketh this difference betwixt the one, and the other, that those in the Scripture, are published, diuulged, & belieued, euery where by all Christian people, & the other are not so diuulged, and belieued; but only knowne and belieued in certaine places, and by particuler persons, though they be diuine miracles no lesse then the former.

12. Furthermore, it is to be obserued for the further discouery of his fraud heerin, that he not only dissembleth the beginning of the sentence (which maketh flatly against him) but also changeth in the later part (which he alleadgeth) an important, & significant word which sheweth the dependance of that which he cyteth vpon the former part, which he concealeth. For whereas S. Augustine speaking of the later miracles, sayth: Nec ista similiter innotescunt, M. Collins alleadgeth it, Nec ista admodum innotescunt,
wherin this difference is to be noted, that the word simliter doth import a comparison of the later miracles, with other which he hath mentioned before, that is to say, with miracles testifyed by holy Scripture; and therfore hauing sayd that God doth miracles now, Qui & illa quae legiimus fecit; who did all those which we read in Scripture, he addeth presently, Sed nec ista similiter innotescunt &c. But these (later miracles) are not diuulged (or generally knowne) in like manner as the other &c.

13. This then being the true sense, & meaning of S. Augustine, it is euident that in this one sentence of his, there may be noted three notable fraudes of M. Collins. The first, his lame cytation of it, omitting the first part of the sentence, whereupon the later dependeth. The second, the change of similiter into admodum in the later part, because similiter might discouer the depēdance of the later part vpō the former. The third (which is one of the notablest falsityes that euer I saw) his false inference vpon the second part, flatte contrary to the expresse wordes of the former, which therefore he wittingly, and purposely concealed: so as it is hard to say, whether my Lord of VVinchester, or M. Collins, haue more abused S. Augustine
about the reliques of S. Stephen. My Lord vpon pretence of an Epistle of S. Augustines, which he most willfully peruerteth, calleth in question, whether there were euer any such miracles done or no, notwithstanding S. Augustine his euident testimony therof vpon his owne knowledg; M. Collins though he will not deny that such miracles were done, yet he laboureth to perswade his Reader, that S. Augustine did not make any great accompt of them, especially as of diuine miracles: & to this purpose he hath egregiously peruerted as you see, both S. Augustines text, and meaning, contrary to his expresse words, in so much that both my Lord and his Champion do make S. Augustine contradict himselfe expresly, and deny that which he constantly affirmeth.

14. Neuertheles M. Collins not content with this, addeth another fraud touching the same point, no lesse remarkable then the former: for whereas I vrged in my Adioynder that these miracles recounted by S. Augustine, were a manifest confirmation of the vse and veneration of holy Reliques, he answereth pag. 441. lin. 21. that, Non sequitur consequentia à miraculis ad cultum, VVitnes, sayth he, Bellarmine himselfe, lib. 4. cap. 14.
de notis Ecclesiae. And this M. Collins affirmeth afterwardes againe pag. 449. lin. 7. saying thus: This is starke false that Miracls done at Saints bodyes infer the honour which you challeng to them, by any probable consequence, as Bellarmine denyes about Hieremyes body, and was quoted to you a little before out of his booke de notis Ecclesiae. Thus sayth M. Collins.

15. But Bellarmine in that Chapter which he quoteth hath no such thing, but rather the contrary; for he teacheth and proueth there, that miracles are not only necessary, but also sufficient to proue a new fayth; and amongst the obiections of our aduersaryes, he hath this (out of Caluins preface to his Institutions, and the Magdeburgenses) that true miracles do confirme the Ghospell (Marci vltimo) and that these miracles of ours doe ouerthrow it, and confirme Idolatry, that is (say they) the worship of reliques, & Images, the inuocation of Saints, Masse &c. So as according to Bellarmine, our Aduersayes themselues doe graunt that the consequence is good, à miraculis ad cultum.

16. For if true miracles confirme the Ghospell, then consequently they do confirme the true worship of God, which is taught, and deliuered by the Ghospel; and
conforme to this, our Aduersaryes do also affirme that our miracles (which they will needs haue to be false miracles) do confirm Idolatry, that is (say they) the worshippe of Saints, and Reliques &c. and therefore according to their opinion we may well say, that as false miracles doe confirme false worship, so true miracles do confirme true worship; whereupon it also followeth, that if the miracles which are done by reliques, can be proued to be true miracles, the worship of reliques is a true, & lawfull worship, and not Idolatry. So as it appeareth euen in that Chapter of Cardinall Bellarmine, cyted by M. Collins, that our Aduersaryes themselues do graunt in their obiection, that the consequence is good, à miraculis ad cultum; and the Cardinall doth not deny it in the solution, but only sayth in answere of the obiection thus: Sed, inquiunt, ista miracula euertunt Euangelium. Respondeo, verum est, sed Caluini, non Christi: vel probent isti quod tam audacter affirmant. But they say that those miracles (of ours) do ouerthrow the Ghospell. I answere, it is true, but the Ghospell of Caluin, and not of Christ, or els let them proue that which they so boldly affirme.

17. Thus sayth the Cardinall, and
then proceedeth to the confutation of foure arguments of theirs, whereby they endeauour to proue that miracles do not facere certam fidem, amongst the which their third argument is, that miracles were done in tymes past at the Prophet Hieremyes tombe, by the illusion of the Diuell, which they say, was manifest, because those miracles were don to the benefite of those, who did worship Hieremy with sacrifices and diuine honour, as a God; whereto the Cardinall answereth thus: Ad tertium, sayth he, dico, mendaciū esse Caluini &c. To the third, I say, that it is a lye of Caluin, that the people did worship Hieremy, with sacrifices, and diuine honours, for he bringeth no witnes of it, but only hath in his margent Hieronymus praefatione in Hieremiam. But neither in the presace of Hierome to the Prophet Hieremy whome he translated, neither in his preface to the Commentaryes of Hieremy, there is any mention at all of this history: moreouer there is another little Preface prefixed before the Prophet Hieremy, in the Bibles set forth by Benedictus, whereat Caluin aymed, as it seemeth, but that preface is not Hieromes, neither is there any mention therein of sacrifices, or diuine honour, but only that miracles were done at his sepulcher. Finally Epiphanius and Isidore, in the life of Hieremy, do say indeed that miracles were done, but of sacrifices,
or diuyne honour done vnto him, they say nothing. Thus sayth the Cardinall, and this is all he sayth to that obiection, or concerning miracles done at Hieremyes body.

18. Now then; how doth the Cardinall deny heere, the consequence à miraculis ad cultum? Is there any one word therein, which may be wrested to any such sense? Wherin al we see is, that Caluin is taken tardy, and charged with a manifest lye; but of the Cardinalls denyall of that consequence, not so much as one sillable, either there, or in all that Chapter, wherein his speciall drift is, to proue that new miracles are sufficient to confirme, and proue any point of fayth not belieued, or taught before, which the Cardinall layeth for a foūdation and ground in the very beginning of the Chapter: and vpon this ground, & the reason which he giueth to proue the same, it followeth directly that the consequence is good, à miraculis ad cultum: for thus argueth the Cardinall: Vera miracula (sayth he) non possunt fieri, nisi Dei virtute &c. True miracles cannot be done, but by the power of God, and therefore they are called in Scripture the testimonyes of God, so as that which is confirmed by miracle, is confirmed by Gods testimony: but God cannot be witnes of a lye; therefore that which is confirmed
by a miracle, must needs be true.

19. Thus sayth the Cardinall, wherupon it must needes follow also, that if the worship of Saints Reliques, or Images be confirmed by a true miracle, it must needes be a true, and lawfull worship; seeing then this directly followeth vpon the Cardinals groundes, discourse, and doctrine in that Chapter, M. Collins hath extremely abused, and belyed him, in making him a witnesse of the contrary, viz. that, Non sequitur consequentia à miraculis ad cultum.

20. Moreouer the Cardinall is so farre from denying that consequence, that in his second Booke De beatitudine Sanctorum c. 3 §. Quartò probatur, he proueth directly the veneratiō, & worship of holy reliques, by the miracles done at them: Quae miracula (sayth he) certè non fierent, si Deo cultus reliquiarum non placeret, which miracles would not be don, if the worship of reliques did not please God, whereof he alleadgeth many examples out of S. Epiphanius in vita Isaiae, Ezechielis, Hieremiae. S. Basil. orat. in Mamantem. S. Gregory Nazianzen orat. in Cyprianum. S. Chrysostome in lib. contra Gent. Palladius in historia lauriaca c. 26. S. Ambrose serm. de SS. Geruasio & Protasio. S. Hierome contra Vigilantium. S. Augustine lib. 22. de ciuitate Dei. cap. 8.

21. And hereto the Cardinall addeth also a further proof thereof (§. Quintò probatur) by miracles which haue often beene seene euen in the dead bodyes of Saints, Per quae, sayth he, Deus apertissimè nos ad eorum venerationem inuitare videtur, by the which God doth manifestly seeme to inuite vs to the worship or veneration of them; and heerof he also alleadgeth diuers notable examples, as out of S. Chrysostome in his sermon of the SS. Iuuentius & Maximus, whose faces he saith, appeared resplendant after their death. Also S. Hierome affirmeth of S.
