Hilarion, that his body was found entyre after ten moneths, and so fragrant that it might seem to be anoynnted with sweet oyntments. S. Augustine witnesseth lib. 9. Confess. cap. 7. that the bodyes of SS. Geruase and Protase, were found whole and vncorrupt. Sulpitius in his Epistle to Bassula testifyed that the body of S. Martyn was after his death more like a glorifyed body, then the body of a dead man. S. Bonauenture affirmeth the like of the body of Saint Francis. Lastly the Cardinall concludeth with the euident and dayly experience of the oyle which doth miraculously distill from the body of S. Andrew the Apostle; all which the Cardinall alleadgeth to proue
that holy reliques are to be worshipped. This then being so, how shameles is Collins, who calleth the Cardinall to witnes that there is no consequence à miraculis ad cultum?

22. But to returne to S. Augustines testimony concerning the miracles done at S. Stephen reliques, you haue seene it proued euidētly, how notoriously false it is which M. Collins hath gathered out of him, to wit, that he did not esteeme the said miracles to be diuine miracles; when neuertheles he sayth, that they were don by the same God who did the miracles which are testified in holy scripture; whereupon it followeth that the honour done to those reliques in the solemne translation, and circumgestation of them (to vse stil M. Collins his phrase) was gratefull to Almighty God, who did miraculously comfort, and releiue those who with deuotion, did concurre, and cooperate thereto, or had recourse to them; whereby the sick recouered their health, the blynd their sight, and the dead their life; in so much that S. Augustine giueth testimony of fiue or sixe seuerall dead persons reuyued, partly by the application of somwhat that had but only touched the holy reliques, and partly by the oyle of the lampe
that burned before them, which therfore S. Augustine calleth oleum Martyris, the oyle of the Martyr.

23. And this I mention the rather, because M. Collins doth formalyze himselfe very seriously against the custome that thē was to apply to diseased persons the flowers that had touched the reliques of Saints; and this he doth by the occasion of a miracle related by me in my Adioynder out of S. Augustine de ciuitate Dei, vbi supra, where he testifyeth that a blynde woman was restored to her sight, by applying to her eyes certaine flowers that had touched the holy reliques of S. Stephen; which M. Collins laboureth to proue to haue beene no good custome, euen by the authority of S. Augustine himselfe, which I beseech thee, good Reader, wel to note, and the notable foolery and fraud withal of this idle fellow. Thus then he sayth pag. 448. lin. 15. In the 8. booke, sayth he, of the aforesaid worke cap. 27. he (S. Augustine) allowes not of meates to be set vpon Martyrs tombes, for obteyning of blessing; a Christianis melioribus, sayth he, hoc non fit, he denyes not but it is done, but he sayes the better sort of Christians do it not, much lesse flowers to be layd vpon their bodyes, and taken of agayne, with
hope of vertue to proceed from them in application to sicke folkes; for of sanctifying meates to necessary vse, wee read in the Apostle (and the martyrs might concurre to it if they were Conscious) but of the flowers no where, nor to such purpose, especially from the dead. The Christians then might do this in S. Augustines tyme, but not the better sort of Christians as he most aduisedly speakes, not meliores Christiani, whom you list not to imitate, but choose the worser part, and clout a religion out of fond Customes, which the iudicious of those tymes neyther allowed then, & much lesse would now.

24. Thus iangleth this cozening Companion, who can say nothing without some fraud, as heer you see. He telleth you of flowers layd vpon the dead bodyes of Saints, and applyed to sick folkes in S. Augustines tyme, but what effects followed it, or with what circumstances, or to what purpose S. Augustine speakes of it, he sayth not one word, and therefore he more boldly argueth agaynst it, out of another place of S. Augustine, as against a custome not vsed by the better sort of Christians, nor approued by S. Augustine himselfe, or by the iudicious of those tymes. Whereas S. Augustine
speaketh not of flowers otherwaies, but only in relating a notable miracle done by Almighty God vpon a blynd woman, who was restored to her sight, by applying to her eyes the flowers that had touched the holy reliques of S. Stephen; wherupon it should follow (according to M. Collins his assertion) that if it were a bad custome to vse flowers to that purpose, God did by a miracle approue a bad custome, and do a singuler benefit to one of the worser sort of Christians, that vsed the same; yea and it would followe also that S. Augustin; wryting against the Paynims (as he did in that book and Chapter) fortyfied and confirmed our Christian religion by bad customes not vsed amongst the better sort of Christians, and disallowed also by himself; for so will M. Collins haue you to suppose.

25, But who would not detest the fraud, and laugh at the folly of this absurd fellow? who maketh S. Augustine, to contradict himself, vpon no better a ground, then S. Augustins dislike of an other custome, not vsed by the better sort of Christians; which yet proueth no more against this custome impugned by M. Collins, thē against any other thing, that he, or any body els
shall list to reiect for a bad custome. For what good argument can M. Collins make out of that place of S. Augustine, against the forsayd application of flowers? Will he argue thus? S. Augustine disallowed the custome of setting meat vpon Martyrs Tombs to be blessed, Ergo, he disalowed the custom of applying to the sicke the flowers that had touched the Reliques of Saints? Auditum admissi risum teneatis amici! Besides that, the difference of these two customes was such in S. Augustines opinion, that he reiecteth the one in expresse words, and approueth the other clearely inough, in that he alleadgeth it against the Paynims, to proue the continuance of diuine miracles, relating that miracle done vpon the blynd woman, by the meanes of those flowers.

26. And to the same purpose he also recounteth afterwardes another notable miracle done in like manner by flowers, vpon a sicke Paynim, who being in great danger of death, and earnestly solicited by his sonne in law, and daughter (who were Christians) to imbrace the Christian fayth, most obstinatly resisted, vntill his sonne-in law (after most feruent prayer made at the Reliques of S. Stephen) tooke some of the flowers which were vpon the Altar, and at
night conueyed them vnder the sicke mans head; who sleeping after a whyle, was so moued in his sleep to be a Christian, that he cryed out before morning to be baptized, and after his Baptisme repeated continually the last wordes of S. Stephen, Act. 7. viz. Christe accipe spiritum meum (albeit he had neuer heard them related) in so much that they were also his last wordes; for he dyed shortly after of the same sicknes.

27. Thus doth S. Augustine recount this miracle done also by flowers, taken only from the altar wher S. Stephens reliques were kept; and now were it not absurd & ridiculous to imagine that he disliked this vse of those flowers, wherby God wroght so great a miracle? Or that he esteemed the pious & godly sonne-in-law of that Paynime, for a Christian of the worser sort, because he vsed those flowers to that purpose? What then shal we say of other things which S. Augustine reporteth to haue beene in like sort ap • l • ed to sicke, yea & to dead persons with like miraculous effects, as clo •••• , and garments which had touched the sayd reliques, and were applyed to dead •• dyes, • hereby three were reuiued, and 〈◊〉
•••• er a • so reuiued by the oyle of the Mar
••• (as I haue signified before) shall we say
that they were also Christians of the worser sort that applyed the same? Or that S. Augustine did also dislike those actions, because he disliked the setting of meats vpon Martyrs tombs? And if those things might be so vsed, why not flowers? For clothes, and garments haue no more warrant, priuiledge, or vertue for that purpose, then flowers haue; so as by M. Collins his graue censure, the greatest miracles, that S. Augustine relateth (as the reuyuing of the dead, which surpassed the Diuels power, & therfore must needs be diuine miracles) were done by bad customes, that is to say, by vnlawfull meanes, and those which vsed thē were Christians of the worser sort, euen in S. Augustines opinion, though he recount the same for the confusion of the Paynims, and for the honour and proofe of the Christian religion.

28. Loe then what an absurd fellow I haue to deale withall, and also how false & fraudulent he is, who not only dissembleth my whole text, but also shamefully peruerteth S. Augustines meaning, the better to couer his owne imposture. But to draw to an end, and to conclude with somwhat more concerning the translation, and circumgestation of holy reliques (which M.
Collins so much disliketh) the vse and practise of both is euident inough, euen in those examples alleadged by me in my Adioynder out of that booke, and chapter of S. Augustine, which M. Collins hath so censured, mangled, and martyred, as you haue seene.

29. And first, for the circumgestation of reliques, the practise of it is manifest in two examples related by S. Augustine in the place aforesayd: the one of Lucillus a Bishop who was cured of a Fistula, carrying a certaine relique of S. Stephen in procession: populo, sayth S. Augustine, praecedente, & subsequente, the people going some before, and some after; and the other example is of another Bishop called Proiectus, who carryed sacra pignora (so S. Augustine calleth the holy reliques of S. Stephen) at what tyme the blind woman (of whome I haue spoken amply before) was restored to her sight by the flowers which had touched those holy reliques, so as it cannot be denyed, but that the reliks of S. Stephen, were circumgested or (by M. Collins his leaue) carryed in processiō, euen by the Bishops themselues, accompanyed with the people for the greater honour of them, which also Almighty God approued by manifest miracles.

30. And as for the translation of reliques, it is as cleare as the Sunne, that those reliques, whereby all those miracles were done in Africke, were translated thither; for S. Stephen was not martyred in Africke, but at Hierusalem; besides that, there is sufficient testimony in approued Authours of the tyme and occasion of their translation, as that Orosius being sent by S. Augustine to S. Hierome, who then resided at Hierusalem to conferre with him concerning the origen or beginning of the soule of man, was the first that brought into the West parts, Reliquias B. Stephani Protomartyris tunc nuper inuētas, the reliques of B. Stephen the first Martyr, which had byn then latly found. So sayth Gennadius in his booke de viris illustribus c. 39. who liued at the same tyme, which was in the raigne of the Emperours Honorius and Theodosius; for then were the holy bodyes of S. Stephen, S. Nicodemus, and S. Gamaliel found by a Priest called Lucianus, to whome it pleased God to reueale the same by an apparition of S. Gamaliel, as may be seene in the history thereof written at lardge by Baronius Anno Domini 415. where also it is related what notable miracles were done, not only in the finding of them, & in translating them to a Church in Hierusalem vpō
the mount Sion, but also in the translation of those which Orosius carryed to Afri • ke, who passing by the Iland called Minorica, was forced to stay there some dayes, in which time so many miracls were wroght there by them, that 540. Iewes were conuerted to the Christian fayth; and af • erwards when those reliques were brought into Africke, and distributed there amongst the Bishops (of whome S. Augustine was one) the miracles were so many, and so cōtinuall, that S. Augustine hauing recounted a great number of them in the aforesayd Chapter of his 22. Booke de ciuitate Dei, lamenteth that he hath not tyme to write all that he knew, and therefore craueth pardon of his Reader, yeilding this reason.

31. Si enim, sayth he, miracula sanitatum, vt alia taceam &c. For if I would now write the miracles of cures, and healing of diseases (to omit others) which haue beene done by this Martyr (that is to say, most glorious Stephen) in the Colony of Calama, and in ours; very many bookes were to be written, and yet all could not be gathered, but those only, which haue beene set downe in little bookes, or registers, to be read to the people: for when we saw the signes of diuin vertues (that is to say the miracles) like vnto the ould, to be so frequently done in our tyme, we thought good to ordayne, that they should be
registred, and read, to the end that they might be remembred, and come to the knowledge of many. It is not yet two yeares, since this memory began to be celebrated heere at Hyppo, and albeit the registers, which haue beene made of many of the miracles that haue beene wrought, haue not beene giuen vp (wherof I am most assured) yet those miracles which haue beene written, and giuen vp, do arriue almost to the number of 70. now when I write this; and at Calama, where the memory began before we had it heere, the number is incomparably greater; also at Vzalis (which is a Colony neere to Vtica) I know many notable thinges haue beene done by the same Martyr, but the custome of registring them, is not, or rather hath not beene vsed there; but now perhaps it is begun there.

32. Thus sayth S. Augustine, and then recounteth a notable miracle done lately before (when he himselfe was there) vpon a noble woman called Petronia, which he sayth he caused her to register: and when he hath related the sayd miracle, he concludeth after a few lines, with that which M. Collins had no li • t to see, and I haue therfore layd downe before, & now will repeate it againe for his greater confusion: Fiunt ergo, sayth S. Augustine, etiam nunc multa miracula eodem Deo faciente &c. Therefore now also many miracles are done, the same God doing them, who
did those which we read (in the Scripture:) but these neither are diuulged, and made knowne alike (as the others are) neither are they with often reading so beaten into the memory of men, that they be not forgotten &c.

33. Thus farre I haue thought good to lay downe S. Augustine his wordes, wherein I wish these things to be noted; first, that S. Augustine acknowledgeth innumerable miracles to haue beene done by the reliques of S. Stephen; the second, that they were diuyne miracles, and esteemed, and declared for such by S. Augustine: and that therefore M. Collins hath abused, and belyed him notably in denying the same, and cyting him lamely and corruptly, to make good his owne fiction, as you haue seene before. Thirdly that the custome of translating, and carrying reliques with solemnity was not only vsuall in the Church in S. Augustines tyme, but also grateful to Almighty God, who confirmed the same with infinite miracles; so as this testimony of S. August. touching holy reliques, giuen by him most seriously, and sincerely vpon his owne knowledge, for the proof of Christian religiō, might suffice alone, though we had no other, to proue the vse, veneration, translation, and circumgestation
of reliques to be not only lawful, but also most acceptable to almighty God, and therefore, both my Lord of VVinchester, and M. Collins had as much reason, as men could haue for so bad a matter, to seeke to diminish the credit, and authority of it, as you see they haue laboured to do; thogh with so manifest, and inexcusable fraudes, that they haue therby notably discouered, aswell their owne bad consciences, as the weakenes of their cause.

34. But he that list to see more ample proofes for the vse and veneration of holy reliques, let him take paynes to read Cardinall Bellarmines 2. booke de Beatitudine Sanctorum, wherin he treateth expresly of the reliques of Saints, and I doubt not but he will rest satisfied for that matter. For my intention was not to treat this cōtrouersy, further then the discouery of M. Collins his fraudulent dealing therein, should giue me iust occasion; albeit I doubt not, but that which I haue had occasion to treate, and debate with him concerning the same, may suffice to satisfy any reasonable man. And therefore hauing now sufficiently performed, what at first I intended (which was to discouer some part of M. Collins his egregious fraudes, in defence of my Lord of
VVinchester, to shew thereby that he deserueth neither thankes of my Lord, nor answere frō me) I will now make an end, albeit there remaine yet behind, so many more of like quality, that truely I am amazed to see the multitude, and enormity of them, as I will make it most cleare, and euident heereafter, if this do not put him to silence, as I hope it will; for such is the force of the truth, which I defend, and so euident are his frauds, & falsityes which I haue discouered, that I doubt not, but as he hath had the power to open my mouth, with his EPPHATA, so I shal haue much more power to stop his, with OBMVTESCE.

div.head: THE CONCLVSION TO THE VNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE.
div.p:
NOvv that I haue discouered vnto you some part of M. Collins his fraudes (I say some part, for so it is in deed, and but a smal part in respect of the rest, which remayne yet vntoucht,) I leaue to you to consider the enormity thereof, and what might moue him to such a desperat resolution to venter the losse of his reputation for euer, for a little flash of vayn glory which he might hope to gayn with the common sort, for a short tyme, vntill his cosenage should be detected; or whether
he was so greedy of the temporall reward, which he expected of his maiesty, and my Lord of VVinchester, as to purchase it with eternall damnation due to his fraudulent impiety, or impious fraud, such as the like (or at least greater) hath not been seene in any writter, that hath made profession of the christian faith: Neuertheles if the infamy or hurt that may ensue thereof, did only touch, or concern himselfe, it lesse imported, and might be the better disgested, and dissembled by you; but seeing that he is a publique member of your Vniuersity, & that there is such a simpathy, and communion betwixt euery member, & the whole body, that si quid patitur vnum membrum (as the Apostle saith) compatiuntur omnia membra, 1. cor. 12. I make no doubt but that you of your wisdomes will consider that the blame and guilt of his offence, may redound to you all, except you seeke to free your selues from the participation thereof; and that therefore you will think it conuenient to execute my sentence of Obmutesce vpon him, by putting him to perpetual silence both of tongue & pen, whereby it may appeare to the world, that his infamous booke printed by the publique printer of your Vniuersity, was not published
with your warrant, or approbation, but by surreption, and his owne priuate authority; for so shall you deliuer yourselues from all participation, not only of his disgrace, but also of the punishment due to him, by Gods iustice, which otherwayes may some way extend it selfe also to you for your conniuency with him.

For I am sure you cannot be ignorant how necessary is the prayer of the Royall Prophet, Psal. 5. Ab occultis meis munda me, & ab alienis parce seruo tuo, seeing that Almighty God doth many tymes seuerely punish whole cōmunityes for priuate mens faults, when they are permitted and dissembled in the delinquents. When Achan (Iosue 7.) concealed, and hid part of the spoile of Iericho, contrary to the Commaundement of Almighty God, his fault was imputed to the whole army of Iosue, and punished in them vntill the offendour was found out, & stone • to death: Peccauit Israel, sayth Almighty God, & praeuaricatus est pactum &c. when neuertheles one man (to wit Achan) had committed the offence; and therfore Almighty God sayd further vnto them: Non ero vltra vobiscum donec conteratis eum qui huius sceleris reus est. And when iustice was executed vpon him, auersus est (sayth the Scripture) furor Domini
abeis: now then if this secret offence of a priuate person was by Gods iustice imputed to al the children of Israel, and punished in them all, because the delinquent was not chastised; what shall we thinke of the offence of a publicke person? Yea of an offence far more heynous then that of Achan was, which being considered in it selfe (& not as it was then extraordinarily forbidbidden by Almighty God) was an indifferent, & a lawfull action; wheras all falshood & fraud is alwayes of it selfe so detestable, & abominable to God & man, that the Psalmist worthily coopleth the deceitful mā, with the blood-sucker, saving Psal. 5. Virum sanguinū & dolosum abominabitur Dominus. And what fraud or deceyt can be comparable to that which is practised in matter of religion, whereby not only God is dishonored, but also mens soules are endangered, or drawne to eternalll perdition? And put the case, that M. Collins had vsed this fraud only to teach a true doctrin (as his freinds may say perhaps to excuse him) yet it were neuertheles inexcusable; seeing it is euident that all falsity, is of it self so contrary to almighty God (who is ipsa veritas) that it can neuer be lawfully practised, in so much that an officious lye is not
to be made to saue the world, or with neuer so great pretense of Gods honour, or seruice, as Iob signifyed, when he said, cap. 13. Nunquid Deus indiget mendacio vestro, vt pro illo loquamini dolos? but now the case is farre otherwayes with M. Collins, who hath wittingly and wilfully, falsified, corrupted, & wrested the fathers against the light of his own conscience, to establishe an erroneous, and false doctrine, wholy opposit, and contrary to theyrs, (as you haue euidently seene) and all this to the extreme danger of innumerable soules. Wherupon I conclude, that it behoueth you to consider of the weight of this cryme, and to seeke to expiate the same by some meanes, least Almighty God may say to you, with farre greater reason, then he said to the children of Israel for Achans offence, Non ero vobiscum donec conteratis eum qui huius sceleris reus est; which neuerthelesse, I say not, I assure you, with desire that he should be otherwise chastised, then to be humbled, and made to know himselfe, and his errours for the saluation of his soule, that is to say, vt conuertatur & viuat, that being truly penitent, and repentant, he may liue not only here in the seruice of God many
yeares, but also hereafter with Almighty God eternally. And this, in good truth, 〈◊〉 all the hurt I wish him, notwithstanding the hoat bickering and conflict that hath passed betwixt vs.

div.head: AN APPENDIX TOVCHING a place of S. Ephraem, alleadged by my Lo. of Winchester, against Prayer to Saints, debated with M. Collins before in the 7. Chap. num. 50. & sequent.
div.p: VVHERAS M. Collins hath affirmed that my Lord alledged it out of a Manuscript which his Lordship hath to shew, and that the sayd Manuscript was printed at Rome by Dominicus Basa, in the year of our Lord 1584. & is entituled the Diurnall of the Maronits, I haue thought good for the better satisfaction of the learned, to cause the Arabicall text of S. Ephraem, as it is in the sayd Diurnall, to be printed there, togeathe • with the explication thereof in Latin letters, and tho Latin translation thereof word for word, wherein I wish these thinges to be obserued.

1. First, that is printed after the manner of the Hebrew, Syriacke, & Calday, and so to be read, to wi • , from the right hand to the left, and that therefore the Latin beginneth with the Arabike in the very last page, at Sus • i • e deprecationem meam &c. & so goeth backward, euery latin word āswering the Arabique which it explicateth.

2. Secondly, that for as much as there
is great difficulty to expresse the true sound of the Arabique in Latin letters, by reason of the different dialects betwixt the Arabique, and other languages (wherby I haue seene the Arabique set downe in Latin letters diuersly, by men of diuers Nations) I haue therefore vsed the aduise of a very learned Maronite, who naturally speaketh the Arabique tongue, and is very expert in the Latin and Italian, by fourty years study and practise of both, whome I haue procured to giue me the translation of the Arabique, and the true sound and pronuntiation therof, expressed by Latin letters as neere as may be, according to the learned and grammaticall Arabique, which sometymes differeth some what from the vulgar in pronuntiation & found; as for example, the word sauaca which signifyeth aequalis tibi, is vulgarly pronounced suaca (as i • is set downe by me in the seauenth chap. num. 54. 55. & 56.) whereas in the explication of the Arabique in this Appendix it is sauaca, according to the grammaticall pronūtiation thereof, which difference may also be noted in diuers other words.

3. Thirdly I desire thee, good Reader, to note the difference betwixt the Arabical words giuen vs by Maister Collins, and those
which thou s • est heer set downe out of the Diurnall of the Maronits alleadged by him. The words he giueth vs for S. Ephraems are, [Illaica we shaueca lam atlabu] whereas the other in the sayd Diurnall are [Flam atlob sauaca] of the difference whereof, as also of the corrupt translation of them, and the omission of an important sentence following immediatly in the text of S. Ephraem, I haue treated amply in the seauenth Chapter: whereto I add heere concerning [atlabu] that although it be an Arabical word, & may be vsed in some sort, yet not in that manner that M. Collins hath it, to wit, when (lam) a negatiue particle, signifying (non) doth go immediatly before it; for then it cannot be [atlabu] as the Maronits do assure me, but [atlob] as we read it in S. Ephraem. So a • it appeareth that of fiue Arabical words which M. Collins hath pretended to giue vs out of S. Ephraems text, at least 4. are not to be found there; besides the corrupt & false sense, which he giueth vs thereof, as I haue shewed euidently in the 7. Chapter.

4. Fourthly wheras I haue also in the 7. Chap. num. 50. & 60. set downe the English translation of certaine salutations of S. Ephraem to the B. Virgin Mary, and to S. Michael the Archangel (contayning also his
expresse inuocatiō of them) together with part of another prayer of his to Almighty God; and finally, the end, and conclusion of the very prayer it selfe, out of which M. Collins hath taken his counterfait text, I haue thought good for the further satisfaction of those that haue skill in the Arabique to cause the same to be printed heer, to the end that they may the more cleerly discouer the egregious fraud of my Lord, & his Champion in the abuse and corruption of S. Ephraem. Wherin neuertheles it is to be noted, that of the salutations to the B. V. and S. Michael, (which in S. Ephraem are very many) I haue taken out but some few to shew the custome and manner of speach of that ancient Father (conforme to the custome of Catholiks at this day) and that it may serue for a preamble to his inuocatiō of them, wherwith he concludeth his sayd salutations. All which I beseech thee good Reader wel to cōsider togeather with that which I haue represented vnto thee, in the 7. Chap. and then I doubt not, but thou wilt euidently see, & detest the impudency of M. Collins, and say to him with me, Obmutesce Syr Samuel, for shame, Obmutesce.
